It is a truth universally acknowledged , that [a single man in possession of a good fortune]223-a single man in possession of a good fortune must be in want of [a wife]224-a wife .

However little known the feelings or views of [such a man]225-such a man may be on [his]225-such a man first entering [a neighbourhood]226-a neighbourhood , this truth is so well fixed in the minds of [the surrounding families]227-the surrounding families , that [he]225-such a man is considered as the rightful property of [some one or other of [[their]227-the surrounding families daughters]229-their daughters]228-some one or other of their daughters .

" [[My]230-his lady dear]2993-my dear [Mr. Bennet]75-mr. bennet , "[230-his lady] said [[his]225-such a man lady]230-his lady to [him]225-such a man one day , " have [you]225-such a man heard that [Netherfield Park]1-netherfield park is let at last ? "[230-his lady]

[Mr. Bennet]75-mr. bennet replied that [he]75-mr. bennet had not .

" But it is , "[230-his lady] returned [she]230-his lady ; " for [Mrs. Long]76-mrs. long has just been [here]2994-here , and [she]76-mrs. long told [me]230-his lady all about it . "[230-his lady]

[Mr. Bennet]75-mr. bennet made no answer .

" Do not [you]225-such a man want to know who has taken it ? "[231-his wife] cried [[his]225-such a man wife]231-his wife , impatiently .

" _ [You]225-such a man _ want to tell [me]75-mr. bennet , and [I]75-mr. bennet have no objection to hearing it . "[75-mr. bennet]

This was invitation enough .

" Why , [[my]75-mr. bennet dear]2993-my dear , [you]2993-my dear must know , [Mrs. Long]76-mrs. long says that [Netherfield]2-netherfield is taken by [a young man of large fortune]2996-a young man of large fortune from [the north of [England]3-england]2997-the north of england ; that [he]2996-a young man of large fortune came down on Monday in a chaise and four to see [the place]2998-the place , and was so much delighted with it that [he]2996-a young man of large fortune agreed with [Mr. Morris]77-mr. morris immediately ; that [he]2996-a young man of large fortune is to take possession before [Michaelmas]78-michaelmas , and [some of [[his]2996-a young man of large fortune servants]3000-his servants]2999-some of his servants are to be in [the house]3001-the house by the end of next week . "[75-mr. bennet]

" What is [his]2996-a young man of large fortune name ? "[75-mr. bennet]

" [Bingley]79-mr. bingley . "[75-mr. bennet]

" Is [he]2996-a young man of large fortune married or single ? "[75-mr. bennet]

" Oh , single , [[my]75-mr. bennet dear]2993-my dear , to be sure ! [A single man of large fortune]3003-a single man of large fortune ; four or five thousand a year . What a fine thing for [[our]3004-our girls]3005-our girls ! "[75-mr. bennet]

" How so ? how can it affect [them]3005-our girls ? "[75-mr. bennet]

" [[My]231-his wife dear]2993-my dear [Mr. Bennet]75-mr. bennet , "[231-his wife] replied [[his]232-his wife]231-his wife , " how can [you]75-mr. bennet be so tiresome ? [You]75-mr. bennet must know that [I]231-his wife am thinking of [his]2996-a young man of large fortune marrying one of [them]3005-our girls . "[231-his wife]

" Is that [his]2996-a young man of large fortune design in settling [here]2994-here ? "[75-mr. bennet]

" Design ? Nonsense , how can [you]75-mr. bennet talk so ! But it is very likely that [he]2996-a young man of large fortune _ may _ fall in love with one of [them]3005-our girls , and therefore [you]75-mr. bennet must visit [him]2996-a young man of large fortune as soon as [he]2996-a young man of large fortune comes . "[231-his wife]

" [I]75-mr. bennet see no occasion for that . [You]75-mr. bennet and [the girls]3008-the girls may go -- or [you]75-mr. bennet may send [them]3005-our girls by [themselves]3005-our girls , which perhaps will be still better ; for as [you]75-mr. bennet are as handsome as any of [them]3005-our girls , [Mr. Bingley]79-mr. bingley might like [you]75-mr. bennet the best of [the party]3009-the party . "[75-mr. bennet]

" [[My]231-his wife dear]2993-my dear , [you]75-mr. bennet flatter [me]231-his wife . [I]231-his wife certainly _ have _ had [my]231-his wife share of beauty , but [I]231-his wife do not pretend to be anything extraordinary now . When [a woman]3011-a woman has [five grown - up daughters]3012-five grown - up daughters , [she]3011-a woman ought to give over thinking of [her]3011-a woman own beauty . "[231-his wife]

" In such cases , [a woman]3011-a woman has not often much beauty to think of . "[75-mr. bennet]

" But , [[my]231-his wife dear]2993-my dear , [you]75-mr. bennet must indeed go and see [Mr. Bingley]79-mr. bingley when [he]79-mr. bingley comes into [the neighbourhood]3015-the neighbourhood . "[231-his wife]

" It is more than [I]75-mr. bennet engage for , [I]75-mr. bennet assure [you]75-mr. bennet . "[75-mr. bennet]

" But consider [[your]75-mr. bennet daughters]3016-your daughters . Only think what an establishment it would be for [one of [them]3016-your daughters]3017-one of them . [Sir William]80-sir william and [Lady Lucas]81-lady lucas are determined to go , merely on that account ; for in general , [you]75-mr. bennet know , [they]3016-your daughters visit [no new comers]3018-no new comers . Indeed [you]75-mr. bennet must go , for it will be impossible for _ [us]3019-us _ to visit [him]79-mr. bingley , if [you]75-mr. bennet do not . "[231-his wife]

" [You]75-mr. bennet are over scrupulous , surely . [I]75-mr. bennet dare say [Mr. Bingley]79-mr. bingley will be very glad to see [you]75-mr. bennet ; and [I]75-mr. bennet will send a few lines by [you]75-mr. bennet to assure [him]79-mr. bingley of [my]75-mr. bennet hearty consent to [his]79-mr. bingley marrying whichever [he]79-mr. bingley chooses of [the girls]3008-the girls -- though [I]75-mr. bennet must throw in a good word for [[my]75-mr. bennet little [Lizzy]82-elizabeth]3021-my little lizzy . "[75-mr. bennet]

" [I]231-his wife desire [you]75-mr. bennet will do no such thing . [Lizzy]82-elizabeth is not a bit better than the others : and [I]231-his wife am sure [she]82-elizabeth is not half so handsome as [Jane]83-jane , nor half so good - humoured as [Lydia]84-lydia . But [you]75-mr. bennet are always giving _ [her]82-elizabeth _ the preference . "[231-his wife]

" [They]3008-the girls have none of [them]3008-the girls much to recommend [them]3008-the girls , "[234-i] replied [he]234-i : " [they]3008-the girls are all silly and ignorant like [other girls]3022-other girls ; but [Lizzy]82-elizabeth has something more of quickness than [[her]82-elizabeth sisters]3023-her sisters . "[234-i]

" [Mr. Bennet]75-mr. bennet , how can [you]75-mr. bennet abuse [[your]75-mr. bennet own children]3024-your own children in such a way ? [You]75-mr. bennet take delight in vexing [me]231-his wife . [You]75-mr. bennet have no compassion on [my]231-his wife poor nerves . "[231-his wife]

" [You]75-mr. bennet mistake [me]234-i , [[my]234-i dear]2993-my dear . [I]234-i have a high respect for [your]75-mr. bennet nerves . [They]3008-the girls are [[my]234-i old friends]3026-my old friends . [I]234-i have heard [you]75-mr. bennet mention [them]3008-the girls with consideration these twenty years at least . "[234-i]

" Ah , [you]75-mr. bennet do not know what [I]231-his wife suffer . "[231-his wife]

" But [I]234-i hope [you]75-mr. bennet will get over it , and live to see [many young men of four thousand a year]3027-many young men of four thousand a year come into [the neighbourhood]3015-the neighbourhood . "[234-i]

" It will be no use to [us]3029-us , if [twenty such]3030-twenty such should come , since [you]75-mr. bennet will not visit [them]3030-twenty such . "[231-his wife]

" Depend upon it , [[my]234-i dear]2993-my dear , that when there are twenty , [I]234-i will visit [them]3030-twenty such all . "[234-i]

[Mr. Bennet]75-mr. bennet was so odd a mixture of quick parts , sarcastic humour , reserve , and caprice , that the experience of three - and - twenty years had been insufficient to make [[his]75-mr. bennet wife]231-his wife understand [his]75-mr. bennet character . _ [Her]231-his wife _ mind was less difficult to develope . [She]231-his wife was [a woman of mean understanding , little information , and uncertain temper]236-a woman of mean understanding , little information , and uncertain temper . When [she]231-his wife was discontented , [she]231-his wife fancied [herself]231-his wife nervous . The business of [her]231-his wife life was to get [[her]231-his wife daughters]237-her daughters married : its solace was visiting and news .

[Mr. Bennet]75-mr. bennet was among [the earliest of those who waited on [Mr. Bingley]79-mr. bingley . [He]75-mr. bennet had always intended to visit [him]79-mr. bingley , though to the last always assuring [[his]75-mr. bennet wife]231-his wife that [he]75-mr. bennet should not go]238-the earliest of those who waited on mr. bingley . he had always intended to visit him , though to the last always assuring his wife that he should not go ; and till the evening after the visit was paid [she]231-his wife had no knowledge of it . It was then disclosed in the following manner . Observing [[his]75-mr. bennet second daughter]240-his second daughter employed in trimming a hat , [he]75-mr. bennet suddenly addressed [her]240-his second daughter with,--

" [I]75-mr. bennet hope [Mr. Bingley]79-mr. bingley will like it , [Lizzy]82-elizabeth . "[75-mr. bennet]

" [We]3032-we are not in a way to know _ what _ [Mr. Bingley]79-mr. bingley likes , "[241-her mother] said [[her]240-his second daughter mother]241-her mother , resentfully , " since [we]3032-we are not to visit . "[241-her mother]

" But [you]241-her mother forget , [mamma]3033-mamma , "[82-elizabeth] said [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth , " that [we]3032-we shall meet [him]79-mr. bingley at [the assemblies]3034-the assemblies , and that [Mrs. Long]76-mrs. long has promised to introduce [him]79-mr. bingley . "[82-elizabeth]

" [I]85-mrs. bennet do not believe [Mrs. Long]76-mrs. long will do any such thing . [She]76-mrs. long has [two nieces of [her]76-mrs. long own]3035-two nieces of her own . [She]76-mrs. long is [a selfish , hypocritical woman]3036-a selfish , hypocritical woman , and [I]85-mrs. bennet have no opinion of [her]76-mrs. long . "[85-mrs. bennet]

" No more have [I]75-mr. bennet , "[75-mr. bennet] said [Mr. Bennet]75-mr. bennet ; " and [I]75-mr. bennet am glad to find that [you]3037-you do not depend on [her]76-mrs. long serving [you]3037-you . "[75-mr. bennet]

[Mrs. Bennet]85-mrs. bennet deigned not to make any reply ; but , unable to contain [herself]85-mrs. bennet , began scolding [one of [[her]85-mrs. bennet daughters]237-her daughters]242-one of her daughters .

" Do n't keep coughing so , [Kitty]86-lady catherine , for heaven 's sake ! Have a little compassion on [my]85-mrs. bennet nerves . [You]3037-you tear [them]3038-them to pieces . "[85-mrs. bennet]

" [Kitty]86-lady catherine has no discretion in [her]86-lady catherine coughs , "[244-her father] said [[her]242-one of her daughters father]244-her father ; " [she]86-lady catherine times [them]3038-them ill . "[244-her father]

" [I]86-lady catherine do not cough for [my]86-lady catherine own amusement , "[86-lady catherine] replied [Kitty]86-lady catherine , fretfully . " When is [your]244-her father next ball to be , [Lizzy]82-elizabeth ? "[86-lady catherine]

" To - morrow fortnight . "[85-mrs. bennet]

" Ay , so it is , "[241-her mother] cried [[her]242-one of her daughters mother]241-her mother , " and [Mrs. Long]76-mrs. long does not come back till the day before ; so , it will be impossible for [her]76-mrs. long to introduce [him]244-her father , for [she]76-mrs. long will not know [him]244-her father [herself]76-mrs. long . "[241-her mother]

" Then , [[my]85-mrs. bennet dear]2993-my dear , [you]2993-my dear may have the advantage of [[your]2993-my dear friend]3040-your friend , and introduce [Mr. Bingley]79-mr. bingley to _ [her]3040-your friend _ . "[85-mrs. bennet]

" Impossible , [Mr. Bennet]75-mr. bennet , impossible , when [I]241-her mother am not acquainted with [him]244-her father [myself]241-her mother ; how can [you]75-mr. bennet be so teasing ? "[241-her mother]

" [I]85-mrs. bennet honour [your]75-mr. bennet circumspection . A fortnight 's acquaintance is certainly very little . [One]3041-one can not know what [a man]3042-a man really is by the end of a fortnight . But if _ [we]3043-we _ do not venture , [somebody else]3044-somebody else will ; and after all , [Mrs. Long]76-mrs. long and [[her]76-mrs. long nieces]3045-her nieces must stand [their]3008-the girls chance ; and , therefore , as [she]76-mrs. long will think it an act of kindness , if [you]75-mr. bennet decline [the office]3046-the office , [I]85-mrs. bennet will take it on [myself]85-mrs. bennet . "[85-mrs. bennet]

[The girls]3008-the girls stared at [[their]3008-the girls father]247-their father . [Mrs. Bennet]85-mrs. bennet said only , " Nonsense , nonsense ! "[85-mrs. bennet]

" What can be the meaning of that emphatic exclamation ? "[247-their father] cried [he]247-their father . " Do [you]75-mr. bennet consider the forms of introduction , and the stress that is laid on them , as nonsense ? [I]247-their father can not quite agree with [you]75-mr. bennet _ there _ . What say [you]75-mr. bennet , [Mary]87-mary ? For [you]75-mr. bennet are [a young lady of deep reflection]3047-a young lady of deep reflection , [I]247-their father know , and read great books , and make extracts . "[247-their father]

[Mary]87-mary wished to say something very sensible , but knew not how .

" While [Mary]87-mary is adjusting [her]87-mary ideas , "[247-their father] [he]247-their father continued , " let [us]3048-us return to [Mr. Bingley]79-mr. bingley . "[247-their father]

" [I]231-his wife am sick of [Mr. Bingley]79-mr. bingley , "[231-his wife] cried [[his]247-their father wife]231-his wife .

" [I]231-his wife am sorry to hear _ that _ ; but why did [you]247-their father not tell [me]231-his wife so before ? If [I]231-his wife had known as much this morning , [I]231-his wife certainly would not have called on [him]79-mr. bingley . It is very unlucky ; but as [I]231-his wife have actually paid the visit , [we]3048-us can not escape the acquaintance now . "[231-his wife]

The astonishment of [the ladies]249-the ladies was just what [he]247-their father wished -- that of [Mrs. Bennet]85-mrs. bennet perhaps surpassing the rest ; though when the first tumult of joy was over , [she]231-his wife began to declare that it was what [she]231-his wife had expected all the while .

" How good it was in [you]247-their father , [[my]231-his wife dear]2993-my dear [Mr. Bennet]75-mr. bennet ! But [I]231-his wife knew [I]231-his wife should persuade [you]247-their father at last . [I]231-his wife was sure [you]247-their father loved [[your]247-their father girls]3050-your girls too well to neglect such an acquaintance . Well , how pleased [I]231-his wife am ! " Now , [Kitty]86-lady catherine , [you]86-lady catherine may cough as much as [you]86-lady catherine choose , "[75-mr. bennet] said [Mr. Bennet]75-mr. bennet ; and , as [he]75-mr. bennet spoke , [he]75-mr. bennet left [the room]250-the room , fatigued with the raptures of [[his]75-mr. bennet wife]231-his wife .

" What [an excellent father]3051-an excellent father [you]247-their father have , [girls]3052-girls , "[231-his wife] said [she]231-his wife , when the door was shut . " [I]231-his wife do not know how [you]247-their father will ever make [him]75-mr. bennet amends for [his]75-mr. bennet kindness ; or [me]231-his wife either , for that matter . At [our]3053-our time of life , it is not so pleasant , [I]231-his wife can tell [you]247-their father , to be making [new acquaintances]3054-new acquaintances every day ; but for [your]247-their father sakes [we]3053-our would do anything . [Lydia]84-lydia , [[my]231-his wife love]3055-my love , though [you]84-lydia _ are _ the youngest , [I]231-his wife dare say [Mr. Bingley]79-mr. bingley will dance with [you]84-lydia at the next ball . "[231-his wife]

" Oh , "[84-lydia] said [Lydia]84-lydia , stoutly , " [I]84-lydia am not afraid ; for though [I]84-lydia _ am _ the youngest , [I]84-lydia 'm [the tallest]3056-the tallest . "[84-lydia]

The rest of the evening was spent in conjecturing how soon [he]252-he would return [Mr. Bennet]75-mr. bennet 's visit , and determining when [they]253-they should ask [him]252-he to dinner .

Not all that [Mrs. Bennet]85-mrs. bennet , however , with the assistance of [[her]85-mrs. bennet five daughters]254-her five daughters , could ask on the subject , was sufficient to draw from [[her]85-mrs. bennet husband]255-her husband any satisfactory description of [Mr. Bingley]79-mr. bingley . [They]253-they attacked [him]79-mr. bingley in various ways , with barefaced questions , ingenious suppositions , and distant surmises ; but [he]79-mr. bingley eluded the skill of [them]253-they all ; and [they]253-they were at last obliged to accept the second - hand intelligence of [[their]253-they neighbour]256-their neighbour , [Lady Lucas]81-lady lucas . [Her]85-mrs. bennet report was highly favourable . [Sir William]80-sir william had been delighted with [him]79-mr. bingley . [He]79-mr. bingley was quite young , wonderfully handsome , extremely agreeable , and , to crown the whole , [he]79-mr. bingley meant to be at the next assembly with [a large party]257-a large party . Nothing could be more delightful ! To be fond of dancing was a certain step towards falling in love ; and very lively hopes of [Mr. Bingley]79-mr. bingley 's heart were entertained .

" If [I]85-mrs. bennet can but see [one of [[my]85-mrs. bennet daughters]3058-my daughters]3057-one of my daughters happily settled at [Netherfield]2-netherfield , "[85-mrs. bennet] said [Mrs. Bennet]85-mrs. bennet to [[her]85-mrs. bennet husband]255-her husband , " and all the others equally well married , [I]85-mrs. bennet shall have nothing to wish for . "[85-mrs. bennet]

In a few days [Mr. Bingley]79-mr. bingley returned [Mr. Bennet]75-mr. bennet 's visit , and sat about ten minutes with [him]75-mr. bennet in [[his]75-mr. bennet library]259-his library . [He]79-mr. bingley had entertained hopes of being admitted to a sight of [the young ladies]260-the young ladies , of whose beauty [he]79-mr. bingley had heard much ; but [he]79-mr. bingley saw only [the father]261-the father . [The ladies]249-the ladies were somewhat more fortunate , for [they]249-the ladies had the advantage of ascertaining , from an upper window , that [he]261-the father wore a blue coat and rode a black horse .

An invitation to dinner was soon afterwards despatched ; and already had [Mrs. Bennet]85-mrs. bennet planned the courses that were to do credit to [[her]85-mrs. bennet housekeeping]263-her housekeeping , when an answer arrived which deferred it all . [Mr. Bingley]79-mr. bingley was obliged to be in [town]264-town the following day , and consequently unable to accept the honour of [their]265-their invitation , etc . [Mrs. Bennet]85-mrs. bennet was quite disconcerted . [She]85-mrs. bennet could not imagine what business [he]79-mr. bingley could have in [town]264-town so soon after [his]79-mr. bingley arrival in [Hertfordshire]4-hertfordshire ; and [she]85-mrs. bennet began to fear that [he]79-mr. bingley might always be flying about from [one place]267-one place to another , and never settled at [Netherfield]2-netherfield as [he]79-mr. bingley ought to be . [Lady Lucas]81-lady lucas quieted [her]81-lady lucas fears a little by starting the idea of [his]79-mr. bingley

being gone to [London]5-london only to get a large party for the ball ; and a report soon followed that [Mr. Bingley]79-mr. bingley was to bring [twelve ladies]268-twelve ladies and [seven gentlemen]269-seven gentlemen with [him]79-mr. bingley to the assembly . [The girls]3008-the girls grieved over [such a number of [ladies]272-ladies]271-such a number of ladies ; but were comforted the day before the ball by hearing that , instead of twelve , [he]79-mr. bingley had brought only six with [him]79-mr. bingley from [London]5-london , [[his]79-mr. bingley five sisters]273-his five sisters and [a cousin]274-a cousin . And when [the party]3009-the party entered [the assembly - room]276-the assembly - room , it consisted of only [five altogether]277-five altogether : [Mr. Bingley]79-mr. bingley , [[his]79-mr. bingley two sisters]278-his two sisters , [the husband of [the eldest]280-the eldest]279-the husband of the eldest , and [another young man]281-another young man .

[Mr. Bingley]79-mr. bingley was good - looking and gentlemanlike : [he]79-mr. bingley had a pleasant countenance , and easy , unaffected manners . [[His]79-mr. bingley sisters]282-his sisters were [fine women , with an air of decided fashion]283-fine women , with an air of decided fashion . [[His]79-mr. bingley brother - in - law]284-his brother - in - law , [Mr. Hurst]88-mr. hurst , merely looked [the gentleman]285-the gentleman ; but [[his]79-mr. bingley friend]286-his friend [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy soon drew the attention of [the room]250-the room by [[his]89-mr. darcy fine , tall person]288-his fine , tall person , handsome features , [noble mien]289-noble mien , and the report , which was in general circulation within five minutes after [his]89-mr. darcy entrance , of [his]89-mr. darcy having ten thousand a year . [The gentlemen]290-the gentlemen pronounced [him]89-mr. darcy to be [a fine figure of a man]291-a fine figure of a man , [the ladies]249-the ladies declared [he]89-mr. darcy was much handsomer than [Mr. Bingley]79-mr. bingley , and [he]89-mr. darcy was looked at with great admiration for about half the evening , till [his]89-mr. darcy manners gave a disgust which turned the tide of [his]89-mr. darcy popularity ; for [he]89-mr. darcy was discovered to be proud , to be above [his]89-mr. darcy company , and above being pleased ; and not all [[his]89-mr. darcy large estate in [Derbyshire]6-derbyshire]293-his large estate in derbyshire could save [him]89-mr. darcy from having a most forbidding , disagreeable countenance , and being unworthy to be compared with [[his]89-mr. darcy friend]286-his friend .

[Mr. Bingley]79-mr. bingley had soon made [himself]79-mr. bingley acquainted with [all the principal people]295-all the principal people in [the room]250-the room : [he]79-mr. bingley was lively and unreserved , danced every dance , was angry that the ball closed so early , and talked of giving one [himself]79-mr. bingley at [Netherfield]2-netherfield . Such amiable qualities must speak for [themselves]297-themselves . What a contrast between [him]79-mr. bingley and [[his]79-mr. bingley friend]286-his friend ! [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy danced only once with [Mrs. Hurst]90-mrs. hurst and once with [Miss Bingley]91-miss bingley , declined being introduced to [any other lady]299-any other lady , and spent the rest of the evening in walking about [the room]250-the room , speaking occasionally to one of [[his]89-mr. darcy own party]301-his own party . [His]79-mr. bingley character was decided . [He]79-mr. bingley was [the proudest , most disagreeable man in [the world]303-the world]302-the proudest , most disagreeable man in the world , and [everybody]304-everybody hoped that [he]79-mr. bingley would never come [there]305-there again . Amongst the most violent against [him]79-mr. bingley was [Mrs. Bennet]85-mrs. bennet , whose dislike of [his]79-mr. bingley general behaviour was sharpened into particular resentment by [his]79-mr. bingley having slighted [one of [[her]85-mrs. bennet daughters]237-her daughters]242-one of her daughters .

[Elizabeth Bennet]82-elizabeth had been obliged , by the scarcity of [gentlemen]308-gentlemen , to sit down for two dances ; and during part of that time , [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy had been standing near enough for [her]82-elizabeth to overhear a conversation between [him]89-mr. darcy and [Mr. Bingley]79-mr. bingley , who came from the dance for a few minutes to press [[his]89-mr. darcy friend]286-his friend to join it .

" Come , [Darcy]89-mr. darcy , "[89-mr. darcy] said [he]89-mr. darcy , " [I]89-mr. darcy must have [you]89-mr. darcy dance . [I]89-mr. darcy hate to see [you]89-mr. darcy standing about by [yourself]89-mr. darcy in this stupid manner . [You]89-mr. darcy had much better dance . "[89-mr. darcy]

" [I]79-mr. bingley certainly shall not . [You]89-mr. darcy know how [I]79-mr. bingley detest it , unless [I]79-mr. bingley am particularly acquainted with [[my]79-mr. bingley partner]3059-my partner . [[Your]89-mr. darcy sisters]3060-your sisters are engaged , and there is [not another woman in [the room]250-the room whom it would not be a punishment to [me]79-mr. bingley to stand up with]3061-not another woman in the room whom it would not be a punishment to me to stand up with . "[79-mr. bingley]

" [I]79-mr. bingley would not be so fastidious as [you]89-mr. darcy are , "[79-mr. bingley] cried [Bingley]79-mr. bingley , " for a kingdom ! "[79-mr. bingley]

" _ [You]89-mr. darcy _ are dancing with [the only handsome girl in [the room]250-the room]3064-the only handsome girl in the room , "[89-mr. darcy] said [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy , looking at [the eldest Miss Bennet]82-elizabeth .

"[89-mr. darcy]

"[89-mr. darcy]

[Mr. Bingley]79-mr. bingley followed [his]89-mr. darcy advice . [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy walked off ; and [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth remained with no very cordial feelings towards [him]89-mr. darcy . [She]82-elizabeth told the story , however , with great spirit among [[her]82-elizabeth friends]310-her friends ; for [she]82-elizabeth had a lively , playful disposition , which delighted in anything ridiculous .

The evening altogether passed off pleasantly to [the whole family]311-the whole family . [Mrs. Bennet]85-mrs. bennet had seen [[her]85-mrs. bennet eldest daughter]312-her eldest daughter much admired by the [Netherfield]2-netherfield party . [Jane]83-jane was as much gratified by this as [[her]83-jane mother]241-her mother could be , though in a quieter way . [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth felt [Jane]83-jane 's pleasure . [Mary]87-mary had heard [herself]87-mary mentioned to [Miss Bingley]91-miss bingley as [the most accomplished girl in [the neighbourhood]3015-the neighbourhood]315-the most accomplished girl in the neighbourhood ; and [Catherine]86-lady catherine and [Lydia]84-lydia had been fortunate enough to be never without [partners]317-partners , which was all that [they]318-they had yet learnt to care for at a ball . [They]318-they returned , therefore , in good spirits to [Longbourn]7-longbourn , [[the village]319-the village where [they]318-they lived , and of which [they]318-they were [the principal inhabitants]321-the principal inhabitants]320-the village where they lived , and of which they were the principal inhabitants . [They]318-they found [Mr. Bennet]75-mr. bennet still up . With a book , [he]75-mr. bennet was regardless of time ; and on the present occasion [he]75-mr. bennet had a good deal of curiosity as to the event of an evening which had raised such splendid expectations . [He]75-mr. bennet had rather hoped that all [[his]75-mr. bennet wife]231-his wife 's views on [the stranger]323-the stranger would be disappointed ; but [he]75-mr. bennet soon found that [he]75-mr. bennet had a very different story to hear .

" Oh , [[my]231-his wife dear]2993-my dear [Mr. Bennet]75-mr. bennet , "[231-his wife] as [she]231-his wife entered [the room]250-the room , " [we]318-they have had a most delightful evening , a most excellent ball . When [Jane]83-jane and [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth were alone , [the former]327-the former , who had been cautious in [her]327-the former praise of [Mr. Bingley]79-mr. bingley before , expressed to [[her]327-the former sister]328-her sister how very much [she]327-the former admired [him]79-mr. bingley .

" [He]79-mr. bingley is just what [a young - man]3092-a young - man ought to be , "[327-the former] said [she]327-the former , " sensible , good - humoured , lively ; and [I]327-the former never saw such happy manners ! so much ease , with such perfect good breeding ! "[327-the former]

" [I]327-the former was very much flattered by [his]79-mr. bingley asking [me]327-the former to dance a second time . [I]327-the former did not expect such a compliment . "[327-the former]

" Did not [you]327-the former ? _ [I]82-elizabeth _ did for [you]327-the former . But that is one great difference between [us]3094-us . " [I]327-the former would wish not to be hasty in censuring [anyone]3102-anyone ; but [I]327-the former always speak what [I]327-the former think . "[327-the former]

" [I]82-elizabeth know [you]327-the former do : and it is _ that _ which makes the wonder . With _ [your]327-the former _ good sense , to be so honestly blind to the follies and nonsense of [others]3103-others ! Affectation of candour is common enough ; [one]3041-one meets with it everywhere . But to be candid without ostentation or design,--to take the good of [everybody]304-everybody 's character and make it still better , and say nothing of the bad,--belongs to [you]327-the former alone . And so , [you]327-the former like [[this man]3106-this man 's sisters]3107-this man 's sisters , too , do [you]327-the former ? "[327-the former]

[Elizabeth]96-dear lizzy listened in silence , but was not convinced : [their]329-they behaviour at the assembly had not been calculated to please in general ; and with more quickness of observation and less pliancy of temper than [[her]96-dear lizzy sister]328-her sister , and with a judgment , too , unassailed by any attention to [herself]96-dear lizzy , [she]96-dear lizzy was very little disposed to approve [them]329-they . [They]329-they were , in fact , [very fine ladies]331-very fine ladies ; not deficient in good - humour when [they]329-they were pleased , nor in the power of being agreeable where [they]329-they chose it ; but proud and conceited . [They]329-they were rather handsome ; had been educated in [one of [the first private seminaries in [town]264-town]333-the first private seminaries in town]332-one of the first private seminaries in town ; had a fortune of twenty thousand pounds ; were in the habit of spending more than [they]329-they ought , and of associating with [people of rank]335-people of rank ; and were , therefore , in every respect entitled to think well of [themselves]329-they and meanly of [others]3103-others . [They]329-they were of [a respectable family in [the north of [England]3-england]2997-the north of england]337-a respectable family in the north of england ; a circumstance more deeply impressed on [their]329-they memories than that [[their]329-they brother]339-their brother 's fortune and [their]329-they own had been acquired by trade .

[Mr. Bingley]79-mr. bingley inherited property to the amount of nearly a hundred thousand pounds from [[his]79-mr. bingley father]340-his father , who had intended to purchase [an estate]341-an estate , but did not live to do it . [Mr. Bingley]79-mr. bingley intended [it]341-an estate likewise , and sometimes made choice of [[his]79-mr. bingley county]342-his county ; but , as [he]79-mr. bingley was now provided with [a good house]343-a good house and the liberty of [a manor]344-a manor , it was doubtful to [many of those who best knew the easiness of [his]79-mr. bingley temper , whether [he]79-mr. bingley might not spend the remainder of [his]79-mr. bingley days at [Netherfield]2-netherfield]345-many of those who best knew the easiness of his temper , whether he might not spend the remainder of his days at netherfield , and leave [the next generation to purchase]346-the next generation to purchase .

[[His]79-mr. bingley sisters]282-his sisters were very anxious for [his]79-mr. bingley having [an estate of [his]79-mr. bingley own]348-an estate of his own ; but though [he]79-mr. bingley was now established only as [a tenant]349-a tenant , [Miss Bingley]91-miss bingley was by no means unwilling to preside at [his]79-mr. bingley table ; nor was [Mrs. Hurst]90-mrs. hurst , who had married [a man of more fashion than fortune]350-a man of more fashion than fortune , less disposed to consider [[his]79-mr. bingley house]3109-his house as [[her]90-mrs. hurst home]352-her home when it suited [her]90-mrs. hurst . [Mr. Bingley]79-mr. bingley had not been of age two years when [he]79-mr. bingley was tempted , by an accidental recommendation , to look at [Netherfield House]8-netherfield house . [He]79-mr. bingley did look at [it]3109-his house , and into it , for half an hour ; was pleased with the situation and [the principal rooms]353-the principal rooms , satisfied with what [the owner]354-the owner said in its praise , and took it immediately .

Between [him]79-mr. bingley and [Darcy]89-mr. darcy there was a very steady friendship , in spite of a great opposition of character . [Bingley]79-mr. bingley was endeared to [Darcy]89-mr. darcy by the easiness , openness , and ductility of [his]79-mr. bingley temper , though no disposition could offer a greater contrast to [his]79-mr. bingley own , and though with [his]79-mr. bingley own [he]79-mr. bingley never appeared dissatisfied . On the strength of [Darcy]89-mr. darcy 's regard , [Bingley]79-mr. bingley had the firmest reliance , and of [his]79-mr. bingley judgment the highest opinion . In understanding , [Darcy]89-mr. darcy was [the superior]355-the superior . [Bingley]79-mr. bingley was by no means deficient ; but [Darcy]89-mr. darcy was clever . [He]89-mr. darcy was at the same time haughty , reserved , and fastidious ; and [his]89-mr. darcy manners , though well bred , were not inviting . In that respect [[his]79-mr. bingley friend]286-his friend had greatly the advantage . [Bingley]79-mr. bingley was sure of being liked wherever [he]79-mr. bingley appeared ; [Darcy]89-mr. darcy was continually giving offence .

The manner in which [they]357-they spoke of [the Meryton]9-meryton assembly was sufficiently characteristic . [Bingley]79-mr. bingley had never met with [pleasanter people]358-pleasanter people or [prettier girls]359-prettier girls in [his]79-mr. bingley life ; [everybody]304-everybody had been most kind and attentive to [him]79-mr. bingley ; there had been no formality , no stiffness ; [he]79-mr. bingley had soon felt acquainted with all [the room]250-the room ; and as to [Miss Bennet]82-elizabeth , [he]79-mr. bingley could not conceive [an angel more beautiful]362-an angel more beautiful . [Darcy]89-mr. darcy , on the contrary , had seen a collection of [people in whom there was little beauty and no fashion]363-people in whom there was little beauty and no fashion , for none of whom [he]89-mr. darcy had felt the smallest interest , and from [none received either attention or pleasure]364-none received either attention or pleasure . [Miss Bennet]82-elizabeth [he]89-mr. darcy acknowledged to be pretty ; but [she]82-elizabeth smiled too much .

[Mrs. Hurst]90-mrs. hurst and [[her]90-mrs. hurst sister]328-her sister allowed it to be so ; but still [they]366-they admired [her]82-elizabeth and liked [her]82-elizabeth , and pronounced [her]82-elizabeth to be [a sweet girl]367-a sweet girl , and one whom [they]366-they should not object to know more of . [Miss Bennet]82-elizabeth was therefore established as [a sweet girl]367-a sweet girl ; and [[their]366-they brother]339-their brother felt authorized by such commendation to think of [her]82-elizabeth as [he]339-their brother chose .

Within a short walk of [Longbourn]7-longbourn lived [a family with whom [the Bennets]99-the bennets were particularly intimate]370-a family with whom the bennets were particularly intimate . [Sir William Lucas]80-sir william had been formerly in trade in [Meryton]9-meryton , where [he]80-sir william had made a tolerable fortune , and risen to the honour of knighthood by an address to [the king]371-the king during [his]80-sir william mayoralty . The distinction had , perhaps , been felt too strongly . It had given [him]80-sir william a disgust to [his]80-sir william business and to [[his]80-sir william residence in [a small market town]373-a small market town]372-his residence in a small market town ; and , quitting [them]374-them both , [he]80-sir william had removed with [[his]80-sir william family]375-his family to [a house about a mile from [Meryton]9-meryton , denominated from that period [Lucas Lodge]10-lucas lodge]376-a house about a mile from meryton , denominated from that period lucas lodge ; where [he]80-sir william could think with pleasure of [his]80-sir william own importance , and , unshackled by business , occupy [himself]80-sir william solely in being civil to [all the world]377-all the world . For , though elated by [his]80-sir william rank , it did not render [him]80-sir william supercilious ; on the contrary , [he]80-sir william was all attention to [everybody]304-everybody . By nature inoffensive , friendly , and obliging , [his]80-sir william presentation at [[St. James]11-st. james 's]379-st. james 's had made [him]80-sir william courteous .

[Lady Lucas]81-lady lucas was [a very good kind of woman]380-a very good kind of woman , not too clever to be [a valuable neighbour to [Mrs. Bennet]85-mrs. bennet]381-a valuable neighbour to mrs. bennet . [They]382-they had [several children]383-several children . [The eldest of [them]383-several children]384-the eldest of them , [a sensible , intelligent young woman , about twenty - seven]385-a sensible , intelligent young woman , about twenty - seven , was [[Elizabeth]82-elizabeth 's intimate friend]386-elizabeth 's intimate friend .

That [the Miss Lucases]100-the lucases and [the Miss Bennets]99-the bennets should meet to talk over a ball was absolutely necessary ; and the morning after the assembly brought [the former]327-the former to [Longbourn]7-longbourn to hear and to communicate .

" [His]89-mr. darcy pride , "[92-miss lucas] said [Miss Lucas]92-miss lucas , " does not offend _ [me]92-miss lucas _ so much as pride often does , because there is an excuse for it . [One]3041-one can not wonder that so very fine [a young man]3093-a young man , with [family]3127-family , fortune , everything in [his]89-mr. darcy favour , should think highly of [himself]89-mr. darcy . " That is very true , "[103-lizzy] replied [Elizabeth]103-lizzy , " and [I]103-lizzy could easily forgive _ [his]89-mr. darcy _ pride , if [he]89-mr. darcy had not mortified _ mine _ . "[103-lizzy]

" Pride , "[87-mary] observed [Mary]87-mary , who piqued [herself]87-mary upon the solidity of [her]87-mary reflections , " is a very common failing , [I]87-mary believe . By all that [I]87-mary have ever read , [I]87-mary am convinced that it is very common indeed ; that human nature is particularly prone to it , and that there are very few of [us]3128-us [who do not cherish a feeling of self - complacency on the score of some quality or other , real or imaginary]3129-who do not cherish a feeling of self - complacency on the score of some quality or other , real or imaginary . Vanity and pride are different things , though the words are often used synonymously . [A person]3130-a person may be proud without being vain . Pride relates more to [our]3128-us opinion of [ourselves]3128-us ; vanity to what [we]3128-us would have [others]3103-others think of [us]3128-us . "[87-mary]

" If [I]390-a young lucas were as rich as [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy , "[390-a young lucas] cried [a young Lucas]390-a young lucas , who came with [[his]390-a young lucas sisters]282-his sisters , " [I]390-a young lucas should not care how proud [I]390-a young lucas was . [I]390-a young lucas would keep a pack of foxhounds , and drink a bottle of wine every day . "[390-a young lucas]

" Then [you]392-the boy would drink a great deal more than [you]392-the boy ought , "[85-mrs. bennet] said [Mrs. Bennet]85-mrs. bennet ; " and if [I]85-mrs. bennet were to see [you]392-the boy at it , [I]85-mrs. bennet should take away [your]392-the boy bottle directly . "[85-mrs. bennet]

[The boy]392-the boy protested that [she]85-mrs. bennet should not ; [she]85-mrs. bennet continued to declare that [she]85-mrs. bennet would ; and the argument ended only with the visit .

[The ladies of [Longbourn]7-longbourn]393-the ladies of longbourn soon waited on [those of [Netherfield]2-netherfield]394-those of netherfield . The visit was returned in due form . [Miss Bennet]82-elizabeth 's pleasing manners grew on the good - will of [Mrs. Hurst]90-mrs. hurst and [Miss Bingley]91-miss bingley ; and though [the mother]395-the mother was found to be intolerable , and [the younger sisters]396-the younger sisters not worth speaking to , a wish of being better acquainted with _ [them]396-the younger sisters _ was expressed towards [the two eldest]397-the two eldest . By [Jane]83-jane this attention was received with the greatest pleasure ; but [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth still saw superciliousness in [their]396-the younger sisters treatment of [everybody]304-everybody , hardly excepting even [[her]82-elizabeth sister]328-her sister , and could not like [them]396-the younger sisters ; though [their]396-the younger sisters kindness to [Jane]83-jane , such as it was , had a value , as arising , in all probability , from the influence of [[their]396-the younger sisters brother]339-their brother 's admiration . It was generally evident , whenever [they]396-the younger sisters met , that [he]339-their brother _ did _ admire [her]83-jane ; and to _ [her]83-jane _ it was equally evident that [Jane]83-jane was yielding to the preference which [she]83-jane had begun to entertain for [him]339-their brother from the first , and was in a way to be very much in love ; but [she]83-jane considered with pleasure that it was not likely to be discovered by [the world]303-the world in general , since [Jane]83-jane united with great strength of feeling , a composure of temper and an uniform cheerfulness of manner , which would guard [her]83-jane from the suspicions of the impertinent . [She]83-jane mentioned this to [[her]83-jane friend]402-her friend , [Miss Lucas]92-miss lucas .

" It may , perhaps , be pleasant , "[101-charlotte] replied [Charlotte]101-charlotte , " to be able to impose on [the public]3132-the public in such a case ; but it is sometimes a disadvantage to be so very guarded . If [a woman]3011-a woman conceals [her]3011-a woman affection with the same skill from the object of it , [she]3011-a woman may lose the opportunity of fixing [him]339-their brother ; and it will then be but poor consolation to believe [the world]303-the world equally in the dark . There is so much of gratitude or vanity in almost every attachment , that it is not safe to leave any to itself . [We]3135-we can all _ begin _ freely -- a slight preference is natural enough ; but there are very few of [us]3135-we who have [heart enough to be really in love without encouragement]3136-heart enough to be really in love without encouragement . In nine cases out of ten , [a woman]3011-a woman had better show _ more _ affection than [she]3011-a woman feels . [Bingley]91-miss bingley likes [[your]3138-your sister]3139-your sister undoubtedly ; but [he]339-their brother may never do more than like [her]3139-your sister , if [she]3139-your sister does not help [him]339-their brother on . "[101-charlotte]

" But [she]3139-your sister does help [him]339-their brother on , as much as [her]3139-your sister nature will allow . If _ [I]83-jane _ can perceive [her]3139-your sister regard for [him]339-their brother , [he]339-their brother must be [a simpleton]3140-a simpleton indeed not to discover it too . "[83-jane]

" Remember , [Eliza]82-elizabeth , that [he]339-their brother does not know [Jane]83-jane 's disposition as [you]82-elizabeth do . "[101-charlotte]

" But if [a woman]3011-a woman is partial to [a man]3042-a man , and does not endeavor to conceal it , [he]339-their brother must find it out . "[83-jane]

" Perhaps [he]339-their brother must , if [he]339-their brother sees enough of [her]3139-your sister . But though [Bingley]91-miss bingley and [Jane]83-jane meet tolerably often , it is never for many hours together ; and as [they]3143-they always see [each other]3144-each other in large mixed parties , it is impossible that every moment should be employed in conversing together . [Jane]83-jane should therefore make the most of every half hour in which [she]83-jane can command [his]339-their brother attention . When [she]83-jane is secure of [him]339-their brother , there will be leisure for falling in love as much as [she]83-jane chooses . "[101-charlotte]

" [Your]82-elizabeth plan is a good one , "[82-elizabeth] replied [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth , " where nothing is in question but the desire of being well married ; and if [I]82-elizabeth were determined to get [a rich husband]3145-a rich husband , or [any husband]3146-any husband , [I]82-elizabeth dare say [I]82-elizabeth should adopt it . But these are not [Jane]83-jane 's feelings ; [she]83-jane is not acting by design . As yet [she]83-jane can not even be certain of the degree of [her]83-jane own regard , nor of its reasonableness . [She]83-jane has known [him]339-their brother only a fortnight . [She]83-jane danced four dances with [him]339-their brother at [Meryton]9-meryton ; [she]83-jane saw [him]339-their brother one morning at [[his]339-their brother own house]3147-his own house , and has since dined in company with [him]339-their brother four times . This is not quite enough to make [her]83-jane understand [his]339-their brother character . "[82-elizabeth]

" Not as [you]82-elizabeth represent it . "[101-charlotte]

" Yes : these four evenings have enabled [them]3148-they to ascertain that [they]3148-they both like [Vingt]105-vingt - un better than [Commerce]106-commerce , but with respect to any other leading characteristic , [I]82-elizabeth do not imagine that much has been unfolded . "[82-elizabeth]

" Well , "[101-charlotte] said [Charlotte]101-charlotte , " [I]101-charlotte wish [Jane]83-jane success with all [my]101-charlotte heart ; and if [she]83-jane were married to [him]339-their brother to - morrow , [I]101-charlotte should think [she]83-jane had as good a chance of happiness as if [she]83-jane were to be studying [his]339-their brother character for a twelvemonth . Happiness in marriage is entirely a matter of chance . If the dispositions of [the parties]3149-the parties are ever so well known to [each other]3144-each other , or ever so similar beforehand , it does not advance [their]3148-they felicity in the least . [They]3148-they always continue to grow sufficiently unlike afterwards to have [their]3148-they share of vexation ; and it is better to know as little as possible of the defects of [the person with whom [you]3152-you are to pass [your]3152-you life]3151-the person with whom you are to pass your life . "[101-charlotte]

" [You]3152-you make [me]89-mr. darcy laugh , [Charlotte]101-charlotte ; but it is not sound . [You]3152-you know it is not sound , and that [you]3152-you would never act in this way [yourself]3152-you . "[89-mr. darcy]

Occupied in observing [Mr. Bingley]79-mr. bingley 's attention to [[her]403-her sister]328-her sister , [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth was far from suspecting that [she]82-elizabeth was [herself]82-elizabeth becoming an object of some interest in the eyes of [[his]403-her friend]286-his friend . [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy had at first scarcely allowed [her]82-elizabeth to be pretty : [he]89-mr. darcy had looked at [her]82-elizabeth without admiration at the ball ; and when [they]406-they next met , [he]89-mr. darcy looked at [her]82-elizabeth only to criticise . But no sooner had [he]89-mr. darcy made it clear to [himself]89-mr. darcy and [[his]89-mr. darcy friends]407-his friends that [she]82-elizabeth had hardly a good feature in [her]82-elizabeth face , than [he]89-mr. darcy began to find it was rendered uncommonly intelligent by the beautiful expression of [her]82-elizabeth dark eyes . To this discovery succeeded some others equally mortifying . Though [he]89-mr. darcy had detected with a critical eye more than one failure of perfect symmetry in [her]82-elizabeth form , [he]89-mr. darcy was forced to acknowledge [her]82-elizabeth figure to be light and pleasing ; and in spite of [his]89-mr. darcy asserting that [her]82-elizabeth manners were not those of the fashionable world , [he]89-mr. darcy was caught by [their]406-they easy playfulness . Of this [she]82-elizabeth was perfectly unaware : to [her]82-elizabeth [he]89-mr. darcy was only [the man who made [himself]89-mr. darcy agreeable nowhere , and who had not thought [her]82-elizabeth handsome enough to dance with]408-the man who made himself agreeable nowhere , and who had not thought her handsome enough to dance with .

[He]89-mr. darcy began to wish to know more of [her]82-elizabeth ; and , as a step towards conversing with [her]82-elizabeth [himself]89-mr. darcy , attended to [her]82-elizabeth conversation with [others]3103-others . [His]89-mr. darcy doing so drew [her]82-elizabeth notice . It was at [[Sir William Lucas]80-sir william 's]410-sir william lucas 's , where [a large party]257-a large party were assembled .

" What does [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy mean , "[82-elizabeth] said [she]82-elizabeth to [Charlotte]101-charlotte , " by listening to [my]82-elizabeth conversation with [Colonel Forster]107-colonel forster ? "[82-elizabeth]

" That is a question which [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy only can answer . "[82-elizabeth]

" But if [he]89-mr. darcy does it any more , [I]82-elizabeth shall certainly let [him]89-mr. darcy know that [I]82-elizabeth see what [he]89-mr. darcy is about . [He]89-mr. darcy has a very satirical eye , and if [I]82-elizabeth do not begin by being impertinent [myself]82-elizabeth , [I]82-elizabeth shall soon grow afraid of [him]89-mr. darcy . "[82-elizabeth]

On [his]80-sir william approaching [them]412-us soon afterwards , though without seeming to have any intention of speaking , [Miss Lucas]92-miss lucas defied [[her]92-miss lucas friend]402-her friend to mention such a subject to [him]80-sir william , which immediately provoking [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth to do it , [she]92-miss lucas turned to [him]80-sir william and said,--

" Did not [you]80-sir william think , [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy , that [I]92-miss lucas expressed [myself]92-miss lucas uncommonly well just now , when [I]92-miss lucas was teasing [Colonel Forster]107-colonel forster to give [us]412-us a ball at [Meryton]9-meryton ? "[92-miss lucas]

" With great energy ; but it is a subject which always makes [a lady]3153-a lady energetic . "[92-miss lucas]

" [You]80-sir william are severe on [us]412-us . "[92-miss lucas]

" It will be _ [her]3153-a lady _ turn soon to be teased , "[92-miss lucas] said [Miss Lucas]92-miss lucas . " [I]92-miss lucas am going to open the instrument , [Eliza]82-elizabeth , and [you]82-elizabeth know what follows . "[92-miss lucas]

" [You]82-elizabeth are [a very strange creature]3154-a very strange creature by way of [a friend!--always]3155-a friend!--always wanting [me]92-miss lucas to play and sing before [anybody]3099-anybody and [everybody]304-everybody ! If [my]92-miss lucas vanity had taken a musical turn , [you]82-elizabeth would have been invaluable ; but as it is , [I]92-miss lucas would really rather not sit down before those who must be in the habit of hearing [the very best performers]3158-the very best performers . "[92-miss lucas] On [Miss Lucas]92-miss lucas 's persevering , however , [she]92-miss lucas added , " Very well ; if it must be so , it must . "[92-miss lucas] And gravely glancing at [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy , " There is a very fine old saying , which [everybody here]3159-everybody here is of course familiar with--'Keep [your]82-elizabeth breath to cool [your]82-elizabeth porridge,'--and [I]92-miss lucas shall keep [mine]92-miss lucas to swell [my]92-miss lucas song . "[92-miss lucas]

[Her]92-miss lucas performance was pleasing , though by no means capital . After a song or two , and before [she]92-miss lucas could reply to the entreaties of several that [she]92-miss lucas would sing again , [she]92-miss lucas was eagerly succeeded at the instrument by [[her]92-miss lucas sister]328-her sister [Mary]87-mary , who having , in consequence of being [the only plain one in [the family]416-the family]415-the only plain one in the family , worked hard for knowledge and accomplishments , was always impatient for display .

[Mary]87-mary had neither genius nor taste ; and though vanity had given [her]87-mary application , it had given [her]87-mary likewise a pedantic air and conceited manner , which would have injured a higher degree of excellence than [she]87-mary had reached . [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth , easy and unaffected , had been listened to with much more pleasure , though not playing half so well ; and [Mary]87-mary , at the end of a long concerto , was glad to purchase praise and gratitude by [Scotch and Irish airs]417-scotch and irish airs , at the request of [[her]87-mary younger sisters]418-her younger sisters , who with [some of [the Lucases]100-the lucases]419-some of the lucases , and [two or three officers]420-two or three officers , joined eagerly in dancing at one end of [the room]250-the room .

[Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy stood near [them]418-her younger sisters in silent indignation at such a mode of passing the evening , to the exclusion of all conversation , and was too much engrossed by [his]89-mr. darcy own thoughts to perceive that [Sir William Lucas]80-sir william was [[his]89-mr. darcy neighbour]422-his neighbour , till [Sir William]80-sir william thus began:--

" What a charming amusement for [young people]3160-young people this is , [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy ! There is nothing like dancing , after all . [I]80-sir william consider it as one of the first refinements of polished societies . "[80-sir william]

" Certainly , [sir]3161-sir ; and it has the advantage also of being in vogue amongst [the less polished societies of [the world]303-the world]3162-the less polished societies of the world : [every savage]3164-every savage can dance . "[80-sir william]

[Sir William]80-sir william only smiled . " [[Your]3161-sir friend]3040-your friend performs delightfully , "[80-sir william] [he]80-sir william continued , after a pause , on seeing [Bingley]79-mr. bingley join [the group]423-the group ; " and [I]80-sir william doubt not that [you]3161-sir are an adept in the science [yourself]3161-sir , [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy . "[80-sir william]

" [You]3161-sir saw [me]80-sir william dance at [Meryton]9-meryton , [I]80-sir william believe , [sir]3161-sir . "[80-sir william]

" Yes , indeed , and received no inconsiderable pleasure from the sight . Do [you]3161-sir often dance at [St. James]11-st. james 's ? "[80-sir william]

" Never , [sir]3161-sir . "[80-sir william]

" [You]3161-sir have [a house in [town]264-town]3169-a house in town , [I]80-sir william conclude ? "[80-sir william]

[Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy bowed .

" [I]89-mr. darcy had once some thoughts of fixing in [town]264-town [myself]89-mr. darcy , for [I]89-mr. darcy am fond of superior society ; but [I]89-mr. darcy did not feel quite certain that the air of [London]5-london would agree with [Lady Lucas]81-lady lucas . "[89-mr. darcy]

" [[My]89-mr. darcy dear]2993-my dear [Miss Eliza]82-elizabeth , why are not [you]82-elizabeth dancing ? " Indeed , [sir]3161-sir , [I]108-sir william,-- have not the least intention of dancing . [I]108-sir william,-- entreat [you]3161-sir not to suppose that [I]108-sir william,-- moved this way in order to beg for [a partner]3176-a partner . "[108-sir william,--]

[Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy , with grave propriety , requested to be allowed the honour of [her]424-his companion hand , but in vain . [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth was determined ; nor did [Sir William]80-sir william at all shake [her]82-elizabeth purpose by [his]80-sir william attempt at persuasion .

" [You]82-elizabeth excel so much in the dance , [Miss Eliza]82-elizabeth , that it is cruel to deny [me]108-sir william,-- the happiness of seeing [you]82-elizabeth ; and though [this gentleman]3177-this gentleman dislikes the amusement in general , [he]3177-this gentleman can have no objection , [I]108-sir william,-- am sure , to oblige [us]3178-us for one half hour . "[108-sir william,--]

" [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy is all politeness , "[82-elizabeth] said [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth , smiling .

" [He]89-mr. darcy is , indeed : but considering the inducement , [[my]108-sir william,-- dear]2993-my dear [Miss Eliza]82-elizabeth , [we]3178-us can not wonder at [his]89-mr. darcy complaisance ; for who would object to [such a partner]3180-such a partner ? "[108-sir william,--]

[Elizabeth]82-elizabeth looked archly , and turned away . [Her]82-elizabeth resistance had not injured [her]82-elizabeth with [the gentleman]285-the gentleman , and [he]285-the gentleman was thinking of [her]82-elizabeth with some complacency , when thus accosted by [Miss Bingley,--]109-miss bingley,--

" [I]108-sir william,-- can guess the subject of [your]82-elizabeth reverie . "[108-sir william,--]

" [I]108-sir william,-- should imagine not . "[108-sir william,--]

" [You]82-elizabeth are considering how insupportable it would be to pass many evenings in this manner,--in such society ; and , indeed , [I]108-sir william,-- am quite of [your]82-elizabeth opinion . [I]108-sir william,-- was never more annoyed ! The insipidity , and yet the noise -- the nothingness , and yet the self - importance , of [all these people]3181-all these people ! " [Your]82-elizabeth conjecture is totally wrong , [I]108-sir william,-- assure [you]82-elizabeth . [My]108-sir william,-- mind was more agreeably engaged . " [Miss Elizabeth Bennet]82-elizabeth . "[108-sir william,--]

" [Miss Elizabeth Bennet]82-elizabeth ! "[91-miss bingley] repeated [Miss Bingley]91-miss bingley . " [I]91-miss bingley am all astonishment . How long has [she]82-elizabeth been such a favourite ? and pray when am [I]91-miss bingley to wish [you]82-elizabeth joy ? "[91-miss bingley]

" That is exactly the question which [I]108-sir william,-- expected [you]82-elizabeth to ask . [A lady]3153-a lady 's imagination is very rapid ; it jumps from admiration to love , from love to matrimony , in a moment . [I]108-sir william,-- knew [you]82-elizabeth would be wishing [me]108-sir william,-- joy . "[108-sir william,--]

"[91-miss bingley]

[He]429-he listened to [her]91-miss bingley with perfect indifference , while [she]91-miss bingley chose to entertain [herself]91-miss bingley in this manner ; and as [his]429-he composure convinced [her]91-miss bingley that all was safe , [her]91-miss bingley wit flowed along .

[[Mr. Bennet]75-mr. bennet 's property]430-mr. bennet 's property consisted almost entirely in an estate of two thousand a year , which , unfortunately for [[his]75-mr. bennet daughters]431-his daughters , was entailed , in default of [heirs male]432-heirs male , on [a distant relation]433-a distant relation ; and [[their]431-his daughters mother]434-their mother 's fortune , though ample for [her]434-their mother situation in life , could but ill supply the deficiency of [his]75-mr. bennet . [[Her]434-their mother father]244-her father had been [an attorney in [Meryton]9-meryton]436-an attorney in meryton , and had left [her]434-their mother four thousand pounds .

[She]434-their mother had [a sister]437-a sister married to [a Mr. Philips]110-philips , who had been [a clerk to [[their]431-his daughters father]247-their father and succeeded [him]75-mr. bennet in the business , and [a brother]440-a brother settled in [London]5-london in a respectable line of trade]438-a clerk to their father and succeeded him in the business , and a brother settled in london in a respectable line of trade .

[The village of Longbourn]441-the village of longbourn was only one mile from [Meryton]9-meryton ; a most convenient distance for [the young ladies]260-the young ladies , who were usually tempted thither three or four times a week , to pay [their]260-the young ladies duty to [[their]260-the young ladies aunt]443-their aunt , and to [a milliner 's shop just over the way]444-a milliner 's shop just over the way . [The two youngest of [the family]416-the family]445-the two youngest of the family , [Catherine]86-lady catherine and [Lydia]84-lydia , were particularly frequent in these attentions : [their]445-the two youngest of the family minds were more vacant than [[their]445-the two youngest of the family sisters]447-their sisters ' , and when nothing better offered , a walk to [Meryton]9-meryton was necessary to amuse [their]445-the two youngest of the family morning hours and furnish conversation for the evening ; and , however bare of news [the country]448-the country in general might be , [they]445-the two youngest of the family always contrived to learn some from [[their]445-the two youngest of the family aunt]443-their aunt . At present , indeed , [they]445-the two youngest of the family were well supplied both with news and happiness by the recent arrival of [a [militia regiment]451-militia regiment in [the neighbourhood]3015-the neighbourhood]450-a militia regiment in the neighbourhood ; it was to remain the whole winter , and [Meryton]9-meryton was [the head - quarters]453-the head - quarters .

[Their]445-the two youngest of the family visits to [Mrs. Philips]111-mrs. philips were now productive of the most interesting intelligence . Every day added something to [their]445-the two youngest of the family knowledge of [the officers]454-the officers ' names and connections . [[Their]445-the two youngest of the family lodgings]455-their lodgings were not long a secret , and at length [they]445-the two youngest of the family began to know [the officers]454-the officers [themselves]445-the two youngest of the family . [Mr. Philips]110-philips visited [them]445-the two youngest of the family all , and this opened to [[his]110-philips nieces]457-his nieces a source of felicity unknown before . [They]445-the two youngest of the family could talk of nothing but [officers]458-officers ; and [Mr. Bingley]79-mr. bingley 's large fortune , the mention of which gave animation to [[their]445-the two youngest of the family mother]434-their mother , was worthless in [their]445-the two youngest of the family eyes when opposed to the regimentals of [an ensign]460-an ensign .

After listening one morning to [their]445-the two youngest of the family effusions on this subject , [Mr. Bennet]75-mr. bennet coolly observed,--

" From all that [I]75-mr. bennet can collect by [your]445-the two youngest of the family manner of talking , [you]445-the two youngest of the family must be [two of [the silliest girls in [the country]448-the country]3186-the silliest girls in the country]3185-two of the silliest girls in the country . " [I]85-mrs. bennet am astonished , [[my]85-mrs. bennet dear]2993-my dear , "[85-mrs. bennet] said [Mrs. Bennet]85-mrs. bennet , " that [you]2993-my dear should be so ready to think [[your]2993-my dear own children]3024-your own children silly . [She]82-elizabeth did at last extort from [[her]82-elizabeth father]244-her father an acknowledgment that the horses were engaged ; [Jane]83-jane was therefore obliged to go on horseback , and [[her]83-jane mother]241-her mother attended [her]83-jane to the door with many cheerful prognostics of a bad day . [Her]83-jane hopes were answered ; [Jane]83-jane had not been gone long before it rained hard . [[Her]83-jane sisters]3023-her sisters were uneasy for [her]83-jane , but [[her]83-jane mother]241-her mother was delighted . The rain continued the whole evening without intermission ; [Jane]83-jane certainly could not come back .

" This was a lucky idea of [mine]85-mrs. bennet , indeed ! "[85-mrs. bennet] said [Mrs. Bennet]85-mrs. bennet , more than once , as if the credit of making it rain were all [her]85-mrs. bennet own . Till the next morning , however , [she]85-mrs. bennet was not aware of all the felicity of [her]85-mrs. bennet contrivance . " Well , [[my]75-mr. bennet dear]2993-my dear , "[75-mr. bennet] said [Mr. Bennet]75-mr. bennet , when [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth had read the note aloud , " if [[your]75-mr. bennet daughter]3233-your daughter should have a dangerous fit of illness -- if [she]3233-your daughter should die -- it would be a comfort to know that it was all in pursuit of [Mr. Bingley]79-mr. bingley , and under [your]75-mr. bennet orders . "[75-mr. bennet]

" Oh , [I]82-elizabeth am not at all afraid of [her]3233-your daughter dying . [People]3234-people do not die of little trifling colds . [She]3233-your daughter will be taken good care of .
