These are the kind of little things which please [[her]85-mrs. bennet Ladyship]3464-her ladyship , and it is a sort of attention which [I]85-mrs. bennet conceive [myself]85-mrs. bennet peculiarly bound to pay . "[85-mrs. bennet]

" [You]3482-you judge very properly , "[75-mr. bennet] said [Mr. Bennet]75-mr. bennet ; " and it is happy for [you]3482-you that [you]3482-you possess the talent of flattering with delicacy . May [I]75-mr. bennet ask whether these pleasing attentions proceed from the impulse of the moment , or are the result of previous study ? "[75-mr. bennet]

" They arise chiefly from what is passing at the time ; and though [I]75-mr. bennet sometimes amuse [myself]75-mr. bennet with suggesting and arranging such little elegant compliments as may be adapted to ordinary occasions , [I]75-mr. bennet always wish to give them as unstudied an air as possible . "[75-mr. bennet]

[Mr. Bennet]75-mr. bennet 's expectations were fully answered . [[His]75-mr. bennet cousin]704-his cousin was as absurd as [he]75-mr. bennet had hoped ; and [he]75-mr. bennet listened to [him]704-his cousin with the keenest enjoyment , maintaining at the same time the most resolute composure of countenance , and , except in an occasional glance at [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth , requiring [no partner]705-no partner in [his]704-his cousin pleasure .

By tea - time , however , the dose had been enough , and [Mr. Bennet]75-mr. bennet was glad to take [[his]75-mr. bennet guest]693-his guest into [the drawing - room]520-the drawing - room again , and when tea was over , glad to invite [him]704-his cousin

to read aloud to [the ladies]249-the ladies . [Mr. Collins]129-mr. collins readily assented , and a book was produced ; but on beholding it ( for everything announced it to be from [a circulating library]709-a circulating library ) [he]75-mr. bennet started back , and , begging pardon , protested that [he]75-mr. bennet never read novels . [Kitty]86-lady catherine stared at [him]75-mr. bennet , and [Lydia]84-lydia exclaimed . Other books were produced , and after some deliberation [he]75-mr. bennet chose " [Fordyce]133-fordyce 's Sermons . "[84-lydia] [Lydia]84-lydia gaped as [he]75-mr. bennet opened the volume ; and before [he]75-mr. bennet had , with very monotonous solemnity , read three pages , [she]84-lydia interrupted [him]75-mr. bennet with,--

" Do [you]75-mr. bennet know , [mamma]3033-mamma , that [[my]84-lydia uncle]3488-my uncle [Philips]111-mrs. philips talks of turning away [Richard]134-richard ? and if [he]3488-my uncle does , [Colonel Forster]107-colonel forster will hire [him]3488-my uncle . [[My]84-lydia aunt]3204-my aunt told [me]84-lydia so [herself]3204-my aunt on Saturday . [I]84-lydia shall walk to [Meryton]9-meryton to - morrow to hear more about it , and to ask when [Mr. Denny]135-denny comes back from [town]264-town . "[84-lydia]

[Lydia]84-lydia was bid by [[her]84-lydia two eldest sisters]710-her two eldest sisters to hold [her]84-lydia tongue ; but [Mr. Collins]129-mr. collins , much offended , laid aside [his]129-mr. collins book , and said,--

" [I]129-mr. collins have often observed how [little young ladies]3491-little young ladies are interested by books of a serious stamp , though written solely for [their]3491-little young ladies benefit . It amazes [me]129-mr. collins , [I]129-mr. collins confess ; for certainly there can be nothing so advantageous to [them]3491-little young ladies as instruction . But [I]129-mr. collins will no longer importune [[my]129-mr. collins young cousin]3492-my young cousin . "[129-mr. collins]

Then , turning to [Mr. Bennet]75-mr. bennet , [he]129-mr. collins offered [himself]129-mr. collins as [[his]129-mr. collins antagonist]711-his antagonist at backgammon . [Mr. Bennet]75-mr. bennet accepted the challenge , observing that [he]129-mr. collins acted very wisely in leaving [the girls]3008-the girls to [their]3008-the girls own trifling amusements . [Mrs. Bennet]85-mrs. bennet and [[her]85-mrs. bennet daughters]237-her daughters apologized most civilly for [Lydia]84-lydia 's interruption , and promised that it should not occur again , if [he]129-mr. collins would resume [his]129-mr. collins book ; but [Mr. Collins]129-mr. collins , after assuring [them]3008-the girls that [he]129-mr. collins bore [[his]129-mr. collins young cousin]714-his young cousin no ill - will , and should never resent [her]714-his young cousin behaviour as any affront , seated [himself]129-mr. collins at another table with [Mr. Bennet]75-mr. bennet , and prepared for backgammon .

[Mr. Collins]129-mr. collins was not [a sensible man]3446-a sensible man , and the deficiency of nature had been but little assisted by education or society ; the greatest part of [his]129-mr. collins life having been spent under the guidance of [an illiterate and miserly father]716-an illiterate and miserly father ; and though [he]129-mr. collins belonged to [one of [the universities]718-the universities]717-one of the universities , [he]129-mr. collins had merely kept the necessary terms without forming at it any useful acquaintance . The subjection in which [[his]129-mr. collins father]340-his father had brought [him]129-mr. collins up had given [him]129-mr. collins originally great humility of manner ; but it was now a good deal counteracted by the self - conceit of a weak head , living in retirement , and the consequential feelings of early and unexpected prosperity . A fortunate chance had recommended [him]129-mr. collins to [Lady Catherine de Bourgh]86-lady catherine when [the living of [Hunsford]15-hunsford]720-the living of hunsford was vacant ; and the respect which [he]129-mr. collins felt for [her]86-lady catherine high rank , and [his]129-mr. collins veneration for [her]86-lady catherine as [[his]129-mr. collins patroness]694-his patroness , mingling with a very good opinion of [himself]129-mr. collins , of [his]129-mr. collins authority as [a clergyman]3429-a clergyman , and [his]129-mr. collins right as [a rector]723-a rector , made [him]129-mr. collins altogether a mixture of pride and obsequiousness , self - importance and humility .

Having now [a good house]343-a good house and a very sufficient income , [he]129-mr. collins intended to marry ; and in seeking a reconciliation with [[the Longbourn]7-longbourn family]725-the longbourn family [he]129-mr. collins had [a wife]224-a wife in view , as [he]129-mr. collins meant to choose [one of [the daughters]728-the daughters]727-one of the daughters , if [he]129-mr. collins found [them]728-the daughters as handsome and amiable as [they]728-the daughters were represented by common report . This was [his]129-mr. collins plan of amends -- of atonement -- for inheriting [[their]728-the daughters father]247-their father 's estate ; and [he]129-mr. collins thought it an excellent one , full of eligibility and suitableness , and excessively generous and disinterested on [his]129-mr. collins own part .

[His]129-mr. collins plan did not vary on seeing [them]728-the daughters . [Miss Bennet]84-lydia 's lovely face confirmed [his]129-mr. collins views , and established all [his]129-mr. collins strictest notions of what was due to seniority ; and for the first evening _ [she]84-lydia _ was [his]129-mr. collins settled choice . The next morning , however , made an alteration ; for in a quarter of an hour 's _ tete - a - tete _ with [Mrs. Bennet]85-mrs. bennet before breakfast , a conversation beginning with [[his]129-mr. collins parsonage - house]730-his parsonage - house , and leading naturally to the avowal of [his]129-mr. collins hopes , that [a mistress for it]731-a mistress for it might be found at [Longbourn]7-longbourn , produced from [her]85-mrs. bennet , amid very complaisant smiles and general encouragement , a caution against the very [Jane]83-jane [he]129-mr. collins had fixed on . " As to [[her]85-mrs. bennet _ younger _ daughters]3493-her _ younger _ daughters , [she]85-mrs. bennet could not take upon [her]85-mrs. bennet to say -- [she]85-mrs. bennet could not positively answer -- but [she]85-mrs. bennet did not _ know _ of any prepossession;--her _ eldest _ daughter [she]85-mrs. bennet must just mention -- [she]85-mrs. bennet felt it incumbent on [her]85-mrs. bennet to hint , was likely to be very soon engaged . "[83-jane]

[Mr. Collins]129-mr. collins had only to change from [Jane]83-jane to [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth -- and it was soon done -- done while [Mrs. Bennet]85-mrs. bennet was stirring the fire . [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth , equally next to [Jane]83-jane in birth and beauty , succeeded [her]82-elizabeth of course .

[Mrs. Bennet]85-mrs. bennet treasured up the hint , and trusted that [she]85-mrs. bennet might soon have [two daughters]732-two daughters married ; and [the man whom [she]85-mrs. bennet could not bear to speak of the day before]733-the man whom she could not bear to speak of the day before , was now high in [her]85-mrs. bennet good graces .

[Lydia]84-lydia 's intention of walking to [Meryton]9-meryton was not forgotten : [every sister]734-every sister except [Mary]87-mary agreed to go with [her]84-lydia ; and [Mr. Collins]129-mr. collins was to attend [them]735-them , at the request of [Mr. Bennet]75-mr. bennet , who was most anxious to get rid of [him]129-mr. collins , and have [[his]129-mr. collins library]259-his library to [himself]129-mr. collins ; for thither [Mr. Collins]129-mr. collins had followed [him]129-mr. collins after breakfast , and there [he]129-mr. collins would continue , nominally engaged with one of the largest folios in the collection , but really talking to [Mr. Bennet]75-mr. bennet , with little cessation , of [[his]129-mr. collins house and garden at [Hunsford]15-hunsford]737-his house and garden at hunsford . Such doings discomposed [Mr. Bennet]75-mr. bennet exceedingly . In [[his]129-mr. collins library]259-his library [he]129-mr. collins had been always sure of leisure and tranquillity ; and though prepared , as [he]129-mr. collins told [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth , to meet with folly and conceit in [every other room in [the house]3001-the house]739-every other room in the house , [he]129-mr. collins was used to be free from [them]741-them [there]305-there : [his]129-mr. collins civility , therefore , was most prompt in inviting [Mr. Collins]129-mr. collins to join [[his]129-mr. collins daughters]431-his daughters in [their]431-his daughters walk ; and [Mr. Collins]129-mr. collins , being in fact much better fitted for [a walker]744-a walker than [a reader]745-a reader , was extremely well pleased to close [his]129-mr. collins large book , and go .

In pompous nothings on [his]129-mr. collins side , and civil assents on that of [[his]129-mr. collins cousins]746-his cousins , [their]431-his daughters time passed till [they]431-his daughters entered [Meryton]9-meryton . The attention of [the younger ones]747-the younger ones was then no longer to be gained by _ [him]129-mr. collins _ . [Their]747-the younger ones eyes were immediately wandering up [the street]748-the street in quest of [the officers]454-the officers , and nothing less than a very smart bonnet , indeed , or a really new muslin in a shop window , could recall [them]747-the younger ones .

But the attention of [every lady]750-every lady was soon caught by [a young man , whom [they]431-his daughters had never seen before , of most gentlemanlike appearance , walking with [an officer on the other side of the way]752-an officer on the other side of the way]751-a young man , whom they had never seen before , of most gentlemanlike appearance , walking with an officer on the other side of the way . [The officer]753-the officer was [the very Mr. Denny concerning whose return from [London]5-london [Lydia]84-lydia]754-the very mr. denny concerning whose return from london lydia came to inquire , and [he]129-mr. collins bowed as [they]431-his daughters passed . [All]755-all were struck with [the stranger]323-the stranger 's air , all wondered who [he]323-the stranger could be ; and [Kitty]86-lady catherine and [Lydia]84-lydia , determined if possible to find out , led the way across [the street]748-the street , under pretence of wanting something in [an opposite shop]758-an opposite shop , and fortunately had just gained [the pavement]759-the pavement , when [the two gentlemen]760-the two gentlemen , turning back , had reached the same spot . [Mr. Denny]135-denny addressed [them]760-the two gentlemen directly , and entreated permission to introduce [[his]135-denny friend]286-his friend , [Mr. Wickham]136-wickham , who had returned with [him]135-denny the day before from [town]264-town , and , [he]135-denny was happy to say , had accepted a commission in [[their]760-the two gentlemen corps]763-their corps . This was exactly as it should be ; for [the young man]764-the young man wanted only regimentals to make [him]764-the young man completely charming . [His]764-the young man appearance was greatly in [his]764-the young man favour : [he]764-the young man had all the best parts of beauty , a fine countenance , a good figure , and very pleasing address . The introduction was followed up on [his]764-the young man side by a happy readiness of conversation -- a readiness at the same time perfectly correct and unassuming ; and [the whole party]521-the whole party were still standing and talking together very agreeably , when the sound of horses drew [their]760-the two gentlemen notice , and [Darcy]89-mr. darcy and [Bingley]79-mr. bingley were seen riding down [the street]748-the street . On distinguishing [the ladies of [the group]423-the group]767-the ladies of the group [the two gentlemen]760-the two gentlemen came directly towards [them]760-the two gentlemen , and began the usual civilities . [Bingley]79-mr. bingley was [the principal spokesman]770-the principal spokesman , and [Miss Bennet]84-lydia [the principal object]771-the principal object . [He]79-mr. bingley was then , [he]79-mr. bingley said , on [his]79-mr. bingley way to [Longbourn]7-longbourn on purpose to inquire after [her]84-lydia . [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy corroborated it with a bow , and was beginning to determine not to fix [his]89-mr. darcy eyes on [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth , when [they]760-the two gentlemen were suddenly arrested by the sight of [the stranger]323-the stranger ; and [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth happening to see the countenance of both as [they]760-the two gentlemen looked at [each other]3144-each other , was all astonishment at the effect of the meeting . [Both]774-both changed colour , one looked white , the other red . [Mr. Wickham]136-wickham , after a few moments , touched [his]136-wickham hat -- a salutation which [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy just deigned to return . What could be the meaning of it ? It was impossible to imagine ; it was impossible not to long to know .

In another minute [Mr. Bingley]79-mr. bingley , but without seeming to have noticed what passed , took leave and rode on with [[his]79-mr. bingley friend]286-his friend .

[Mr. Denny]135-denny and [Mr. Wickham]136-wickham walked with [the young ladies]260-the young ladies to the door of [[Mr. Philips]110-philips 's house]777-mr. philips 's house , and then made [their]760-the two gentlemen bows , in spite of [Miss Lydia]84-lydia 's pressing entreaties that [they]760-the two gentlemen would come in , and even in spite of [Mrs. Philips]111-mrs. philips 's throwing up the parlour window , and loudly seconding the invitation .

[Mrs. Philips]111-mrs. philips was always glad to see [[her]111-mrs. philips nieces]3045-her nieces ; and [the two eldest]397-the two eldest , from [their]397-the two eldest recent absence , were particularly welcome ; and [she]111-mrs. philips was eagerly expressing [her]111-mrs. philips surprise at [their]397-the two eldest sudden return [home]3219-home , which , as [[their]397-the two eldest own carriage]781-their own carriage had not fetched [them]397-the two eldest , [she]111-mrs. philips should have known nothing about , if [she]111-mrs. philips had not happened to see [[Mr. Jones]121-mr. jones 's shopboy]782-mr. jones 's shopboy in [the street]748-the street , who had told [her]111-mrs. philips that [they]397-the two eldest were not to send any more draughts to [Netherfield]2-netherfield , because [the Miss Bennets]99-the bennets were come away , when [her]111-mrs. philips civility was claimed towards [Mr. Collins]129-mr. collins by [Jane]83-jane 's introduction of [him]129-mr. collins . [She]111-mrs. philips received [him]129-mr. collins with [her]111-mrs. philips very best politeness , which [he]129-mr. collins returned with as much more , apologizing for [his]129-mr. collins intrusion , without any previous acquaintance with [her]111-mrs. philips , which [he]129-mr. collins could not help flattering [himself]129-mr. collins , however , might be justified by [his]129-mr. collins relationship to [the young ladies who introduced [him]129-mr. collins to [her]111-mrs. philips notice]784-the young ladies who introduced him to her notice . [Mrs. Philips]111-mrs. philips was quite awed by such an excess of good breeding ; but [her]111-mrs. philips contemplation of [one stranger]785-one stranger was soon put an end to by exclamations and inquiries about the other , of whom , however , [she]111-mrs. philips could only tell [[her]111-mrs. philips nieces]3045-her nieces what [they]3045-her nieces already knew , that [Mr. Denny]135-denny had brought [him]129-mr. collins from [London]5-london , and that [he]129-mr. collins was to have [a lieutenant]787-a lieutenant 's commission in [the ----shire]21-the ----shire . [She]111-mrs. philips had been watching [him]129-mr. collins the last hour , [she]111-mrs. philips said , as [he]129-mr. collins walked up and down [the street,--and]788-the street,--and had [Mr. Wickham]136-wickham appeared , [Kitty]86-lady catherine and [Lydia]84-lydia would certainly have continued the occupation ; but unluckily [no one]3271-no one passed the windows now except a few of [the officers]454-the officers , who , in comparison with [the stranger]323-the stranger , were become " [stupid , disagreeable fellows]3494-stupid , disagreeable fellows . "[3045-her nieces] [Some of [them]3045-her nieces]792-some of them were to dine with [the Philipses]137-the philipses the next day , and [[their]3045-her nieces aunt]443-their aunt promised to make [[her]443-their aunt husband]255-her husband call on [Mr. Wickham]136-wickham , and give [him]136-wickham an invitation also , if [the family]416-the family from [Longbourn]7-longbourn would come in the evening . This was agreed to ; and [Mrs. Philips]111-mrs. philips protested that [they]3045-her nieces would have a nice comfortable noisy game of lottery tickets , and a little bit of hot supper afterwards . The prospect of such delights was very cheering , and [they]3045-her nieces parted in mutual good spirits . [Mr. Collins]129-mr. collins repeated [his]129-mr. collins apologies in quitting [the room]250-the room , and was assured , with unwearying civility , that [they]3045-her nieces were perfectly needless .

As [they]3045-her nieces walked [home]3219-home , [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth related to [Jane]83-jane what [she]82-elizabeth had seen pass between [the two gentlemen]760-the two gentlemen ; but though [Jane]83-jane would have defended either or both , had [they]760-the two gentlemen appeared to be wrong , [she]83-jane could no more explain such behaviour than [[her]83-jane sister]328-her sister .

[Mr. Collins]129-mr. collins on [his]129-mr. collins return highly gratified [Mrs. Bennet]85-mrs. bennet by admiring [Mrs. Philips]111-mrs. philips 's manners and politeness . [He]129-mr. collins protested that , except [Lady Catherine]86-lady catherine and [[her]86-lady catherine daughter]463-her daughter , [he]129-mr. collins had never seen [a more elegant woman]801-a more elegant woman ; for [she]85-mrs. bennet had not only received [him]129-mr. collins with the utmost civility , but had even pointedly included [him]129-mr. collins in [her]85-mrs. bennet invitation for the next evening , although utterly unknown to [her]85-mrs. bennet before . Something , [he]129-mr. collins supposed , might be attributed to [his]129-mr. collins connection with [them]802-them , but yet [he]129-mr. collins had never met with so much attention in the whole course of [his]129-mr. collins life .

As no objection was made to [the young people]803-the young people 's engagement with [[their]803-the young people aunt]443-their aunt , and all [Mr. Collins]129-mr. collins 's scruples of leaving [Mr.]805-mr. and [Mrs. Bennet]85-mrs. bennet for a single evening during [his]129-mr. collins visit were most steadily resisted , [the coach]3221-the coach conveyed [him]129-mr. collins and [[his]129-mr. collins five cousins]807-his five cousins at a suitable hour to [Meryton]9-meryton ; and [the girls]3008-the girls had the pleasure of hearing , as [they]3008-the girls entered [the drawing - room]520-the drawing - room , that [Mr. Wickham]136-wickham had accepted [[their]3008-the girls uncle]3247-their uncle 's invitation , and was then in [the house]3001-the house .

When this information was given , and [they]3008-the girls had all taken [their]3008-the girls seats , [Mr. Collins]129-mr. collins was at leisure to look around [him]129-mr. collins and admire , and [he]129-mr. collins was so much struck with the size and furniture of [the apartment]812-the apartment , that [he]129-mr. collins declared [he]129-mr. collins might almost have supposed [himself]129-mr. collins in [the small summer breakfast parlour at [Rosings]20-rosings]813-the small summer breakfast parlour at rosings ; a comparison that did not at first convey much gratification ; but when [Mrs. Philips]111-mrs. philips understood from [him]129-mr. collins what [Rosings]20-rosings was , and who was [its proprietor]814-its proprietor , when [she]111-mrs. philips had listened to the description of only one of [[Lady Catherine]86-lady catherine 's drawing - rooms]815-lady catherine 's drawing - rooms , and found that the chimney - piece alone had cost eight hundred pounds , [she]111-mrs. philips felt all the force of the compliment , and would hardly have resented a comparison with [[the housekeeper]816-the housekeeper 's room]817-the housekeeper 's room .

In describing to [her]111-mrs. philips all the grandeur of [Lady Catherine]86-lady catherine and [[her]86-lady catherine mansion]818-her mansion , with occasional digressions in praise of [[his]129-mr. collins own humble abode]819-his own humble abode , and the improvements it was receiving , [he]129-mr. collins was happily employed until [the gentlemen]290-the gentlemen joined [them]290-the gentlemen ; and [he]129-mr. collins found in [Mrs. Philips]111-mrs. philips a very attentive listener , whose opinion of [his]129-mr. collins consequence increased with what [she]111-mrs. philips heard , and who was resolving to retail it all among [[her]111-mrs. philips neighbours]821-her neighbours as soon as [she]111-mrs. philips could . To [[the girls]3008-the girls , who could not listen to [[their]3008-the girls cousin]671-their cousin , and who had nothing to do but to wish for an instrument , and examine [their]3008-the girls own indifferent imitations of china on the mantel - piece]823-the girls , who could not listen to their cousin , and who had nothing to do but to wish for an instrument , and examine their own indifferent imitations of china on the mantel - piece , the interval of waiting appeared very long . It was over at last , however . [The gentlemen]290-the gentlemen did approach : and when [Mr. Wickham]136-wickham walked into [the room]250-the room , [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth felt that [she]82-elizabeth had neither been seeing [him]136-wickham before , nor thinking of [him]136-wickham since , with the smallest degree of unreasonable admiration . [The officers of the ----shire]827-the officers of the ----shire were in general [a very creditable , gentlemanlike set]828-a very creditable , gentlemanlike set and the best of [them]827-the officers of the ----shire were of [the present party]3384-the present party ; but [Mr , Wickham]136-wickham was as far beyond [them]827-the officers of the ----shire all in person , countenance , air , and walk , as _ [they]827-the officers of the ----shire _ were superior to [the broad - faced stuffy uncle [Philips]111-mrs. philips , breathing port wine , who followed [them]827-the officers of the ----shire into [the room]250-the room]830-the broad - faced stuffy uncle philips , breathing port wine , who followed them into the room .

[Mr. Wickham]136-wickham was [the happy man towards whom almost every female eye was turned]832-the happy man towards whom almost every female eye was turned , and [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth was [the happy woman by whom [he]136-wickham finally seated [himself]136-wickham]833-the happy woman by whom he finally seated himself ; and the agreeable manner in which [he]136-wickham immediately fell into conversation , though it was only on its being a wet night , and on the probability of a rainy season , made [her]82-elizabeth feel that the commonest , dullest , most threadbare topic might be rendered interesting by the skill of [the speaker]834-the speaker .

With [such rivals for the notice of the fair]835-such rivals for the notice of the fair as [Mr. Wickham]136-wickham and [the officers]454-the officers , [Mr. Collins]129-mr. collins seemed to sink into insignificance ; to [the young ladies]260-the young ladies [he]129-mr. collins certainly was nothing ; but [he]136-wickham had still at intervals a kind listener in [Mrs. Philips]111-mrs. philips , and was , by [her]111-mrs. philips watchfulness , most abundantly supplied with coffee and muffin .

When the card tables were placed , [he]136-wickham had an opportunity of obliging [her]111-mrs. philips , in return , by sitting down to whist .

" [I]136-wickham know little of the game at present , "[136-wickham] said [he]136-wickham , " but [I]136-wickham shall be glad to improve [myself]136-wickham ; for in [my]136-wickham situation of life---- "[136-wickham] [Mrs. Philips]111-mrs. philips was very thankful for [his]136-wickham compliance , but could not wait for [his]136-wickham reason .

[Mr. Wickham]136-wickham did not play at whist , and with ready delight was [he]136-wickham received at the other table between [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth and [Lydia]84-lydia . At first there seemed danger of [Lydia]84-lydia 's engrossing [him]136-wickham entirely , for [she]84-lydia was [a most determined talker]838-a most determined talker ; but being likewise extremely fond of lottery tickets , [she]84-lydia soon grew too much interested in the game , too eager in making bets and exclaiming after prizes , to have attention for [anyone in particular]839-anyone in particular . Allowing for the common demands of the game , [Mr. Wickham]136-wickham was therefore at leisure to talk to [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth , and [she]82-elizabeth was very willing to hear [him]136-wickham , though what [she]82-elizabeth chiefly wished to hear [she]82-elizabeth could not hope to be told , the history of [his]136-wickham acquaintance with [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy . [She]82-elizabeth dared not even mention [that gentleman]3305-that gentleman . [Her]82-elizabeth curiosity , however , was unexpectedly relieved . [Mr. Wickham]136-wickham began the subject [himself]136-wickham . [He]136-wickham inquired how far [Netherfield]2-netherfield was from [Meryton]9-meryton ; and , after receiving [her]82-elizabeth answer , asked in a hesitating manner how long [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy had been staying [there]305-there .

" About a month , "[82-elizabeth] said [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth ; and then , unwilling to let the subject drop , added , " [he]89-mr. darcy is [a man of very large property in [Derbyshire]6-derbyshire]3495-a man of very large property in derbyshire , [I]82-elizabeth understand . "[82-elizabeth]

" Yes , "[136-wickham] replied [Wickham]136-wickham ; " [[his]89-mr. darcy estate]3496-his estate there is [a noble one]3497-a noble one . A clear ten thousand per annum . [You]82-elizabeth could not have met with [a person more capable of giving [you]82-elizabeth certain information on that head than [myself]136-wickham]3498-a person more capable of giving you certain information on that head than myself -- for [I]136-wickham have been connected with [[his]89-mr. darcy family]375-his family , in a particular manner , from [my]136-wickham infancy . "[136-wickham]

[Elizabeth]82-elizabeth could not but look surprised .

" [You]82-elizabeth may well be surprised , [Miss Bennet]82-elizabeth , at such an assertion , after seeing , as [you]82-elizabeth probably might , the very cold manner of [our]3500-our meeting yesterday . Are [you]82-elizabeth much acquainted with [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy ? "[82-elizabeth]

" As much as [I]82-elizabeth ever wish to be , "[82-elizabeth] cried [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth , warmly . " [I]82-elizabeth have spent four days in [the same house]3501-the same house with [him]89-mr. darcy , and [I]82-elizabeth think [him]89-mr. darcy very disagreeable . "[82-elizabeth]

" [I]136-wickham have no right to give _ [my]136-wickham _ opinion , "[136-wickham] said [Wickham]136-wickham , " as to [his]89-mr. darcy being agreeable or otherwise . [I]136-wickham am not qualified to form one . [I]136-wickham have known [him]89-mr. darcy too long and too well to be [a fair judge]3502-a fair judge . It is impossible for _ [me]136-wickham _ to be impartial . But [I]136-wickham believe [your]82-elizabeth opinion of [him]89-mr. darcy would in general astonish -- and , perhaps , [you]82-elizabeth would not express it quite so strongly anywhere else . Here [you]82-elizabeth are in [[your]82-elizabeth own family]3503-your own family . "[136-wickham]

" Upon [my]82-elizabeth word [I]82-elizabeth say no more _ here _ than [I]82-elizabeth might say in [any house in [the neighbourhood]3015-the neighbourhood]3504-any house in the neighbourhood , except [Netherfield]2-netherfield . [He]89-mr. darcy is not at all liked in [Hertfordshire]4-hertfordshire . [Everybody]304-everybody is disgusted with [his]89-mr. darcy pride . [You]82-elizabeth will not find [him]89-mr. darcy more favourably spoken of by [anyone]3102-anyone . "[82-elizabeth]

" [I]136-wickham can not pretend to be sorry , "[136-wickham] said [Wickham]136-wickham , after a short interruption , " that [he]89-mr. darcy or that [any man]3508-any man should not be estimated beyond [their]3508-any man deserts ; but with _ [him]89-mr. darcy _ [I]136-wickham believe it does not often happen . [The world]303-the world is blinded by [his]89-mr. darcy fortune and consequence , or frightened by [his]89-mr. darcy high and imposing manners , and sees [him]89-mr. darcy only as [he]89-mr. darcy chooses to be seen . "[136-wickham]

" [I]82-elizabeth should take [him]89-mr. darcy , even on _ [my]82-elizabeth _ slight acquaintance , to be [an ill - tempered man]3510-an ill - tempered man . "[82-elizabeth]

[Wickham]136-wickham only shook [his]136-wickham head .

" [I]136-wickham wonder , "[136-wickham] said [he]136-wickham , at the next opportunity of speaking , " whether [he]89-mr. darcy is likely to be in [this country]3511-this country much longer . "[136-wickham]

" [I]82-elizabeth do not at all know ; but [I]82-elizabeth _ heard _ nothing of [his]89-mr. darcy going away when [I]82-elizabeth was at [Netherfield]2-netherfield . [I]82-elizabeth hope [your]136-wickham plans in favour of [the ----shire]21-the ----shire will not be affected by [his]89-mr. darcy being in [the neighbourhood]3015-the neighbourhood . "[82-elizabeth]

" Oh no -- it is not for _ [me]136-wickham _ to be driven away by [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy . If _ [he]89-mr. darcy _ wishes to avoid seeing _ [me]136-wickham _ [he]89-mr. darcy must go . [We]3513-we are not on friendly terms , and it always gives [me]136-wickham pain to meet [him]89-mr. darcy , but [I]136-wickham have no reason for avoiding _ [him]89-mr. darcy _ but what [I]136-wickham might proclaim to all [the world]303-the world -- a sense of very great ill - usage , and most painful regrets at [his]89-mr. darcy being what [he]89-mr. darcy is . [[His]89-mr. darcy father]340-his father , [Miss Bennet]82-elizabeth , [the late Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy , was one of [the best men that ever breathed]3516-the best men that ever breathed , and [the truest friend [I]136-wickham ever had]3517-the truest friend i ever had ; and [I]136-wickham can never be in company with [this Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy without being grieved to the soul by a thousand tender recollections . [His]89-mr. darcy behaviour to [myself]136-wickham has been scandalous ; but [I]136-wickham verily believe [I]136-wickham could forgive [him]89-mr. darcy anything and everything , rather than [his]89-mr. darcy disappointing the hopes and disgracing the memory of [[his]89-mr. darcy father]340-his father . "[136-wickham]

[Elizabeth]82-elizabeth found the interest of the subject increase , and listened with all [her]82-elizabeth heart ; but the delicacy of it prevented further inquiry .

[Mr. Wickham]136-wickham began to speak on more general topics , [Meryton]9-meryton , [the neighbourhood]3015-the neighbourhood , [the society]843-the society , appearing highly pleased with all that [he]136-wickham had yet seen , and speaking of [the latter]487-the latter , especially , with gentle but very intelligible gallantry .

" It was the prospect of constant society , and good society , "[136-wickham] [he]136-wickham added , " which was [my]136-wickham chief inducement to enter [the ----shire]21-the ----shire . [I]136-wickham know it to be [a most respectable , agreeable corps]3519-a most respectable , agreeable corps ; and [[my]136-wickham friend]3353-my friend [Denny]135-denny tempted [me]136-wickham further by [his]3353-my friend account of [[their]3521-their present quarters]3522-their present quarters , and the very great attentions and excellent acquaintance [Meryton]9-meryton had procured [them]3521-their . Society , [I]136-wickham own , is necessary to [me]136-wickham . [I]136-wickham have been [a disappointed man]3523-a disappointed man , and [my]136-wickham spirits will not bear solitude . [I]136-wickham _ must _ have employment and society . A military life is not what [I]136-wickham was intended for , but circumstances have now made it eligible . [The church]3524-the church _ ought _ to have been [my]136-wickham profession -- [I]136-wickham was brought up for the church ; and [I]136-wickham should at this time have been in possession of a most valuable living , had it pleased [the gentleman]285-the gentleman [we]3526-we were speaking of just now . "[136-wickham]

" Indeed ! "[136-wickham]

" Yes -- [the late Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy bequeathed [me]136-wickham the next presentation of the best living in [his]89-mr. darcy gift . [He]89-mr. darcy was [[my]136-wickham godfather]3527-my godfather , and excessively attached to [me]136-wickham . [I]136-wickham can not do justice to [his]89-mr. darcy kindness . [He]89-mr. darcy meant to provide for [me]136-wickham amply , and thought [he]89-mr. darcy had done it ; but when the living fell , it was given elsewhere . "[136-wickham]

" Good heavens ! "[82-elizabeth] cried [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth ; " but how could _ that _ be ? How could [his]89-mr. darcy will be disregarded ? Why did not [you]136-wickham seek legal redress ? "[82-elizabeth]

" There was just such an informality in the terms of the bequest as to give [me]136-wickham no hope from law . [A man of honour]3528-a man of honour could not have doubted the intention , but [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy chose to doubt it -- or to treat it as a merely conditional recommendation , and to assert that [I]136-wickham had forfeited all claim to it by extravagance , imprudence , in short , anything or nothing . Certain it is that the living became vacant two years ago , exactly as [I]136-wickham was of an age to hold it , and that it was given to [another man]3529-another man ; and no less certain is it , that [I]136-wickham can not accuse [myself]136-wickham of having really done anything to deserve to lose it . [I]136-wickham have a warm unguarded temper , and [I]136-wickham may perhaps have sometimes spoken [my]136-wickham opinion _ of _ [him]89-mr. darcy , and _ to _ [him]89-mr. darcy , too freely . [I]136-wickham can recall nothing worse . But the fact is , that [we]3530-we are [very different sort of men]3531-very different sort of men , and that [he]89-mr. darcy hates [me]136-wickham . "[136-wickham]

" This is quite shocking ! [He]89-mr. darcy deserves to be publicly disgraced . "[82-elizabeth]

" Some time or other [he]89-mr. darcy _ will _ be -- but it shall not be by _ [me]136-wickham _ . Till [I]136-wickham can forget [[his]89-mr. darcy father]340-his father , [I]136-wickham can never defy or expose _ [him]89-mr. darcy _ . "[136-wickham]

[Elizabeth]82-elizabeth honoured [him]845-him for such feelings , and thought [him]845-him handsomer than ever as [he]845-him expressed them .

" But what , "[82-elizabeth] said [she]82-elizabeth , after a pause , " can have been [his]845-him motive ? what can have induced [him]845-him to behave so cruelly ? "[82-elizabeth]

" A thorough , determined dislike of [me]82-elizabeth -- a dislike which [I]82-elizabeth can not but attribute in some measure to jealousy . Had [the late Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy liked [me]82-elizabeth less , [[his]89-mr. darcy son]3533-his son might have borne with [me]82-elizabeth better ; but [[his]89-mr. darcy father]340-his father 's uncommon attachment to [me]82-elizabeth irritated [him]845-him , [I]82-elizabeth believe , very early in life . [He]845-him had not a temper to bear the sort of competition in which [we]3535-we stood -- the sort of preference which was often given [me]82-elizabeth . "[82-elizabeth]

" [I]82-elizabeth had not thought [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy so bad as this -- though [I]82-elizabeth have never liked [him]845-him , [I]82-elizabeth had not thought so very ill of [him]845-him -- [I]82-elizabeth had supposed [him]845-him to be despising [his]845-him fellow - creatures in general , but did not suspect [him]845-him of descending to such malicious revenge , such injustice , such inhumanity as this ! "[82-elizabeth]

After a few minutes ' reflection , however , [she]846-she continued , " [I]846-she _ do _ remember [his]845-him boasting one day , at [Netherfield]2-netherfield , of the implacability of [his]845-him resentments , of [his]845-him having an unforgiving temper . [His]845-him disposition must be dreadful . "[846-she]

" [I]136-wickham will not trust [myself]136-wickham on the subject , "[136-wickham] replied [Wickham]136-wickham ; " _ [I]136-wickham _ can hardly be just to [him]845-him . "[136-wickham]

[Elizabeth]82-elizabeth was again deep in thought , and after a time exclaimed , " To treat in such a manner [the godson]3536-the godson , [the friend]3537-the friend , [the favourite of [[his]845-him father]340-his father]3538-the favourite of his father ! "[82-elizabeth] [She]846-she could have added , " [A young man]3093-a young man , too , like _ [you]3093-a young man _ , whose very countenance may vouch for [your]3093-a young man being amiable . "[82-elizabeth] But [she]846-she contented [herself]846-she with--"And one , too , who had probably been [[his]845-him own companion]3541-his own companion from childhood , connected together , as [I]846-she think [you]3093-a young man said , in the closest manner . "[846-she]

" [We]3542-we were born in [the same parish]3543-the same parish , within [the same park]3544-the same park ; the greatest part of [our]3542-we youth was passed together : [inmates of [the same house]3501-the same house]3545-inmates of the same house , sharing the same amusements , objects of the same parental care . _ [[My]136-wickham _ father]3547-my _ father began life in the profession which [[your]3093-a young man uncle]3374-your uncle , [Mr. Philips]110-philips , appears to do so much credit to ; but [he]3547-my _ father gave up everything to be of use to [the late Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy , and devoted all [his]3547-my _ father time to the care of [the Pemberley property]3549-the pemberley property . [He]3547-my _ father was most highly esteemed by [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy , [a most intimate , confidential friend]3550-a most intimate , confidential friend . [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy often acknowledged [himself]89-mr. darcy to be under the greatest obligations to [[my]136-wickham father]3256-my father 's active superintendence ; and when , immediately before [[my]136-wickham father]3256-my father 's death , [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy gave [him]89-mr. darcy a voluntary promise of providing for [me]136-wickham , [I]136-wickham am convinced that [he]89-mr. darcy felt it to be as much a debt of gratitude to _ [him]89-mr. darcy _ as of affection to [myself]136-wickham . "[136-wickham]

" How strange ! "[82-elizabeth] cried [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth . " How abominable ! [I]82-elizabeth wonder that the very pride of [this Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy has not made [him]89-mr. darcy just to [you]82-elizabeth . If from no better motive , that [he]89-mr. darcy should not have been too proud to be dishonest,--for dishonesty [I]82-elizabeth must call it . "[82-elizabeth]

" [It]3553-it _ is _ wonderful , "[136-wickham] replied [Wickham]136-wickham ; " for almost all [his]89-mr. darcy actions may be traced to pride ; and pride has often been [[his]89-mr. darcy best friend]3554-his best friend . It has connected [him]89-mr. darcy nearer with virtue than any other feeling . But [we]3555-we are none of [us]3555-we consistent ; and in [his]89-mr. darcy behaviour to [me]136-wickham there were stronger impulses even than pride . "[136-wickham]

" Can such abominable pride as [his]89-mr. darcy have ever done [him]89-mr. darcy good ? "[136-wickham]

" Yes ; it has often led [him]89-mr. darcy to be liberal and generous ; to give [his]89-mr. darcy money freely , to display hospitality , to assist [[his]89-mr. darcy tenants]3556-his tenants , and relieve the poor . [Family pride]3557-family pride , and _ filial _ pride , for [he]89-mr. darcy is very proud of what [[his]89-mr. darcy father]340-his father was , have done this . Not to appear to disgrace [[his]89-mr. darcy family]375-his family , to degenerate from the popular qualities , or lose the influence of [the Pemberley House]3560-the pemberley house , is a powerful motive . [He]89-mr. darcy has also _ brotherly _ pride , which , with _ some _ brotherly affection , makes [him]89-mr. darcy [a very kind and careful guardian of [[his]89-mr. darcy sister]559-his sister]3561-a very kind and careful guardian of his sister ; and [you]3563-you will hear [him]89-mr. darcy generally cried up as [the most attentive and best of [brothers]3565-brothers]3564-the most attentive and best of brothers . "[136-wickham]

" What sort of [a girl]3566-a girl is [Miss Darcy]124-miss darcy ? "[136-wickham]

[He]847-i shook [his]847-i head . " [I]847-i wish [I]847-i could call [her]124-miss darcy amiable . It gives [me]847-i pain to speak ill of [a Darcy]3567-a darcy ; but [she]124-miss darcy is too much like [[her]124-miss darcy brother,--very]3568-her brother,--very , very proud . As [a child]3569-a child , [she]124-miss darcy was affectionate and pleasing , and extremely fond of [me]847-i ; and [I]847-i have devoted hours and hours to [her]124-miss darcy amusement . But [she]124-miss darcy is nothing to [me]847-i now . [She]124-miss darcy is [a handsome girl]3570-a handsome girl , about fifteen or sixteen , and , [I]847-i understand , highly accomplished . Since [[her]124-miss darcy father]244-her father 's death [[her]124-miss darcy home]352-her home has been [London]5-london , where [a lady]3153-a lady lives with [her]124-miss darcy , and superintends [her]124-miss darcy education . "[847-i]

After many pauses and many trials of other subjects , [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth could not help reverting once more to the first , and saying,--

" [I]136-wickham am astonished at [his]244-her father intimacy with [Mr. Bingley]79-mr. bingley . How can [Mr. Bingley]79-mr. bingley , who seems good - humour itself , and is , [I]136-wickham really believe , truly amiable , be in friendship with [such a man]225-such a man ? How can [they]3575-they suit [each other]3144-each other ? Do [you]847-i know [Mr. Bingley]79-mr. bingley ? "[136-wickham]

" Not at all . "[848-the whist party]

" [He]79-mr. bingley is [a sweet - tempered , amiable , charming man]3577-a sweet - tempered , amiable , charming man . [He]79-mr. bingley can not know what [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy is . "[136-wickham]

" Probably not ; but [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy can please where [he]89-mr. darcy chooses . [He]89-mr. darcy does not want abilities . [He]89-mr. darcy can be [a conversible companion]3578-a conversible companion if [he]89-mr. darcy thinks it worth [his]89-mr. darcy while . [His]89-mr. darcy pride never deserts [him]89-mr. darcy ; but with [the rich]3581-the rich [he]89-mr. darcy is liberal - minded , just , sincere , rational , honourable , and , perhaps , agreeable,--allowing something for fortune and figure . "[848-the whist party]

[The whist party]848-the whist party soon afterwards breaking up , [the players]849-the players gathered round the other table , and [Mr. Collins]129-mr. collins took [his]129-mr. collins station between [[his]129-mr. collins cousin]704-his cousin [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth and [Mrs. Philips]111-mrs. philips . The usual inquiries as to [his]129-mr. collins success were made by [the latter]487-the latter . It had not been very great ; [he]129-mr. collins had lost every point ; but when [Mrs. Philips]111-mrs. philips began to express [her]111-mrs. philips concern thereupon , [he]129-mr. collins assured [her]111-mrs. philips , with much earnest gravity , that it was not of the least importance ; that [he]129-mr. collins considered the money as a mere trifle , and begged [she]111-mrs. philips would not make [herself]111-mrs. philips uneasy .

" [I]129-mr. collins know very well , [madam]3281-madam , "[129-mr. collins] said [he]129-mr. collins , " that when [persons]3583-persons sit down to a card table [they]3583-persons must take [their]3583-persons chance of these things,--and happily [I]129-mr. collins am not in such circumstances as to make five shillings any object . There are , undoubtedly , [many who could not say the same]3584-many who could not say the same ; but , thanks to [Lady Catherine de Bourgh]86-lady catherine , [I]129-mr. collins am removed far beyond the necessity of regarding little matters . "[129-mr. collins]

[Mr. Wickham]136-wickham 's attention was caught ; and after observing [Mr. Collins]129-mr. collins for a few moments , [he]129-mr. collins asked [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth in a low voice whether [[her]82-elizabeth relations]577-her relations were very intimately acquainted with [the family of [De Bourgh]132-miss de bourgh]853-the family of de bourgh .

" [Lady Catherine de Bourgh]86-lady catherine , "[82-elizabeth] [she]82-elizabeth replied , " has very lately given [him]129-mr. collins a living . [I]82-elizabeth hardly know how [Mr. Collins]129-mr. collins was first introduced to [her]86-lady catherine notice , but [he]129-mr. collins certainly has not known [her]86-lady catherine long . "[82-elizabeth]

" [You]82-elizabeth know of course that [Lady Catherine de Bourgh]86-lady catherine and [Lady Anne Darcy]139-anne were [sisters]3585-sisters ; consequently that [she]86-lady catherine is aunt to [the present Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy . "[129-mr. collins]

" No , indeed , [I]82-elizabeth did not . [I]82-elizabeth knew nothing at all of [Lady Catherine]86-lady catherine 's connections . [I]82-elizabeth never heard of [her]86-lady catherine existence till the day before yesterday . "[82-elizabeth]

" [[Her]86-lady catherine daughter]463-her daughter , [Miss de Bourgh]132-miss de bourgh , will have a very large fortune , and it is believed that [she]86-lady catherine and [[her]86-lady catherine cousin]3587-her cousin will unite [the two estates]3588-the two estates . "[91-miss bingley]

This information made [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth smile , as [she]82-elizabeth thought of [poor Miss Bingley]91-miss bingley . [Vain]140-vain indeed must be all [her]91-miss bingley attentions , vain and useless [her]91-miss bingley affection for [[his]854-his sister]559-his sister and [her]91-miss bingley praise of [himself]854-his , if [he]854-his were already self - destined to another .

" [Mr. Collins]129-mr. collins , "[82-elizabeth] said [she]82-elizabeth , " speaks highly both of [Lady Catherine]86-lady catherine and [[her]86-lady catherine daughter]463-her daughter ; but , from some particulars that [he]129-mr. collins has related of [her]86-lady catherine Ladyship , [I]82-elizabeth suspect [his]129-mr. collins gratitude misleads [him]129-mr. collins ; and that , in spite of [her]86-lady catherine being [[his]129-mr. collins patroness]694-his patroness , [she]86-lady catherine is [an arrogant , conceited woman]3591-an arrogant , conceited woman . "[82-elizabeth]

" [I]136-wickham believe [her]86-lady catherine to be both in a great degree , "[136-wickham] replied [Wickham]136-wickham ; " [I]136-wickham have not seen [her]86-lady catherine for many years ; but [I]136-wickham very well remember that [I]136-wickham never liked [her]86-lady catherine , and that [her]86-lady catherine manners were dictatorial and insolent . [She]86-lady catherine has the reputation of being remarkably sensible and clever ; but [I]136-wickham rather believe [she]86-lady catherine derives part of [her]86-lady catherine abilities from [her]86-lady catherine rank and fortune , part from [her]86-lady catherine authoritative manner , and the rest from the pride of [[her]86-lady catherine nephew]3592-her nephew , who chooses that [everyone connected with [him]3592-her nephew]3593-everyone connected with him should have an understanding of [the first class]3594-the first class . "[136-wickham]

[Elizabeth]82-elizabeth allowed that [he]136-wickham had given a very rational account of it , and [they]856-they continued talking together with mutual satisfaction till supper put an end to cards , and gave [the rest of [the ladies]249-the ladies]857-the rest of the ladies [their]857-the rest of the ladies share of [Mr. Wickham]136-wickham 's attentions . There could be no conversation in the noise of [Mrs. Philips]111-mrs. philips 's supper party , but [his]136-wickham manners recommended [him]136-wickham to [everybody]304-everybody . Whatever [he]136-wickham said , was said well ; and whatever [he]136-wickham did , done gracefully . [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth went away with [her]82-elizabeth head full of [him]136-wickham . [She]82-elizabeth could think of nothing but of [Mr. Wickham]136-wickham , and of what [he]136-wickham had told [her]82-elizabeth , all the way [home]3219-home ; but there was not time for [her]82-elizabeth even to mention [his]136-wickham name as [they]861-they went , for neither [Lydia]84-lydia nor [Mr. Collins]129-mr. collins were once silent . [Lydia]84-lydia talked incessantly of lottery tickets , of the fish [she]84-lydia had lost and the fish [she]84-lydia had won ; and [Mr. Collins]129-mr. collins , in describing the civility of [Mr.]862-mr. and [Mrs. Philips]111-mrs. philips , protesting that [he]129-mr. collins did not in the least regard [his]129-mr. collins losses at whist , enumerating all the dishes at supper , and repeatedly fearing that [he]129-mr. collins crowded [[his]129-mr. collins cousins]746-his cousins , had more to say than [he]129-mr. collins could well manage before [the carriage]3217-the carriage stopped at [Longbourn House]24-longbourn house .

[Elizabeth]82-elizabeth related to [Jane]83-jane , the next day , what had passed between [Mr. Wickham]136-wickham and [herself]82-elizabeth . [Jane]83-jane listened with astonishment and concern : [she]83-jane knew not how to believe that [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy could be so unworthy of [Mr. Bingley]79-mr. bingley 's regard ; and yet it was not in [her]83-jane nature to question the veracity of [a young man of such amiable appearance]865-a young man of such amiable appearance as [Wickham]136-wickham . The possibility of [his]89-mr. darcy having really endured such unkindness was enough to interest all [her]83-jane tender feelings ; and nothing therefore remained to be done but to think well of [them]866-them both , to defend the conduct of [each]867-each , and throw into the account of accident or mistake whatever could not be otherwise explained .

" [They]866-them have both , "[83-jane] said [she]83-jane , " been deceived , [I]83-jane dare say , in some way or other , of which [we]3595-we can form no idea . [Interested people]3596-interested people have perhaps misrepresented each to the other . It is , in short , impossible for [us]3595-we to conjecture the causes or circumstances which may have alienated [them]3596-interested people , without actual blame on either side . "[83-jane]

" Very true , indeed ; and now , [my]83-jane dear [Jane]83-jane , what have [you]83-jane got to say in behalf of [the interested people who have probably been concerned in the business]3597-the interested people who have probably been concerned in the business ? Do clear _ [them]3596-interested people _ , too , or [we]3595-we shall be obliged to think ill of [somebody]3598-somebody . "[83-jane]

" Laugh as much as [you]83-jane choose , but [you]83-jane will not laugh [me]83-jane out of [my]83-jane opinion . [[My]83-jane dearest]3228-my dearest [Lizzy]82-elizabeth , do but consider in what a disgraceful light it places [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy , to be treating [[[his]89-mr. darcy father]340-his father 's favourite in such a manner,--one whom [[his]89-mr. darcy father]340-his father had promised to provide for . It is impossible . [No man of common humanity]3603-no man of common humanity , [no man who had any value for [his]89-mr. darcy character]3604-no man who had any value for his character , could be capable of it . Can [[his]89-mr. darcy most intimate friends]3605-his most intimate friends]3601-his father 's favourite in such a manner,--one whom his father had promised to provide for . it is impossible . no man of common humanity , no man who had any value for his character , could be capable of it . can his most intimate friends be so excessively deceived in [him]89-mr. darcy ? Oh no . "[83-jane]

" [I]83-jane can much more easily believe [Mr. Bingley]79-mr. bingley 's being imposed on than that [Mr. Wickham]136-wickham should invent such a history of [himself]136-wickham as [he]136-wickham gave [me]83-jane last night ; names , facts , everything mentioned without ceremony . If it be not so , let [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy contradict it . Besides , there was truth in [his]136-wickham looks . "[83-jane]

" It is difficult , indeed -- it is distressing . [One]3041-one does not know what to think . "[83-jane]

" [I]83-jane beg [your]83-jane pardon;--one knows exactly what to think . "[83-jane]

But [Jane]83-jane could think with certainty on only one point,--that [Mr. Bingley]79-mr. bingley , if [he]79-mr. bingley _ had been _ imposed on , would have much to suffer when the affair became public .

[The two young ladies]868-the two young ladies were summoned from the shrubbery , where this conversation passed , by the arrival of [some of [the very persons of whom [they]868-the two young ladies had been speaking]870-the very persons of whom they had been speaking]869-some of the very persons of whom they had been speaking ; [Mr. Bingley]79-mr. bingley and [[his]79-mr. bingley sisters]282-his sisters came to give [their]868-the two young ladies personal invitation for the long expected ball at [Netherfield]2-netherfield , which was fixed for the following Tuesday . [The two ladies]501-the two ladies were delighted to see [[their]501-the two ladies dear friend]516-their dear friend again , called it an age since [they]501-the two ladies had met , and repeatedly asked what [she]516-their dear friend had been doing with [herself]516-their dear friend since [their]501-the two ladies separation . To [the rest of [the family]416-the family]874-the rest of the family [they]501-the two ladies paid little attention ; avoiding [Mrs. Bennet]85-mrs. bennet as much as possible , saying not much to [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth , and nothing at all to [the others]507-the others . [They]501-the two ladies were soon gone again , rising from [their]501-the two ladies seats with an activity which took [[their]501-the two ladies brother]339-their brother by surprise , and hurrying off as if eager to escape from [Mrs. Bennet]85-mrs. bennet 's civilities .

The prospect of the Netherfield ball was extremely agreeable to [every female of [the family]416-the family]878-every female of the family . [Mrs. Bennet]85-mrs. bennet chose to consider it as given in compliment to [[her]85-mrs. bennet eldest daughter]312-her eldest daughter , and was particularly flattered by receiving the invitation from [Mr. Bingley]79-mr. bingley [himself]79-mr. bingley , instead of a ceremonious card . [Jane]83-jane pictured to [herself]83-jane a happy evening in the society of [[her]83-jane two friends]609-her two friends , and the attentions of [[their]501-the two ladies brother]339-their brother ; and [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth thought with pleasure of dancing a great deal with [Mr. Wickham]136-wickham , and of seeing a confirmation of everything in [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy 's look and behaviour . The happiness anticipated by [Catherine]86-lady catherine and [Lydia]84-lydia depended less on any single event , or [any particular person]883-any particular person ; for though [they]501-the two ladies each , like [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth , meant to dance half the evening with [Mr. Wickham]136-wickham , [he]136-wickham was by no means [the only partner who could satisfy [them]501-the two ladies]884-the only partner who could satisfy them , and a ball was , at any rate , a ball . And even [Mary]87-mary could assure [[her]87-mary family]885-her family that [she]87-mary had no disinclination for it .

" While [I]87-mary can have [my]87-mary mornings to [myself]87-mary , "[87-mary] said [she]87-mary , " it is enough . [I]87-mary think it is no sacrifice to join occasionally in evening engagements . Society has claims on [us]3607-us all ; and [I]87-mary profess [myself]87-mary one of [those who consider intervals of recreation and amusement]3608-those who consider intervals of recreation and amusement as desirable for [everybody]304-everybody . "[87-mary]

[Elizabeth]82-elizabeth 's spirits were so high on the occasion , that though [she]82-elizabeth did not often speak unnecessarily to [Mr. Collins]129-mr. collins , [she]82-elizabeth could not help asking [him]129-mr. collins whether [he]129-mr. collins intended to accept [Mr. Bingley]79-mr. bingley 's invitation , and if [he]129-mr. collins did , whether [he]129-mr. collins would think it proper to join in the evening 's amusement ; and [she]82-elizabeth was rather surprised to find that [he]129-mr. collins entertained no scruple whatever on that head , and was very far from dreading a rebuke , either from [the Archbishop]886-the archbishop or [Lady Catherine de Bourgh]86-lady catherine , by venturing to dance .

" [I]129-mr. collins am by no means of opinion , [I]129-mr. collins assure [you]82-elizabeth , "[129-mr. collins] said [he]129-mr. collins , " that a ball of this kind , given by [a young man of character]3610-a young man of character , to [respectable people]3611-respectable people , can have any evil tendency ; and [I]129-mr. collins am so far from objecting to dancing [myself]129-mr. collins , that [I]129-mr. collins shall hope to be honoured with the hands of all [[my]129-mr. collins fair cousins]3455-my fair cousins in the course of the evening ; and [I]129-mr. collins take this opportunity of soliciting [yours]82-elizabeth , [Miss Elizabeth]82-elizabeth , for the two first dances especially ; a preference which [I]129-mr. collins trust [[my]129-mr. collins cousin]3414-my cousin [Jane]83-jane will attribute to the right cause , and not to any disrespect for [her]83-jane . "[129-mr. collins]

[Elizabeth]82-elizabeth felt [herself]82-elizabeth completely taken in . [She]82-elizabeth had fully proposed being engaged by [Wickham]136-wickham for those very dances ; and to have [Mr. Collins]129-mr. collins instead!--her liveliness had been never worse timed . There was no help for it , however . [Mr. Wickham]136-wickham 's happiness and [her]82-elizabeth own was perforce delayed a little longer , and [Mr. Collins]129-mr. collins 's proposal accepted with as good a grace as [she]82-elizabeth could . [She]82-elizabeth was not the better pleased with [his]129-mr. collins gallantry , from the idea it suggested of something more . It now first struck [her]82-elizabeth , that _ [she]82-elizabeth _ was selected from among [[her]82-elizabeth sisters]3023-her sisters as worthy of being [the mistress of [Hunsford Parsonage]889-hunsford parsonage]888-the mistress of hunsford parsonage , and of assisting to form a quadrille table at [Rosings]20-rosings , in the absence of [more eligible visitors]890-more eligible visitors . The idea soon reached to conviction , as [she]82-elizabeth observed [his]129-mr. collins increasing civilities towards [herself]82-elizabeth , and heard [his]129-mr. collins frequent attempt at a compliment on [her]82-elizabeth wit and vivacity ; and though more astonished than gratified [herself]82-elizabeth by this effect of [her]82-elizabeth charms , it was not long before [[her]82-elizabeth mother]241-her mother gave [her]82-elizabeth to understand that the probability of [their]892-their marriage was exceedingly agreeable to _ [her]241-her mother _ . [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth , however , did not choose to take the hint , being well aware that a serious dispute must be the consequence of any reply . [Mr. Collins]129-mr. collins might never make the offer , and , till [he]129-mr. collins did , it was useless to quarrel about [him]129-mr. collins .

If there had not been a [Netherfield]2-netherfield ball to prepare for and talk of , [the younger Miss Bennets]99-the bennets would have been in a pitiable state at this time ; for , from the day of the invitation to the day of the ball , there was such a succession of rain as prevented [their]892-their walking to [Meryton]9-meryton once . [No aunt]893-no aunt , [no officers]894-no officers , no news could be sought after ; the very shoe - roses for [Netherfield]2-netherfield were got by proxy . Even [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth might have found some trial of [her]82-elizabeth patience in weather which totally suspended the improvement of [her]82-elizabeth acquaintance with [Mr. Wickham]136-wickham ; and nothing less than a dance on Tuesday could have made such a Friday , Saturday , Sunday , and Monday endurable to [Kitty]86-lady catherine and [Lydia]84-lydia .

Till [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth entered [the drawing - room]520-the drawing - room at [Netherfield]2-netherfield , and looked in vain for [Mr. Wickham]136-wickham among the cluster of red coats there assembled , a doubt of [his]136-wickham being present had never occurred to [her]82-elizabeth . The certainty of meeting [him]136-wickham had not been checked by any of those recollections that might not unreasonably have alarmed [her]82-elizabeth . [She]82-elizabeth had dressed with more than usual care , and prepared in the highest spirits for the conquest of all that remained unsubdued of [his]136-wickham heart , trusting that it was not more than might be won in the course of the evening . But in an instant arose the dreadful suspicion of [his]136-wickham being purposely omitted , for [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy 's pleasure , in [the Bingleys]141-the bingleys ' invitation to [the officers]454-the officers ; and though this was not exactly the case , the absolute fact of [his]136-wickham absence was pronounced by [[his]136-wickham friend]286-his friend [Mr. Denny]135-denny , to whom [Lydia]84-lydia eagerly applied , and who told [them]454-the officers that [Wickham]136-wickham had been obliged to go to [town]264-town on business the day before , and was not yet returned ; adding , with a significant smile,--

" [I]136-wickham do not imagine [his]136-wickham business would have called [him]136-wickham away just now , if [he]136-wickham had not wished to avoid [a certain gentleman]3614-a certain gentleman [here]2994-here . "[136-wickham]

This part of [his]136-wickham intelligence , though unheard by [Lydia]84-lydia , was caught by [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth ; and , as it assured [her]82-elizabeth that [Darcy]89-mr. darcy was not less answerable for [Wickham]136-wickham 's absence than if [her]82-elizabeth first surmise had been just , every feeling of displeasure against [the former]327-the former was so sharpened by immediate disappointment , that [she]82-elizabeth could hardly reply with tolerable civility to the polite inquiries which [he]136-wickham directly afterwards approached to make . Attention , forbearance , patience with [Darcy]89-mr. darcy , was injury to [Wickham]136-wickham . [She]82-elizabeth was resolved against any sort of conversation with [him]136-wickham , and turned away with a degree of ill - humour which [she]82-elizabeth could not wholly surmount even in speaking to [Mr. Bingley]79-mr. bingley , whose blind partiality provoked [her]82-elizabeth .

But [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth was not formed for ill - humour ; and though every prospect of [her]82-elizabeth own was destroyed for the evening , it could not dwell long on [her]82-elizabeth spirits ; and , having told all [her]82-elizabeth griefs to [Charlotte Lucas]101-charlotte , whom [she]82-elizabeth had not seen for a week , [she]82-elizabeth was soon able to make a voluntary transition to the oddities of [[her]82-elizabeth cousin]3587-her cousin , and to point [him]3587-her cousin out to [her]82-elizabeth particular notice . The two first dances , however , brought a return of distress : they were dances of mortification . [Mr. Collins]129-mr. collins , awkward and solemn , apologizing instead of attending , and often moving wrong without being aware of it , gave [her]82-elizabeth all the shame and misery which [a disagreeable partner]901-a disagreeable partner for a couple of dances can give . The moment of [her]82-elizabeth release from [him]136-wickham was ecstasy .

[She]82-elizabeth danced next with [an officer]902-an officer , and had the refreshment of talking of [Wickham]136-wickham , and of hearing that [he]136-wickham was universally liked . When those dances were over , [she]82-elizabeth returned to [Charlotte Lucas]101-charlotte , and was in conversation with [her]101-charlotte , when [she]82-elizabeth found [herself]82-elizabeth suddenly addressed by [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy , who took [her]82-elizabeth so much by surprise in [his]89-mr. darcy application for [her]82-elizabeth hand , that , without knowing what [she]82-elizabeth did , [she]82-elizabeth accepted [him]89-mr. darcy . [He]89-mr. darcy walked away again immediately , and [she]82-elizabeth was left to fret over [her]82-elizabeth own want of presence of mind : [Charlotte]101-charlotte tried to console [her]82-elizabeth .

" [I]101-charlotte dare say [you]89-mr. darcy will find [him]89-mr. darcy very agreeable . "[101-charlotte]

" Heaven forbid ! _ That _ would be the greatest misfortune of all ! To find [a man agreeable whom [one]3041-one is determined to hate]3616-a man agreeable whom one is determined to hate ! Do not wish [me]101-charlotte such an evil . "[101-charlotte]

When the dancing recommenced , however , and [Darcy]89-mr. darcy approached to claim [her]82-elizabeth hand , [Charlotte]101-charlotte could not help cautioning [her]82-elizabeth , in a whisper , not to be [a simpleton]3140-a simpleton , and allow [her]82-elizabeth fancy for [Wickham]136-wickham to make [her]82-elizabeth appear unpleasant in the eyes of [a man often times [his]89-mr. darcy consequence]904-a man often times his consequence . [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth made no answer , and took [her]82-elizabeth place in the set , amazed at the dignity to which [she]82-elizabeth was arrived in being allowed to stand opposite to [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy , and reading in [[her]82-elizabeth neighbours]821-her neighbours ' looks [their]821-her neighbours equal amazement in beholding it . [They]906-we stood for some time without speaking a word ; and [she]82-elizabeth began to imagine that [their]906-we silence was to last through the two dances , and , at first , was resolved not to break it ; till suddenly fancying that it would be the greater punishment to [[her]82-elizabeth partner]907-her partner to oblige [him]89-mr. darcy to talk , [she]82-elizabeth made some slight observation on the dance . [He]89-mr. darcy replied , and was again silent . After a pause of some minutes , [she]82-elizabeth addressed [him]89-mr. darcy a second time , with--

" It is _ [your]89-mr. darcy _ turn to say something now , [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy . _ [I]82-elizabeth _ talked about the dance , and _ [you]89-mr. darcy _ ought to make some kind of remark on the size of [the room]250-the room , or the number of [couples]3619-couples . "[82-elizabeth]

[He]89-mr. darcy smiled , and assured [her]82-elizabeth that whatever [she]82-elizabeth wished [him]89-mr. darcy to say should be said .

" Very well ; that reply will do for the present . Perhaps , by - and - by , [I]82-elizabeth may observe that private balls are much pleasanter than public ones ; but _ now _ [we]906-we may be silent . "[82-elizabeth]

" Do [you]89-mr. darcy talk by rule , then , while [you]89-mr. darcy are dancing ? "[82-elizabeth]

" Sometimes . [One]3041-one must speak a little , [you]89-mr. darcy know . It would look odd to be entirely silent for half an hour together ; and yet , for the advantage of _ some _ , conversation ought to be so arranged as that [they]3619-couples may have the trouble of saying as little as possible . "[82-elizabeth]

" Are [you]89-mr. darcy consulting [your]89-mr. darcy own feelings in the present case , or do [you]89-mr. darcy imagine that [you]89-mr. darcy are gratifying [mine]82-elizabeth ? "[82-elizabeth]

" Both , "[82-elizabeth] replied [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth archly ; " for [I]82-elizabeth have always seen a great similarity in the turn of [our]906-we minds . [We]906-we are [each of an unsocial , taciturn disposition]3621-each of an unsocial , taciturn disposition , unwilling to speak , unless [we]906-we expect to say something that will amaze [the whole room]3622-the whole room , and be handed down to posterity with all the _ eclat _ of a proverb . "[82-elizabeth]

" This is no very striking resemblance of [your]82-elizabeth own character , [I]908-he am sure , "[908-he] said [he]908-he . " How near it may be to _ mine _ , [I]908-he can not pretend to say . _ [You]82-elizabeth _ think it a faithful portrait , undoubtedly . "[908-he]

" [I]908-he must not decide on [my]908-he own performance . "[908-he]

[He]908-he made no answer ; and [they]909-they were again silent till [they]909-they had gone down the dance , when [he]908-he asked [her]82-elizabeth if [she]82-elizabeth and [[her]82-elizabeth sisters]3023-her sisters did not very often walk to [Meryton]9-meryton . [She]82-elizabeth answered in the affirmative ; and , unable to resist the temptation , added , " When [you]908-he met [us]909-they [there]305-there the other day , [we]909-they had just been forming a new acquaintance . "[82-elizabeth]

The effect was immediate . A deeper shade of _ hauteur _ overspread [his]908-he features , but [he]908-he said not a word ; and [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth , though blaming [herself]82-elizabeth for [her]82-elizabeth own weakness , could not go on . At length [Darcy]89-mr. darcy spoke , and in a constrained manner said,--

" [Mr. Wickham]136-wickham is blessed with such happy manners as may insure [[his]136-wickham _ making _ friends]3624-his _ making _ friends ; whether [he]136-wickham may be equally capable of _ retaining _ [them]3624-his _ making _ friends , is less certain . "[89-mr. darcy]

" [He]136-wickham has been so unlucky as to lose [your]89-mr. darcy friendship , "[82-elizabeth] replied [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth , with emphasis , " and in a manner which [he]136-wickham is likely to suffer from all [his]136-wickham life . "[82-elizabeth]

[Darcy]89-mr. darcy made no answer , and seemed desirous of changing the subject . At that moment [Sir William Lucas]80-sir william appeared close to [them]911-them , meaning to pass through the set to the other side of [the room]250-the room ; but , on perceiving [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy , [he]80-sir william stopped , with a bow of superior courtesy , to compliment [him]80-sir william on [his]80-sir william dancing and [[his]80-sir william partner]913-his partner .

" [I]80-sir william have been most highly gratified , indeed , [[my]80-sir william dear sir]3625-my dear sir ; such very superior dancing is not often seen . It is evident that [you]89-mr. darcy belong to the first circles . Allow [me]80-sir william to say , however , that [[your]89-mr. darcy fair partner]3626-your fair partner does not disgrace [you]89-mr. darcy : and that [I]80-sir william must hope to have this pleasure often repeated , especially when a certain desirable event , [[my]80-sir william dear]2993-my dear [Miss Eliza]82-elizabeth ( glancing at [[her]82-elizabeth sister]328-her sister and [Bingley]79-mr. bingley ) , shall take place . What congratulations will then flow in ! [I]80-sir william appeal to [Mr. Darcy;--but]142-mr. darcy;--but let [me]80-sir william not interrupt [you]89-mr. darcy , [sir]3161-sir . [You]89-mr. darcy will not thank [me]80-sir william for detaining [you]89-mr. darcy from the bewitching converse of [that young lady]3630-that young lady , whose bright eyes are also upbraiding [me]80-sir william . "[80-sir william]

The latter part of this address was scarcely heard by [Darcy]89-mr. darcy ; but [Sir William]80-sir william 's allusion to [[his]80-sir william friend]286-his friend seemed to strike [him]89-mr. darcy forcibly , and [his]80-sir william eyes were directed , with a very serious expression , towards [Bingley]79-mr. bingley and [Jane]83-jane , who were dancing together . Recovering [himself]80-sir william , however , shortly , [he]80-sir william turned to [[his]80-sir william partner]913-his partner , and said,--

" [Sir William]80-sir william 's interruption has made [me]80-sir william forget what [we]3631-we were talking of . "[80-sir william]

" [I]80-sir william do not think [we]3631-we were speaking at all . [Sir William]80-sir william could not have interrupted [any two people in [the room]250-the room who had less to say for [themselves]3632-any two people in the room who had less to say for themselves]3632-any two people in the room who had less to say for themselves . [We]3631-we have tried two or three subjects already without success , and what [we]3631-we are to talk of next [I]80-sir william can not imagine . "[80-sir william]

" What think [you]913-his partner of books ? "[80-sir william] said [he]80-sir william , smiling .

" Books -- oh no!--I am sure [we]3631-we never read the same , or not with the same feelings . "[80-sir william]

" [I]80-sir william am sorry [you]80-sir william think so ; but if that be the case , there can at least be no want of subject . [We]3631-we may compare [our]3631-we different opinions . "[80-sir william]

" No -- [I]80-sir william can not talk of books in [a ball - room]3634-a ball - room ; [my]80-sir william head is always full of something else . "[80-sir william]

" The _ present _ always occupies [you]916-i in such scenes -- does it ? "[80-sir william] said [he]80-sir william , with a look of doubt .

" Yes , always , "[916-i] [she]916-i replied , without knowing what [she]916-i said ; for [her]916-i thoughts had wandered far from the subject , as soon afterwards appeared by [her]916-i suddenly exclaiming , " [I]916-i remember hearing [you]80-sir william once say , [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy , that [you]80-sir william hardly ever forgave;--that [your]80-sir william resentment , once created , was unappeasable . [You]80-sir william are very cautious , [I]916-i suppose , as to its _ being created _ ? "[916-i]

" [I]80-sir william am , "[80-sir william] said [he]80-sir william , with a firm voice .

" And never allow [yourself]80-sir william to be blinded by prejudice ? "[916-i]

" [I]916-i hope not . "[916-i]

" It is particularly incumbent on those who never change [their]3635-their opinion , to be secure of judging properly at first . "[916-i]

" May [I]916-i ask to what these questions tend ? "[916-i]

" Merely to the illustration of _ [your]80-sir william _ character , "[916-i] said [she]916-i , endeavouring to shake off [her]916-i gravity . " [I]916-i am trying to make it out . "[916-i]

" And what is [your]80-sir william success ? "[916-i]

[She]916-i shook [her]916-i head . " [I]916-i do not get on at all . [I]916-i hear such different accounts of [you]80-sir william as puzzle [me]916-i exceedingly . "[916-i]

" [I]80-sir william can readily believe , "[80-sir william] answered [he]80-sir william , gravely , " that reports may vary greatly with respect to [me]80-sir william ; and [I]80-sir william could wish , [Miss Bennet]82-elizabeth , that [you]916-i were not to sketch [my]80-sir william character at the present moment , as there is reason to fear that the performance would reflect no credit on either . "[80-sir william]

" But if [I]916-i do not take [your]916-i likeness now , [I]916-i may never have another opportunity . "[916-i]

" [I]80-sir william would by no means suspend any pleasure of [yours]916-i , "[80-sir william] [he]80-sir william coldly replied . [She]916-i said no more , and [they]917-they went down the other dance and parted in silence ; on each side dissatisfied , though not to an equal degree ; for in [Darcy]89-mr. darcy 's breast there was a tolerably powerful feeling towards [her]916-i , which soon procured [her]916-i pardon , and directed all [his]80-sir william anger against another .

[They]917-they had not long separated when [Miss Bingley]91-miss bingley came towards [her]916-i , and , with an expression of civil disdain , thus accosted [her,--]916-i

" So , [Miss Eliza]82-elizabeth , [I]91-miss bingley hear [you]916-i are quite delighted with [George Wickham]143-george wickham ? [[Your]916-i sister]3139-your sister has been talking to [me]91-miss bingley about [him]80-sir william , and asking [me]91-miss bingley a thousand questions ; and [I]91-miss bingley find that [the young man]764-the young man forgot to tell [you]916-i , among [his]80-sir william other communications , that [he]764-the young man was [the son of [old Wickham]143-george wickham]3638-the son of old wickham , [the late Mr. [Darcy]89-mr. darcy 's steward]3639-the late mr. darcy 's steward . Let [me]91-miss bingley recommend [you]916-i , however , as [a friend]3352-a friend , not to give implicit confidence to all [his]80-sir william assertions ; for , as to [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy 's using [him]89-mr. darcy ill , it is perfectly false : for , on the contrary , [he]89-mr. darcy has been always remarkably kind to [him]89-mr. darcy , though [George Wickham]143-george wickham has treated [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy in a most infamous manner .
