[I]91-miss bingley do not know the particulars , but [I]91-miss bingley know very well that [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy is not in the least to blame ; that [he]89-mr. darcy can not bear to hear [George Wickham]143-george wickham mentioned ; and that though [[my]91-miss bingley brother]3212-my brother thought [he]3212-my brother could not well avoid including [him]89-mr. darcy in [his]3212-my brother invitation to [the officers]454-the officers , [he]3212-my brother was excessively glad to find that [he]89-mr. darcy had taken [himself]89-mr. darcy out of the way . [His]89-mr. darcy coming into [the country]448-the country at all is a most insolent thing , indeed , and [I]91-miss bingley wonder how [he]89-mr. darcy could presume to do it . [I]91-miss bingley pity [you]82-elizabeth , [Miss Eliza]82-elizabeth , for this discovery of [[your]82-elizabeth favourite]3644-your favourite 's guilt ; but really , considering [his]89-mr. darcy descent , one could not expect much better . "[91-miss bingley]

" [His]89-mr. darcy guilt and [his]89-mr. darcy descent appear , by [your]82-elizabeth account , to be the same , "[82-elizabeth] said [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth , angrily ; " for [I]82-elizabeth have heard [you]82-elizabeth accuse [him]89-mr. darcy of nothing worse than of being [the son of [[Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy 's steward]3646-mr. darcy 's steward]3645-the son of mr. darcy 's steward , and of _ that _ , [I]82-elizabeth can assure [you]82-elizabeth , [he]89-mr. darcy informed [me]82-elizabeth [himself]89-mr. darcy . "[82-elizabeth]

" [I]91-miss bingley beg [your]82-elizabeth pardon , "[91-miss bingley] replied [Miss Bingley]91-miss bingley , turning away with a sneer . " Excuse [my]91-miss bingley interference ; it was kindly meant . "[91-miss bingley]

" [Insolent girl]3647-insolent girl ! "[82-elizabeth] said [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth to [herself]82-elizabeth . " [You]82-elizabeth are much mistaken if [you]82-elizabeth expect to influence [me]82-elizabeth by such a paltry attack as this . [I]82-elizabeth see nothing in it but [your]82-elizabeth own wilful ignorance and the malice of [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy . "[82-elizabeth] [She]82-elizabeth then sought [[her]82-elizabeth eldest sister]918-her eldest sister , who had undertaken to make inquiries on the same subject of [Bingley]91-miss bingley . [Jane]83-jane met [her]82-elizabeth with a smile of such sweet complacency , a glow of such happy expression , as sufficiently marked how well [she]83-jane was satisfied with the occurrences of the evening . [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth instantly read [her]82-elizabeth feelings ; and , at that moment , solicitude for [Wickham]143-george wickham , resentment against [[his]143-george wickham enemies]919-his enemies , and everything else , gave way before the hope of [Jane]83-jane 's being in the fairest way for happiness .

" [I]83-jane want to know , "[83-jane] said [she]83-jane , with a countenance no less smiling than [[her]82-elizabeth sister]328-her sister 's , " what [you]82-elizabeth have learnt about [Mr. Wickham]136-wickham . But perhaps [you]82-elizabeth have been too pleasantly engaged to think of [any third person]3648-any third person , in which case [you]82-elizabeth may be sure of [my]83-jane pardon . "[83-jane]

" No , "[83-jane] replied [Jane]83-jane , " [I]83-jane have not forgotten [him]136-wickham ; but [I]83-jane have nothing satisfactory to tell [you]82-elizabeth . [Mr. Bingley]79-mr. bingley does not know the whole of [his]79-mr. bingley history , and is quite ignorant of the circumstances which have principally offended [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy ; but [he]79-mr. bingley will vouch for the good conduct , the probity and honour , of [[his]79-mr. bingley friend]286-his friend , and is perfectly convinced that [Mr. Wickham]136-wickham has deserved much less attention from [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy than [he]79-mr. bingley has received ; and [I]83-jane am sorry to say that by [his]79-mr. bingley account , as well as [[his]79-mr. bingley sister]559-his sister 's , [Mr. Wickham]136-wickham is by no means [a respectable young man]3651-a respectable young man . [I]83-jane am afraid [he]136-wickham has been very imprudent , and has deserved to lose [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy 's regard . "[83-jane]

" [Mr. Bingley]79-mr. bingley does not know [Mr. Wickham]136-wickham [himself]79-mr. bingley . "[83-jane]

" No ; [he]79-mr. bingley never saw [him]136-wickham till the other morning at [Meryton]9-meryton . "[83-jane]

" This account then is what [he]79-mr. bingley has received from [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy . [I]83-jane am perfectly satisfied . But what does [he]79-mr. bingley say of [the living]3652-the living ? "[83-jane]

" [He]79-mr. bingley does not exactly recollect the circumstances , though [he]79-mr. bingley has heard them from [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy more than once , but [he]79-mr. bingley believes that it was left to [him]79-mr. bingley _ conditionally _ only . "[83-jane]

" [I]82-elizabeth have not a doubt of [Mr. Bingley]79-mr. bingley 's sincerity , "[82-elizabeth] said [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth warmly , " but [you]79-mr. bingley must excuse [my]82-elizabeth not being convinced by assurances only . [Mr. Bingley]79-mr. bingley 's defence of [[his]79-mr. bingley friend]286-his friend was a very able one , [I]82-elizabeth dare say ; but since [he]79-mr. bingley is unacquainted with several parts of the story , and has learnt the rest from [that friend]3654-that friend [himself]79-mr. bingley , [I]82-elizabeth shall venture still to think of [both gentlemen]3655-both gentlemen as [I]82-elizabeth did before . "[82-elizabeth]

[She]82-elizabeth then changed the discourse to one more gratifying to each , and on which there could be no difference of sentiment . [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth listened with delight to the happy though modest hopes which [Jane]83-jane entertained of [Bingley]79-mr. bingley 's regard , and said all in [her]82-elizabeth power to heighten [her]82-elizabeth confidence in it . On [their]921-their being joined by [Mr. Bingley]79-mr. bingley [himself]79-mr. bingley , [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth withdrew to [Miss Lucas]92-miss lucas ; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of [[her]82-elizabeth last partner]922-her last partner [she]82-elizabeth had scarcely replied , before [Mr. Collins]129-mr. collins came up to [them]921-their , and told [her]82-elizabeth with great exultation , that [he]129-mr. collins had just been so fortunate as to make a most important discovery .

" [I]129-mr. collins have found out , "[129-mr. collins] said [he]129-mr. collins , " by a singular accident , that there is now in [the room]250-the room a near relation to [[my]129-mr. collins patroness]3657-my patroness . [I]129-mr. collins happened to overhear [the gentleman]285-the gentleman [himself]285-the gentleman mentioning to [the young lady who does the honours of [this house]3416-this house]3659-the young lady who does the honours of this house the names of [[his]285-the gentleman cousin]704-his cousin [Miss De Bourgh]132-miss de bourgh , and of [[her]3659-the young lady who does the honours of this house mother]241-her mother , [Lady Catherine]86-lady catherine . How wonderfully these sort of things occur ! Who would have thought of [my]129-mr. collins meeting with -- perhaps -- [a nephew of [Lady Catherine de Bourgh]86-lady catherine in this assembly]3663-a nephew of lady catherine de bourgh in this assembly ! [I]129-mr. collins am most thankful that the discovery is made in time for [me]129-mr. collins to pay [my]129-mr. collins respects to [him]285-the gentleman , which [I]129-mr. collins am now going to do , and trust [he]285-the gentleman will excuse [my]129-mr. collins not having done it before . [My]129-mr. collins total ignorance of the connection must plead [my]129-mr. collins apology . "[129-mr. collins]

" [You]129-mr. collins are not going to introduce [yourself]129-mr. collins to [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy ? "[923-him]

" Indeed [I]129-mr. collins am . [I]129-mr. collins shall entreat [his]285-the gentleman pardon for not having done it earlier . [I]129-mr. collins believe [him]285-the gentleman to be [[Lady Catherine]86-lady catherine 's _ nephew]3664-lady catherine 's _ nephew _ . It will be in [my]129-mr. collins power to assure [him]285-the gentleman that [[her]86-lady catherine Ladyship]3464-her ladyship was quite well yesterday se'nnight . "[129-mr. collins]

[Elizabeth]82-elizabeth tried hard to dissuade [him]923-him from such a scheme ; assuring [him]923-him that [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy would consider [his]923-him addressing [him]923-him without introduction as an impertinent freedom , rather than a compliment to [[his]923-him aunt]924-his aunt ; that it was not in the least necessary there should be any notice on either side , and that if it were , it must belong to [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy , [the superior in consequence]925-the superior in consequence , to begin the acquaintance . [Mr. Collins]129-mr. collins listened to [her]82-elizabeth with the determined air of following [his]129-mr. collins own inclination , and when [she]82-elizabeth ceased speaking , replied thus,--

" [[My]926-me dear]2993-my dear [Miss Elizabeth]82-elizabeth , [I]926-me have the highest opinion in [the world]303-the world of [your]82-elizabeth excellent judgment in all matters within the scope of [your]82-elizabeth understanding , but permit [me]926-me to say that there must be a wide difference between the established forms of ceremony amongst [the laity]3668-the laity and those which regulate [the clergy]3669-the clergy ; for , give [me]926-me leave to observe that [I]926-me consider the clerical office as equal in point of dignity with the highest rank in [the kingdom]3670-the kingdom -- provided that a proper humility of behaviour is at the same time maintained . [You]82-elizabeth must , therefore , allow [me]926-me to follow the dictates of [my]926-me conscience on this occasion , which lead [me]926-me to perform what [I]926-me look on as a point of duty . Pardon [me]926-me for neglecting to profit by [your]82-elizabeth advice , which on every other subject shall be [my]926-me constant guide , though in the case before [us]3671-us [I]926-me consider [myself]926-me more fitted by education and habitual study to decide on what is right than [a young lady like [yourself]82-elizabeth]3672-a young lady like yourself ; "[926-me] and with a low bow [he]926-me left [her]927-her to attack [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy , whose reception of [his]926-me advances [she]927-her eagerly watched , and whose astonishment at being so addressed was very evident . [[Her]927-her cousin]3587-her cousin prefaced [his]926-me speech with a solemn bow , and though [she]927-her could not hear a word of it , [she]927-her felt as if hearing it all , and saw in the motion of [his]926-me lips the words " apology , "[926-me] " [Hunsford]15-hunsford , "[926-me] and " [Lady Catherine de Bourgh]86-lady catherine . "[926-me] It vexed [her]927-her to see [him]926-me expose [himself]926-me to [such a man]225-such a man . [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy was eyeing [him]926-me with unrestrained wonder ; and when at last [Mr. Collins]129-mr. collins allowed [him]926-me to speak , replied with an air of distant civility . [Mr. Collins]129-mr. collins , however , was not discouraged from speaking again , and [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy 's contempt seemed abundantly increasing with the length of [his]89-mr. darcy second speech ; and at the end of it [he]89-mr. darcy only made [him]89-mr. darcy a slight bow , and moved another way : [Mr. Collins]129-mr. collins then returned to [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth .

" [I]129-mr. collins have no reason , [I]129-mr. collins assure [you]82-elizabeth , "[129-mr. collins] said [he]129-mr. collins , " to be dissatisfied with [my]129-mr. collins reception . [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy seemed much pleased with the attention . [He]89-mr. darcy answered [me]129-mr. collins with the utmost civility , and even paid [me]129-mr. collins the compliment of saying , that [he]89-mr. darcy was so well convinced of [Lady Catherine]86-lady catherine 's discernment as to be certain [she]86-lady catherine could never bestow a favour unworthily . It was really a very handsome thought . Upon the whole , [I]129-mr. collins am much pleased with [him]89-mr. darcy . "[129-mr. collins]

As [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth had no longer any interest of [her]82-elizabeth own to pursue , [she]82-elizabeth turned [her]82-elizabeth attention almost entirely on [[her]82-elizabeth sister]328-her sister and [Mr. Bingley]79-mr. bingley ; and the train of agreeable reflections which [her]82-elizabeth observations gave birth to made [her]82-elizabeth perhaps almost as happy as [Jane]83-jane . [She]82-elizabeth saw [her]83-jane in idea settled in [that very house]931-that very house , in all the felicity which a marriage of true affection could bestow ; and [she]82-elizabeth felt capable , under such circumstances , of endeavouring even to like [[Bingley]79-mr. bingley 's two sisters]932-bingley 's two sisters . [[Her]82-elizabeth mother]241-her mother 's thoughts [she]82-elizabeth plainly saw were bent the same way , and [she]82-elizabeth determined not to venture near [her]241-her mother , lest [she]82-elizabeth might hear too much . When [they]934-them sat down to supper , therefore , [she]82-elizabeth considered it a most unlucky perverseness which placed [them]934-them within one of [each other]3144-each other ; and deeply was [she]82-elizabeth vexed to find that [[her]82-elizabeth mother]241-her mother was talking to [that one person]937-that one person ( [Lady Lucas]81-lady lucas ) freely , openly , and of nothing else but of [her]241-her mother expectation that [Jane]83-jane would be soon married to [Mr. Bingley]79-mr. bingley . It was an animating subject , and [Mrs. Bennet]85-mrs. bennet seemed incapable of fatigue while enumerating the advantages of the match . [His]79-mr. bingley being such [a charming young man]938-a charming young man , and so rich , and living but three miles from [them]934-them , were the first points of self - gratulation ; and then it was such a comfort to think how fond [the two sisters]939-the two sisters were of [Jane]83-jane , and to be certain that [they]939-the two sisters must desire the connection as much as [she]83-jane could do . It was , moreover , such a promising thing for [[her]241-her mother younger daughters]940-her younger daughters , as [Jane]83-jane 's marrying so greatly must throw [them]940-her younger daughters in the way of [other rich men]941-other rich men ; and , lastly , it was so pleasant at [her]241-her mother time of life to be able to consign [[her]241-her mother single daughters]942-her single daughters to the care of [[their]942-her single daughters sister]943-their sister , that [she]241-her mother might not be obliged to go into company more than [she]241-her mother liked . It was necessary to make this circumstance a matter of pleasure , because on such occasions it is the etiquette ; but [no one]3271-no one was less likely than [Mrs. Bennet]85-mrs. bennet to find comfort in staying at [home]3219-home at any period of [her]241-her mother life . [She]241-her mother concluded with many good wishes that [Lady Lucas]81-lady lucas might soon be equally fortunate , though evidently and triumphantly believing there was no chance of it .

In vain did [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth endeavour to check the rapidity of [[her]82-elizabeth mother]241-her mother 's words , or persuade [her]241-her mother to describe [her]241-her mother felicity in a less audible whisper ; for to [her]82-elizabeth inexpressible vexation [she]82-elizabeth could perceive that [the chief of it]947-the chief of it was overheard by [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy , who sat opposite to [them]948-them . [[Her]82-elizabeth mother]241-her mother only scolded [her]82-elizabeth for being nonsensical .

" What is [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy to [me]241-her mother , pray , that [I]241-her mother should be afraid of [him]89-mr. darcy ? [I]241-her mother am sure [we]948-them owe [him]89-mr. darcy no such particular civility as to be obliged to say nothing _ [he]89-mr. darcy _ may not like to hear . "[241-her mother]

" For heaven 's sake , [madam]3281-madam , speak lower . What advantage can it be to [you]82-elizabeth to offend [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy ? [You]82-elizabeth will never recommend [yourself]82-elizabeth to [[his]89-mr. darcy friend]286-his friend by so doing . "[89-mr. darcy]

Nothing that [she]82-elizabeth could say , however , had any influence . [[Her]82-elizabeth mother]241-her mother would talk of [her]241-her mother views in the same intelligible tone . [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth blushed and blushed again with shame and vexation . [She]82-elizabeth could not help frequently glancing [her]82-elizabeth eye at [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy , though every glance convinced [her]82-elizabeth of what [she]82-elizabeth dreaded ; for though [he]89-mr. darcy was not always looking at [[her]82-elizabeth mother]241-her mother , [she]82-elizabeth was convinced that [his]89-mr. darcy attention was invariably fixed by [her]241-her mother . The expression of [his]89-mr. darcy face changed gradually from indignant contempt to a composed and steady gravity .

At length , however , [Mrs. Bennet]85-mrs. bennet had no more to say ; and [Lady Lucas]81-lady lucas , who had been long yawning at the repetition of delights which [she]81-lady lucas saw no likelihood of sharing , was left to the comforts of cold ham and chicken . [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth now began to revive . But not long was the interval of tranquillity ; for when supper was over , singing was talked of , and [she]82-elizabeth had the mortification of seeing [Mary]87-mary , after very little entreaty , preparing to oblige [the company]952-the company . By many significant looks and silent entreaties did [she]82-elizabeth endeavour to prevent such a proof of complaisance,--but in vain ; [Mary]87-mary would not understand them ; such an opportunity of exhibiting was delightful to [her]82-elizabeth , and [she]82-elizabeth began [her]82-elizabeth song . [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth 's eyes were fixed on [her]82-elizabeth , with most painful sensations ; and [she]82-elizabeth watched [her]82-elizabeth progress through the several stanzas with an impatience which was very ill rewarded at their close ; for [Mary]87-mary , on receiving amongst the thanks of the table the hint of a hope that [she]87-mary might be prevailed on to favour [them]953-them again , after the pause of half a minute began another . [Mary]87-mary 's powers were by no means fitted for such a display ; [her]87-mary voice was weak , and [her]87-mary manner affected . [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth was in agonies . [She]82-elizabeth looked at [Jane]83-jane to see how [she]82-elizabeth bore it ; but [Jane]83-jane was very composedly talking to [Bingley]79-mr. bingley . [She]82-elizabeth looked at [[his]79-mr. bingley two sisters]278-his two sisters , and saw [them]278-his two sisters making signs of derision at [each other]3144-each other , and at [Darcy]89-mr. darcy , who continued , however , impenetrably grave . [She]82-elizabeth looked at [[her]82-elizabeth father]244-her father to entreat [his]244-her father interference , lest [Mary]87-mary should be singing all night . [He]244-her father took the hint , and , when [Mary]87-mary had finished [her]87-mary second song , said aloud,--

" That will do extremely well , [child]3675-child . [You]3675-child have delighted [us]3676-us long enough . Let [the other young ladies]3677-the other young ladies have time to exhibit . "[244-her father]

[Mary]87-mary , though pretending not to hear , was somewhat disconcerted ; and [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth , sorry for [her]87-mary , and sorry for [[her]82-elizabeth father]244-her father 's speech , was afraid [her]82-elizabeth anxiety had done no good . [Others of the party]958-others of the party were now applied to .

" If [I]129-mr. collins , "[129-mr. collins] said [Mr. Collins]129-mr. collins , " were so fortunate as to be able to sing , [I]129-mr. collins should have great pleasure , [I]129-mr. collins am sure , in obliging [the company]952-the company with an air ; for [I]129-mr. collins consider music as a very innocent diversion , and perfectly compatible with the profession of [a clergyman]3429-a clergyman . [I]129-mr. collins do not mean , however , to assert that [we]3676-us can be justified in devoting too much of [our]3676-us time to music , for there are certainly other things to be attended to . [The rector of [a parish]3681-a parish]3680-the rector of a parish has much to do . In the first place , [he]3680-the rector of a parish must make such an agreement for tithes as may be beneficial to [himself]3680-the rector of a parish and not offensive to [[his]3680-the rector of a parish patron]3682-his patron . [He]3680-the rector of a parish must write [his]3680-the rector of a parish own sermons ; and the time that remains will not be too much for [his]3680-the rector of a parish parish duties , and the care and improvement of [his]3680-the rector of a parish dwelling , which [he]3680-the rector of a parish can not be excused from making as comfortable as possible . And [I]129-mr. collins do not think it of light importance that [he]3680-the rector of a parish should have attentive and conciliatory manners towards [everybody]304-everybody , especially towards those to whom [he]3680-the rector of a parish owes [his]3680-the rector of a parish preferment . [I]129-mr. collins can not acquit [him]3680-the rector of a parish of that duty ; nor could [I]129-mr. collins think well of [the man who should omit an occasion of testifying [his]3680-the rector of a parish respect towards anybody connected with [the family]416-the family]3684-the man who should omit an occasion of testifying his respect towards anybody connected with the family . "[129-mr. collins] And with a bow to [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy , [he]89-mr. darcy concluded [his]89-mr. darcy speech , which had been spoken so loud as to be heard by half [the room]250-the room . [Many]960-many stared -- [many]960-many smiled ; but [no one]3271-no one looked more amused than [Mr. Bennet]75-mr. bennet [himself]75-mr. bennet , while [[his]75-mr. bennet wife]231-his wife seriously commended [Mr. Collins]129-mr. collins for having spoken so sensibly , and observed , in a half - whisper to [Lady Lucas]81-lady lucas , that [he]89-mr. darcy was [a remarkably clever , good kind of young man]964-a remarkably clever , good kind of young man .

To [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth it appeared , that had [[her]82-elizabeth family]885-her family made an agreement to expose [themselves]885-her family as much as [they]885-her family could during the evening , it would have been impossible for [them]885-her family to play [their]885-her family parts with more spirit , or finer success ; and happy did [she]82-elizabeth think it for [Bingley]79-mr. bingley and [[her]82-elizabeth sister]328-her sister that some of the exhibition had escaped [his]75-mr. bennet notice , and that [his]75-mr. bennet feelings were not of a sort to be much distressed by the folly which [he]75-mr. bennet must have witnessed . That [[his]75-mr. bennet two sisters]278-his two sisters and [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy , however , should have such an opportunity of ridiculing [her]82-elizabeth relations was bad enough ; and [she]82-elizabeth could not determine whether the silent contempt of [the gentleman]285-the gentleman , or the insolent smiles of [the ladies]249-the ladies , were more intolerable .

The rest of the evening brought [her]82-elizabeth little amusement . [She]82-elizabeth was teased by [Mr. Collins]129-mr. collins , who continued most perseveringly by [her]82-elizabeth side ; and though [he]129-mr. collins could not prevail with [her]82-elizabeth to dance with [him]129-mr. collins again , put it out of [her]82-elizabeth power to dance with [others]3103-others . In vain did [she]82-elizabeth entreat [him]129-mr. collins to stand up with [somebody else]3044-somebody else , and offered to introduce [him]129-mr. collins to [any young lady in [the room]250-the room]972-any young lady in the room . [He]129-mr. collins assured [her]82-elizabeth that , as to dancing , [he]129-mr. collins was perfectly indifferent to it ; that [his]129-mr. collins chief object was , by delicate attentions , to recommend [himself]129-mr. collins to [her]82-elizabeth ; and that [he]129-mr. collins should therefore make a point of remaining close to [her]82-elizabeth the whole evening . There was no arguing upon such a project . [She]82-elizabeth owed [her]82-elizabeth greatest relief to [[her]82-elizabeth friend]402-her friend [Miss Lucas]92-miss lucas , who often joined [them]975-their , and good - naturedly engaged [Mr. Collins]129-mr. collins 's conversation to [herself]82-elizabeth .

[She]82-elizabeth was at least free from the offence of [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy 's further notice : though often standing within a very short distance of [her]82-elizabeth , quite disengaged , [he]89-mr. darcy never came near enough to speak . [She]82-elizabeth felt it to be the probable consequence of [her]82-elizabeth allusions to [Mr. Wickham]136-wickham , and rejoiced in it .

The Longbourn party were the last of [all the company]976-all the company to depart ; and by a manœuvre of [Mrs. Bennet]85-mrs. bennet had to wait for [[their]975-their carriage]977-their carriage a quarter of an hour after [everybody else]978-everybody else was gone , which gave [them]975-their time to see how heartily [they]975-their were wished away by [some of [the family]416-the family]979-some of the family . [Mrs. Hurst]90-mrs. hurst and [[her]90-mrs. hurst sister]328-her sister scarcely opened [their]975-their mouths except to complain of fatigue , and were evidently impatient to have [the house]3001-the house to [themselves]975-their . [They]975-their repulsed every attempt of [Mrs. Bennet]85-mrs. bennet at conversation , and , by so doing , threw a languor over the whole party , which was very little relieved by the long speeches of [Mr. Collins]129-mr. collins , who was complimenting [Mr. Bingley]79-mr. bingley and [[his]129-mr. collins sisters]282-his sisters on the elegance of [their]975-their entertainment , and the hospitality and politeness which had marked [their]975-their behaviour to [[their]975-their guests]984-their guests . [Darcy]89-mr. darcy said nothing at all . [Mr. Bennet]75-mr. bennet , in equal silence , was enjoying the scene . [Mr. Bingley]79-mr. bingley and [Jane]83-jane were standing together a little detached from the rest , and talked only to [each other]3144-each other . [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth preserved as steady a silence as either [Mrs. Hurst]90-mrs. hurst or [Miss Bingley]91-miss bingley ; and even [Lydia]84-lydia was too much fatigued to utter more than the occasional exclamation of " [Lord]3686-lord , how tired [I]84-lydia am ! "[84-lydia] accompanied by a violent yawn .

When at length [they]975-their arose to take leave , [Mrs. Bennet]85-mrs. bennet was most pressingly civil in [her]85-mrs. bennet hope of seeing [the whole family]311-the whole family soon at [Longbourn]7-longbourn ; and addressed [herself]85-mrs. bennet particularly to [Mr. Bingley]79-mr. bingley , to assure [him]79-mr. bingley how happy [he]79-mr. bingley would make [them]975-their , by eating a family dinner with [them]975-their at any time , without the ceremony of a formal invitation . [Bingley]79-mr. bingley was all grateful pleasure ; and [he]79-mr. bingley readily engaged for taking the earliest opportunity of waiting on [her]85-mrs. bennet after [his]79-mr. bingley return from [London]5-london , whither [he]79-mr. bingley was obliged to go the next day for a short time .

[Mrs. Bennet]85-mrs. bennet was perfectly satisfied ; and quitted [the house]3001-the house under the delightful persuasion that , allowing for the necessary preparations of settlements , new carriages , and wedding clothes , [she]85-mrs. bennet should undoubtedly see [[her]85-mrs. bennet daughter]463-her daughter settled at [Netherfield]2-netherfield in the course of three or four months . Of having [another daughter]989-another daughter married to [Mr. Collins]129-mr. collins [she]85-mrs. bennet thought with equal certainty , and with considerable , though not equal , pleasure . [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth was the least dear to [her]85-mrs. bennet of all [[her]85-mrs. bennet children]990-her children ; and though [the man]3091-the man and the match were quite good enough for _ [her]82-elizabeth _ , the worth of each was eclipsed by [Mr. Bingley]79-mr. bingley and [Netherfield]2-netherfield .

The next day opened a new scene at [Longbourn]7-longbourn . [Mr. Collins]129-mr. collins made [his]129-mr. collins declaration in form . Having resolved to do it without loss of time , as [his]129-mr. collins leave of absence extended only to the following Saturday , and having no feelings of diffidence to make it distressing to [himself]129-mr. collins even at the moment , [he]129-mr. collins set about it in a very orderly manner , with all the observances which [he]129-mr. collins supposed a regular part of the business . On finding [Mrs. Bennet]85-mrs. bennet , [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth , and [one of [the younger girls]3371-the younger girls]992-one of the younger girls together , soon after breakfast , [he]129-mr. collins addressed [the mother]395-the mother in these words,--

" May [I]129-mr. collins hope , [madam]3281-madam , for [your]395-the mother interest with [[your]395-the mother fair daughter]3688-your fair daughter [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth , when [I]129-mr. collins solicit for the honour of a private audience with [her]82-elizabeth in the course of this morning ? "[129-mr. collins]

Before [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth had time for anything but a blush of surprise , [Mrs. Bennet]85-mrs. bennet instantly answered,--

" Oh dear ! Yes , certainly . [I]82-elizabeth am sure [Lizzy]82-elizabeth will be very happy -- [I]82-elizabeth am sure [she]82-elizabeth can have no objection . Come , [Kitty]86-lady catherine , [I]82-elizabeth want [you]86-lady catherine [upstairs]703-upstairs . "[82-elizabeth] And gathering [her]82-elizabeth work together , [she]82-elizabeth was hastening away , when [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth called out,--

" [Dear ma'am]3690-dear ma'am , do not go . [I]82-elizabeth beg [you]3690-dear ma'am will not go . [Mr. Collins]129-mr. collins must excuse [me]82-elizabeth . [He]129-mr. collins can have nothing to say to [me]82-elizabeth that [anybody]3099-anybody need not hear . [I]82-elizabeth am going away [myself]82-elizabeth . "[82-elizabeth]

" No , no , nonsense , [Lizzy]82-elizabeth . [I]82-elizabeth desire [you]82-elizabeth will stay where [you]82-elizabeth are . "[82-elizabeth] And upon [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth 's seeming really , with vexed and embarrassed looks , about to escape , [she]82-elizabeth added , " [Lizzy]82-elizabeth , [I]82-elizabeth _ insist _ upon [your]82-elizabeth staying and hearing [Mr. Collins]129-mr. collins . "[82-elizabeth]

[Elizabeth]82-elizabeth would not oppose such an injunction ; and a moment 's consideration making [her]82-elizabeth also sensible that it would be wisest to get it over as soon and as quietly as possible , [she]82-elizabeth sat down again , and tried to conceal , by incessant employment , the feelings which were divided between distress and diversion . [Mrs. Bennet]85-mrs. bennet and [Kitty]86-lady catherine walked off , and as soon as [they]995-they were gone , [Mr. Collins]129-mr. collins began,--

" Believe [me]129-mr. collins , [[my]129-mr. collins dear]2993-my dear [Miss Elizabeth]82-elizabeth , that [your]82-elizabeth modesty , so far from doing [you]82-elizabeth any disservice , rather adds to [your]82-elizabeth other perfections . [You]82-elizabeth would have been less amiable in [my]129-mr. collins eyes had there _ not _ been this little unwillingness ; but allow [me]129-mr. collins to assure [you]82-elizabeth that [I]129-mr. collins have [[your]82-elizabeth respected mother]3693-your respected mother 's permission for this address . [You]82-elizabeth can hardly doubt the purport of [my]129-mr. collins discourse , however [your]82-elizabeth natural delicacy may lead [you]82-elizabeth to dissemble ; [my]129-mr. collins attentions have been too marked to be mistaken . Almost as soon as [I]129-mr. collins entered [the house]3001-the house [I]129-mr. collins singled [you]82-elizabeth out as the companion of [my]129-mr. collins future life . But before [I]129-mr. collins am run away with by [my]129-mr. collins feelings on this subject , perhaps it will be advisable for [me]129-mr. collins to state [my]129-mr. collins reasons for marrying -- and , moreover , for coming into [Hertfordshire]4-hertfordshire with the design of selecting [a wife]224-a wife , as [I]129-mr. collins certainly did . "[129-mr. collins]

The idea of [Mr. Collins]129-mr. collins , with all [his]129-mr. collins solemn composure , being run away with by [his]129-mr. collins feelings , made [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth so near laughing that [she]82-elizabeth could not use the short pause [he]129-mr. collins allowed in any attempt to stop [him]129-mr. collins farther , and [he]129-mr. collins continued,--

" [My]129-mr. collins reasons for marrying are , first , that [I]129-mr. collins think it a right thing for [every clergyman in easy circumstances]3696-every clergyman in easy circumstances ( like [myself]129-mr. collins ) to set the example of matrimony in [[his]3696-every clergyman in easy circumstances parish]700-his parish ; secondly , that [I]129-mr. collins am convinced it will add very greatly to [my]129-mr. collins happiness ; and , thirdly , which perhaps [I]129-mr. collins ought to have mentioned earlier , that it is the particular advice and recommendation of [the very noble lady whom [I]129-mr. collins have the honour of calling [patroness]3699-patroness]3698-the very noble lady whom i have the honour of calling patroness . Twice has [she]3698-the very noble lady whom i have the honour of calling patroness condescended to give [me]129-mr. collins [her]3698-the very noble lady whom i have the honour of calling patroness opinion ( unasked too ! ) on this subject ; and it was but the very Saturday night before [I]129-mr. collins left Hunsford,--between [[our]3700-our pools]3701-our pools at quadrille , while [Mrs. Jenkinson]145-mrs. jenkinson was arranging [Miss De Bourgh]132-miss de bourgh 's footstool,--that [she]145-mrs. jenkinson said , ' [Mr. Collins]129-mr. collins , [you]129-mr. collins must marry . [A clergyman like [you]129-mr. collins]3702-a clergyman like you must marry . Choose properly , choose [a gentlewoman]3703-a gentlewoman for _ [my]129-mr. collins _ sake , and for [your]129-mr. collins _ own _ ; let [her]3703-a gentlewoman be [an active , useful sort of person]3704-an active , useful sort of person , not brought up high , but able to make a small income go a good way . This is [my]129-mr. collins advice . Find [such a woman]3274-such a woman as soon as [you]129-mr. collins can , bring [her]3274-such a woman to [Hunsford]15-hunsford , and [I]129-mr. collins will visit [her]3274-such a woman . ' Allow [me]129-mr. collins , by the way , to observe , [[my]129-mr. collins fair cousin]3706-my fair cousin , that [I]129-mr. collins do not reckon the notice and kindness of [Lady Catherine de Bourgh]86-lady catherine as among the least of the advantages in [my]129-mr. collins power to offer . [You]129-mr. collins will find [her]3274-such a woman manners beyond anything [I]129-mr. collins can describe ; and [your]129-mr. collins wit and vivacity , [I]129-mr. collins think , must be acceptable to [her]3274-such a woman , especially when tempered with the silence and respect which [her]3274-such a woman rank will inevitably excite . Thus much for [my]129-mr. collins general intention in favour of matrimony ; it remains to be told why [my]129-mr. collins views were directed to [Longbourn]7-longbourn instead of [[my]129-mr. collins own neighbourhood]3707-my own neighbourhood , where [I]129-mr. collins assure [you]129-mr. collins there are [many amiable young women]3708-many amiable young women . But the fact is , that being , as [I]129-mr. collins am , to inherit [this estate]3450-this estate after the death of [[your]129-mr. collins honoured father]3710-your honoured father ( who , however , may live many years longer ) , [I]129-mr. collins could not satisfy [myself]129-mr. collins without resolving to choose [a wife]224-a wife from among [[his]3710-your honoured father daughters]431-his daughters , that the loss to [them]431-his daughters might be as little as possible when the melancholy event takes place -- which , however , as [I]129-mr. collins have already said , may not be for several years . This has been [my]129-mr. collins motive , [[my]129-mr. collins fair cousin]3706-my fair cousin , and [I]129-mr. collins flatter [myself]129-mr. collins it will not sink [me]129-mr. collins in [your]129-mr. collins esteem . And now nothing remains for [me]129-mr. collins but to assure [you]129-mr. collins in the most animated language of the violence of [my]129-mr. collins affection . To fortune [I]129-mr. collins am perfectly indifferent , and shall make no demand of that nature on [[your]129-mr. collins father]3223-your father , since [I]129-mr. collins am well aware that it could not be complied with ; and that one thousand pounds in the 4 per cents . , which will not be [yours]129-mr. collins till after [[your]129-mr. collins mother]3715-your mother 's decease , is all that [you]129-mr. collins may ever be entitled to . On that head , therefore , [I]129-mr. collins shall be uniformly silent : and [you]129-mr. collins may assure [yourself]129-mr. collins that no ungenerous reproach shall ever pass [my]129-mr. collins lips when [we]3716-we are married . "[129-mr. collins]

It was absolutely necessary to interrupt [him]996-you now .

" [You]996-you are too hasty , [sir]3161-sir , "[997-me] [she]997-me cried . " [You]996-you forget that [I]997-me have made no answer . Let [me]997-me do it without further loss of time . Accept [my]997-me thanks for the compliment [you]996-you are paying [me]997-me . [I]997-me am very sensible of the honour of [your]996-you proposals , but it is impossible for [me]997-me to do otherwise than decline them . "[997-me]

" [I]129-mr. collins am not now to learn , "[129-mr. collins] replied [Mr. Collins]129-mr. collins , with a formal wave of the hand , " that it is usual with [young ladies]3263-young ladies to reject the addresses of [the man whom [they]3263-young ladies secretly mean to accept , when [he]3719-the man whom they secretly mean to accept , when he first applies for their favour first applies for [their]3263-young ladies favour]3719-the man whom they secretly mean to accept , when he first applies for their favour ; and that sometimes the refusal is repeated a second or even a third time . [I]129-mr. collins am , therefore , by no means discouraged by what [you]996-you have just said , and shall hope to lead [you]996-you to the altar ere long . "[129-mr. collins]

" Upon [my]82-elizabeth word , [sir]3161-sir , "[82-elizabeth] cried [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth , " [your]3161-sir hope is rather an extraordinary one after [my]82-elizabeth declaration . [I]82-elizabeth do assure [you]3161-sir that [I]82-elizabeth am not one of [those young ladies ( if [such young ladies there]3722-such young ladies there are ) who are so daring as to risk [their]3263-young ladies happiness on the chance of being asked a second time]3721-those young ladies ( if such young ladies there are ) who are so daring as to risk their happiness on the chance of being asked a second time . [I]82-elizabeth am perfectly serious in [my]82-elizabeth refusal . [You]3161-sir could not make _ [me]82-elizabeth _ happy , and [I]82-elizabeth am convinced that [I]82-elizabeth am [the last woman in [the world]303-the world]3723-the last woman in the world who would make _ [you]3161-sir _ so . Nay , were [[your]3161-sir friend]3040-your friend [Lady Catherine]86-lady catherine to know [me]82-elizabeth , [I]82-elizabeth am persuaded [she]86-lady catherine would find [me]82-elizabeth in every respect ill qualified for the situation . "[82-elizabeth]

" Were it certain that [Lady Catherine]86-lady catherine would think so , "[129-mr. collins] said [Mr. Collins]129-mr. collins , very gravely--"but [I]129-mr. collins can not imagine that [[her]86-lady catherine Ladyship]3464-her ladyship would at all disapprove of [you]3161-sir . And [you]3161-sir may be certain that when [I]129-mr. collins have the honour of seeing [her]86-lady catherine again [I]129-mr. collins shall speak in the highest terms of [your]3161-sir modesty , economy , and other amiable qualifications . "[129-mr. collins]

" Indeed , [Mr. Collins]129-mr. collins , all praise of [me]998-me will be unnecessary . [You]129-mr. collins must give [me]998-me leave to judge for [myself]998-me , and pay [me]998-me the compliment of believing what [I]998-me say . [I]998-me wish [you]3161-sir very happy and very rich , and by refusing [your]3161-sir hand , do all in [my]998-me power to prevent [your]3161-sir being otherwise . In making [me]998-me the offer , [you]3161-sir must have satisfied the delicacy of [your]3161-sir feelings with regard to [[my]998-me family]3727-my family , and may take possession of [Longbourn estate]3431-longbourn estate whenever it falls , without any self - reproach . This matter may be considered , therefore , as finally settled . "[998-me] And rising as [she]998-me thus spoke , [she]998-me would have quitted [the room]250-the room , had not [Mr. Collins]129-mr. collins thus addressed [her,--]1000-her,--

" When [I]129-mr. collins do [myself]129-mr. collins the honour of speaking to [you]3161-sir next on the subject , [I]129-mr. collins shall hope to receive a more favourable answer than [you]3161-sir have now given [me]129-mr. collins ; though [I]129-mr. collins am far from accusing [you]3161-sir of cruelty at present , because [I]129-mr. collins know it to be the established custom of [your]3161-sir sex to reject [a man]3042-a man on the first application , and , perhaps , [you]3161-sir have even now said as much to encourage [my]129-mr. collins suit as would be consistent with the true delicacy of [the female character]3730-the female character . "[129-mr. collins]

" Really , [Mr. Collins]129-mr. collins , "[82-elizabeth] cried [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth , with some warmth , " [you]129-mr. collins puzzle [me]82-elizabeth exceedingly . If what [I]82-elizabeth have hitherto said can appear to [you]129-mr. collins in the form of encouragement , [I]82-elizabeth know not how to express [my]82-elizabeth refusal in such a way as may convince [you]129-mr. collins of its being one . "[82-elizabeth]

" [You]3161-sir must give [me]129-mr. collins leave to flatter [myself]129-mr. collins , [[my]129-mr. collins dear cousin]3731-my dear cousin , that [your]3161-sir refusal of [my]129-mr. collins addresses are merely words of course . [My]129-mr. collins reasons for believing it are briefly these:--It does not appear to [me]129-mr. collins that [my]129-mr. collins hand is unworthy [your]3161-sir acceptance , or that the establishment [I]129-mr. collins can offer would be any other than highly desirable . [My]129-mr. collins situation in life , [my]129-mr. collins connections with [the family of [De Bourgh]132-miss de bourgh]853-the family of de bourgh , and [my]129-mr. collins relationship to [your]3161-sir own , are circumstances highly in [my]129-mr. collins favour ; and [you]3161-sir should take it into further consideration that , in spite of [your]3161-sir manifold attractions , it is by no means certain that another offer of marriage may ever be made [you]3161-sir . [Your]3161-sir portion is unhappily so small , that it will in all likelihood undo the effects of [your]3161-sir loveliness and amiable qualifications . As [I]129-mr. collins must , therefore , conclude that [you]3161-sir are not serious in [your]3161-sir rejection of [me]129-mr. collins , [I]129-mr. collins shall choose to attribute it to [your]3161-sir wish of increasing [my]129-mr. collins love by suspense , according to the usual practice of [elegant females]3733-elegant females . "[129-mr. collins]

" [I]82-elizabeth do assure [you]3161-sir , [sir]3161-sir , that [I]82-elizabeth have no pretensions whatever to that kind of elegance which consists in tormenting [a respectable man]3735-a respectable man . [I]82-elizabeth would rather be paid the compliment of being believed sincere . [I]82-elizabeth thank [you]3161-sir again and again for the honour [you]3161-sir have done [me]82-elizabeth in [your]3161-sir proposals , but to accept them is absolutely impossible . [My]82-elizabeth feelings in every respect forbid it . Can [I]82-elizabeth speak plainer ? Do not consider [me]82-elizabeth now as [an elegant female]3736-an elegant female intending to plague [you]3161-sir , but as a rational creature speaking the truth from [her]82-elizabeth heart . "[82-elizabeth]

" [You]82-elizabeth are uniformly charming ! "[1001-he] cried [he]1001-he , with an air of awkward gallantry ; " and [I]1001-he am persuaded that , when sanctioned by the express authority of both [[your]82-elizabeth excellent parents]3737-your excellent parents , [my]1001-he proposals will not fail of being acceptable . "[1001-he]

To such perseverance in wilful self - deception [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth would make no reply , and immediately and in silence withdrew ; determined , that if [he]1001-he persisted in considering [her]82-elizabeth repeated refusals as flattering encouragement , to apply to [[her]82-elizabeth father]244-her father , whose negative might be uttered in such a manner as must be decisive , and whose behaviour at least could not be mistaken for the affectation and coquetry of [an elegant female]3736-an elegant female .

[Mr. Collins]129-mr. collins was not left long to the silent contemplation of [his]129-mr. collins successful love ; for [Mrs. Bennet]85-mrs. bennet , having dawdled about in [the vestibule]1004-the vestibule to watch for the end of the conference , no sooner saw [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth open the door and with quick step pass [her]82-elizabeth towards the staircase , than [she]85-mrs. bennet entered [the breakfast - room]1005-the breakfast - room , and congratulated both [him]1001-he and [herself]85-mrs. bennet in warm terms on the happy prospect of [their]1006-their nearer connection . [Mr. Collins]129-mr. collins received and returned these felicitations with equal pleasure , and then proceeded to relate the particulars of [their]1006-their interview , with the result of which [he]129-mr. collins trusted [he]129-mr. collins had every reason to be satisfied , since the refusal which [[his]129-mr. collins cousin]704-his cousin had steadfastly given [him]129-mr. collins would naturally flow from [her]704-his cousin bashful modesty and the genuine delicacy of [her]704-his cousin character .

This information , however , startled [Mrs. Bennet]85-mrs. bennet : [she]85-mrs. bennet would have been glad to be equally satisfied that [[her]85-mrs. bennet daughter]463-her daughter had meant to encourage [him]129-mr. collins by protesting against [his]129-mr. collins proposals , but [she]85-mrs. bennet dared not believe it , and could not help saying so .

" But depend upon it , [Mr. Collins]129-mr. collins , "[85-mrs. bennet] [she]85-mrs. bennet added , " that [Lizzy]82-elizabeth shall be brought to reason . [I]85-mrs. bennet will speak to [her]82-elizabeth about it [myself]85-mrs. bennet directly . [She]82-elizabeth is [a very headstrong , foolish girl]3738-a very headstrong , foolish girl , and does not know [her]82-elizabeth own interest ; but [I]85-mrs. bennet will _ make _ [her]82-elizabeth know it . "[85-mrs. bennet]

" Pardon [me]129-mr. collins for interrupting [you]85-mrs. bennet , [madam]3281-madam , "[129-mr. collins] cried [Mr. Collins]129-mr. collins ; " but if [she]82-elizabeth is really headstrong and foolish , [I]129-mr. collins know not whether [she]82-elizabeth would altogether be [a very desirable wife to [a man in [my]129-mr. collins situation , who naturally looks for happiness in the marriage state]3741-a man in my situation , who naturally looks for happiness in the marriage state]3740-a very desirable wife to a man in my situation , who naturally looks for happiness in the marriage state . If , therefore , [she]82-elizabeth actually persists in rejecting [my]129-mr. collins suit , perhaps it were better not to force [her]82-elizabeth into accepting [me]129-mr. collins , because , if liable to such defects of temper , [she]82-elizabeth could not contribute much to [my]129-mr. collins felicity . "[129-mr. collins]

" [Sir]3161-sir , [you]3161-sir quite misunderstand [me]85-mrs. bennet , "[85-mrs. bennet] said [Mrs. Bennet]85-mrs. bennet , alarmed . " [Lizzy]82-elizabeth is only headstrong in such matters as these . In everything else [she]82-elizabeth is as good - natured [a girl as ever lived]3743-a girl as ever lived . [She]85-mrs. bennet would not give [him]1009-him time to reply , but hurrying instantly to [[her]85-mrs. bennet husband]255-her husband , called out , as [she]85-mrs. bennet entered the library,--

" Oh , [Mr. Bennet]75-mr. bennet , [you]75-mr. bennet are wanted immediately ; [we]3744-we are all in an uproar .
