From [the drawing - room]520-the drawing - room [they]1420-their could distinguish nothing in [the lane]1065-the lane , and were indebted to [Mr. Collins]129-mr. collins for the knowledge of what carriages went along , and how often especially [Miss De Bourgh]132-miss de bourgh drove by in [her]132-miss de bourgh phaeton , which [he]129-mr. collins never failed coming to inform [them]1420-their of , though it happened almost every day . [She]82-elizabeth not unfrequently stopped at [the Parsonage]1285-the parsonage , and had a few minutes ' conversation with [Charlotte]101-charlotte , but was scarcely ever prevailed on to get out .

Very few days passed in which [Mr. Collins]129-mr. collins did not walk to [Rosings]20-rosings , and not many in which [[his]129-mr. collins wife]231-his wife did not think it necessary to go likewise ; and till [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth recollected that there might be other family livings to be disposed of , [she]82-elizabeth could not understand the sacrifice of so many hours . Now and then [they]1420-their were honoured with a call from [[her]82-elizabeth Ladyship]3464-her ladyship , and nothing escaped [her]82-elizabeth observation that was passing in [the room]250-the room during these visits . [She]82-elizabeth examined into [their]1420-their employments , looked at [their]1420-their work , and advised [them]1420-their to do it differently ; found fault with the arrangement of the furniture , or detected [the housemaid]1427-the housemaid in negligence ; and if [she]82-elizabeth accepted any refreshment , seemed to do it only for the sake of finding out that [Mrs. Collins]158-mrs. collins 's joints of meat were too large for [[her]82-elizabeth family]885-her family .

[Elizabeth]82-elizabeth soon perceived , that though [this great lady]1384-this great lady was not in the commission of the peace for [the county]1430-the county , [she]1384-this great lady was [a most active magistrate in [[her]1384-this great lady own parish]1432-her own parish]1431-a most active magistrate in her own parish , the minutest concerns of which were carried to [her]1384-this great lady by [Mr. Collins]129-mr. collins ; and whenever [any of [the cottagers]1434-the cottagers]1433-any of the cottagers were disposed to be quarrelsome , discontented , or too poor , [she]82-elizabeth sallied forth into [the village]319-the village to settle [their]1420-their differences , silence [their]1420-their complaints , and scold [them]1420-their into harmony and plenty .

The entertainment of dining at Rosings was repeated about twice a week ; and , allowing for the loss of [Sir William]80-sir william , and there being only one card - table in the evening , every such entertainment was the counterpart of the first . [Their]1420-their other engagements were few , as the style of living of [the neighbourhood]3015-the neighbourhood in general was beyond [the Collinses]163-the collinses ' reach . This , however , was no evil to [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth , and upon the whole [she]82-elizabeth spent [her]82-elizabeth time comfortably enough : there were half hours of pleasant conversation with [Charlotte]101-charlotte , and the weather was so fine for the time of year , that [she]82-elizabeth had often great enjoyment out of doors . [Her]82-elizabeth favourite walk , and where [she]82-elizabeth frequently went while [the others]507-the others were calling on [Lady Catherine]86-lady catherine , was along the open grove which edged [that side of [the park]1315-the park]1438-that side of the park , where there was a nice sheltered path , which [no one]3271-no one seemed to value but [herself]82-elizabeth , and where [she]82-elizabeth felt beyond the reach of [Lady Catherine]86-lady catherine 's curiosity .

In this quiet way the first fortnight of [her]82-elizabeth visit soon passed away . Easter was approaching , and the week preceding it was to bring an addition to [the family]416-the family at [Rosings]20-rosings , which in so small a circle must be important . [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth had heard , soon after [her]82-elizabeth arrival , that [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy was expected [there]305-there in the course of a few weeks ; and though there were not many of [her]82-elizabeth acquaintance whom [she]82-elizabeth did not prefer , [his]89-mr. darcy coming would furnish one comparatively new to look at in [their]1443-their Rosings parties , and [she]82-elizabeth might be amused in seeing how hopeless [Miss Bingley]91-miss bingley 's designs on [him]89-mr. darcy were , by [his]89-mr. darcy behaviour to [[his]89-mr. darcy cousin]704-his cousin , for whom [he]89-mr. darcy was evidently destined by [Lady Catherine]86-lady catherine , who talked of [his]89-mr. darcy coming with the greatest satisfaction , spoke of [him]89-mr. darcy in terms of the highest admiration , and seemed almost angry to find that [he]89-mr. darcy had already been frequently seen by [Miss Lucas]92-miss lucas and [herself]92-miss lucas .

[His]89-mr. darcy arrival was soon known at [the Parsonage]1285-the parsonage ; for [Mr. Collins]129-mr. collins was walking the whole morning within view of [the lodges]1446-the lodges opening into [Hunsford Lane]29-hunsford lane , in order to have

the earliest assurance of [it]1447-it ; and , after making [his]129-mr. collins bow as [the carriage]3217-the carriage turned into [the park]1315-the park , hurried [home]3219-home with the great intelligence . On the following morning [he]129-mr. collins hastened to [Rosings]20-rosings to pay [his]129-mr. collins respects . There were [two nephews of [Lady Catherine]86-lady catherine]1451-two nephews of lady catherine to require [them]1451-two nephews of lady catherine , for [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy had brought with [him]89-mr. darcy a Colonel Fitzwilliam , [the younger son of [[his]89-mr. darcy uncle]1453-his uncle , [Lord ----]1454-lord ----]1452-the younger son of his uncle , lord ---- ; and , to the great surprise of [all the party]1455-all the party , when [Mr. Collins]129-mr. collins returned , [the gentlemen]290-the gentlemen accompanied [him]129-mr. collins . [Charlotte]101-charlotte had seen [them]290-the gentlemen from [[[her]101-charlotte husband]255-her husband 's room]1458-her husband 's room , crossing [the road]1290-the road , and immediately running into the other , told [the girls]3008-the girls what an honour [they]3008-the girls might expect , adding,--

" [I]101-charlotte may thank [you]3008-the girls , [Eliza]82-elizabeth , for this piece of civility . [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy would never have come so soon to wait upon [me]101-charlotte . "[101-charlotte]

[Elizabeth]82-elizabeth had scarcely time to disclaim all right to the compliment before [their]290-the gentlemen approach was announced by the door - bell , and shortly afterwards [the three gentlemen]1461-the three gentlemen entered [the room]250-the room . [Colonel Fitzwilliam]164-colonel fitzwilliam , who led the way , was about thirty , not handsome , but in person and address most truly [the gentleman]285-the gentleman . [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy looked just as [he]89-mr. darcy had been used to look in [Hertfordshire]4-hertfordshire , paid [his]89-mr. darcy compliments , with [his]89-mr. darcy usual reserve , to [Mrs. Collins]158-mrs. collins ; and whatever might be [his]89-mr. darcy feelings towards [[her]158-mrs. collins friend]402-her friend , met [her]158-mrs. collins with every appearance of composure . [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth merely courtesied to [him]89-mr. darcy , without saying a word .

[Colonel Fitzwilliam]164-colonel fitzwilliam entered into conversation directly , with the readiness and ease of [a well - bred man]1465-a well - bred man , and talked very pleasantly ; but [[his]164-colonel fitzwilliam cousin]704-his cousin , after having addressed a slight observation on [the house]3001-the house and [garden]1468-garden to [Mrs. Collins]158-mrs. collins , sat for some time without speaking to [anybody]3099-anybody . At length , however , [his]89-mr. darcy civility was so far awakened as to inquire of [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth after the health of [[her]82-elizabeth family]885-her family . [She]82-elizabeth answered [him]89-mr. darcy in the usual way ; and , after a moment 's pause , added,--

" [[My]82-elizabeth eldest sister]4086-my eldest sister has been in [town]264-town these three months . Have [you]89-mr. darcy never happened to see [her]4086-my eldest sister [there]305-there ? "[82-elizabeth]

[She]82-elizabeth was perfectly sensible that [he]89-mr. darcy never had : but [she]82-elizabeth wished to see whether [he]89-mr. darcy would betray any consciousness of what had passed between [the Bingleys]141-the bingleys and [Jane]83-jane ; and [she]82-elizabeth thought [he]89-mr. darcy looked a little confused as [he]89-mr. darcy answered that [he]89-mr. darcy had never been so fortunate as to meet [Miss Bennet]82-elizabeth . The subject was pursued no further , and [the gentlemen]290-the gentlemen soon afterwards went away .

[Colonel Fitzwilliam]164-colonel fitzwilliam 's manners were very much admired at [the Parsonage]1285-the parsonage , and [the ladies all]1473-the ladies all felt that [he]89-mr. darcy must add considerably to the pleasure of [their]1473-the ladies all engagements at Rosings . It was some days , however , before [they]1473-the ladies all received any invitation thither , for while there were visitors in [the house]3001-the house [they]1473-the ladies all could not be necessary ; and it was not till Easter - day , almost a week after [the gentlemen]290-the gentlemen 's arrival , that [they]1473-the ladies all were honoured by such an attention , and then [they]1473-the ladies all were merely asked on leaving [church]4012-church to come [there]305-there in the evening . For the last week [they]1473-the ladies all had seen very little of either [Lady Catherine]86-lady catherine or [[her]86-lady catherine daughter]463-her daughter . [Colonel Fitzwilliam]164-colonel fitzwilliam had called at [the Parsonage]1285-the parsonage more than once during the time , but [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy [they]1473-the ladies all had only seen at [church]4012-church .

The invitation was accepted , of course , and at a proper hour [they]1473-the ladies all joined the party in [[Lady Catherine]86-lady catherine 's drawing - room]1481-lady catherine 's drawing - room . [[Her]86-lady catherine Ladyship]3464-her ladyship received [them]1473-the ladies all civilly , but it was plain that [their]1473-the ladies all company was by no means so acceptable as when [she]86-lady catherine could get [nobody else]1483-nobody else ; and [she]86-lady catherine was , in fact , almost engrossed by [[her]86-lady catherine nephews]1484-her nephews , speaking to [them]1484-her nephews , especially to [Darcy]89-mr. darcy , much more than to [any other person in [the room]250-the room]1485-any other person in the room .

[Colonel Fitzwilliam]164-colonel fitzwilliam seemed really glad to see [them]1473-the ladies all : anything was a welcome relief to [him]164-colonel fitzwilliam at Rosings ; and [[Mrs. Collins]158-mrs. collins 's pretty friend]1487-mrs. collins 's pretty friend had , moreover , caught [his]164-colonel fitzwilliam fancy very much . [He]164-colonel fitzwilliam now seated [himself]164-colonel fitzwilliam by [her]1487-mrs. collins 's pretty friend , and talked so agreeably of [Kent]17-kent and [Hertfordshire]4-hertfordshire , of travelling and staying at [home]3219-home , of new books and music , that [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth had never been half so well entertained in [that room]1489-that room before ; and [they]1473-the ladies all conversed with so much spirit and flow as to draw the attention of [Lady Catherine]86-lady catherine [herself]86-lady catherine , as well as of [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy . _ [His]164-colonel fitzwilliam _ eyes had been soon and repeatedly turned towards [them]1473-the ladies all with a look of curiosity ; and that [[her]1487-mrs. collins 's pretty friend Ladyship]3464-her ladyship , after a while , shared the feeling , was more openly acknowledged , for [she]3464-her ladyship did not scruple to call out,--

" What is that [you]164-colonel fitzwilliam are saying , [Fitzwilliam]164-colonel fitzwilliam ? What is it [you]164-colonel fitzwilliam are talking of ? What are [you]164-colonel fitzwilliam telling [Miss Bennet]82-elizabeth ? Let [me]3464-her ladyship hear what it is . "[3464-her ladyship]

" [We]1473-the ladies all were talking of music , [madam]3281-madam , "[164-colonel fitzwilliam] said [he]164-colonel fitzwilliam , when no longer able to avoid a reply .

" Of music ! Then pray speak aloud . It is of all subjects [my]3464-her ladyship delight . [I]3464-her ladyship must have [my]3464-her ladyship share in the conversation , if [you]164-colonel fitzwilliam are speaking of music . There are [few people in [England]3-england]4090-few people in england , [I]3464-her ladyship suppose , who have more true enjoyment of music than [myself]3464-her ladyship , or a better natural taste . If [I]3464-her ladyship had ever learnt , [I]3464-her ladyship should have been [a great proficient]4091-a great proficient . And so would [Anne]139-anne , if [her]139-anne health had allowed [her]139-anne to apply . [I]3464-her ladyship am confident that [she]139-anne would have performed delightfully . How does [Georgiana]147-georgiana get on , [Darcy]147-georgiana ? "[3464-her ladyship]

[Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy spoke with affectionate praise of [[his]89-mr. darcy sister]559-his sister 's proficiency .

" [I]86-lady catherine am very glad to hear such a good account of [her]147-georgiana , "[86-lady catherine] said [Lady Catherine]86-lady catherine ; " and pray tell [her]147-georgiana from [me]86-lady catherine , that [she]147-georgiana can not expect to excel , if [she]147-georgiana does not practise a great deal . "[86-lady catherine]

" [I]89-mr. darcy assure [you]86-lady catherine , [madam]3281-madam , "[89-mr. darcy] [he]89-mr. darcy replied , " that [she]147-georgiana does not need such advice . [She]147-georgiana practises very constantly . "[89-mr. darcy]

" So much the better . It can not be done too much ; and when [I]89-mr. darcy next write to [her]147-georgiana , [I]89-mr. darcy shall charge [her]147-georgiana not to neglect it on any account . [I]89-mr. darcy often tell [young ladies]3263-young ladies , that no excellence in music is to be acquired without constant practice . [I]89-mr. darcy have told [Miss Bennet]82-elizabeth several times , that [she]147-georgiana will never play really well , unless [she]147-georgiana practises more ; and though [Mrs. Collins]158-mrs. collins has no instrument , [she]147-georgiana is very welcome , as [I]89-mr. darcy have often told [her]147-georgiana , to come to Rosings every day , and play on the pianoforte in [[Mrs. Jenkinson]145-mrs. jenkinson 's room]4094-mrs. jenkinson 's room . [She]147-georgiana would be in [nobody]3077-nobody 's way , [you]4096-you know , in [that part of [the house]3001-the house]4097-that part of the house . "[89-mr. darcy]

[Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy looked a little ashamed of [[his]89-mr. darcy aunt]924-his aunt 's ill - breeding , and made no answer .

When coffee was over , [Colonel Fitzwilliam]164-colonel fitzwilliam reminded [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth of having promised to play to [him]89-mr. darcy ; and [she]82-elizabeth sat down directly to the instrument . [He]89-mr. darcy drew a chair near [her]82-elizabeth . [Lady Catherine]86-lady catherine listened to half a song , and then talked , as before , to [[her]86-lady catherine other nephew]1493-her other nephew ; till [the latter]487-the latter walked away from [her]86-lady catherine , and moving with [his]89-mr. darcy usual deliberation towards the pianoforte , stationed [himself]89-mr. darcy so as to command a full view of [the fair performer]1495-the fair performer 's countenance . [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth saw what [he]89-mr. darcy was doing , and at the first convenient pause turned to [him]89-mr. darcy with an arch smile , and said,--

" [You]89-mr. darcy mean to frighten [me]82-elizabeth , [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy , by coming in all this state to hear [me]82-elizabeth . But [I]82-elizabeth will not be alarmed , though [[your]89-mr. darcy sister]3139-your sister _ does _ play so well . There is a stubbornness about [me]82-elizabeth that never can bear to be frightened at the will of [others]3103-others . [My]82-elizabeth courage always rises with every attempt to intimidate [me]82-elizabeth . "[82-elizabeth]

" [I]89-mr. darcy shall not say that [you]82-elizabeth are mistaken , "[89-mr. darcy] [he]89-mr. darcy replied , " because [you]82-elizabeth could not really believe [me]89-mr. darcy to entertain any design of alarming [you]82-elizabeth ; and [I]89-mr. darcy have had the pleasure of [your]82-elizabeth acquaintance long enough to know , that [you]82-elizabeth find great enjoyment in occasionally professing opinions which , in fact , are not [your]82-elizabeth own . "[89-mr. darcy]

[Elizabeth]82-elizabeth laughed heartily at this picture of [herself]82-elizabeth , and said to [Colonel Fitzwilliam]164-colonel fitzwilliam , " [[Your]89-mr. darcy cousin]4101-your cousin will give [you]89-mr. darcy a very pretty notion of [me]82-elizabeth , and teach [you]89-mr. darcy not to believe a word [I]82-elizabeth say . [I]82-elizabeth am particularly unlucky in meeting with [a person so well able to expose [my]82-elizabeth real character , in [a part of the world where [I]82-elizabeth had hoped to pass [myself]82-elizabeth off with some degree of credit]4103-a part of the world where i had hoped to pass myself off with some degree of credit]4102-a person so well able to expose my real character , in a part of the world where i had hoped to pass myself off with some degree of credit . Indeed , [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy , it is very ungenerous in [you]89-mr. darcy to mention all that [you]89-mr. darcy knew to [my]82-elizabeth disadvantage in [Hertfordshire]4-hertfordshire -- and , give [me]82-elizabeth leave to say , very impolitic too -- for it is provoking [me]82-elizabeth to retaliate , and such things may come out as will shock [[your]89-mr. darcy relations]4104-your relations to hear . "[82-elizabeth]

" [I]1496-he am not afraid of [you]82-elizabeth , "[1496-he] said [he]1496-he , smilingly .

" Pray let [me]164-colonel fitzwilliam hear what [you]89-mr. darcy have to accuse [him]1496-he of , "[164-colonel fitzwilliam] cried [Colonel Fitzwilliam]164-colonel fitzwilliam . " [I]164-colonel fitzwilliam should like to know how [he]1496-he behaves among [strangers]4105-strangers . "[164-colonel fitzwilliam]

" [You]89-mr. darcy shall hear , then -- but prepare for something very dreadful . The first time of [my]82-elizabeth ever seeing [him]1496-he in [Hertfordshire]4-hertfordshire , [you]89-mr. darcy must know , was at a ball -- and at this ball , what do [you]89-mr. darcy think [he]1496-he did ? [He]1496-he danced only four dances ! [I]82-elizabeth am sorry to pain [you]89-mr. darcy , but so it was . [He]1496-he danced only four dances , though [gentlemen]308-gentlemen were scarce ; and , to [my]82-elizabeth certain knowledge , [more than one young lady]4107-more than one young lady was sitting down in want of [a partner]3176-a partner . [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy , [you]89-mr. darcy can not deny the fact . "[82-elizabeth]

" [I]164-colonel fitzwilliam had not at that time the honour of knowing [any lady in the assembly]4109-any lady in the assembly beyond [my]164-colonel fitzwilliam own party . "[164-colonel fitzwilliam]

" True ; and [nobody]3077-nobody can ever be introduced in [a ball - room]3634-a ball - room . Well , [Colonel Fitzwilliam]164-colonel fitzwilliam , what do [I]82-elizabeth play next ? [My]82-elizabeth fingers wait [your]89-mr. darcy orders . "[82-elizabeth]

" Perhaps , "[89-mr. darcy] said [Darcy]89-mr. darcy , " [I]89-mr. darcy should have judged better had [I]89-mr. darcy sought an introduction , but [I]89-mr. darcy am ill - qualified to recommend [myself]89-mr. darcy to [strangers]4105-strangers . "[89-mr. darcy]

" Shall [we]4113-we ask [[your]164-colonel fitzwilliam cousin]4101-your cousin the reason of this ? "[82-elizabeth] said [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth , still addressing [Colonel Fitzwilliam]164-colonel fitzwilliam . " Shall [we]4113-we ask [him]4101-your cousin why [a man of sense and education]4115-a man of sense and education , and who has lived in [the world]303-the world , is ill - qualified to recommend [himself]4101-your cousin to [strangers]4105-strangers ? "[164-colonel fitzwilliam]

" [I]164-colonel fitzwilliam can answer [your]164-colonel fitzwilliam question , "[164-colonel fitzwilliam] said [Fitzwilliam]164-colonel fitzwilliam , " without applying to [him]4101-your cousin . It is because [he]4101-your cousin will not give [himself]4101-your cousin the trouble . "[164-colonel fitzwilliam]

" [I]89-mr. darcy certainly have not the talent which [some people]4118-some people possess , "[89-mr. darcy] said [Darcy]89-mr. darcy , " of conversing easily with those [I]89-mr. darcy have never seen before . [I]89-mr. darcy can not catch [their]4118-some people tone of conversation , or appear interested in [their]4118-some people concerns , as [I]89-mr. darcy often see done . "[89-mr. darcy]

" [My]82-elizabeth fingers , "[82-elizabeth] said [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth , " do not move over this instrument in the masterly manner which [I]82-elizabeth see [so many women]4119-so many women 's do . [They]4118-some people have not the same force or rapidity , and do not produce the same expression . But then [I]82-elizabeth have always supposed it to be [my]82-elizabeth own fault -- because [I]82-elizabeth would not take the trouble of practising . It is not that [I]82-elizabeth do not believe _ [my]82-elizabeth _ fingers as capable as [any other woman]4120-any other woman 's of superior execution . "[82-elizabeth]

[Darcy]89-mr. darcy smiled and said , " [You]82-elizabeth are perfectly right . [You]82-elizabeth have employed [your]82-elizabeth time much better . [No one]3271-no one admitted to the privilege of hearing [you]82-elizabeth can think anything wanting . [We]1497-they neither of [us]1497-they perform to [strangers]4105-strangers . "[89-mr. darcy]

Here [they]1497-they were interrupted by [Lady Catherine]86-lady catherine , who called out to know what [they]1497-they were talking of . [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth immediately began playing again . [Lady Catherine]86-lady catherine approached , and , after listening for a few minutes , said to [Darcy,--]165-darcy,--

" [Miss Bennet]82-elizabeth would not play at all amiss if [she]82-elizabeth practised more , and could have the advantage of [a London master]4123-a london master . [She]82-elizabeth has a very good notion of fingering , though [her]82-elizabeth taste is not equal to [Anne]139-anne 's . [Anne]139-anne would have been a delightful performer , had [her]139-anne health allowed [her]139-anne to learn . "[86-lady catherine]

[Elizabeth]82-elizabeth looked at [Darcy]139-anne , to see how cordially [he]1498-his assented to [[his]1498-his cousin]704-his cousin 's praise : but neither at that moment nor at any other could [she]82-elizabeth discern any symptom of love ; and from the whole of [his]1498-his behaviour to [Miss De Bourgh]132-miss de bourgh [she]82-elizabeth derived this comfort for [Miss Bingley]91-miss bingley , that [he]1498-his might have been just as likely to marry _ [her]91-miss bingley _ , had [she]91-miss bingley been [[his]1498-his relation]1500-his relation .

[Lady Catherine]86-lady catherine continued [her]86-lady catherine remarks on [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth 's performance , mixing with [them]1501-them many instructions on execution and taste . [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth received [them]1501-them with all the forbearance of civility ; and at the request of [the gentlemen]290-the gentlemen remained at the instrument till [[her]82-elizabeth Ladyship]3464-her ladyship 's carriage was ready to take [them]290-the gentlemen all [home]3219-home .

[Elizabeth]82-elizabeth was sitting by [herself]82-elizabeth the next morning , and writing to [Jane]83-jane , while [Mrs. Collins]158-mrs. collins and [Maria]94-maria were gone on business into [the village]319-the village , when [she]82-elizabeth was startled by a ring at the door , the certain signal of [a visitor]1506-a visitor . As [she]82-elizabeth had heard [no carriage]1507-no carriage , [she]82-elizabeth thought it not unlikely to be [Lady Catherine]86-lady catherine ; and under that apprehension was putting away [her]82-elizabeth half - finished letter , that [she]82-elizabeth might escape all impertinent questions , when the door opened , and to [her]82-elizabeth very great surprise [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy , and [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy only , entered [the room]250-the room .

[He]89-mr. darcy seemed astonished too on finding [her]82-elizabeth alone , and apologized for [his]89-mr. darcy intrusion , by letting [her]82-elizabeth know that [he]89-mr. darcy had understood all [the ladies to be within]1509-the ladies to be within .

[They]1510-they then sat down , and when [her]82-elizabeth inquiries after Rosings were made , seemed in danger of sinking into total silence . It was absolutely necessary , therefore , to think of something ; and in this emergency recollecting _ when _ [she]82-elizabeth had seen [him]89-mr. darcy last in [Hertfordshire]4-hertfordshire , and feeling curious to know what [he]89-mr. darcy would say on the subject of [their]1510-they hasty departure , [she]82-elizabeth observed,--

" How very suddenly [you]89-mr. darcy all quitted [Netherfield]2-netherfield last November , [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy ! It must have been a most agreeable surprise to [Mr. Bingley]79-mr. bingley to see [you]89-mr. darcy all after [him]79-mr. bingley so soon ; for , if [I]82-elizabeth recollect right , [he]79-mr. bingley went but the day before . [He]79-mr. bingley and [[his]79-mr. bingley sisters]282-his sisters were well , [I]82-elizabeth hope , when [you]89-mr. darcy left [London]5-london ? "[82-elizabeth]

" Perfectly so , [I]82-elizabeth thank [you]89-mr. darcy . "[82-elizabeth]

[She]82-elizabeth found that [she]82-elizabeth was to receive no other answer ; and , after a short pause , added,--

" [I]82-elizabeth think [I]82-elizabeth have understood that [Mr. Bingley]79-mr. bingley has not much idea of ever returning to [Netherfield]2-netherfield again ? "[82-elizabeth]

" [I]82-elizabeth have never heard [him]79-mr. bingley say so ; but it is probable that [he]79-mr. bingley may spend very little of [his]79-mr. bingley time [there]305-there in future . [He]79-mr. bingley has many [friends]3787-friends , and [he]79-mr. bingley is at a time of life when [friends]3787-friends and engagements are continually increasing . "[82-elizabeth]

" If [he]79-mr. bingley means to be but little at [Netherfield]2-netherfield , it would be better for [the neighbourhood]3015-the neighbourhood that [he]79-mr. bingley should give up [the place]2998-the place entirely , for then [we]4130-we might possibly get [a settled family]4131-a settled family [there]305-there . But , perhaps , [Mr. Bingley]79-mr. bingley did not take [the house]3001-the house so much for the convenience of [the neighbourhood]3015-the neighbourhood as for [his]79-mr. bingley own , and [we]4130-we must expect [him]79-mr. bingley to keep or quit [it]3001-the house on the same principle . "[82-elizabeth]

" [I]89-mr. darcy should not be surprised , "[89-mr. darcy] said [Darcy]89-mr. darcy , " if [he]79-mr. bingley were to give it up as soon as any eligible purchase offers . "[89-mr. darcy]

[Elizabeth]82-elizabeth made no answer . [She]82-elizabeth was afraid of talking longer of [[his]89-mr. darcy friend]286-his friend ; and , having nothing else to say , was now determined to leave the trouble of finding a subject to [him]89-mr. darcy .

[He]89-mr. darcy took the hint and soon began with , " This seems [a very comfortable house]4135-a very comfortable house . [Lady Catherine]86-lady catherine , [I]89-mr. darcy believe , did a great deal to it when [Mr. Collins]129-mr. collins first came to [Hunsford]15-hunsford . "[89-mr. darcy]

" [I]89-mr. darcy believe [she]86-lady catherine did -- and [I]89-mr. darcy am sure [she]86-lady catherine could not have bestowed [her]86-lady catherine kindness on [a more grateful object]4136-a more grateful object . "[89-mr. darcy]

" [Mr. Collins]129-mr. collins appears very fortunate in [his]129-mr. collins choice of [a wife]224-a wife . "[89-mr. darcy]

" Yes , indeed ; [[his]129-mr. collins friends]407-his friends may well rejoice in [his]129-mr. collins having met with [one of [the very few sensible women who would have accepted [him]129-mr. collins , or have made [him]129-mr. collins happy if [they]407-his friends had]4140-the very few sensible women who would have accepted him , or have made him happy if they had . [[My]89-mr. darcy friend]3353-my friend]4139-one of the very few sensible women who would have accepted him , or have made him happy if they had . my friend has an excellent understanding -- though [I]89-mr. darcy am not certain that [I]89-mr. darcy consider [her]3353-my friend marrying [Mr. Collins]129-mr. collins as the wisest thing [she]3353-my friend ever did . [She]3353-my friend seems perfectly happy , however ; and , in a prudential light , it is certainly a very good match for [her]3353-my friend . "[89-mr. darcy]

" It must be very agreeable to [her]3353-my friend to be settled within so easy a distance of [[her]3353-my friend own family]4142-her own family and [friends]3787-friends . "[89-mr. darcy]

" An easy distance do [you]89-mr. darcy call it ? [It]4144-it is nearly fifty miles . "[89-mr. darcy]

" And what is fifty miles of [good road]4145-good road ? Little more than half a day 's journey . Yes , [I]89-mr. darcy call it a very easy distance . "[89-mr. darcy]

" [I]82-elizabeth should never have considered the distance as one of the _ advantages _ of the match , "[82-elizabeth] cried [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth . " [I]82-elizabeth should never have said [Mrs. Collins]158-mrs. collins was settled _ near _ [[her]158-mrs. collins family]885-her family . "[82-elizabeth]

" It is a proof of [your]82-elizabeth own attachment to [Hertfordshire]4-hertfordshire . Anything beyond [the very neighbourhood of [Longbourn]7-longbourn]4147-the very neighbourhood of longbourn , [I]1512-i suppose , would appear far . "[1512-i]

As [he]1512-i spoke there was a sort of smile , which [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth fancied [she]82-elizabeth understood ; [he]1512-i must be supposing [her]82-elizabeth to be thinking of [Jane]83-jane and [Netherfield]2-netherfield , and [she]82-elizabeth blushed as [she]82-elizabeth answered,--

" [I]1512-i do not mean to say that [a woman]3011-a woman may not be settled too near [[her]3011-a woman family]885-her family . [The far and the near]4150-the far and the near must be relative , and depend on many varying circumstances . Where there is fortune to make the expense of travelling unimportant , distance becomes no evil . But that is not the case _ here _ . [Mr.]4151-mr. and [Mrs. Collins]158-mrs. collins have a comfortable income , but not such a one as will allow of frequent journeys -- and [I]1512-i am persuaded [[my]1512-i friend]3353-my friend would not call [herself]3353-my friend _ near _ [[her]3353-my friend family]885-her family under less than _ half _ the present distance . "[1512-i]

[Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy drew [his]89-mr. darcy chair a little towards [her]82-elizabeth , and said , " _ [You]82-elizabeth _ can not have a right to such very strong local attachment . _ [You]82-elizabeth _ can not have been always at [Longbourn]7-longbourn . "[89-mr. darcy]

[Elizabeth]82-elizabeth looked surprised . [The gentleman]285-the gentleman experienced some change of feeling ; [he]89-mr. darcy drew back [his]89-mr. darcy chair , took a newspaper from the table , and , glancing over it , said , in a colder voice,--

" Are [you]82-elizabeth pleased with [Kent]17-kent ? "[89-mr. darcy]

A short dialogue on the subject of [the country]448-the country ensued , on either side calm and concise -- and soon put an end to by the entrance of [Charlotte]101-charlotte and [[her]101-charlotte sister]328-her sister , just returned from [their]1516-their walk . The _ tete - a - tete _ surprised [them]1516-their . [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy related the mistake which had occasioned [his]89-mr. darcy intruding on [Miss Bennet]82-elizabeth , and , after sitting a few minutes longer , without saying much to [anybody]3099-anybody , went away .

" What can be the meaning of this ? "[101-charlotte] said [Charlotte]101-charlotte , as soon as [he]89-mr. darcy was gone . " [[My]101-charlotte dear]2993-my dear [Eliza]82-elizabeth , [he]89-mr. darcy must be in love with [you]82-elizabeth , or [he]89-mr. darcy would never have called on [us]1516-their in this familiar way . "[101-charlotte]

But when [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth told of [his]89-mr. darcy silence , it did not seem very likely , even to [Charlotte]101-charlotte 's wishes , to be the case ; and , after various conjectures , [they]1516-their could at last only suppose [his]89-mr. darcy visit to proceed from the difficulty of finding anything to do , which was the more probable from the time of year . All field sports were over . Within doors there was [Lady Catherine]86-lady catherine , books , and a billiard table , but [gentlemen]308-gentlemen can not be always within doors ; and in the nearness of [the Parsonage]1285-the parsonage , or the pleasantness of the walk to [it]1285-the parsonage , or of [the people who lived in [it]1285-the parsonage]1520-the people who lived in it , [the two cousins]1521-the two cousins found a temptation from this period of walking thither almost every day . [They]1521-the two cousins called at various times of the morning , sometimes separately , sometimes together , and now and then accompanied by [[their]1521-the two cousins aunt]443-their aunt . It was plain to [them]1516-their all that [Colonel Fitzwilliam]164-colonel fitzwilliam came because [he]164-colonel fitzwilliam had pleasure in [their]1516-their society , a persuasion which of course recommended [him]164-colonel fitzwilliam still more ; and [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth was reminded by [her]82-elizabeth own satisfaction in being with [him]164-colonel fitzwilliam , as well as by [his]164-colonel fitzwilliam evident admiration , of [[her]82-elizabeth former favourite]1523-her former favourite , [George Wickham]143-george wickham ; and though , in comparing [them]1521-the two cousins , [she]82-elizabeth saw there was less captivating softness in [Colonel Fitzwilliam]164-colonel fitzwilliam 's manners , [she]82-elizabeth believed [he]164-colonel fitzwilliam might have the best informed mind .

But why [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy came so often to [the Parsonage]1285-the parsonage it was more difficult to understand . It could not be for society , as [he]164-colonel fitzwilliam frequently sat there ten minutes together without opening [his]164-colonel fitzwilliam lips ; and when [he]164-colonel fitzwilliam did speak , it seemed the effect of necessity rather than of choice -- a sacrifice to propriety , not a pleasure to [himself]164-colonel fitzwilliam . [He]164-colonel fitzwilliam seldom appeared really animated . [Mrs. Collins]158-mrs. collins knew not what to make of [him]164-colonel fitzwilliam . [Colonel Fitzwilliam]164-colonel fitzwilliam 's occasionally laughing at [his]164-colonel fitzwilliam stupidity proved that [he]164-colonel fitzwilliam was generally different , which [her]82-elizabeth own knowledge of [him]164-colonel fitzwilliam could not have told [her]82-elizabeth ; and as [she]82-elizabeth would have liked to believe this change the effect of love , and the object of that love [[her]82-elizabeth friend]402-her friend [Eliza]82-elizabeth , [she]82-elizabeth set [herself]82-elizabeth seriously to work to find it out : [she]82-elizabeth watched [him]164-colonel fitzwilliam whenever [they]1526-they were at Rosings , and whenever [he]164-colonel fitzwilliam came to [Hunsford]15-hunsford ; but without much success . [He]164-colonel fitzwilliam certainly looked at [[her]82-elizabeth friend]402-her friend a great deal , but the expression of that look was disputable . It was an earnest , steadfast gaze , but [she]82-elizabeth often doubted whether there were much admiration in it , and sometimes it seemed nothing but absence of mind .

[She]82-elizabeth had once or twice suggested to [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth the possibility of [his]164-colonel fitzwilliam being partial to [her]82-elizabeth , but [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth always laughed at the idea ; and [Mrs. Collins]158-mrs. collins did not think it right to press the subject , from the danger of raising expectations which might only end in disappointment ; for in [her]158-mrs. collins opinion it admitted not of a doubt , that all [[her]158-mrs. collins friend]402-her friend 's dislike would vanish , if [she]158-mrs. collins could suppose [him]164-colonel fitzwilliam to be in [her]158-mrs. collins power .

In [her]158-mrs. collins kind schemes for [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth , [she]158-mrs. collins sometimes planned [her]158-mrs. collins marrying [Colonel Fitzwilliam]164-colonel fitzwilliam . [He]164-colonel fitzwilliam was , beyond comparison , [the pleasantest man]1529-the pleasantest man : [he]164-colonel fitzwilliam certainly admired [her]82-elizabeth , and [his]164-colonel fitzwilliam situation in life was most eligible ; but , to counterbalance these advantages , [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy had considerable patronage in [the church]3524-the church , and [[his]89-mr. darcy cousin]704-his cousin could have none at all .

More than once did [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth , in [her]82-elizabeth ramble within [the park]1315-the park , unexpectedly meet [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy . [She]82-elizabeth felt all the perverseness of the mischance that should bring [him]89-mr. darcy where [no one else]3871-no one else was brought ; and , to prevent its ever happening again , took care to inform [him]89-mr. darcy , at first , that it was a favourite haunt of [hers]82-elizabeth . How it could occur a second time , therefore , was very odd ! Yet it did , and even the third . It seemed like wilful ill - nature , or a voluntary penance ; for on these occasions it was not merely a few formal inquiries and an awkward pause and then away , but [he]89-mr. darcy actually thought it necessary to turn back and walk with [her]82-elizabeth . [He]89-mr. darcy never said a great deal , nor did [she]82-elizabeth give [herself]82-elizabeth the trouble of talking or of listening much ; but it struck [her]82-elizabeth in the course of [their]1534-their third rencounter that [he]89-mr. darcy was asking some odd unconnected questions -- about [her]82-elizabeth pleasure in being at [Hunsford]15-hunsford , [her]82-elizabeth love of solitary walks , and [her]82-elizabeth opinion of [Mr.]1535-mr. and [Mrs. Collins]158-mrs. collins 's happiness ; and that in speaking of Rosings , and [her]82-elizabeth not perfectly understanding [the house]3001-the house , [he]89-mr. darcy seemed to expect that whenever [she]82-elizabeth came into [Kent]17-kent again [she]82-elizabeth would be staying _ [there]305-there _ too . [His]89-mr. darcy words seemed to imply it . Could [he]89-mr. darcy have [Colonel Fitzwilliam]164-colonel fitzwilliam in [his]89-mr. darcy thoughts ? [She]82-elizabeth supposed , if [he]89-mr. darcy meant anything , [he]89-mr. darcy must mean an allusion to what might arise in [that quarter]1538-that quarter . It distressed [her]82-elizabeth a little , and [she]82-elizabeth was quite glad to find [herself]82-elizabeth at the gate in [the pales opposite [the Parsonage]1285-the parsonage]1539-the pales opposite the parsonage .

[She]82-elizabeth was engaged one day , as [she]82-elizabeth walked , in re - perusing [Jane]83-jane 's last letter , and dwelling on some passages which proved that [Jane]83-jane had not written in spirits , when , instead of being again surprised by [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy , [she]82-elizabeth saw , on looking up , that [Colonel Fitzwilliam]164-colonel fitzwilliam was meeting [her]82-elizabeth . Putting away the letter immediately , and forcing a smile , [she]82-elizabeth said,--

" [I]82-elizabeth did not know before that [you]89-mr. darcy ever walked this way . "[82-elizabeth]

" [I]89-mr. darcy have been making the tour of [the park]1315-the park , "[89-mr. darcy] [he]89-mr. darcy replied , " as [I]89-mr. darcy generally do every year , and intended to close it with a call at [the Parsonage]1285-the parsonage . Are [you]82-elizabeth going much farther ? "[89-mr. darcy]

" No , [I]82-elizabeth should have turned in a moment . "[82-elizabeth]

And accordingly [she]82-elizabeth did turn , and [they]1541-they walked towards [the Parsonage]1285-the parsonage together .

" Do [you]89-mr. darcy certainly leave [Kent]17-kent on Saturday ? "[82-elizabeth] said [she]82-elizabeth .

" Yes -- if [Darcy]89-mr. darcy does not put it off again . But [I]82-elizabeth am at [his]89-mr. darcy disposal . [He]89-mr. darcy arranges the business just as [he]89-mr. darcy pleases . "[82-elizabeth]

" And if not able to please [himself]89-mr. darcy in the arrangement , [he]89-mr. darcy has at least great pleasure in the power of choice . [I]82-elizabeth do not know anybody who seems more to enjoy the power of doing what [he]89-mr. darcy likes than [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy . "[82-elizabeth]

" [He]89-mr. darcy likes to have [his]89-mr. darcy own way very well , "[164-colonel fitzwilliam] replied [Colonel Fitzwilliam]164-colonel fitzwilliam . " But so [we]1541-they all do . It is only that [he]89-mr. darcy has better means of having it than [many others]4157-many others , because [he]89-mr. darcy is rich , and [many others]4157-many others are poor . [I]164-colonel fitzwilliam speak feelingly . [A younger son]4159-a younger son , [you]164-colonel fitzwilliam know , must be inured to self - denial and dependence . "[164-colonel fitzwilliam]

" In [my]82-elizabeth opinion , [the younger son of [an earl]4161-an earl]4160-the younger son of an earl can know very little of either . Now , seriously , what have [you]164-colonel fitzwilliam ever known of self - denial and dependence ? When have [you]164-colonel fitzwilliam been prevented by want of money from going wherever [you]164-colonel fitzwilliam chose or procuring anything [you]164-colonel fitzwilliam had a fancy for ? "[82-elizabeth]

" These are [home]3219-home questions -- and perhaps [I]164-colonel fitzwilliam can not say that [I]164-colonel fitzwilliam have experienced many hardships of that nature . But in matters of greater weight , [I]164-colonel fitzwilliam may suffer from the want of money . [Younger sons]4163-younger sons can not marry where [they]4163-younger sons like . "[164-colonel fitzwilliam]

" Unless where [they]4163-younger sons like [women of fortune]4164-women of fortune , which [I]82-elizabeth think [they]4163-younger sons very often do . "[82-elizabeth]

" [Our]4165-our habits of expense make [us]4165-our too dependent , and there are not many in [my]164-colonel fitzwilliam rank of life who can afford to marry without some attention to money . "[164-colonel fitzwilliam]

" Is this , "[82-elizabeth] thought [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth , " meant for [me]82-elizabeth ? "[82-elizabeth] and [she]82-elizabeth coloured at the idea ; but , recovering [herself]82-elizabeth , said in a lively tone , " And pray , what is the usual price of [[an earl]4161-an earl 's younger son]4167-an earl 's younger son ? Unless [the elder brother]4168-the elder brother is very sickly , [I]82-elizabeth suppose [you]1543-you would not ask above fifty thousand pounds . "[82-elizabeth]

[He]1543-you answered [her]82-elizabeth in the same style , and the subject dropped . To interrupt a silence which might make [him]1543-you fancy [her]82-elizabeth affected with what had passed , [she]82-elizabeth soon afterwards said,--

" [I]82-elizabeth imagine [[your]1543-you cousin]4101-your cousin brought [you]1543-you down with [him]4101-your cousin chiefly for the sake of having [somebody]3598-somebody at [his]4101-your cousin disposal . [I]82-elizabeth wonder [he]4101-your cousin does not marry , to secure a lasting convenience of that kind . But , perhaps , [[his]4101-your cousin sister]559-his sister does as well for the present ; and , as [she]559-his sister is under [his]4101-your cousin sole care , [he]4101-your cousin may do what [he]4101-your cousin likes with [her]559-his sister . "[82-elizabeth]

" No , "[164-colonel fitzwilliam] said [Colonel Fitzwilliam]164-colonel fitzwilliam , " that is an advantage which [he]4101-your cousin must divide with [me]164-colonel fitzwilliam . [I]164-colonel fitzwilliam am joined with [him]4101-your cousin in the guardianship of [Miss Darcy]124-miss darcy . "[164-colonel fitzwilliam]

" Are [you]1543-you , indeed ? And pray what sort of [a guardian]4172-a guardian do [you]1543-you make ? Does [your]1543-you charge give [you]1543-you much trouble ? [Young ladies of [her]124-miss darcy age]4173-young ladies of her age are sometimes a little difficult to manage ; and if [she]124-miss darcy has the true Darcy spirit , [she]124-miss darcy may like to have [her]124-miss darcy own way . "[1544-i]

As [she]1544-i spoke , [she]1544-i observed [him]1545-you looking at [her]1544-i earnestly ; and the manner in which [he]1545-you immediately asked [her]1544-i why [she]1544-i supposed [Miss Darcy]124-miss darcy likely to give [them]1546-them any uneasiness , convinced [her]1544-i that [she]1544-i had somehow or other got pretty near the truth . [She]1544-i directly replied,--

" [You]1545-you need not be frightened . [I]1544-i never heard any harm of [her]124-miss darcy ; and [I]1544-i dare say [she]124-miss darcy is one of the most tractable creatures in [the world]303-the world . [She]124-miss darcy is a very great favourite with [some ladies of [my]1544-i acquaintance]4175-some ladies of my acquaintance , [Mrs. Hurst]90-mrs. hurst and [Miss Bingley]91-miss bingley . [I]1544-i think [I]1544-i have heard [you]1545-you say that [you]1545-you know [them]4175-some ladies of my acquaintance . "[1544-i]

" [I]1544-i know [them]4175-some ladies of my acquaintance a little . [[Their]4175-some ladies of my acquaintance brother]339-their brother is [a pleasant , gentlemanlike man]4177-a pleasant , gentlemanlike man -- [he]339-their brother is [a great friend of [Darcy]124-miss darcy 's]4178-a great friend of darcy 's . "[1544-i]

" Oh yes , "[82-elizabeth] said [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth drily--"Mr . [Darcy]124-miss darcy is uncommonly kind to [Mr. Bingley]79-mr. bingley , and takes a prodigious deal of care of [him]79-mr. bingley . "[1544-i]

" Care of [him]79-mr. bingley ! Yes , [I]1544-i really believe [Darcy]124-miss darcy _ does _ take care of [him]79-mr. bingley in those points where [he]79-mr. bingley most wants care . From something that [he]79-mr. bingley told [me]1544-i in [our]4179-our journey hither , [I]1544-i have reason to think [Bingley]79-mr. bingley very much indebted to [him]79-mr. bingley . But [I]1544-i ought to beg [his]79-mr. bingley pardon , for [I]1544-i have no right to suppose that [Bingley]79-mr. bingley was [the person]4180-the person meant . It was all conjecture . "[1544-i]

" What is it [you]1544-i mean ? "[1544-i]

" It is a circumstance which [Darcy]124-miss darcy of course could not wish to be generally known , because if it were to get round to [[the lady]584-the lady 's family]4182-the lady 's family it would be an unpleasant thing . "[1544-i]

" [You]1544-i may depend upon [my]1544-i not mentioning it . "[1544-i]

" And remember that [I]1544-i have not much reason for supposing it to be [Bingley]79-mr. bingley . What [he]79-mr. bingley told [me]1544-i was merely this : that [he]79-mr. bingley congratulated [himself]79-mr. bingley on having lately saved [a friend]3352-a friend from the inconveniences of a most imprudent marriage , but without mentioning names or any other particulars ; and [I]1544-i only suspected it to be [Bingley]79-mr. bingley from believing [him]79-mr. bingley the kind of young man to get into [a scrape of that sort]4184-a scrape of that sort , and from knowing [them]4185-them to have been together the whole of last summer . "[1544-i]

" Did [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy give [you]1544-i [his]89-mr. darcy reasons for this interference ? "[1544-i]

" [I]1544-i understood that there were some very strong objections against [the lady]584-the lady . "[1544-i]

" And what arts did [he]89-mr. darcy use to separate [them]4185-them ? "[1544-i]

" [He]89-mr. darcy did not talk to [me]89-mr. darcy of [his]89-mr. darcy own arts , "[89-mr. darcy] said [Fitzwilliam]89-mr. darcy , smiling . " [He]89-mr. darcy only told [me]89-mr. darcy what [I]89-mr. darcy have now told [you]82-elizabeth . "[89-mr. darcy]

[Elizabeth]82-elizabeth made no answer , and walked on , [her]82-elizabeth heart swelling with indignation . After watching [her]82-elizabeth a little , [Fitzwilliam]89-mr. darcy asked [her]82-elizabeth why [she]82-elizabeth was so thoughtful .

" [I]82-elizabeth am thinking of what [you]89-mr. darcy have been telling [me]82-elizabeth , "[82-elizabeth] said [she]82-elizabeth . " [[Your]89-mr. darcy cousin]4101-your cousin 's conduct does not suit [my]82-elizabeth feelings . Why was [he]89-mr. darcy to be [the judge]3378-the judge ? "[82-elizabeth]

" [You]89-mr. darcy are rather disposed to call [his]89-mr. darcy interference officious ? "[89-mr. darcy]

" [I]82-elizabeth do not see what right [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy had to decide on the propriety of [[his]89-mr. darcy friend]286-his friend 's inclination ; or why , upon [his]89-mr. darcy own judgment alone , [he]89-mr. darcy was to determine and direct in what manner [that friend]3654-that friend was to be happy . But , "[82-elizabeth] [she]82-elizabeth continued , recollecting [herself]82-elizabeth , " as [we]1547-them know none of the particulars , it is not fair to condemn [him]89-mr. darcy . It is not to be supposed that there was much affection in the case . "[82-elizabeth]

" That is not an unnatural surmise , "[89-mr. darcy] said [Fitzwilliam]89-mr. darcy ; " but it is lessening the honour of [[my]89-mr. darcy cousin]3414-my cousin 's triumph very sadly . "[89-mr. darcy]

This was spoken jestingly , but it appeared to [her]82-elizabeth so just a picture of [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy , that [she]82-elizabeth would not trust [herself]82-elizabeth with an answer ; and , therefore , abruptly changing the conversation , talked on indifferent matters till [they]1547-them reached [the Parsonage]1285-the parsonage . There , shut into [[her]82-elizabeth own room]1549-her own room , as soon as [[their]1547-them visitor]1550-their visitor left [them]1547-them , [she]82-elizabeth could think without interruption of all that [she]82-elizabeth had heard . It was not to be supposed that [any other people]1551-any other people could be meant than [those with whom [she]82-elizabeth was connected]1552-those with whom she was connected . There could not exist in [the world]303-the world _ two _ men over whom [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy could have such boundless influence . That [he]89-mr. darcy had been concerned in the measures taken to separate [Mr. Bingley]79-mr. bingley and [Jane]83-jane , [she]82-elizabeth had never doubted ; but [she]82-elizabeth had always attributed to [Miss Bingley]91-miss bingley the principal design and arrangement of [them]1547-them . If [his]89-mr. darcy own vanity , however , did not mislead [him]89-mr. darcy , _ [he]89-mr. darcy _ was the cause -- [his]89-mr. darcy pride and caprice were the cause -- of all that [Jane]83-jane had suffered , and still continued to suffer . [He]89-mr. darcy had ruined for a while every hope of happiness for the most affectionate , generous heart in [the world]303-the world ; and [no one]3271-no one could say how lasting an evil [he]89-mr. darcy might have inflicted .

" There were some very strong objections against [the lady]584-the lady , "[164-colonel fitzwilliam] were [Colonel Fitzwilliam]164-colonel fitzwilliam 's words ; and these strong objections probably were , [her]82-elizabeth having [one uncle who was [a country attorney]1557-a country attorney , and another who was in business in [London]5-london]1556-one uncle who was a country attorney , and another who was in business in london .

" To [Jane]83-jane [herself]83-jane , "[82-elizabeth] [she]82-elizabeth exclaimed , " there could be no possibility of objection,--all loveliness and goodness as [she]584-the lady is ! [Her]584-the lady understanding excellent , [her]584-the lady mind improved , and [her]584-the lady manners captivating . Neither could anything be urged against [[my]82-elizabeth father]3256-my father , who , though with some peculiarities , has abilities which [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy [himself]89-mr. darcy need not disdain , and respectability which [he]89-mr. darcy will probably never reach . "[82-elizabeth] When [she]82-elizabeth thought of [[her]82-elizabeth mother]241-her mother , indeed , [her]82-elizabeth confidence gave way a little ; but [she]82-elizabeth would not allow that any objections _ there _ had material weight with [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy , whose pride , [she]82-elizabeth was convinced , would receive a deeper wound from the want of importance in [[his]89-mr. darcy friend]286-his friend 's connections than from [their]1560-their want of sense ; and [she]82-elizabeth was quite decided , at last , that [he]89-mr. darcy had been partly governed by this worst kind of pride , and partly by the wish of retaining [Mr. Bingley]79-mr. bingley for [[his]89-mr. darcy sister]559-his sister .

The agitation and tears which the subject occasioned brought on a headache ; and it grew so much worse towards the evening that , added to [her]82-elizabeth unwillingness to see [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy , it determined [her]82-elizabeth not to attend [[her]82-elizabeth cousins]1562-her cousins to [Rosings]20-rosings , where [they]1562-her cousins were engaged to drink tea . [Mrs. Collins]158-mrs. collins , seeing that [she]82-elizabeth was really unwell , did not press [her]82-elizabeth to go , and as much as possible prevented [[her]158-mrs. collins husband]255-her husband from pressing [her]82-elizabeth ; but [Mr. Collins]129-mr. collins could not conceal [his]129-mr. collins apprehension of [Lady Catherine]86-lady catherine 's being rather displeased by [her]86-lady catherine staying at [home]3219-home .

When [they]1565-they were gone , [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth , as if intending to exasperate [herself]82-elizabeth as much as possible against [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy , chose for [her]82-elizabeth employment the examination of all the letters which [Jane]83-jane had written to [her]82-elizabeth since [her]83-jane being in [Kent]17-kent . They contained no actual complaint , nor was there any revival of past occurrences , or any communication of present suffering . But in all , and in almost every line of each , there was a want of that cheerfulness which had been used to characterize [her]82-elizabeth style , and which , proceeding from the serenity of a mind at ease with itself , and kindly disposed towards [everyone]1054-everyone , had been scarcely ever clouded . [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth noticed every sentence conveying the idea of uneasiness , with an attention which it had hardly received on the first perusal . [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy 's shameful boast of what misery [he]89-mr. darcy had been able to inflict gave [her]82-elizabeth a keener sense of [[her]82-elizabeth sister]328-her sister 's sufferings . It was some consolation to think that [his]89-mr. darcy visit to [Rosings]20-rosings was to end on the day after the next , and a still greater that in less than a fortnight [she]82-elizabeth should [herself]82-elizabeth be with [Jane]83-jane again , and enabled to contribute to the recovery of [her]82-elizabeth spirits , by all that affection could do .

[She]82-elizabeth could not think of [Darcy]89-mr. darcy 's leaving [Kent]17-kent without remembering that [[his]89-mr. darcy cousin]704-his cousin was to go with [him]89-mr. darcy ; but [Colonel Fitzwilliam]164-colonel fitzwilliam had made it clear that [he]89-mr. darcy had no intentions at all , and , agreeable as [he]89-mr. darcy was , [she]82-elizabeth did not mean to be unhappy about [him]89-mr. darcy .

While settling this point , [she]82-elizabeth was suddenly roused by the sound of the door - bell ; and [her]82-elizabeth spirits were a little fluttered by the idea of its being [Colonel Fitzwilliam]164-colonel fitzwilliam [himself]164-colonel fitzwilliam , who had [once before called late in the evening]1569-once before called late in the evening , and might now come to inquire particularly after [her]82-elizabeth . But this idea was soon banished , and [her]82-elizabeth spirits were very differently affected , when , to [her]82-elizabeth utter amazement , [she]82-elizabeth saw [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy walk into [the room]250-the room . In a hurried manner [he]89-mr. darcy immediately began an inquiry after [her]82-elizabeth health , imputing [his]89-mr. darcy visit to a wish of hearing that [she]82-elizabeth were better . [She]82-elizabeth answered [him]89-mr. darcy with cold civility . [He]89-mr. darcy sat down for a few moments , and then getting up walked about [the room]250-the room . [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth was surprised , but said not a word . After a silence of several minutes , [he]89-mr. darcy came towards [her]82-elizabeth in an agitated manner , and thus began:--

" In vain have [I]89-mr. darcy struggled . It will not do . [My]89-mr. darcy feelings will not be repressed . [You]82-elizabeth must allow [me]89-mr. darcy to tell [you]82-elizabeth how ardently [I]89-mr. darcy admire and love [you]82-elizabeth . "[89-mr. darcy]

[Elizabeth]82-elizabeth 's astonishment was beyond expression . [She]82-elizabeth stared , coloured , doubted , and was silent . This [he]89-mr. darcy considered sufficient encouragement , and the avowal of all that [he]89-mr. darcy felt and had long felt for [her]82-elizabeth immediately followed . [He]89-mr. darcy spoke well ; but there were feelings besides those of the heart to be detailed , and [he]89-mr. darcy was not more eloquent on the subject of tenderness than of pride . [His]89-mr. darcy sense of [her]82-elizabeth inferiority , of its being a degradation , of the family obstacles which judgment had always opposed to inclination , were dwelt on with a warmth which seemed due to the consequence [he]89-mr. darcy was wounding , but was very unlikely to recommend [his]89-mr. darcy suit .

In spite of [her]82-elizabeth deeply - rooted dislike , [she]82-elizabeth could not be insensible to the compliment of [such a man]225-such a man 's affection , and though [her]82-elizabeth intentions did not vary for an instant , [she]82-elizabeth was at first sorry for the pain [he]89-mr. darcy was to receive ; till roused to resentment by [his]89-mr. darcy subsequent language , [she]82-elizabeth lost all compassion in anger . [She]82-elizabeth tried , however , to compose [herself]82-elizabeth to answer [him]89-mr. darcy with patience , when [he]89-mr. darcy should have done . [He]89-mr. darcy concluded with representing to [her]82-elizabeth the strength of that attachment which in spite of all [his]89-mr. darcy endeavours [he]89-mr. darcy had found impossible to conquer ; and with expressing [his]89-mr. darcy hope that it would now be rewarded by [her]82-elizabeth acceptance of [his]89-mr. darcy hand . As [he]89-mr. darcy said this [she]82-elizabeth could easily see that [he]89-mr. darcy had no doubt of a favourable answer . [He]89-mr. darcy _ spoke _ of apprehension and anxiety , but [his]89-mr. darcy countenance expressed real security . Such a circumstance could only exasperate farther ; and when [he]89-mr. darcy ceased the colour rose into [her]82-elizabeth cheeks and [she]82-elizabeth said,--

" In such cases as this , it is , [I]82-elizabeth believe , the established mode to express a sense of obligation for the sentiments avowed , however unequally they may be returned . It is natural that obligation should be felt , and if [I]82-elizabeth could _ feel _ gratitude , [I]82-elizabeth would now thank [you]89-mr. darcy . But [I]82-elizabeth cannot -- [I]82-elizabeth have never desired [your]89-mr. darcy good opinion , and [you]89-mr. darcy have certainly bestowed it most unwillingly . [I]82-elizabeth am sorry to have occasioned pain to [anyone]3102-anyone . It has been most unconsciously done , however , and [I]82-elizabeth hope will be of short duration . The feelings which [you]89-mr. darcy tell [me]82-elizabeth have long prevented the acknowledgment of [your]89-mr. darcy regard can have little difficulty in overcoming it after this explanation . "[82-elizabeth]

[Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy , who was leaning against the mantel - piece with [his]89-mr. darcy eyes fixed on [her]82-elizabeth face , seemed to catch [her]82-elizabeth words with no less resentment than surprise . [His]89-mr. darcy complexion became pale with anger , and the disturbance of [his]89-mr. darcy mind was visible in every feature . [He]89-mr. darcy was struggling for the appearance of composure , and would not open [his]89-mr. darcy lips till [he]89-mr. darcy believed [himself]89-mr. darcy to have attained it . The pause was to [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth 's feelings dreadful . At length , in a voice of forced calmness , [he]89-mr. darcy said,--

" And this is all the reply which [I]89-mr. darcy am to have the honour of expecting ! [I]89-mr. darcy might , perhaps , wish to be informed why , with so little _ endeavour _ at civility , [I]89-mr. darcy am thus rejected . But it is of small importance . "[89-mr. darcy]

" [I]82-elizabeth might as well inquire , "[82-elizabeth] replied [she]82-elizabeth , " why , with so evident a design of offending and insulting [me]82-elizabeth , [you]89-mr. darcy chose to tell [me]82-elizabeth that [you]89-mr. darcy liked [me]82-elizabeth against [your]89-mr. darcy will , against [your]89-mr. darcy reason , and even against [your]89-mr. darcy character ? Was not this some excuse for incivility , if [I]82-elizabeth _ was _ uncivil ? But [I]82-elizabeth have other provocations . [You]89-mr. darcy know [I]82-elizabeth have . Had not [my]82-elizabeth own feelings decided against [you]89-mr. darcy , had [they]4195-they been indifferent , or had they even been favourable , do [you]89-mr. darcy think that any consideration would tempt [me]82-elizabeth to accept [the man who has been the means of ruining , perhaps for ever]4196-the man who has been the means of ruining , perhaps for ever , the happiness of [a most beloved sister]4197-a most beloved sister ? "[82-elizabeth]

As [she]82-elizabeth pronounced these words , [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy changed colour ; but the emotion was short , and [he]89-mr. darcy listened without attempting to interrupt [her]82-elizabeth while [she]82-elizabeth continued,--

" [I]82-elizabeth have every reason in [the world]303-the world to think ill of [you]89-mr. darcy . No motive can excuse the unjust and ungenerous part [you]89-mr. darcy acted _ there _ . [You]89-mr. darcy dare not , [you]89-mr. darcy can not deny that [you]89-mr. darcy have been the principal , if not the only means of dividing [them]4199-them from [each other]3144-each other , of exposing one to the censure of [the world]303-the world for caprice and instability , the other to its derision for disappointed hopes , and involving [them]4199-them both in misery of the acutest kind . "[82-elizabeth]

[She]82-elizabeth paused , and saw with no slight indignation that [he]89-mr. darcy was listening with an air which proved [him]89-mr. darcy wholly unmoved by any feeling of remorse . [He]89-mr. darcy even looked at [her]82-elizabeth with a smile of affected incredulity .

" Can [you]89-mr. darcy deny that [you]89-mr. darcy have done it ? "[82-elizabeth] [she]82-elizabeth repeated .

With assumed tranquillity [he]89-mr. darcy then replied , " [I]89-mr. darcy have no wish of denying that [I]89-mr. darcy did everything in [my]89-mr. darcy power to separate [[my]89-mr. darcy friend]3353-my friend from [[your]82-elizabeth sister]3139-your sister , or that [I]89-mr. darcy rejoice in [my]89-mr. darcy success . Towards _ [him]3353-my friend _ [I]89-mr. darcy have been kinder than towards [myself]89-mr. darcy . "[89-mr. darcy]

[Elizabeth]82-elizabeth disdained the appearance of noticing this civil reflection , but its meaning did not escape , nor was it likely to conciliate [her]82-elizabeth .

" But it is not merely this affair , "[82-elizabeth] [she]82-elizabeth continued , " on which [my]82-elizabeth dislike is founded . Long before it had taken place , [my]82-elizabeth opinion of [you]89-mr. darcy was decided . [Your]89-mr. darcy character was unfolded in the recital which [I]82-elizabeth received many months ago from [Mr. Wickham]136-wickham . On this subject , what can [you]89-mr. darcy have to say ? In what imaginary act of friendship can [you]89-mr. darcy here defend [yourself]89-mr. darcy ? or under what misrepresentation can [you]89-mr. darcy here impose upon [others]3103-others ? "[82-elizabeth]

" [You]82-elizabeth take an eager interest in [that gentleman]3305-that gentleman 's concerns , "[89-mr. darcy] said [Darcy]89-mr. darcy , in a less tranquil tone , and with a heightened colour .

" Who that knows what [his]3305-that gentleman misfortunes have been can help feeling an interest in [him]3305-that gentleman ? "[82-elizabeth]

" [His]3305-that gentleman misfortunes ! "[89-mr. darcy] repeated [Darcy]89-mr. darcy , contemptuously,--"yes , [his]3305-that gentleman misfortunes have been great indeed . "[89-mr. darcy]

" And of [your]89-mr. darcy infliction , "[82-elizabeth] cried [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth , with energy ; " [You]89-mr. darcy have reduced [him]3305-that gentleman to [his]3305-that gentleman present state of poverty -- comparative poverty . [You]89-mr. darcy have withheld the advantages which [you]89-mr. darcy must know to have been designed for [him]3305-that gentleman . [You]89-mr. darcy have deprived the best years of [his]3305-that gentleman life of that independence which was no less [his]3305-that gentleman due than [his]3305-that gentleman desert . [You]89-mr. darcy have done all this ! and yet [you]89-mr. darcy can treat the mention of [his]3305-that gentleman misfortunes with contempt and ridicule . "[82-elizabeth]

" And this , "[89-mr. darcy] cried [Darcy]89-mr. darcy , as [he]89-mr. darcy walked with quick steps across [the room]250-the room , " is [your]1574-you opinion of [me]89-mr. darcy ! This is the estimation in which [you]1574-you hold [me]89-mr. darcy ! [I]89-mr. darcy thank [you]1574-you for explaining it so fully . [My]89-mr. darcy faults , according to this calculation , are heavy indeed ! But , perhaps , "[89-mr. darcy] added [he]89-mr. darcy , stopping in [his]89-mr. darcy walk , and turning towards [her]1574-you , " these offences might have been overlooked , had not [your]1574-you pride been hurt by [my]89-mr. darcy honest confession of the scruples that had long prevented [my]89-mr. darcy forming any serious design . These bitter accusations might have been suppressed , had [I]89-mr. darcy , with greater policy , concealed [my]89-mr. darcy struggles , and flattered [you]1574-you into the belief of [my]89-mr. darcy being impelled by unqualified , unalloyed inclination ; by reason , by reflection , by everything . But disguise of every sort is [my]89-mr. darcy abhorrence . Nor am [I]89-mr. darcy ashamed of the feelings [I]89-mr. darcy related . They were natural and just . Could [you]1574-you expect [me]89-mr. darcy to rejoice in the inferiority of [your]1574-you connections?--to congratulate [myself]89-mr. darcy on the hope of relations whose condition in life is so decidedly beneath [my]89-mr. darcy own ? "[89-mr. darcy]

[Elizabeth]82-elizabeth felt [herself]82-elizabeth growing more angry every moment ; yet [she]82-elizabeth tried to the utmost to speak with composure when [she]82-elizabeth said,--

" [You]1575-you are mistaken , [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy , if [you]1575-you suppose that the mode of [your]1575-you declaration affected [me]82-elizabeth in any other way than as it spared [me]82-elizabeth the concern which [I]82-elizabeth might have felt in refusing [you]1575-you , had [you]1575-you behaved in a more gentlemanlike manner . "[82-elizabeth]

[She]82-elizabeth saw [him]1575-you start at this ; but [he]1575-you said nothing , and [she]82-elizabeth continued,--

" [You]1575-you could not have made [me]82-elizabeth the offer of [your]1575-you hand in any possible way that would have tempted [me]82-elizabeth to accept it . "[82-elizabeth]

Again [his]1575-you astonishment was obvious ; and [he]1575-you looked at [her]82-elizabeth with an expression of mingled incredulity and mortification . [She]82-elizabeth went on,--

" From the very beginning , from the first moment , [I]82-elizabeth may almost say , of [my]82-elizabeth acquaintance with [you]1575-you , [your]1575-you manners impressing [me]82-elizabeth with the fullest belief of [your]1575-you arrogance , [your]1575-you conceit , and [your]1575-you selfish disdain of the feelings of [others]3103-others , were such as to form that groundwork of disapprobation , on which succeeding events have built so immovable a dislike ; and [I]82-elizabeth had not known [you]1575-you a month before [I]82-elizabeth felt that [you]1575-you were [the last man in [the world]303-the world whom [I]82-elizabeth could ever be prevailed on to marry]4207-the last man in the world whom i could ever be prevailed on to marry . "[82-elizabeth]

" [You]1575-you have said quite enough , [madam]3281-madam . [I]1576-his perfectly comprehend [your]1575-you feelings , and have now only to be ashamed of what [my]1576-his own have been . Forgive [me]1576-his for having taken up so much of [your]1575-you time , and accept [my]1576-his best wishes for [your]1575-you health and happiness . "[1576-his]

And with these words [he]1576-his hastily left [the room]250-the room , and [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth heard [him]1576-his the next moment open the front door and quit [the house]3001-the house . The tumult of [her]82-elizabeth mind was now painfully great . [She]82-elizabeth knew not how to support [herself]82-elizabeth , and , from actual weakness , sat down and cried for half an hour . [Her]82-elizabeth astonishment , as [she]82-elizabeth reflected on what had passed , was increased by every review of it . That [she]82-elizabeth should receive an offer of marriage from [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy ! that [he]1576-his should have been in love with [her]82-elizabeth for so many months ! so much in love as to wish to marry [her]82-elizabeth in spite of all the objections which had made [him]1576-his prevent [[his]1576-his friend]286-his friend 's marrying [[her]286-his friend sister]328-her sister , and which must appear at least with equal force in [his]1576-his own case , was almost incredible ! it was gratifying to have inspired unconsciously so strong an affection . But [his]1576-his pride , [his]1576-his abominable pride , [his]1576-his shameless avowal of what [he]1576-his had done with respect to [Jane]83-jane , [his]1576-his unpardonable assurance in acknowledging , though [he]1576-his could not justify it , and the unfeeling manner which [he]1576-his had mentioned [Mr. Wickham]136-wickham , [his]1576-his cruelty towards whom [he]1576-his had not attempted to deny , soon overcame the pity which the consideration of [his]1576-his attachment had for a moment excited .

[She]82-elizabeth continued in very agitating reflections till the sound of [Lady Catherine]86-lady catherine 's carriage made [her]82-elizabeth feel how unequal [she]82-elizabeth was to encounter [Charlotte]101-charlotte 's observation , and hurried [her]82-elizabeth away to [[her]82-elizabeth room]489-her room .

[Elizabeth]82-elizabeth awoke the next morning to the same thoughts and meditations which had at length closed [her]82-elizabeth eyes . [She]82-elizabeth could not yet recover from the surprise of what had happened : it was impossible to think of anything else ; and , totally indisposed for employment , [she]82-elizabeth resolved soon after breakfast to indulge [herself]82-elizabeth in air and exercise . [She]82-elizabeth was proceeding directly to [her]82-elizabeth favourite walk , when the recollection of [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy 's sometimes coming [there]305-there stopped [her]82-elizabeth , and instead of entering [the park]1315-the park , [she]82-elizabeth turned up [the lane which led [her]82-elizabeth farther from [the turnpike road]1585-the turnpike road]1584-the lane which led her farther from the turnpike road . [The park paling]1586-the park paling was still the boundary on one side , and [she]82-elizabeth soon passed one of the gates into the ground .

After walking two or three times along that part of [the lane]1065-the lane , [she]82-elizabeth was tempted , by the pleasantness of the morning , to stop at the gates and look into [the park]1315-the park . The five weeks which [she]82-elizabeth had now passed in [Kent]17-kent had made a great difference in [the country]448-the country , and every day was adding to the verdure of the early trees . [She]82-elizabeth was on the point of continuing [her]82-elizabeth walk , when [she]82-elizabeth caught a glimpse of [a gentleman within the sort of grove which edged [the park]1315-the park]1590-a gentleman within the sort of grove which edged the park : [he]1590-a gentleman within the sort of grove which edged the park was moving that way ; and fearful of its being [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy , [she]82-elizabeth was directly retreating . But [the person who advanced]1592-the person who advanced was now near enough to see [her]82-elizabeth , and stepping forward with eagerness , pronounced [her]82-elizabeth name . [She]82-elizabeth had turned away ; but on hearing [herself]82-elizabeth called , though in a voice which proved it to be [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy , [she]82-elizabeth moved again towards the gate . [He]1590-a gentleman within the sort of grove which edged the park had by that time reached it also ; and , holding out a letter , which [she]82-elizabeth instinctively took , said , with a look of haughty composure , " [I]82-elizabeth have been walking in [the grove]4210-the grove some time , in the hope of meeting [you]82-elizabeth . Will [you]82-elizabeth do [me]82-elizabeth the honour of reading that letter ? "[82-elizabeth] and then , with a slight bow , turned again into [the plantation]1593-the plantation , and was soon out of sight .

With no expectation of pleasure , but with the strongest curiosity , [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth opened the letter , and to [her]82-elizabeth still increasing wonder , perceived an envelope containing two sheets of letter paper , written quite through , in a very close hand . The envelope itself was likewise full . Pursuing [her]82-elizabeth way along [the lane]1065-the lane , [she]82-elizabeth then began it . It was dated from [Rosings]20-rosings , at eight o'clock in the morning , and was as follows:--

" Be not alarmed , [madam]3281-madam , on receiving this letter , by the apprehension of its containing any repetition of those sentiments , or renewal of those offers , which were last night so disgusting to [you]82-elizabeth . [I]82-elizabeth write without any intention of paining [you]82-elizabeth , or humbling [myself]82-elizabeth , by dwelling on wishes , which , for the happiness of both , can not be too soon forgotten ; and the effort which the formation and the perusal of this letter must occasion , should have been spared , had not [my]82-elizabeth character required it to be written and read . [You]82-elizabeth must , therefore , pardon the freedom with which [I]82-elizabeth demand [your]82-elizabeth attention ; [your]82-elizabeth feelings , [I]82-elizabeth know , will bestow it unwillingly , but [I]82-elizabeth demand it of [your]82-elizabeth justice .[82-elizabeth]

" Two offences of a very different nature , and by no means of equal magnitude , [you]82-elizabeth last night laid to [my]82-elizabeth charge . The first mentioned was , that , regardless of the sentiments of either , [I]82-elizabeth had detached [Mr. Bingley]79-mr. bingley from [your]82-elizabeth sister,--and the other , that [I]82-elizabeth had , in defiance of various claims , in defiance of honour and humanity , ruined the immediate prosperity and blasted the prospects of [Mr. Wickham]136-wickham . Wilfully and wantonly to have thrown off [the companion of [my]82-elizabeth youth]4212-the companion of my youth , [the acknowledged favourite of [[my]82-elizabeth father]3256-my father]4213-the acknowledged favourite of my father , [a young man who had scarcely any other dependence than on [our]4216-our patronage]4215-a young man who had scarcely any other dependence than on our patronage , and [who had been brought up to expect its exertion]4217-who had been brought up to expect its exertion , would be a depravity , to which the separation of [two young persons whose affection could be the growth of only a few weeks]4218-two young persons whose affection could be the growth of only a few weeks , could bear no comparison . But from the severity of that blame which was last night so liberally bestowed , respecting each circumstance , [I]82-elizabeth shall hope to be in future secured , when the following account of [my]82-elizabeth actions and their motives has been read . If , in the explanation of them which is due to [myself]82-elizabeth , [I]82-elizabeth am under the necessity of relating feelings which may be offensive to [yours]82-elizabeth , [I]82-elizabeth can only say that [I]82-elizabeth am sorry . The necessity must be obeyed , and further apology would be absurd . [I]82-elizabeth had not been long in [Hertfordshire]4-hertfordshire before [I]82-elizabeth saw , in common with [others]3103-others , that [Bingley]79-mr. bingley preferred [[your]82-elizabeth elder sister]4220-your elder sister to [any other young woman in [the country]448-the country]4221-any other young woman in the country . But it was not till the evening of the dance at [Netherfield]2-netherfield that [I]82-elizabeth had any apprehension of [his]79-mr. bingley feeling a serious attachment . [I]82-elizabeth had often seen [him]79-mr. bingley in love before . At that ball , while [I]82-elizabeth had the honour of dancing with [you]82-elizabeth , [I]82-elizabeth was first made acquainted , by [Sir William Lucas]80-sir william 's accidental information , that [Bingley]79-mr. bingley 's attentions to [[your]82-elizabeth sister]3139-your sister had given rise to a general expectation of [their]4224-their marriage . [He]79-mr. bingley spoke of it as a certain event , of which the time alone could be undecided . From that moment [I]82-elizabeth observed [[my]82-elizabeth friend]3353-my friend 's behaviour attentively ; and [I]82-elizabeth could then perceive that [his]79-mr. bingley partiality for [Miss Bennet]82-elizabeth was beyond what [I]82-elizabeth had ever witnessed in [him]79-mr. bingley . [[Your]82-elizabeth sister]3139-your sister [I]82-elizabeth also watched .
