[Her]3139-your sister look and manners were open , cheerful , and engaging as ever , but without any symptom of peculiar regard ; and [I]82-elizabeth remained convinced , from the evening 's scrutiny , that though [she]3139-your sister received [his]79-mr. bingley attentions with pleasure , [she]3139-your sister did not invite [them]4227-them by any participation of sentiment . If _ [you]82-elizabeth _ have not been mistaken here , _ [I]82-elizabeth _ must have been in an error . [Your]82-elizabeth superior knowledge of [[your]82-elizabeth sister]3139-your sister must make the latter probable . If it be so , if [I]82-elizabeth have been misled by such error to inflict pain on [her]3139-your sister , [your]82-elizabeth resentment has not been unreasonable . But [I]82-elizabeth shall not scruple to assert , that the serenity of [[your]82-elizabeth sister]3139-your sister 's countenance and air was such as might have given [the most acute observer]4230-the most acute observer a conviction that , however amiable [her]3139-your sister temper , [her]3139-your sister heart was not likely to be easily touched . That [I]82-elizabeth was desirous of believing [her]3139-your sister indifferent is certain ; but [I]82-elizabeth will venture to say that [my]82-elizabeth investigations and decisions are not usually influenced by [my]82-elizabeth hopes or fears . [I]82-elizabeth did not believe [her]3139-your sister to be indifferent because [I]82-elizabeth wished it ; [I]82-elizabeth believed it on impartial conviction , as truly as [I]82-elizabeth wished it in reason . [My]82-elizabeth objections to the marriage were not merely those which [I]82-elizabeth last night acknowledged to have required the utmost force of passion to put aside in [my]82-elizabeth own case ; the want of connection could not be so great an evil to [[my]82-elizabeth friend]3353-my friend as to [me]82-elizabeth . But there were other causes of repugnance ; causes which , though still existing , and existing to an equal degree in both instances , [I]82-elizabeth had [myself]82-elizabeth endeavoured to forget , because they were not immediately before [me]82-elizabeth . These causes must be stated , though briefly . The situation of [[[your]4232-your mother]3715-your mother 's family]4234-your mother 's family , though objectionable , was nothing in comparison of that total want of propriety so frequently , so almost uniformly betrayed by [herself]3715-your mother , by [[your]4232-your three younger sisters]4235-your three younger sisters , and occasionally even by [[your]4232-your father:--pardon]4236-your father:--pardon me,--it pains [me]82-elizabeth to offend [you]4232-your . But amidst [your]4232-your concern for the defects of [[your]4232-your nearest relations]4237-your nearest relations , and [your]4232-your displeasure at this representation of [them]4237-your nearest relations , let it give [you]4232-your consolation to consider that to have conducted [yourselves]4232-your so as to avoid any share of the like censure is praise no less generally bestowed on [you]4232-your and [[your]4232-your eldest sister]4238-your eldest sister than it is honourable to the sense and disposition of both . [I]82-elizabeth will only say , farther , that from what passed that evening [my]82-elizabeth opinion of [all parties]4239-all parties was confirmed , and every inducement heightened , which could have led [me]82-elizabeth before to preserve [[my]82-elizabeth friend]3353-my friend from what [I]82-elizabeth esteemed a most unhappy connection . [He]3353-my friend left [Netherfield]2-netherfield for [London]5-london on the day following , as [you]4232-your , [I]82-elizabeth am certain , remember , with the design of soon returning . The part which [I]82-elizabeth acted is now to be explained . [[His]3353-my friend sisters]282-his sisters ' uneasiness had been equally excited with [my]82-elizabeth own : [our]4242-we coincidence of feeling was soon discovered ; and , alike sensible that no time was to be lost in detaching [[their]282-his sisters brother]339-their brother , [we]4242-we shortly resolved on joining [him]339-their brother directly in [London]5-london . [We]4242-we accordingly went -- and there [I]82-elizabeth readily engaged in the office of pointing out to [[my]82-elizabeth friend]3353-my friend the certain evils of such a choice . [I]82-elizabeth described and enforced [them]282-his sisters earnestly . But however this remonstrance might have staggered or delayed [his]339-their brother determination , [I]82-elizabeth do not suppose that it would ultimately have prevented the marriage , had it not been seconded by the assurance , which [I]82-elizabeth hesitated not in giving , of [[your]3353-my friend sister]3139-your sister 's indifference . [He]339-their brother had before believed [her]3139-your sister to return [his]339-their brother affection with sincere , if not with equal , regard . But [Bingley]79-mr. bingley has great natural modesty , with a stronger dependence on [my]82-elizabeth judgment than on [his]79-mr. bingley own . To convince [him]79-mr. bingley , therefore , that [he]79-mr. bingley had deceived [himself]79-mr. bingley was no very difficult point . To persuade [him]79-mr. bingley against returning into [Hertfordshire]4-hertfordshire , when that conviction had been given , was scarcely the work of a moment . [I]82-elizabeth can not blame [myself]82-elizabeth for having done thus much . There is but one part of [my]82-elizabeth conduct , in the whole affair , on which [I]82-elizabeth do not reflect with satisfaction ; it is that [I]82-elizabeth condescended to adopt the measures of art so far as to conceal from [him]79-mr. bingley [[your]3353-my friend sister]3139-your sister 's being in [town]264-town . [I]82-elizabeth knew it [myself]82-elizabeth , as it was known to [Miss Bingley]91-miss bingley ; but [[her]91-miss bingley brother]3108-her brother is even yet ignorant of it . That [they]4249-they might have met without ill consequence is , perhaps , probable ; but [his]79-mr. bingley regard did not appear to [me]82-elizabeth enough extinguished for [him]79-mr. bingley to see [her]91-miss bingley without some danger . Perhaps this concealment , this disguise , was beneath [me]82-elizabeth . It is done , however , and it was done for the best . On this subject [I]82-elizabeth have nothing more to say , no other apology to offer . If [I]82-elizabeth have wounded [[your]3353-my friend sister]3139-your sister 's feelings , it was unknowingly done ; and though the motives which governed [me]82-elizabeth may to [you]3353-my friend very naturally appear insufficient , [I]82-elizabeth have not yet learnt to condemn them.--With respect to that other , more weighty accusation , of having injured [Mr. Wickham]136-wickham , [I]82-elizabeth can only refute it by laying before [you]3353-my friend the whole of [his]79-mr. bingley connection with [[my]82-elizabeth family]3727-my family . Of what [he]79-mr. bingley has _ particularly _ accused [me]82-elizabeth [I]82-elizabeth am ignorant ; but of the truth of what [I]82-elizabeth shall relate [I]82-elizabeth can summon more than one witness of undoubted veracity . [Mr. Wickham]136-wickham is [the son of [a very respectable man]4253-a very respectable man , who had for many years the management of all [the Pemberley estates]4254-the pemberley estates , and whose good conduct in the discharge of [his]79-mr. bingley trust naturally inclined [[my]82-elizabeth father]3256-my father to be of service to [him]79-mr. bingley]4252-the son of a very respectable man , who had for many years the management of all the pemberley estates , and whose good conduct in the discharge of his trust naturally inclined my father to be of service to him ; and on [George Wickham]143-george wickham , who was [[his]136-wickham godson]4256-his godson , [his]136-wickham kindness was therefore liberally bestowed . [[My]82-elizabeth father]3256-my father supported [him]136-wickham at [school]4258-school , and afterwards at [Cambridge]30-cambridge ; most important assistance , as [[his]136-wickham own father]4259-his own father , always poor from the extravagance of [[his]3256-my father wife]231-his wife , would have been unable to give [him]136-wickham [a gentleman]3407-a gentleman 's education . [[My]82-elizabeth father]3256-my father was not only fond of [this young man]3929-this young man 's society , whose manners were always engaging , [he]3256-my father had also the highest opinion of [him]3929-this young man , and hoping [the church]3524-the church would be [his]3256-my father profession , intended to provide for [him]3256-my father in it . As for [myself]82-elizabeth , it is many , many years since [I]82-elizabeth first began to think of [him]3929-this young man in a very different manner . The vicious propensities , the want of principle , which [he]3256-my father was careful to guard from the knowledge of [[his]3256-my father best friend]3554-his best friend , could not escape the observation of [a young man of nearly the same age]4266-a young man of nearly the same age with [himself]3256-my father , and who had opportunities of seeing [him]3929-this young man in unguarded moments , which [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy could not have . Here again [I]82-elizabeth shall give [you]4267-you pain -- to what degree [you]4267-you only can tell . But whatever may be the sentiments which [Mr. Wickham]136-wickham has created , a suspicion of [their]4268-their nature shall not prevent [me]82-elizabeth from unfolding [his]136-wickham real character . It adds even another motive . [[My]82-elizabeth excellent father]4269-my excellent father died about five years ago ; and [his]136-wickham attachment to [Mr. Wickham]136-wickham was to the last so steady , that in [his]136-wickham will [he]136-wickham particularly recommended it to [me]82-elizabeth to promote [his]136-wickham advancement in the best manner that [his]136-wickham profession might allow , and if [he]136-wickham took orders , desired that [a valuable family]4270-a valuable family living might be [his]136-wickham as soon as [it]4270-a valuable family became vacant . There was also a legacy of one thousand pounds . [[His]136-wickham own father]4259-his own father did not long survive [mine]82-elizabeth ; and within half a year from these events [Mr. Wickham]136-wickham wrote to inform [me]82-elizabeth that , having finally resolved against taking orders , [he]136-wickham hoped [I]82-elizabeth should not think it unreasonable for [him]136-wickham to expect some more immediate pecuniary advantage , in lieu of the preferment , by which [he]136-wickham could not be benefited . [He]136-wickham had some intention , [he]136-wickham added , of studying the law , and [I]82-elizabeth must be aware that the interest of one thousand pounds would be a very insufficient support therein . [I]82-elizabeth rather wished than believed [him]136-wickham to be sincere ; but , at any rate , was perfectly ready to accede to [his]136-wickham proposal . [I]82-elizabeth knew that [Mr. Wickham]136-wickham ought not to be [a clergyman]3429-a clergyman . The business was therefore soon settled . [He]136-wickham resigned all claim to assistance in [the church]3524-the church , were it possible that [he]136-wickham could ever be in a situation to receive it , and accepted in return three thousand pounds . All connection between [us]4274-us seemed now dissolved . [I]82-elizabeth thought too ill of [him]136-wickham to invite [him]136-wickham to [Pemberley]12-pemberley , or admit [[his]136-wickham society]4275-his society in [town]264-town . In [town]264-town , [I]82-elizabeth believe , [he]136-wickham chiefly lived , but [his]136-wickham studying the law was a mere pretence ; and being now free from all restraint , [his]136-wickham life was a life of idleness and dissipation . For about three years [I]82-elizabeth heard little of [him]136-wickham ; but on the decease of [the incumbent of the living]4278-the incumbent of the living which had been designed for [him]136-wickham , [he]136-wickham applied to [me]82-elizabeth again by letter for the presentation . [His]136-wickham circumstances , [he]136-wickham assured [me]82-elizabeth , and [I]82-elizabeth had no difficulty in believing it , were exceedingly bad . [He]136-wickham had found the law a most unprofitable study , and was now absolutely resolved on being ordained , if [I]82-elizabeth would present [him]136-wickham to [the living in question]4279-the living in question -- of which [he]136-wickham trusted there could be little doubt , as [he]136-wickham was well assured that [I]82-elizabeth had [no other person]4280-no other person to provide for , and [I]82-elizabeth could not have forgotten [[my]82-elizabeth revered father]4281-my revered father 's intentions . [You]4282-you will hardly blame [me]82-elizabeth for refusing to comply with this entreaty , or for resisting every repetition of it . [His]136-wickham resentment was in proportion to the distress of [his]136-wickham circumstances -- and [he]136-wickham was doubtless as violent in [his]136-wickham abuse of [me]82-elizabeth to [others]3103-others as in [his]136-wickham reproaches to [myself]82-elizabeth . After this period , every appearance of acquaintance was dropped . How [he]136-wickham lived , [I]82-elizabeth know not . But last summer [he]136-wickham was again most painfully obtruded on [my]82-elizabeth notice . [I]82-elizabeth must now mention a circumstance which [I]82-elizabeth would wish to forget [myself]82-elizabeth , and which no obligation less than the present should induce [me]82-elizabeth to unfold to [any human being]4284-any human being . Having said thus much , [I]82-elizabeth feel no doubt of [your]4282-you secrecy . [[My]82-elizabeth sister , who is more than ten years [my]82-elizabeth junior]4285-my sister , who is more than ten years my junior , was left to the guardianship of [[my]82-elizabeth mother 's nephew]4286-my mother 's nephew , [Colonel Fitzwilliam]164-colonel fitzwilliam , and [myself]82-elizabeth . About a year ago , [she]4285-my sister , who is more than ten years my junior was taken from [school]4258-school , and [an establishment formed for [her]4285-my sister , who is more than ten years my junior in [London]5-london]4288-an establishment formed for her in london ; and last summer [she]4285-my sister , who is more than ten years my junior went with [the lady who presided over it]4289-the lady who presided over it to [Ramsgate]31-ramsgate ; and thither also went [Mr. Wickham]136-wickham , undoubtedly by design ; for there proved to have been a prior acquaintance between [him]136-wickham and [Mrs. Younge]124-miss darcy , in whose character [we]4290-we were most unhappily deceived ; and by [her]124-miss darcy connivance and aid [he]136-wickham so far recommended [himself]136-wickham to [Georgiana]147-georgiana , whose affectionate heart retained a strong impression of [his]136-wickham kindness to [her]147-georgiana as [a child]3569-a child , that [she]147-georgiana was persuaded to believe [herself]147-georgiana in love and to consent to an elopement . [She]147-georgiana was then but fifteen , which must be [her]147-georgiana excuse ; and after stating [her]147-georgiana imprudence , [I]82-elizabeth am happy to add , that [I]82-elizabeth owed the knowledge of it to [herself]147-georgiana . [I]82-elizabeth joined [them]4292-them unexpectedly a day or two before the intended elopement ; and then [Georgiana]147-georgiana , unable to support the idea of grieving and offending [a brother whom [she]147-georgiana almost looked up to as [a father]3245-a father]4293-a brother whom she almost looked up to as a father , acknowledged the whole to [me]82-elizabeth . [You]4295-you may imagine what [I]82-elizabeth felt and how [I]82-elizabeth acted . Regard for [[my]82-elizabeth sister]3280-my sister 's credit and feelings prevented any public exposure ; but [I]82-elizabeth wrote to [Mr. Wickham]136-wickham , who left [the place]2998-the place immediately , and [Mrs. Younge]124-miss darcy was of course removed from [her]124-miss darcy charge . [Mr. Wickham]136-wickham 's chief object was unquestionably [[my]82-elizabeth sister]3280-my sister 's fortune , which is thirty thousand pounds ; but [I]82-elizabeth can not help supposing that the hope of revenging [himself]136-wickham on [me]82-elizabeth was a strong inducement . [His]136-wickham revenge would have been complete indeed . This , [madam]3281-madam , is a faithful narrative of every event in which [we]4300-we have been concerned together ; and if [you]4295-you do not absolutely reject it as false , [you]4295-you will , [I]82-elizabeth hope , acquit [me]82-elizabeth henceforth of cruelty towards [Mr. Wickham]136-wickham . [I]82-elizabeth know not in what manner , under what form of falsehood , [he]136-wickham has imposed on [you]4295-you ; but [his]136-wickham success is not perhaps to be wondered at , ignorant as [you]4295-you previously were of everything concerning either . [Detection]167-detection could not be in [your]4295-you power , and suspicion certainly not in [your]4295-you inclination . [You]4295-you may possibly wonder why all this was not told [you]4295-you last night . But [I]82-elizabeth was not then master enough of [myself]82-elizabeth to know what could or ought to be revealed . For the truth of everything here related , [I]82-elizabeth can appeal more particularly to the testimony of [Colonel Fitzwilliam]164-colonel fitzwilliam , who , from [our]4300-we near relationship and constant intimacy , and still more as [one of the executors of [[my]82-elizabeth father]3256-my father 's will]4301-one of the executors of my father 's will , has been unavoidably acquainted with every particular of these transactions . If [your]4295-you abhorrence of _ [me]82-elizabeth _ should make _ [my]82-elizabeth _ assertions valueless , [you]4295-you can not be prevented by the same cause from confiding in [[my]82-elizabeth cousin]3414-my cousin ; and that there may be the possibility of consulting [him]3414-my cousin , [I]82-elizabeth shall endeavour to find some opportunity of putting this letter in [your]4295-you hands in the course of the morning . [I]82-elizabeth will only add , God bless [you]4295-you .[82-elizabeth]

" [FITZWILLIAM DARCY]89-mr. darcy . "[82-elizabeth]

[Elizabeth]82-elizabeth , when [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy gave [her]82-elizabeth the letter , did not expect it to contain a renewal of [his]89-mr. darcy offers , [she]82-elizabeth had formed no expectation at all of its contents . But such as they were , it may be well supposed how eagerly [she]82-elizabeth went through them , and what a contrariety of emotion [they]1595-they excited . [Her]82-elizabeth feelings as [she]82-elizabeth read were scarcely to be defined . With amazement did [she]82-elizabeth first understand that [he]89-mr. darcy believed any apology to be in [his]89-mr. darcy power ; and steadfastly was [she]82-elizabeth persuaded , that [he]89-mr. darcy could have no explanation to give , which a just sense of shame would not conceal . With a strong prejudice against everything [he]89-mr. darcy might say , [she]82-elizabeth began [his]89-mr. darcy account of what had happened at [Netherfield]2-netherfield . [She]82-elizabeth read with an eagerness which hardly left [her]82-elizabeth power of comprehension ; and from impatience of knowing what the next sentence might bring , was incapable of attending to the sense of the one before [her]82-elizabeth eyes . [His]89-mr. darcy belief of [[her]82-elizabeth sister]328-her sister 's insensibility [she]82-elizabeth instantly resolved to be false ; and [his]89-mr. darcy account of the real , the worst objections to the match , made [her]82-elizabeth too angry to have any wish of doing [him]89-mr. darcy justice . [He]89-mr. darcy expressed no regret for what [he]89-mr. darcy had done which satisfied [her]82-elizabeth ; [his]89-mr. darcy style was not penitent , but haughty . It was all pride and insolence .

But when this subject was succeeded by [his]89-mr. darcy account of [Mr. Wickham]136-wickham -- when [she]82-elizabeth read , with somewhat clearer attention , a relation of events which , if true , must overthrow every cherished opinion of [his]89-mr. darcy worth , and which bore so alarming an affinity to [his]89-mr. darcy own history of [himself]89-mr. darcy -- [her]82-elizabeth feelings were yet more acutely painful and more difficult of definition . Astonishment , apprehension , and even horror , oppressed [her]82-elizabeth . [She]82-elizabeth wished to discredit it entirely , repeatedly exclaiming , " This must be false ! This can not be ! This must be the grossest falsehood!"--and[82-elizabeth] when [she]82-elizabeth had gone through the whole letter , though scarcely knowing anything of the last page or two , put it hastily away , protesting that [she]82-elizabeth would not regard it , that [she]82-elizabeth would never look in it again .

In this perturbed state of mind , with thoughts that could rest on nothing , [she]82-elizabeth walked on ; but it would not do : in half a minute the letter was unfolded again ; and collecting [herself]82-elizabeth as well as [she]82-elizabeth could , [she]82-elizabeth again began the mortifying perusal of all that related to [Wickham]136-wickham , and commanded [herself]82-elizabeth so far as to examine the meaning of every sentence . The account of [his]89-mr. darcy connection with [the Pemberley family]1597-the pemberley family was exactly what [he]89-mr. darcy had related [himself]89-mr. darcy ; and the kindness of [the late Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy , though [she]82-elizabeth had not before known its extent , agreed equally well with [his]89-mr. darcy own words . So far each recital confirmed the other ; but when [she]82-elizabeth came to the will , the difference was great . What [Wickham]136-wickham had said of [the living]3652-the living was fresh in [her]82-elizabeth memory ; and as [she]82-elizabeth recalled [his]136-wickham very words , it was impossible not to feel that there was gross duplicity on one side or the other , and , for a few moments , [she]82-elizabeth flattered [herself]82-elizabeth that [her]82-elizabeth wishes did not err . But when [she]82-elizabeth read and re - read , with the closest attention , the particulars immediately following of [Wickham]136-wickham 's resigning all pretensions to the living , of [his]89-mr. darcy receiving in lieu so considerable a sum as three thousand pounds , again was [she]82-elizabeth forced to hesitate . [She]82-elizabeth put down the letter , weighed every circumstance with what [she]82-elizabeth meant to be impartiality -- deliberated on the probability of each statement -- but with little success . On both sides it was only assertion . Again [she]82-elizabeth read on . But every line proved more clearly that the affair , which [she]82-elizabeth had believed it impossible that any contrivance could so represent as to render [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy 's conduct in it less than infamous , was capable of a turn which must make [him]89-mr. darcy entirely blameless throughout the whole .

The extravagance and general profligacy which [he]89-mr. darcy scrupled not to lay to [Mr. Wickham]136-wickham 's charge exceedingly shocked [her]82-elizabeth ; the more so , as [she]82-elizabeth could bring no proof of its injustice . [She]82-elizabeth had never heard of [him]89-mr. darcy before [his]89-mr. darcy entrance into the ----shire militia , in which [he]89-mr. darcy had engaged at the persuasion of [the young man]764-the young man , who , on meeting [him]89-mr. darcy accidentally in [town]264-town , had there renewed a slight acquaintance . Of [his]89-mr. darcy former way of life , nothing had been known in [Hertfordshire]4-hertfordshire but what [he]89-mr. darcy told

[himself]89-mr. darcy . As to [his]89-mr. darcy real character , had information been in [her]82-elizabeth power , [she]82-elizabeth had never felt a wish of inquiring . [His]89-mr. darcy countenance , voice , and manner , had established [him]89-mr. darcy at once in the possession of every virtue . [She]82-elizabeth tried to recollect some instance of goodness , some distinguished trait of integrity or benevolence , that might rescue [him]89-mr. darcy from the attacks of [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy ; or at least , by the predominance of virtue , atone for those casual errors , under which [she]82-elizabeth would endeavour to class what [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy had described as the idleness and vice of many years ' continuance . But no such recollection befriended [her]82-elizabeth . [She]82-elizabeth could see [him]89-mr. darcy instantly before [her]82-elizabeth , in every charm of air and address , but [she]82-elizabeth could remember no more substantial good than the general approbation of [the neighbourhood]3015-the neighbourhood , and the regard which [his]89-mr. darcy social powers had gained [him]89-mr. darcy in the mess . After pausing on this point a considerable while , [she]82-elizabeth once more continued to read . But , alas ! the story which followed , of [his]89-mr. darcy designs on [Miss Darcy]124-miss darcy , received some confirmation from what had passed between [Colonel Fitzwilliam]164-colonel fitzwilliam and [herself]82-elizabeth only the morning before ; and at last [she]82-elizabeth was referred for the truth of every particular to [Colonel Fitzwilliam]164-colonel fitzwilliam [himself]164-colonel fitzwilliam -- from whom [she]82-elizabeth had previously received the information of [his]89-mr. darcy near concern in all [[his]89-mr. darcy cousin]704-his cousin 's affairs and whose character [she]82-elizabeth had no reason to question . At one time [she]82-elizabeth had almost resolved on applying to [him]89-mr. darcy , but the idea was checked by the awkwardness of the application , and at length wholly banished by the conviction that [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy would never have hazarded such a proposal , if [he]89-mr. darcy had not been well assured of [[his]89-mr. darcy cousin]704-his cousin 's corroboration .

[She]82-elizabeth perfectly remembered everything that had passed in conversation between [Wickham]136-wickham and [herself]82-elizabeth in [their]1604-their first evening at [[Mr. Philips]110-philips 's]1605-mr. philips 's . Many of [his]89-mr. darcy expressions were still fresh in [her]82-elizabeth memory . [She]82-elizabeth was _ now _ struck with the impropriety of such communications to [a stranger]3408-a stranger , and wondered it had escaped [her]82-elizabeth before . [She]82-elizabeth saw the indelicacy of putting [himself]89-mr. darcy forward as [he]89-mr. darcy had done , and the inconsistency of [his]89-mr. darcy professions with [his]89-mr. darcy conduct . [She]82-elizabeth remembered that [he]89-mr. darcy had boasted of having no fear of seeing [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy -- that [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy might leave [the country]448-the country , but that _ [he]89-mr. darcy _ should stand [his]89-mr. darcy ground ; yet [he]89-mr. darcy had avoided the Netherfield ball the very next week . [She]82-elizabeth remembered , also , that till [the Netherfield family]2-netherfield had quitted [the country]448-the country , [he]89-mr. darcy had told [his]89-mr. darcy story to [no one]3271-no one but [herself]82-elizabeth ; but that after [their]1610-their removal , it had been everywhere discussed ; that [he]89-mr. darcy had then no reserves , no scruples in sinking [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy 's character , though [he]89-mr. darcy had assured [her]82-elizabeth that respect for [the father]261-the father would always prevent [his]89-mr. darcy exposing [the son]1612-the son .

How differently did everything now appear in which [he]89-mr. darcy was concerned ! [His]89-mr. darcy attentions to [Miss King]93-miss king were now the consequence of views solely and hatefully mercenary ; and the mediocrity of [her]82-elizabeth fortune proved no longer the moderation of [his]89-mr. darcy wishes , but [his]89-mr. darcy eagerness to grasp at anything . [His]89-mr. darcy behaviour to [herself]82-elizabeth could now have had no tolerable motive : [he]89-mr. darcy had either been deceived with regard to [her]82-elizabeth fortune , or had been gratifying [his]89-mr. darcy vanity by encouraging the preference which [she]82-elizabeth believed [she]82-elizabeth had most incautiously shown . Every lingering struggle in [his]89-mr. darcy favour grew fainter and fainter ; and in further justification of [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy , [she]82-elizabeth could not but allow that [Mr. Bingley]79-mr. bingley , when questioned by [Jane]83-jane , had long ago asserted [his]79-mr. bingley blamelessness in the affair;--that , proud and repulsive as were [his]79-mr. bingley manners , [she]82-elizabeth had never , in the whole course of [their]1613-their acquaintance -- an acquaintance which had latterly brought [them]1613-their much together , and given [her]82-elizabeth a sort of intimacy with [his]79-mr. bingley ways -- seen anything that betrayed [him]79-mr. bingley to be unprincipled or unjust -- anything that spoke [him]79-mr. bingley of irreligious or immoral habits;--that among [his]79-mr. bingley own connections [he]79-mr. bingley was esteemed and valued;--that even [Wickham]136-wickham had allowed [him]79-mr. bingley merit as [a brother]440-a brother , and that [she]82-elizabeth had often heard [him]79-mr. bingley speak so affectionately of [[his]79-mr. bingley sister]559-his sister as to prove [him]79-mr. bingley capable of some amiable feeling;--that had [his]79-mr. bingley actions been what [Wickham]136-wickham represented [them]1616-them , so gross a violation of everything right could hardly have been concealed from [the world]303-the world ; and that friendship between [a person capable of it]1618-a person capable of it and such [an amiable man]1619-an amiable man as [Mr. Bingley]79-mr. bingley was incomprehensible .

[She]82-elizabeth grew absolutely ashamed of [herself]82-elizabeth . Of neither [Darcy nor Wickham]168-darcy nor wickham could [she]82-elizabeth think , without feeling that [she]82-elizabeth had been blind , partial , prejudiced , absurd .

" How despicably have [I]82-elizabeth acted ! "[82-elizabeth] [she]82-elizabeth cried . " [I]82-elizabeth , who have prided [myself]82-elizabeth on [my]82-elizabeth discernment ! [I]82-elizabeth , who have valued [myself]82-elizabeth on [my]82-elizabeth abilities ! who have often disdained the generous candour of [[my]82-elizabeth sister]3280-my sister , and gratified [my]82-elizabeth vanity in useless or blameless distrust . How humiliating is this discovery ! Yet , how just a humiliation ! Had [I]82-elizabeth been in love , [I]82-elizabeth could not have been more wretchedly blind . But vanity , not love , has been [my]82-elizabeth folly . Pleased with the preference of one , and offended by the neglect of the other , on the very beginning of [our]4305-our acquaintance , [I]82-elizabeth have courted prepossession and ignorance , and driven reason away where either were concerned . Till this moment , [I]82-elizabeth never knew [myself]82-elizabeth . "[82-elizabeth]

From [herself]82-elizabeth to [Jane]83-jane , from [Jane]83-jane to [Bingley]79-mr. bingley , [her]82-elizabeth thoughts were in a line which soon brought to [her]82-elizabeth recollection that [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy 's explanation _ there _ had appeared very insufficient ; and [she]82-elizabeth read it again . Widely different was the effect of a second perusal . How could [she]82-elizabeth deny that credit to [his]89-mr. darcy assertions , in one instance , which [she]82-elizabeth had been obliged to give in the other ? [He]89-mr. darcy declared [himself]89-mr. darcy to have been totally unsuspicious of [[her]82-elizabeth sister]328-her sister 's attachment ; and [she]82-elizabeth could not help remembering what [Charlotte]101-charlotte 's opinion had always been . Neither could [she]82-elizabeth deny the justice of [his]89-mr. darcy description of [Jane]83-jane . [She]82-elizabeth felt that [Jane]83-jane 's feelings , though fervent , were little displayed , and that there was a constant complacency in [her]83-jane air and manner , not often united with great sensibility .

When [she]82-elizabeth came to that part of the letter in which [[her]82-elizabeth family]885-her family were mentioned , in tones of such mortifying , yet merited , reproach , [her]82-elizabeth sense of shame was severe . The justice of the charge struck [her]82-elizabeth too forcibly for denial ; and the circumstances to which [he]89-mr. darcy particularly alluded , as having passed at the Netherfield ball , and as confirming all [his]89-mr. darcy first disapprobation , could not have made a stronger impression on [his]89-mr. darcy mind than on [hers]82-elizabeth .

The compliment to [herself]82-elizabeth and [[her]82-elizabeth sister]328-her sister was not unfelt . It soothed , but it could not console [her]82-elizabeth for the contempt which had been thus self - attracted by [the rest of [[her]82-elizabeth family]885-her family]1623-the rest of her family ; and as [she]82-elizabeth considered that [Jane]83-jane 's disappointment had , in fact , been the work of [[her]83-jane nearest relations]1625-her nearest relations , and reflected how materially the credit of both must be hurt by such impropriety of conduct , [she]82-elizabeth felt depressed beyond anything [she]82-elizabeth had ever known before .

After wandering along [the lane]1065-the lane for two hours , giving way to every variety of thought , reconsidering events , determining probabilities , and reconciling [herself]82-elizabeth , as well as [she]82-elizabeth could , to a change so sudden and so important , fatigue , and a recollection of [her]82-elizabeth long absence , made [her]82-elizabeth at length return [home]3219-home ; and [she]82-elizabeth entered [the house]3001-the house with the wish of appearing cheerful as usual , and the resolution of repressing such reflections as must make [her]82-elizabeth unfit for conversation .

[She]82-elizabeth was immediately told , that [the two gentlemen from [Rosings]20-rosings]1629-the two gentlemen from rosings had each called during [her]82-elizabeth absence ; [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy , only for a few minutes , to take leave , but that [Colonel Fitzwilliam]164-colonel fitzwilliam had been sitting with [them]1629-the two gentlemen from rosings at least an hour , hoping for [her]82-elizabeth return , and almost resolving to walk after [her]82-elizabeth till [she]82-elizabeth could be found . [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth could but just _ affect _ concern in missing [him]164-colonel fitzwilliam ; [she]82-elizabeth really rejoiced at it . [Colonel Fitzwilliam]164-colonel fitzwilliam was no longer an object . [She]82-elizabeth could think only of [her]82-elizabeth letter .

[The two gentlemen]760-the two gentlemen left [Rosings]20-rosings the next morning ; and [Mr. Collins]129-mr. collins having been in waiting near [the lodges]1446-the lodges , to make [them]760-the two gentlemen [his]129-mr. collins parting obeisance , was able to bring home the pleasing intelligence of [their]760-the two gentlemen appearing in very good health , and in as tolerable spirits as could be expected , after the melancholy scene so lately gone through at [Rosings]20-rosings . To [Rosings]20-rosings [he]129-mr. collins then hastened to console [Lady Catherine]86-lady catherine and [[her]86-lady catherine daughter]463-her daughter ; and on [his]129-mr. collins return brought back , with great satisfaction , a message from [[her]86-lady catherine Ladyship]3464-her ladyship , importing that [she]86-lady catherine felt [herself]86-lady catherine so dull as to make [her]86-lady catherine very desirous of having [them]760-the two gentlemen all to dine with [her]86-lady catherine .

[Elizabeth]82-elizabeth could not see [Lady Catherine]86-lady catherine without recollecting that , had [she]82-elizabeth chosen it , [she]82-elizabeth might by this time have been presented to [her]86-lady catherine as [[her]82-elizabeth future niece]1634-her future niece ; nor could [she]82-elizabeth think , without a smile , of what [[her]82-elizabeth Ladyship]3464-her ladyship 's indignation would have been . " What would [she]86-lady catherine have said ? how would [she]86-lady catherine have behaved ? "[82-elizabeth] were the questions with which [she]82-elizabeth amused [herself]82-elizabeth .

[Their]1636-their first subject was the diminution of [the Rosings]1637-the rosings ' party . " [I]86-lady catherine assure [you]4306-you , [I]86-lady catherine feel it exceedingly , "[86-lady catherine] said [Lady Catherine]86-lady catherine ; " [I]86-lady catherine believe [nobody]3077-nobody feels the loss of [friends]3787-friends so much as [I]86-lady catherine do . But [I]86-lady catherine am particularly attached to [these young men]4309-these young men ; and know [them]4309-these young men to be so much attached to [me]86-lady catherine ! [They]4309-these young men were excessively sorry to go ! But so [they]4309-these young men always are . [The dear Colonel]4310-the dear colonel rallied [his]4310-the dear colonel spirits tolerably till just at last ; but [Darcy]89-mr. darcy seemed to feel it most acutely -- more , [I]86-lady catherine think , than last year . [His]89-mr. darcy attachment to [Rosings]20-rosings certainly increases . "[86-lady catherine]

[Mr. Collins]129-mr. collins had a compliment and an allusion to throw in here , which were kindly smiled on by [the mother]395-the mother and [daughter]4036-daughter .

[Lady Catherine]86-lady catherine observed , after dinner , that [Miss Bennet]82-elizabeth seemed out of spirits ; and immediately accounting for it [herself]86-lady catherine , by supposing that [she]82-elizabeth did not like to go [home]3219-home again so soon , [she]86-lady catherine added,--

" But if that is the case , [you]4036-daughter must write to [[your]4036-daughter mother]3715-your mother to beg that [you]4036-daughter may stay a little longer . [Mrs. Collins]158-mrs. collins will be very glad of [your]4036-daughter company , [I]86-lady catherine am sure . "[86-lady catherine]

" [I]82-elizabeth am much obliged to [[your]4036-daughter Ladyship]4084-your ladyship for [your]4036-daughter kind invitation , "[82-elizabeth] replied [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth ; " but it is not in [my]82-elizabeth power to accept it . [I]82-elizabeth must be in [town]264-town next Saturday . "[82-elizabeth]

" Why , at that rate , [you]4036-daughter will have been [here]2994-here only six weeks . [I]86-lady catherine expected [you]4036-daughter to stay two months . [I]86-lady catherine told [Mrs. Collins]158-mrs. collins so before [you]4036-daughter came . There can be no occasion for [your]4036-daughter going so soon . " But [[my]82-elizabeth father]3256-my father can not . [He]3256-my father wrote last week to hurry [my]82-elizabeth return . "[82-elizabeth]

[Daughters]3439-daughters are never of so much consequence to [a father]3245-a father . "[86-lady catherine]

" [You]4036-daughter are all kindness , [madam]3281-madam ; but [I]82-elizabeth believe [we]4323-we must abide by [our]4323-we original plan . "[82-elizabeth]

[Lady Catherine]86-lady catherine seemed resigned . " [Mrs. Collins]158-mrs. collins , [you]158-mrs. collins must send [a servant]499-a servant with [them]4036-daughter . [Young women]4328-young women should always be properly guarded and attended , according to [their]4328-young women situation in life . [Lady Catherine]86-lady catherine had many other questions to ask respecting [their]1641-their journey ; and as [she]86-lady catherine did not answer [them]1642-them all [herself]86-lady catherine attention was necessary -- which [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth believed to be lucky for [her]86-lady catherine ; or , with a mind so occupied , [she]86-lady catherine might have forgotten where [she]86-lady catherine was . Reflection must be reserved for solitary hours : whenever [she]86-lady catherine was alone , [she]86-lady catherine gave way to it as the greatest relief ; and not a day went by without a solitary walk , in which [she]86-lady catherine might indulge in all the delight of unpleasant recollections .

[Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy 's letter [she]86-lady catherine was in a fair way of soon knowing by heart . [She]86-lady catherine studied every sentence ; and [her]86-lady catherine feelings towards [its writer]669-its writer were at times widely different . When [she]86-lady catherine remembered the style of [his]89-mr. darcy address , [she]86-lady catherine was still full of indignation : but when [she]86-lady catherine considered how unjustly [she]86-lady catherine had condemned and upbraided [him]89-mr. darcy , [her]86-lady catherine anger was turned against [herself]86-lady catherine ; and [his]89-mr. darcy disappointed feelings became the object of compassion . [His]89-mr. darcy attachment excited gratitude , [his]89-mr. darcy general character respect : but [she]86-lady catherine could not approve [him]89-mr. darcy ; nor could [she]86-lady catherine for a moment repent [her]86-lady catherine refusal , or feel the slightest inclination ever to see [him]89-mr. darcy again . In [her]86-lady catherine own past behaviour , there was a constant source of vexation and regret : and in the unhappy defects of [[her]86-lady catherine family]885-her family , a subject of yet heavier chagrin . [They]885-her family were hopeless of remedy . [[Her]86-lady catherine father]244-her father , contented with laughing at [them]885-her family , would never exert [himself]244-her father to restrain the wild giddiness of [[his]244-her father youngest daughters]1646-his youngest daughters ; and [[her]86-lady catherine mother]241-her mother , with manners so far from right [herself]241-her mother , was entirely insensible of the evil . [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth had frequently united with [Jane]83-jane in an endeavour to check the imprudence of [Catherine]86-lady catherine and [Lydia]84-lydia ; but while [they]885-her family were supported by [[their]885-her family mother]434-their mother 's indulgence , what chance could there be of improvement ? [Catherine]86-lady catherine , weak - spirited , irritable , and completely under [Lydia]84-lydia 's guidance , had been always affronted by [their]885-her family advice ; and [Lydia]84-lydia , self - willed and careless , would scarcely give [them]885-her family a hearing . [They]885-her family were ignorant , idle , and vain . While there was [an officer in [Meryton]9-meryton]1649-an officer in meryton , [they]885-her family would flirt with [him]1649-an officer in meryton ; and while [Meryton]9-meryton was within a walk of [Longbourn]7-longbourn , [they]885-her family would be going [there]305-there for ever .

Anxiety on [Jane]83-jane 's behalf was another prevailing concern ; and [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy 's explanation , by restoring [Bingley]79-mr. bingley to all [her]83-jane former good opinion , heightened the sense of what [Jane]83-jane had lost . [His]89-mr. darcy affection was proved to have been sincere , and [his]89-mr. darcy conduct cleared of all blame , unless any could attach to the implicitness of [his]89-mr. darcy confidence in [[his]89-mr. darcy friend]286-his friend . How grievous then was the thought that , of a situation so desirable in every respect , so replete with advantage , so promising for happiness , [Jane]83-jane had been deprived , by the folly and indecorum of [[her]83-jane own family]4142-her own family !

When to these recollections was added the development of [Wickham]136-wickham 's character , it may be easily believed that the happy spirits which had seldom been depressed before were now so much affected as to make it almost impossible for [her]83-jane to appear tolerably cheerful .

[Their]885-her family engagements at Rosings were as frequent during the last week of [her]83-jane stay as they had been at first . The very last evening was spent [there]305-there ; and [[her]83-jane Ladyship]3464-her ladyship again inquired minutely into the particulars of [their]885-her family journey , gave [them]885-her family directions as to the best method of packing , and was so urgent on the necessity of placing gowns in the only right way , that [Maria]94-maria thought [herself]94-maria obliged , on [her]94-maria return , to undo all the work of the morning , and pack [her]94-maria trunk afresh .

When [they]885-her family parted , [Lady Catherine]86-lady catherine , with great condescension , wished [them]885-her family a good journey , and invited [them]885-her family to come to [Hunsford]15-hunsford again next year ; and [Miss de Bourgh]132-miss de bourgh exerted [herself]132-miss de bourgh so far as to courtesy and hold out [her]132-miss de bourgh hand to [both]774-both .

On Saturday morning [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth and [Mr. Collins]129-mr. collins met for breakfast a few minutes before [the others]507-the others appeared ; and [he]129-mr. collins took the opportunity of paying the parting civilities which [he]129-mr. collins deemed indispensably necessary .

" [I]129-mr. collins know not , [Miss Elizabeth]82-elizabeth , "[129-mr. collins] said [he]129-mr. collins , " whether [Mrs. Collins]158-mrs. collins has yet expressed [her]158-mrs. collins sense of [your]82-elizabeth kindness in coming to [us]885-her family ; but [I]129-mr. collins am very certain [you]82-elizabeth will not leave [the house]3001-the house without receiving [her]158-mrs. collins thanks for it . The favour of [your]82-elizabeth company has been much felt , [I]129-mr. collins assure [you]82-elizabeth . [We]885-her family know how little there is to tempt [anyone]3102-anyone to [[our]885-her family humble abode]4342-our humble abode . [Our]885-her family plain manner of living , [[our]885-her family small rooms]4343-our small rooms , and few domestics , and the little [we]885-her family see of [the world]303-the world , must make [Hunsford]15-hunsford extremely dull to [a young lady like [yourself]82-elizabeth]3672-a young lady like yourself ; but [I]129-mr. collins hope [you]82-elizabeth will believe [us]885-her family grateful for the condescension , and that [we]885-her family have done everything in [our]885-her family power to prevent [you]82-elizabeth spending [your]82-elizabeth time unpleasantly . "[129-mr. collins]

[Elizabeth]82-elizabeth was eager with [her]82-elizabeth thanks and assurances of happiness . [She]82-elizabeth had spent six weeks with great enjoyment ; and the pleasure of being with [Charlotte]101-charlotte , and the kind attention [she]101-charlotte had received , must make _ [her]82-elizabeth _ feel the obliged . [Mr. Collins]129-mr. collins was gratified ; and with a more smiling solemnity replied,--

" It gives [me]129-mr. collins the greatest pleasure to hear that [you]82-elizabeth have passed [your]82-elizabeth time not disagreeably . [We]885-her family have certainly done [our]885-her family best ; and most fortunately having it in [our]885-her family power to introduce [you]82-elizabeth to very superior society , and from [our]885-her family connection with Rosings , the frequent means of varying the humble home scene , [I]129-mr. collins think [we]885-her family may flatter [ourselves]885-her family that [your]82-elizabeth Hunsford visit can not have been entirely irksome . [Our]885-her family situation with regard to [[Lady Catherine]86-lady catherine 's family]4346-lady catherine 's family is , indeed , the sort of extraordinary advantage and blessing which few can boast . [You]82-elizabeth see on what a footing [we]885-her family are . [You]82-elizabeth see how continually [we]885-her family are engaged [there]305-there . In truth , [I]129-mr. collins must acknowledge , that , with all the disadvantages of [this humble parsonage]4348-this humble parsonage , [I]129-mr. collins should not think anyone abiding in it an object of compassion , while [they]4349-they are sharers of [our]885-her family intimacy at Rosings . "[129-mr. collins]

Words were insufficient for the elevation of [his]1657-my feelings ; and [he]1657-my was obliged to walk about [the room]250-the room , while [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth tried to unite civility and truth in a few short sentences .

" [You]82-elizabeth may , in fact , carry a very favourable report of [us]885-her family into [Hertfordshire]4-hertfordshire , [[my]1657-my dear cousin]3731-my dear cousin . [I]1657-my flatter [myself]1657-my , at least , that [you]82-elizabeth will be able to do so . [Lady Catherine]86-lady catherine 's great attentions to [Mrs. Collins]158-mrs. collins [you]82-elizabeth have been a daily witness of ; and altogether [I]1657-my trust it does not appear that [[your]82-elizabeth friend]3040-your friend has drawn an unfortunate -- but on this point it will be as well to be silent . Only let [me]1657-my assure [you]82-elizabeth , [[my]1657-my dear]2993-my dear [Miss Elizabeth]82-elizabeth , that [I]1657-my can from [my]1657-my heart most cordially wish [you]82-elizabeth equal felicity in marriage . [[My]1657-my dear]2993-my dear [Charlotte]101-charlotte and [I]1657-my have but one mind and one way of thinking . There is in everything a most remarkable resemblance of character and ideas between [us]1660-their . [We]1660-their seem to have been designed for [each other]3144-each other . "[1657-my]

[Elizabeth]82-elizabeth could safely say that it was a great happiness where that was the case , and with equal sincerity could add , that [she]82-elizabeth firmly believed and rejoiced in [his]1659-his domestic comforts . [She]82-elizabeth was not sorry , however , to have the recital of [them]1660-their interrupted by the entrance of [the lady from whom [they]1660-their sprang]1661-the lady from whom they sprang . [Poor Charlotte]172-charlotte ! it was melancholy to leave [her]172-charlotte to such society ! But [she]172-charlotte had chosen it with [her]172-charlotte eyes open ; and though evidently regretting that [[her]172-charlotte visitors]1370-her visitors were to go , [she]172-charlotte did not seem to ask for compassion . [[Her]172-charlotte home]352-her home and [[her]172-charlotte housekeeping]263-her housekeeping , [[her]172-charlotte parish]1665-her parish and [[her]172-charlotte poultry]1666-her poultry , and all [their]1660-their dependent concerns , had not yet lost [their]1660-their charms .

At length the chaise arrived , the trunks were fastened on , the parcels placed within , and it was pronounced to be ready . After an affectionate parting between [the friends]1667-the friends , [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth was attended to [the carriage]3217-the carriage by [Mr. Collins]129-mr. collins ; and as [they]1669-they walked down [the garden]1289-the garden , [he]129-mr. collins was commissioning [her]82-elizabeth with [his]129-mr. collins best respects to [all [her]82-elizabeth family]1671-all her family , not forgetting [his]129-mr. collins thanks for the kindness [he]129-mr. collins had received at [Longbourn]7-longbourn in the winter , and [his]129-mr. collins compliments to [Mr.]1672-mr. and [Mrs. Gardiner]125-mrs. gardiner , though unknown . [He]129-mr. collins then handed [her]82-elizabeth in , [Maria]94-maria followed , and the door was on the point of being closed , when [he]129-mr. collins suddenly reminded [them]1669-they , with some consternation , that [they]1669-they had hitherto forgotten to leave any message for [the ladies of Rosings]1673-the ladies of rosings .

" But , "[129-mr. collins] [he]129-mr. collins added , " [you]82-elizabeth will of course wish to have [your]82-elizabeth humble respects delivered to [them]1673-the ladies of rosings , with [your]82-elizabeth grateful thanks for [their]1673-the ladies of rosings kindness to [you]82-elizabeth while [you]82-elizabeth have been [here]2994-here . "[129-mr. collins]

[Elizabeth]82-elizabeth made no objection : the door was then allowed to be shut , and [the carriage]3217-the carriage drove off .

" Good gracious ! "[94-maria] cried [Maria]94-maria , after a few minutes ' silence , " it seems but a day or two since [we]1676-we first came ! and yet how many things have happened ! "[94-maria]

" [A great many indeed]4356-a great many indeed , "[1675-her companion] said [[her]82-elizabeth companion]1675-her companion , with a sigh .

" [We]1676-we have dined nine times at [Rosings]20-rosings , besides drinking tea there twice ! How much [I]94-maria shall have to tell ! "[94-maria]

[Elizabeth]82-elizabeth privately added , " And how much [I]82-elizabeth shall have to conceal ! "[82-elizabeth]

[Their]1676-we journey was performed without much conversation , or any alarm ; and within four hours of [their]1676-we leaving [Hunsford]15-hunsford [they]1676-we reached [[Mr. Gardiner]153-mr. gardiner 's house]1677-mr. gardiner 's house , where [they]1676-we were to remain a few days .

[Jane]83-jane looked well , and [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth had little opportunity of studying [her]83-jane spirits , amidst the various engagements which the kindness of [[her]82-elizabeth aunt]1198-her aunt had reserved for [them]1676-we . But [Jane]83-jane was to go [home]3219-home with [her]83-jane , and at [Longbourn]7-longbourn there would be leisure enough for observation .

It was not without an effort , meanwhile , that [she]83-jane could wait even for [Longbourn]7-longbourn , before [she]83-jane told [[her]83-jane sister]328-her sister of [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy 's proposals . To know that [she]83-jane had the power of revealing what would so exceedingly astonish [Jane]83-jane , and must , at the same time , so highly gratify whatever of [her]83-jane own vanity [she]83-jane had not yet been able to reason away , was such a temptation to openness as nothing could have conquered , but the state of indecision in which [she]83-jane remained as to the extent of what [she]83-jane should communicate , and [her]83-jane fear , if [she]83-jane once entered on the subject , of being hurried into repeating something of [Bingley]79-mr. bingley , which might only grieve [[her]83-jane sister]328-her sister further .

It was the second week in May , in which [the three young ladies]474-the three young ladies set out together from [Gracechurch Street]28-gracechurch street for [the town of ----]1683-the town of ---- , in [Hertfordshire]4-hertfordshire ; and , as [they]474-the three young ladies drew near [the appointed inn where [Mr. Bennet]75-mr. bennet 's carriage]1684-the appointed inn where mr. bennet 's carriage was to meet [them]474-the three young ladies , [they]474-the three young ladies quickly perceived , in token of [the coachman]1685-the coachman 's punctuality , both [Kitty]86-lady catherine and [Lydia]84-lydia looking out of [a dining - room]1686-a dining - room [upstairs]703-upstairs . [These two girls]1688-these two girls had been above an hour in [the place]2998-the place , happily employed in visiting [an opposite milliner]1690-an opposite milliner , watching the sentinel on guard , and dressing a salad and cucumber .

After welcoming [[their]1688-these two girls sisters]447-their sisters , [they]1688-these two girls triumphantly displayed a table set out with such cold meat as [an inn larder]1692-an inn larder usually affords , exclaiming , " Is not this nice ? is not this an agreeable surprise ? "[1688-these two girls]

" And [we]1688-these two girls mean to treat [you]1688-these two girls all , "[84-lydia] added [Lydia]84-lydia ; " but [you]1688-these two girls must lend [us]1688-these two girls the money , for [we]1688-these two girls have just spent [ours]1688-these two girls at [the shop out there]4357-the shop out there . "[84-lydia] Then showing [her]84-lydia purchases,--"Look here , [I]84-lydia have bought this bonnet . [I]84-lydia do not think it is very pretty ; but [I]84-lydia thought [I]84-lydia might as well buy it as not . [I]84-lydia shall pull it to pieces as soon as [I]84-lydia get [home]3219-home , and see if [I]84-lydia can make it up any better . "[84-lydia]

And when [[her]84-lydia sisters]3023-her sisters abused it as ugly , [she]84-lydia added , with perfect unconcern , " Oh , but there were two or three much uglier in [the shop]4359-the shop ; and when [I]84-lydia have bought some prettier - coloured satin to trim it with fresh , [I]84-lydia think it will be very tolerable . Besides , it will not much signify what one wears this summer , after the ----shire have left [Meryton]9-meryton , and [they]3023-her sisters are going in a fortnight . "[84-lydia]

" Are [they]3023-her sisters , indeed ? "[82-elizabeth] cried [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth , with the greatest satisfaction .

" [They]3023-her sisters are going to be encamped near [Brighton]32-brighton ; and [I]84-lydia do so want [papa]173-papa to take [us]4360-us all there for the summer ! It would be such a delicious scheme , and [I]84-lydia dare say would hardly cost anything at all . [Mamma]113-mamma would like to go , too , of all things ! Only think what a miserable summer else [we]4360-us shall have ! "[84-lydia]

" Yes , "[82-elizabeth] thought [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth ; " _ that _ would be a delightful scheme , indeed , and completely do for [us]4360-us at once . Good Heaven ! [Brighton]32-brighton and [a whole campful of [soldiers]4362-soldiers]4361-a whole campful of soldiers , to [us]4360-us , who have been overset already by [one poor regiment of militia]4363-one poor regiment of militia , and the monthly balls of [Meryton]9-meryton ! "[82-elizabeth]

" Now [I]84-lydia have got some news for [you]1696-the waiter , "[84-lydia] said [Lydia]84-lydia , as [they]1694-they sat down to table . " What do [you]1696-the waiter think ? It is excellent news , capital news , and about [a certain person that [we]4360-us all like]4364-a certain person that we all like . "[84-lydia]

[Jane]83-jane and [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth looked at [each other]3144-each other , and [the waiter]1696-the waiter was told that [he]1696-the waiter need not stay . [Lydia]84-lydia laughed , and said,--

" Ay , that is just like [your]1696-the waiter formality and discretion . [You]1696-the waiter thought [the waiter]1696-the waiter must not hear , as if [he]1696-the waiter cared ! [I]84-lydia dare say [he]1696-the waiter often hears worse things said than [I]84-lydia am going to say . But [he]1696-the waiter is [an ugly fellow]4366-an ugly fellow ! [I]84-lydia am glad [he]1696-the waiter is gone . [I]84-lydia never saw such a long chin in [my]84-lydia life . Well , but now for [my]84-lydia news : it is about [dear Wickham]136-wickham ; too good for [the waiter]1696-the waiter , is not it ? There is no danger of [Wickham]136-wickham 's marrying [Mary King]87-mary -- there 's for [you]1696-the waiter ! [She]87-mary is gone down to [[her]87-mary uncle]573-her uncle at [Liverpool]33-liverpool ; gone to stay . [Wickham]136-wickham is safe . "[84-lydia]

" And [Mary King]87-mary is safe ! "[82-elizabeth] added [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth ; " safe from a connection imprudent as to fortune . "[82-elizabeth]

" [She]87-mary is [a great fool]4369-a great fool for going away , if [she]87-mary liked [him]136-wickham . "[84-lydia]

" But [I]83-jane hope there is no strong attachment on either side , "[83-jane] said [Jane]83-jane .

" [I]84-lydia am sure there is not on _ [his]136-wickham _ . [I]84-lydia will answer for it , [he]136-wickham never cared three straws about [her]87-mary . Who _ could _ about such a nasty little freckled thing ? "[84-lydia]

[Elizabeth]82-elizabeth was shocked to think that , however incapable of such coarseness of _ expression _ [herself]82-elizabeth , the coarseness of the _ sentiment _ was little other than [her]82-elizabeth own breast had formerly harboured and fancied liberal !

As soon as all had ate , and [the elder ones]1697-the elder ones paid , [the carriage]3217-the carriage was ordered ; and , after some contrivance , [the whole party]521-the whole party , with all [their]521-the whole party boxes , workbags , and parcels , and the unwelcome addition of [Kitty]86-lady catherine 's and [Lydia]84-lydia 's purchases , were seated in [it]3217-the carriage .

" How nicely [we]521-the whole party are crammed in ! "[84-lydia] cried [Lydia]84-lydia . " [I]84-lydia am glad [I]84-lydia brought [my]84-lydia bonnet , if it is only for the fun of having another band - box ! Well , now let [us]521-the whole party be quite comfortable and snug , and talk and laugh all the way [home]3219-home . And in the first place , let [us]521-the whole party hear what has happened to [you]4371-you all since [you]4371-you went away . Have [you]4371-you seen [any pleasant men]4372-any pleasant men ? Have [you]4371-you had any flirting ? [I]84-lydia was in great hopes that one of [you]4371-you would have got [a husband]3760-a husband before [you]4371-you came back . [Jane]83-jane will be quite [an old maid]1081-an old maid soon , [I]84-lydia declare . [She]83-jane is almost three - and - twenty ! [Lord]4375-lord ! how ashamed [I]84-lydia should be of not being married before three - and - twenty ! [[My]84-lydia aunt]3204-my aunt [Philips]110-philips wants [you]4371-you so to get [husbands]4377-husbands [you]4371-you ca n't think . [She]3204-my aunt says [Lizzy]82-elizabeth had better have taken [Mr. Collins]129-mr. collins ; but _ [I]84-lydia _ do not think there would have been any fun in it . [Lord]4378-lord ! how [I]84-lydia should like to be married before any of [you]4371-you ! and then [I]84-lydia would _ chaperon _ [you]4371-you about to all the balls . Dear [me]84-lydia ! [we]4379-we had such a good piece of fun the other day at [Colonel Forster]107-colonel forster 's ! [Kitty]86-lady catherine and [me]84-lydia were to spend the day [there]305-there , and [Mrs. Forster]107-colonel forster promised to have a little dance in the evening ; ( by - the - bye , [Mrs. Forster]107-colonel forster and [me]84-lydia are _ [such _ friends]4381-such _ friends ! ) and so [she]3204-my aunt asked [the two Harringtons]4382-the two harringtons to come : but [Harriet]174-harriet was ill , and so [Pen]175-pen was forced to come by [herself]175-pen ; and then , what do [you]4371-you think [we]4379-we did ? [We]4379-we dressed up [Chamberlayne]176-chamberlayne in [woman]4383-woman 's clothes , on purpose to pass for [a lady,--only]4384-a lady,--only think what fun ! [Not a soul]4385-not a soul knew of it , but [Colonel and Mrs. Forster]107-colonel forster , and [Kitty]86-lady catherine and [me]84-lydia , except [[my]84-lydia aunt]3204-my aunt , for [we]4379-we were forced to borrow one of [her]3204-my aunt gowns ; and [you]4371-you can not imagine how well [he]176-chamberlayne looked ! When [Denny]135-denny , and [Wickham]136-wickham , and [Pratt]177-pratt , and [two or three more of [the men]4388-the men]4387-two or three more of the men came in , [they]1700-their did not know [him]176-chamberlayne in the least . [Lord]4389-lord ! how [I]84-lydia laughed ! and so did [Mrs. Forster]107-colonel forster . [I]84-lydia thought [I]84-lydia should have died . And _ that _ made [the men]4388-the men suspect something , and then [they]4388-the men soon found out what was the matter . "[84-lydia]

With such kind of histories of [their]1700-their parties and good jokes did [Lydia]84-lydia , assisted by [Kitty]86-lady catherine 's hints and additions , endeavour to amuse [[her]84-lydia companions]3898-her companions all the way to [Longbourn]7-longbourn . [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth listened as little as [she]82-elizabeth could , but there was no escaping the frequent mention of [Wickham]136-wickham 's name .

[Their]1700-their reception at [home]3219-home was most kind . [Mrs. Bennet]85-mrs. bennet rejoiced to see [Jane]83-jane in undiminished beauty ; and more than once during dinner did [Mr. Bennet]75-mr. bennet say voluntarily to [Elizabeth,----]178-elizabeth,----

" [I]1700-their am glad [you]178-elizabeth,---- are come back , [Lizzy]82-elizabeth . "[1700-their]

[Their]1700-their party in [the dining - room]686-the dining - room was large , for almost all [the Lucases]1704-the lucases came to meet [Maria]94-maria and hear the news ; and various were the subjects which occupied [them]1700-their : [Lady Lucas]81-lady lucas was inquiring of [Maria]94-maria , across the table , after the welfare and poultry of [[her]81-lady lucas eldest daughter]312-her eldest daughter ; [Mrs. Bennet]85-mrs. bennet was doubly engaged , on one hand collecting an account of the present fashions from [Jane]83-jane , who sat some way below [her]83-jane , and on the other , retailing them all to [the younger Miss Lucases]100-the lucases ; and [Lydia]84-lydia , in a voice rather louder than [any other person]1085-any other person 's , was enumerating the various pleasures of the morning to [anybody who would hear [her]84-lydia]1707-anybody who would hear her .

" Oh , [Mary]87-mary , "[85-mrs. bennet] said [she]85-mrs. bennet , " [I]85-mrs. bennet wish [you]87-mary had gone with [us]4391-we , for [we]4391-we had such fun ! as [we]4391-we went along [Kitty]86-lady catherine and [me]85-mrs. bennet drew up all the blinds , and pretended there was [nobody]3077-nobody in [the coach]3221-the coach ; and [I]85-mrs. bennet should have gone so all the way , if [Kitty]86-lady catherine had not been sick ; and when [we]4391-we got to the [George]143-george wickham , [I]85-mrs. bennet do think [we]4391-we behaved very handsomely , for [we]4391-we treated the other three with the nicest cold luncheon in [the world]303-the world , and if [you]87-mary would have gone , [we]4391-we would have treated [you]87-mary too . And then when [we]4391-we came away it was such fun ! [I]85-mrs. bennet thought [we]4391-we never should have got into [the coach]3221-the coach . [I]85-mrs. bennet was ready to die of laughter . And then [we]4391-we were so merry all the way [home]3219-home ! [we]4391-we talked and laughed so loud , that [anybody]3099-anybody might have heard [us]4391-we ten miles off ! "[85-mrs. bennet]

To this , [Mary]87-mary very gravely replied , " Far be it from [me]87-mary , [[my]87-mary dear sister]3825-my dear sister , to depreciate such pleasures . [They]4399-they would doubtless be congenial with the generality of female minds . But [I]87-mary confess [they]4399-they would have no charms for _ [me]87-mary _ . [I]87-mary should infinitely prefer a book . "[87-mary]

But of this answer [Lydia]84-lydia heard not a word . [She]84-lydia seldom listened to [anybody]3099-anybody for more than half a minute , and never attended to [Mary]87-mary at all .

In the afternoon [Lydia]84-lydia was urgent with [the rest of [the girls]3008-the girls]1709-the rest of the girls to walk to [Meryton]9-meryton , and see how [everybody]304-everybody went on ; but [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth steadily opposed the scheme . It should not be said , that [the Miss Bennets]99-the bennets could not be at [home]3219-home half a day before [they]1713-they were in pursuit of [the officers]454-the officers . There was another reason , too , for [her]82-elizabeth opposition . [She]82-elizabeth dreaded seeing [Wickham]136-wickham again , and was resolved to avoid it as long as possible . The comfort to _ [her]82-elizabeth _ , of [the regiment]650-the regiment 's approaching removal , was indeed beyond expression . In a fortnight [they]1713-they were to go , and once gone , [she]82-elizabeth hoped there could be nothing more to plague [her]82-elizabeth on [his]136-wickham account .

[She]82-elizabeth had not been many hours at [home]3219-home , before [she]82-elizabeth found that the Brighton scheme , of which [Lydia]84-lydia had given [them]1713-they a hint at [the inn]1717-the inn , was under frequent discussion between [[her]82-elizabeth parents]1718-her parents . [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth saw directly that [[her]82-elizabeth father]244-her father had not the smallest intention of yielding ; but [his]244-her father answers were at the same time so vague and equivocal , that [[her]82-elizabeth mother]241-her mother , though often disheartened , had never yet despaired of succeeding at last .

.

[Elizabeth]82-elizabeth 's impatience to acquaint [Jane]83-jane with what had happened could no longer be overcome ; and at length resolving to suppress every particular in which [[her]82-elizabeth sister]328-her sister was concerned , and preparing [her]83-jane to be surprised , [she]82-elizabeth related to [her]83-jane the next morning [the chief of the scene between [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy and [herself]82-elizabeth]1722-the chief of the scene between mr. darcy and herself .

[Miss Bennet]82-elizabeth 's astonishment was soon lessened by the strong sisterly partiality which made any admiration of [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth appear perfectly natural ; and all surprise was shortly lost in other feelings . [She]82-elizabeth was sorry that [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy should have delivered [his]89-mr. darcy sentiments in a manner so little suited to recommend them ; but still more was [she]82-elizabeth grieved for the unhappiness which [[her]82-elizabeth sister]328-her sister 's refusal must have given [him]89-mr. darcy .

" [His]89-mr. darcy being so sure of succeeding was wrong , "[82-elizabeth] said [she]82-elizabeth , " and certainly ought not to have appeared ; but consider how much it must increase [his]89-mr. darcy disappointment . "[82-elizabeth]

" Indeed , "[82-elizabeth] replied [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth , " [I]82-elizabeth am heartily sorry for [him]89-mr. darcy ; but [he]89-mr. darcy has other feelings which will probably soon drive away [his]89-mr. darcy regard for [me]82-elizabeth . [You]82-elizabeth do not blame [me]82-elizabeth , however , for refusing [him]89-mr. darcy ? "[82-elizabeth]

" Blame [you]82-elizabeth ! Oh , no . "[82-elizabeth]

" But [you]82-elizabeth blame [me]82-elizabeth for having spoken so warmly of [Wickham]136-wickham ? "[82-elizabeth]

" No -- [I]82-elizabeth do not know that [you]82-elizabeth were wrong in saying what [you]82-elizabeth did . "[82-elizabeth]

" But [you]82-elizabeth _ will _ know it , when [I]82-elizabeth have told [you]82-elizabeth what happened the very next day . "[82-elizabeth]

[She]82-elizabeth then spoke of the letter , repeating the whole of its contents as far as [they]1724-them concerned [George Wickham]143-george wickham . What a stroke was this for [poor [Jane]83-jane , who would willingly have gone through [the world]303-the world without believing that so much wickedness existed in [the whole race of mankind as was here collected in one individual]1726-the whole race of mankind as was here collected in one individual]83-jane ! Nor was [Darcy]89-mr. darcy 's vindication , though grateful to [her]83-jane feelings , capable of consoling [her]83-jane for such discovery . Most earnestly did [she]83-jane labour to prove the probability of error , and seek to clear one , without involving [the other]590-the other .

" This will not do , "[82-elizabeth] said [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth ; " [you]82-elizabeth never will be able to make both of [them]1724-them good for anything . Take [your]82-elizabeth choice , but [you]82-elizabeth must be satisfied with only one . There is but such a quantity of merit between [them]1724-them ; just enough to make [one good sort of man]4400-one good sort of man ; and of late it has been shifting about pretty much . For [my]82-elizabeth part , [I]82-elizabeth am inclined to believe it all [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy 's , but [you]82-elizabeth shall do as [you]82-elizabeth choose . "[82-elizabeth]

It was some time , however , before a smile could be extorted from [Jane]83-jane .

" [I]83-jane do not know when [I]83-jane have been more shocked , "[83-jane] said [she]83-jane . " [Wickham]136-wickham so very bad ! It is almost past belief . And poor [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy ! [dear Lizzy]82-elizabeth , only consider what [he]89-mr. darcy must have suffered . Such a disappointment ! and with the knowledge of [your]82-elizabeth ill opinion too ! and having to relate such a thing of [[his]89-mr. darcy sister]559-his sister ! It is really too distressing , [I]83-jane am sure [you]82-elizabeth must feel it so . "[83-jane]

" Oh no , [my]83-jane regret and compassion are all done away by seeing [you]82-elizabeth so full of both . [I]83-jane know [you]82-elizabeth will do [him]89-mr. darcy such ample justice , that [I]83-jane am growing every moment more unconcerned and indifferent . [Your]82-elizabeth profusion makes [me]83-jane saving ; and if [you]82-elizabeth lament over [him]89-mr. darcy much longer , [my]83-jane heart will be as light as a feather . "[83-jane]

" [Poor Wickham]179-poor wickham ! there is such an expression of goodness in [his]89-mr. darcy countenance ! such an openness and gentleness in [his]89-mr. darcy manner . "[83-jane]

" There certainly was some great mismanagement in the education of [those two young men]4402-those two young men . [One]3041-one has got all the goodness , and the other all the appearance of it . "[83-jane]

" [I]83-jane never thought [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy so deficient in the _ appearance _ of it as [you]82-elizabeth used to do . "[83-jane]

" And yet [I]83-jane meant to be uncommonly clever in taking so decided a dislike to [him]89-mr. darcy , without any reason . It is such a spur to one 's genius , such an opening for wit , to have a dislike of that kind . [One]180-one may be continually abusive without saying anything just ; but [one]3041-one can not be always laughing at [a man]3042-a man without now and then stumbling on something witty . "[83-jane]

" [Lizzy]82-elizabeth , when [you]82-elizabeth first read that letter , [I]83-jane am sure [you]82-elizabeth could not treat the matter as [you]82-elizabeth do now . "[83-jane]

" Indeed , [I]83-jane could not . [I]83-jane was uncomfortable enough , [I]83-jane was very uncomfortable -- [I]83-jane may say unhappy . And with [no one]3271-no one to speak to of what [I]83-jane felt , no [Jane]83-jane to comfort [me]83-jane , and say that [I]83-jane had not been so very weak , and vain , and nonsensical , as [I]83-jane knew [I]83-jane had ! Oh , how [I]83-jane wanted [you]82-elizabeth ! "[83-jane]

" How unfortunate that [you]82-elizabeth should have used such very strong expressions in speaking of [Wickham]136-wickham to [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy , for now [they]4407-they _ do _ appear wholly undeserved . "[83-jane]

" Certainly . But the misfortune of speaking with bitterness is a most natural consequence of the prejudices [I]83-jane had been encouraging . There is one point on which [I]83-jane want [your]82-elizabeth advice . [I]83-jane want to be told whether [I]83-jane ought , or ought not , to make [our]4408-our acquaintance in general understand [Wickham]136-wickham 's character . "[83-jane]

[Miss Bennet]82-elizabeth paused a little , and then replied , " Surely there can be no occasion for exposing [him]136-wickham so dreadfully . What is [your]82-elizabeth own opinion ? "[82-elizabeth]

" That it ought not to be attempted . [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy has not authorized [me]83-jane to make [his]89-mr. darcy communication public . On the contrary , [every particular relative to [[his]89-mr. darcy sister]559-his sister]4409-every particular relative to his sister was meant to be kept as much as possible to [myself]83-jane ; and if [I]83-jane endeavour to undeceive [people]3234-people as to the rest of [his]89-mr. darcy conduct , who will believe [me]83-jane ? The general prejudice against [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy is so violent , that it would be the death of [half the good people]4412-half the good people in [Meryton]9-meryton , to attempt to place [him]89-mr. darcy in an amiable light . [I]83-jane am not equal to it . [Wickham]136-wickham will soon be gone ; and , therefore , it will not signify to [anybody here]4413-anybody here what [he]136-wickham really is . Some time hence it will be all found out , and then [we]4414-we may laugh at [their]3234-people stupidity in not knowing it before . At present [I]83-jane will say nothing about it . "[83-jane]

" [You]83-jane are quite right . To have [his]89-mr. darcy errors made public might ruin [him]89-mr. darcy for ever . [He]89-mr. darcy is now , perhaps , sorry for what [he]89-mr. darcy has done , and anxious to re - establish a character . [We]4414-we must not make [him]89-mr. darcy desperate . "[82-elizabeth]

The tumult of [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth 's mind was allayed by this conversation . [She]82-elizabeth had got rid of two of the secrets which had weighed on [her]82-elizabeth for a fortnight , and was certain of [a willing listener]1728-a willing listener in [Jane]83-jane , whenever [she]82-elizabeth might wish to talk again of either . But there was still something lurking behind , of which prudence forbade the disclosure . [She]82-elizabeth dared not relate the other half of [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy 's letter , nor explain to [[her]82-elizabeth sister]328-her sister how sincerely [she]82-elizabeth had been valued by [[his]89-mr. darcy friend]286-his friend . Here was knowledge in which [no one]3271-no one could partake ; and [she]82-elizabeth was sensible that nothing less than a perfect understanding between [the parties]3149-the parties could justify [her]82-elizabeth in throwing off this last encumbrance of mystery . " And then , "[82-elizabeth] said [she]82-elizabeth , " if that very improbable event should ever take place , [I]82-elizabeth shall merely be able to tell what [Bingley]79-mr. bingley may tell in a much more agreeable manner [himself]79-mr. bingley . The liberty of communication can not be mine till it has lost all its value ! "[82-elizabeth]

[She]82-elizabeth was now , on being settled at [home]3219-home , at leisure to observe the real state of [[her]82-elizabeth sister]328-her sister 's spirits . [Jane]83-jane was not happy . [She]83-jane still cherished a very tender affection for [Bingley]79-mr. bingley . Having never even fancied [herself]82-elizabeth in love before , [her]82-elizabeth regard had all the warmth of first attachment , and from [her]82-elizabeth age and disposition , greater steadiness than first attachments often boast ; and so fervently did [she]82-elizabeth value [his]79-mr. bingley remembrance , and prefer [him]79-mr. bingley to [every other man]1735-every other man , that all [her]82-elizabeth good sense , and all [her]82-elizabeth attention to the feelings of [[her]82-elizabeth friends]310-her friends , were requisite to check the indulgence of those regrets which must have been injurious to [her]82-elizabeth own health and [their]310-her friends tranquillity .

" Well , [Lizzy]82-elizabeth , "[85-mrs. bennet] said [Mrs. Bennet]85-mrs. bennet , one day , " what is [your]82-elizabeth opinion _ now _ of this sad business of [Jane]83-jane 's ? For [my]85-mrs. bennet part , [I]85-mrs. bennet am determined never to speak of it again to [anybody]3099-anybody . [I]85-mrs. bennet told [[my]85-mrs. bennet sister]3280-my sister [Philips]110-philips so the other day . But [I]85-mrs. bennet can not find out that [Jane]83-jane saw anything of [him]4417-he in [London]5-london . Well , [he]4417-he is [a very undeserving young man]4418-a very undeserving young man -- and [I]85-mrs. bennet do not suppose there is the least chance in [the world]303-the world of [her]83-jane ever getting [him]4417-he now . There is no talk of [his]4417-he coming to [Netherfield]2-netherfield again in the summer ; and [I]85-mrs. bennet have inquired of [everybody]304-everybody , too , who is likely to know . "[85-mrs. bennet]

" [I]241-her mother do not believe that [he]4417-he will ever live at [Netherfield]2-netherfield any more . "[241-her mother]
