" Oh , well ! it is just as [he]4417-he chooses . [Nobody]3077-nobody wants [him]4417-he to come ; though [I]85-mrs. bennet shall always say that [he]4417-he used [[my]85-mrs. bennet daughter]4422-my daughter extremely ill ; and , if [I]85-mrs. bennet was [her]4422-my daughter , [I]85-mrs. bennet would not have put up with it . Well , [my]85-mrs. bennet comfort is , [I]85-mrs. bennet am sure [Jane]83-jane will die of a broken heart , and then [he]4417-he will be sorry for what [he]4417-he has done . "[85-mrs. bennet]

But as [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth could not receive comfort from any such expectation [she]82-elizabeth made no answer .

" Well , [Lizzy]82-elizabeth , "[241-her mother] continued [[her]82-elizabeth mother]241-her mother , soon afterwards , " and so [the Collinses]4423-the collinses live very comfortable , do [they]4423-the collinses ? Well , well , [I]241-her mother only hope it will last . And what sort of table do [they]4423-the collinses keep ? [Charlotte]172-charlotte is [an excellent manager]4424-an excellent manager , [I]241-her mother dare say . If [she]172-charlotte is half as sharp as [[her]172-charlotte mother]241-her mother , [she]172-charlotte is saving enough . There is nothing extravagant in _ [[their]4423-the collinses _ housekeeping]4426-their _ housekeeping , [I]241-her mother dare say . "[241-her mother]

" No , nothing at all . "[241-her mother]

" A great deal of good management , depend upon it . Yes , yes . _ [They]4423-the collinses _ will take care not to outrun [their]4423-the collinses income . _ [They]4423-the collinses _ will never be distressed for money . Well , much good may it do [them]4423-the collinses ! And so , [I]241-her mother suppose , [they]4423-the collinses often talk of having [Longbourn]7-longbourn when [[your]4427-your father]3223-your father is dead . [They]4423-the collinses look upon it quite as [their]4423-the collinses own , [I]241-her mother dare say , whenever that happens . "[241-her mother]

" It was a subject which [they]4423-the collinses could not mention before [me]241-her mother . "[241-her mother]

" No ; it would have been strange if [they]4423-the collinses had . But [I]241-her mother make no doubt [they]4423-the collinses often talk of it between [themselves]4423-the collinses . Well , if [they]4423-the collinses can be easy with [an estate that is not lawfully [their]4423-the collinses own]4429-an estate that is not lawfully their own , so much the better . _ [I]241-her mother _ should be ashamed of having one that was only entailed on [me]241-her mother . "[241-her mother]

[I.]1738-i.

The first week of [their]1739-their return was soon gone . The second began . It was the last of [the regiment]650-the regiment 's stay in [Meryton]9-meryton , and [all the young ladies in [the neighbourhood]3015-the neighbourhood]1741-all the young ladies in the neighbourhood were drooping apace . The dejection was almost universal . [The elder Miss Bennets]99-the bennets alone were still able to eat , drink , and sleep , and pursue the usual course of [their]1739-their employments . Very frequently were [they]1739-their reproached for this insensibility by [Kitty]86-lady catherine and [Lydia]84-lydia , whose own misery was extreme , and who could not comprehend such hard - heartedness in [any of [the family]416-the family]1086-any of the family .

" [Good Heaven]181-heaven ! What is to become of [us]1739-their ? What are [we]1739-their to do ? "[1739-their] would [they]1739-their often exclaim in the bitterness of woe . " How can [you]1745-their affectionate mother be smiling so , [Lizzy]82-elizabeth ? "[1739-their]

[[Their]1739-their affectionate mother]1745-their affectionate mother shared all [their]1739-their grief ; [she]1745-their affectionate mother remembered what [she]1745-their affectionate mother had [herself]1745-their affectionate mother endured on a similar occasion five - and - twenty years ago .

" [I]1745-their affectionate mother am sure , "[1745-their affectionate mother] said [she]1745-their affectionate mother , " [I]1745-their affectionate mother cried for two days together when [[Colonel Miller]182-colonel miller 's regiment]4430-colonel miller 's regiment went away . [I]1745-their affectionate mother thought [I]1745-their affectionate mother should have broke [my]1745-their affectionate mother heart . "[1745-their affectionate mother]

" [I]84-lydia am sure [I]84-lydia shall break _ mine _ , "[84-lydia] said [Lydia]84-lydia .

" If one could but go to [Brighton]32-brighton ! "[85-mrs. bennet] observed [Mrs. Bennet]85-mrs. bennet .

" Oh yes!--if [one]3041-one could but go to [Brighton]32-brighton ! But [papa]4432-papa is so disagreeable . "[1745-their affectionate mother]

" A little sea - bathing would set [me]1745-their affectionate mother up for ever . "[1745-their affectionate mother]

" And [[my]86-lady catherine aunt]3204-my aunt [Philips]110-philips is sure it would do _ [me]86-lady catherine _ a great deal of good , "[86-lady catherine] added [Kitty]86-lady catherine .

Such were the kind of lamentations resounding perpetually through [Longbourn House]24-longbourn house . [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth tried to be diverted by [them]1746-them ; but all sense of pleasure was lost in shame . [She]82-elizabeth felt anew the justice of [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy 's objections ; and never had [she]82-elizabeth before been so much disposed to pardon [his]89-mr. darcy interference in the views of [[his]89-mr. darcy friend]286-his friend .

But the gloom of [Lydia]84-lydia 's prospect was shortly cleared away ; for [she]82-elizabeth received an invitation from [Mrs. Forster]107-colonel forster , [the wife of [the colonel of [the regiment]650-the regiment]1749-the colonel of the regiment]1748-the wife of the colonel of the regiment , to accompany [her]82-elizabeth to [Brighton]32-brighton . [This invaluable friend]1751-this invaluable friend was [a very young woman , and very lately married]1752-a very young woman , and very lately married . A resemblance in good - humour and good spirits had recommended [her]82-elizabeth and [Lydia]84-lydia to [each other]3144-each other , and out of [their]1754-their _ three _ months ' acquaintance [they]1754-their had been intimate _ two _ .

The rapture of [Lydia]84-lydia on this occasion , [her]84-lydia adoration of [Mrs. Forster]107-colonel forster , the delight of [Mrs. Bennet]85-mrs. bennet , and the mortification of [Kitty]86-lady catherine , are scarcely to be described . Wholly inattentive to [[her]84-lydia sister]328-her sister 's feelings , [Lydia]84-lydia flew about [the house]3001-the house in restless ecstasy , calling for [everyone]1054-everyone 's congratulations , and laughing and talking with more violence than ever ; whilst [the luckless Kitty]86-lady catherine continued in the parlour repining at [her]86-lady catherine fate in terms as unreasonable as [her]86-lady catherine accent was peevish .

" [I]86-lady catherine can not see why [Mrs. Forster]107-colonel forster should not ask _ [me]86-lady catherine _ as well as [Lydia]84-lydia , "[86-lady catherine] said [she]86-lady catherine , " though [I]86-lady catherine am _ not _ [[her]84-lydia particular friend]4434-her particular friend . [I]86-lady catherine have just as much right to be asked as [she]84-lydia has , and more too , for [I]86-lady catherine am two years older . "[86-lady catherine]

In vain did [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth attempt to make [her]86-lady catherine reasonable , and [Jane]83-jane to make [her]86-lady catherine resigned . As for [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth [herself]82-elizabeth , this invitation was so far from exciting in [her]82-elizabeth the same feelings as in [[her]82-elizabeth mother]241-her mother and [Lydia]84-lydia , that [she]82-elizabeth considered it as the death - warrant of all possibility of common sense for the latter ; and detestable as such a step must make [her]82-elizabeth , were it known , [she]82-elizabeth could not help secretly advising [[her]82-elizabeth father]244-her father not to let [her]82-elizabeth go . [She]82-elizabeth represented to [him]244-her father all the improprieties of [Lydia]84-lydia 's general behaviour , the little advantage [she]82-elizabeth could derive from the friendship of [such a woman]3274-such a woman as [Mrs. Forster]107-colonel forster , and the probability of [her]82-elizabeth being yet more imprudent with [such a companion at [Brighton]32-brighton]1761-such a companion at brighton , where the temptations must be greater than at [home]3219-home . [He]244-her father heard [her]82-elizabeth attentively , and then said,--

" [Lydia]84-lydia will never be easy till [she]84-lydia has exposed [herself]84-lydia in some public place or other , and [we]4435-our can never expect [her]84-lydia to do it with so little expense or inconvenience to [[her]84-lydia family]885-her family as under the present circumstances . "[244-her father]

" If [you]244-her father were aware , "[82-elizabeth] said [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth , " of the very great disadvantage to [us]4435-our all , which must arise from the public notice of [Lydia]84-lydia 's unguarded and imprudent manner , nay , which has already arisen from it , [I]82-elizabeth am sure [you]244-her father would judge differently in the affair . "[82-elizabeth]

" Already arisen ! "[75-mr. bennet] repeated [Mr. Bennet]75-mr. bennet . " What ! has [she]84-lydia frightened away [some of [[your]75-mr. bennet lovers]4438-your lovers]4437-some of your lovers ? [Poor little Lizzy]82-elizabeth ! But do not be cast down . [Such squeamish youths]4439-such squeamish youths as can not bear to be connected with a little absurdity are not worth a regret . Come , let [me]75-mr. bennet see the list of [the pitiful fellows who have been kept aloof by [Lydia]84-lydia 's folly]4440-the pitiful fellows who have been kept aloof by lydia 's folly . "[75-mr. bennet]

" Indeed , [you]244-her father are mistaken . [I]75-mr. bennet have no such injuries to resent . It is not of peculiar , but of general evils , which [I]75-mr. bennet am now complaining . [Our]4435-our importance , [our]4435-our respectability in [the world]303-the world , must be affected by the wild volatility , the assurance and disdain of all restraint which mark [Lydia]84-lydia 's character . Excuse me,--for [I]75-mr. bennet must speak plainly . If [you]244-her father , [[my]75-mr. bennet dear father]4442-my dear father , will not take the trouble of checking [her]84-lydia exuberant spirits , and of teaching [her]84-lydia that [her]84-lydia present pursuits are not to be the business of [her]84-lydia life , [she]84-lydia will soon be beyond the reach of amendment . [Her]84-lydia character will be fixed ; and [she]84-lydia will , at sixteen , be [the most determined flirt that ever made [herself]84-lydia and [[her]84-lydia family]885-her family]4443-the most determined flirt that ever made herself and her family ridiculous;--a flirt , too , in the worst and meanest degree of flirtation ; without any attraction beyond youth and [a tolerable person]4445-a tolerable person ; and , from the ignorance and emptiness of [her]84-lydia mind , wholly unable to ward off any portion of that universal contempt which [her]84-lydia rage for admiration will excite . In this danger [Kitty]86-lady catherine is also comprehended . [She]86-lady catherine will follow wherever [Lydia]84-lydia leads . Vain , ignorant , idle , and absolutely uncontrolled ! Oh , [[my]75-mr. bennet dear father]4442-my dear father , can [you]4442-my dear father suppose it possible that [they]4447-they will not be censured and despised wherever [they]4447-they are known , and that [[their]4447-they sisters]447-their sisters will not be often involved in the disgrace ? "[75-mr. bennet]

[Mr. Bennet]75-mr. bennet saw that [her]1763-you whole heart was in the subject ; and , affectionately taking [her]1763-you hand , said , in reply,--

" Do not make [yourself]1763-you uneasy , [[my]75-mr. bennet love]3055-my love . Wherever [you]1763-you and [Jane]83-jane are known , [you]1763-you must be respected and valued ; and [you]1763-you will not appear to less advantage for having a couple of -- or [I]75-mr. bennet may say , [three -- very silly sisters]4450-three -- very silly sisters . [We]4451-us shall have no peace at [Longbourn]7-longbourn if [Lydia]84-lydia does not go to [Brighton]32-brighton . Let [her]84-lydia go , then . [Colonel Forster]107-colonel forster is [a sensible man]3446-a sensible man , and will keep [her]84-lydia out of any real mischief ; and [she]84-lydia is luckily too poor to be an object of prey to [anybody]3099-anybody . At [Brighton]32-brighton [she]84-lydia will be of less importance even as [a common flirt]4454-a common flirt than [she]84-lydia has been [here]2994-here . [The officers]454-the officers will find [women]3880-women better worth [their]454-the officers notice . Let [us]4451-us hope , therefore , that [her]84-lydia being [there]305-there may teach [her]84-lydia [her]84-lydia own insignificance . At any rate , [she]84-lydia can not grow many degrees worse , without authorizing [us]4451-us to lock [her]84-lydia up for the rest of [her]84-lydia life . "[75-mr. bennet]

With this answer [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth was forced to be content ; but [her]82-elizabeth own opinion continued the same , and [she]82-elizabeth left [him]1764-him disappointed and sorry . It was not in [her]82-elizabeth nature , however , to increase [her]82-elizabeth vexations by dwelling on them . [She]82-elizabeth was confident of having performed [her]82-elizabeth duty ; and to fret over unavoidable evils , or augment them by anxiety , was no part of [her]82-elizabeth disposition .

Had [Lydia]84-lydia and [[her]84-lydia mother]241-her mother known the substance of [her]84-lydia conference with [[her]84-lydia father]244-her father , [their]1767-their indignation would hardly have found expression in [their]1767-their united volubility . In [Lydia]84-lydia 's imagination , a visit to [Brighton]32-brighton comprised every possibility of earthly happiness . [She]84-lydia saw , with the creative eye of fancy , [the streets of [that gay bathing - place covered with [officers]458-officers]1769-that gay bathing - place covered with officers]1768-the streets of that gay bathing - place covered with officers . [She]84-lydia saw [herself]84-lydia the object of attention to [tens]1771-tens and to scores of [them]1771-tens at present unknown . [She]84-lydia saw all the glories of [the camp]1772-the camp : [its]1772-the camp tents stretched forth in beauteous uniformity of lines , crowded with [the young]1773-the young and [the gay]1774-the gay , and dazzling with scarlet ; and , to complete the view , [she]84-lydia saw [herself]84-lydia seated beneath [a tent]1775-a tent , tenderly flirting with at least [six officers]1776-six officers at once .

Had [she]84-lydia known that [[her]84-lydia sister]328-her sister sought to tear [her]84-lydia from such prospects and such realities as these , what would have been [her]84-lydia sensations ? [They]1778-they could have been understood only by [[her]84-lydia mother]241-her mother , who might have felt nearly the same . [Lydia]84-lydia 's going to [Brighton]32-brighton was all that consoled [her]84-lydia for the melancholy conviction of [[her]84-lydia husband]255-her husband 's never intending to go [there]305-there [himself]255-her husband .

But [they]1782-their were entirely ignorant of what had passed ; and [their]1782-their raptures continued , with little intermission , to the very day of [Lydia]84-lydia 's leaving [home]3219-home .

[Elizabeth]82-elizabeth was now to see [Mr. Wickham]136-wickham for the last time . Having been frequently in company with [him]136-wickham since [her]82-elizabeth return , agitation was pretty well over ; the agitations of former partiality entirely so . [She]82-elizabeth had even learnt to detect , in the very gentleness which had first delighted [her]82-elizabeth , an affectation and a sameness to disgust and weary . In [his]136-wickham present behaviour to [herself]82-elizabeth , moreover , [she]82-elizabeth had a fresh source of displeasure ; for the inclination [he]136-wickham soon testified of renewing those attentions which had marked the early part of [their]1782-their acquaintance could only serve , after what had since passed , to provoke [her]82-elizabeth . [She]82-elizabeth lost all concern for [him]136-wickham in finding [herself]82-elizabeth thus selected as the object of such idle and frivolous gallantry ; and while [she]82-elizabeth steadily repressed it , could not but feel the reproof contained in [his]136-wickham believing , that however long , and for whatever cause , [his]136-wickham attentions had been withdrawn , [her]82-elizabeth vanity would be gratified , and [her]82-elizabeth preference secured , at any time , by [their]1782-their renewal .

On the very last day of [the regiment]650-the regiment 's remaining in [Meryton]9-meryton , [he]136-wickham dined , with [others of [the officers]454-the officers]1785-others of the officers , at [Longbourn]7-longbourn ; and so little was [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth disposed to part from [him]136-wickham in good - humour , that , on [his]136-wickham making some inquiry as to the manner in which [her]82-elizabeth time had passed at [Hunsford]15-hunsford , [she]82-elizabeth mentioned [Colonel Fitzwilliam]164-colonel fitzwilliam 's and [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy 's having both spent three weeks at [Rosings]20-rosings , and asked [him]136-wickham if [he]136-wickham were acquainted with [the former]327-the former .

[He]136-wickham looked surprised , displeased , alarmed ; but , with a moment 's recollection , and a returning smile , replied , that [he]136-wickham had formerly seen [him]136-wickham often ; and , after observing that [he]136-wickham was [a very gentlemanlike man]1788-a very gentlemanlike man , asked [her]82-elizabeth how [she]82-elizabeth had liked [him]136-wickham . [Her]82-elizabeth answer was warmly in [his]136-wickham favour . With an air of indifference , [he]136-wickham soon afterwards added , " How long did [you]82-elizabeth say that [he]136-wickham was at [Rosings]20-rosings ? "[136-wickham]

" Nearly three weeks . "[136-wickham]

" And [you]82-elizabeth saw [him]136-wickham frequently ? "[136-wickham]

" Yes , almost every day . "[136-wickham]

" [His]136-wickham manners are very different from [[his]136-wickham cousin]704-his cousin 's . "[136-wickham]

" Yes , very different ; but [I]136-wickham think [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy improves on acquaintance . "[136-wickham]

" Indeed ! "[136-wickham] cried [Wickham]136-wickham , with a look which did not escape [her]82-elizabeth . " And pray may [I]136-wickham ask-- "[136-wickham] but checking [himself]136-wickham , [he]136-wickham added , in a gayer tone , " Is it in address that [he]136-wickham improves ? Has [he]136-wickham deigned to add aught of civility to [his]136-wickham ordinary style ? for [I]136-wickham dare not hope , "[136-wickham] [he]136-wickham continued , in a lower and more serious tone , " that [he]136-wickham is improved in essentials . "[136-wickham]

" Oh , no ! "[82-elizabeth] said [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth . " In essentials , [I]82-elizabeth believe , [he]136-wickham is very much what [he]136-wickham ever was . "[82-elizabeth]

While [she]82-elizabeth spoke , [Wickham]136-wickham looked as if scarcely knowing whether to rejoice over [her]82-elizabeth words or to distrust their meaning . There was a something in [her]82-elizabeth countenance which made [him]136-wickham listen with an apprehensive and anxious attention , while [she]82-elizabeth added,--

" When [I]82-elizabeth said that [he]136-wickham improved on acquaintance , [I]82-elizabeth did not mean that either [his]136-wickham mind or manners were in a state of improvement ; but that , from knowing [him]136-wickham better , [his]136-wickham disposition was better understood . "[82-elizabeth]

[Wickham]136-wickham 's alarm now appeared in a heightened complexion and agitated look ; for a few minutes [he]136-wickham was silent ; till , shaking off [his]136-wickham embarrassment , [he]136-wickham turned to [her]82-elizabeth again , and said in the gentlest of accents,--

" [You]82-elizabeth , who so well know [my]136-wickham feelings towards [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy , will readily comprehend how sincerely [I]136-wickham must rejoice that [he]136-wickham is wise enough to assume even the _ appearance _ of what is right . [His]136-wickham pride , in that direction , may be of service , if not to [himself]136-wickham , to [many others]4157-many others , for it must deter [him]136-wickham from such foul misconduct as [I]136-wickham have suffered by . [I]136-wickham only fear that the sort of cautiousness to which [you]82-elizabeth , [I]136-wickham imagine , have been alluding , is merely adopted on [his]136-wickham visits to [[his]136-wickham aunt]924-his aunt , of whose good opinion and judgment [he]136-wickham stands much in awe . [His]136-wickham fear of [her]924-his aunt has always operated , [I]136-wickham know , when [they]4462-they were together ; and a good deal is to be imputed to [his]136-wickham wish of forwarding the match with [Miss de Bourgh]132-miss de bourgh , which [I]136-wickham am certain [he]136-wickham has very much at heart . "[136-wickham]

[Elizabeth]82-elizabeth could not repress a smile at this , but [she]82-elizabeth answered only by a slight inclination of the head . [She]82-elizabeth saw that [he]1789-his wanted to engage [her]82-elizabeth on the old subject of [his]1789-his grievances , and [she]82-elizabeth was in no humour to indulge [him]1789-his . The rest of the evening passed with the _ appearance _ , on [his]1789-his side , of usual cheerfulness , but with no further attempt to distinguish [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth ; and [they]1790-they parted at last with mutual civility , and possibly a mutual desire of never meeting again .

When the party broke up , [Lydia]84-lydia returned with [Mrs. Forster]107-colonel forster to [Meryton]9-meryton , from whence [they]1790-they were to set out early the next morning . The separation between [her]84-lydia and [[her]84-lydia family]885-her family was rather noisy than pathetic . [Kitty]86-lady catherine was [the only one who shed tears]1792-the only one who shed tears ; but [she]86-lady catherine did weep from vexation and envy . [Mrs. Bennet]85-mrs. bennet was diffuse in [her]85-mrs. bennet good wishes for the felicity of [[her]85-mrs. bennet daughter]463-her daughter , and impressive in [her]85-mrs. bennet injunctions that [she]85-mrs. bennet would not miss the opportunity of enjoying [herself]85-mrs. bennet as much as possible,--advice which there was every reason to believe would be attended to ; and , in the clamorous happiness of [Lydia]84-lydia [herself]84-lydia in bidding farewell , [the more gentle adieus of [[her]84-lydia sisters]3023-her sisters]1794-the more gentle adieus of her sisters were uttered without being heard .

II .

Had [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth 's opinion been all drawn from [[her]82-elizabeth own family]4142-her own family , [she]82-elizabeth could not have formed a very pleasing picture of conjugal felicity or domestic comfort . [[Her]82-elizabeth father]244-her father , captivated by youth and beauty , and that appearance of good - humour which youth and beauty generally give , had married [a woman whose weak understanding and illiberal mind]1798-a woman whose weak understanding and illiberal mind had very early in [their]1799-their marriage put an end to all real affection for [her]1798-a woman whose weak understanding and illiberal mind . Respect , esteem , and confidence had vanished for ever ; and all [his]244-her father views of domestic happiness were overthrown . But [Mr. Bennet]75-mr. bennet was not of a disposition to seek comfort for the disappointment which [his]244-her father own imprudence had brought on in any of those pleasures which too often console [the unfortunate]1800-the unfortunate for [their]1800-the unfortunate folly or [their]1800-the unfortunate vice . [He]244-her father was fond of [the country]448-the country and of books ; and from these tastes had arisen [his]244-her father principal enjoyments . To [[his]244-her father wife]231-his wife [he]244-her father was very little otherwise indebted than as [her]231-his wife ignorance and folly had contributed to [his]244-her father amusement . This is not the sort of happiness which [a man]3042-a man would in general wish to owe to [[his]244-her father wife]231-his wife ; but where other powers of entertainment are wanting , [the true philosopher]1805-the true philosopher will derive benefit from such as are given .

[Elizabeth]82-elizabeth , however , had never been blind to the impropriety of [[her]82-elizabeth father]244-her father 's behaviour as [a husband]3760-a husband . [She]82-elizabeth had always seen it with pain ; but respecting [his]244-her father abilities , and grateful for [his]244-her father affectionate treatment of [herself]82-elizabeth , [she]82-elizabeth endeavoured to forget what [she]82-elizabeth could not overlook , and to banish from [her]82-elizabeth thoughts that continual breach of conjugal obligation and decorum which , in exposing [[his]244-her father wife]231-his wife to the contempt of [[her]82-elizabeth own children]1809-her own children , was so highly reprehensible . But [she]82-elizabeth had never felt so strongly as now the disadvantages which must attend [the children of so unsuitable a marriage]1810-the children of so unsuitable a marriage , nor ever been so fully aware of the evils arising from so ill - judged a direction of talents -- talents which , rightly used , might at least have preserved the respectability of [[his]244-her father daughters]431-his daughters , even if incapable of enlarging the mind of [[his]244-her father wife]231-his wife .

When [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth had rejoiced over [Wickham]136-wickham 's departure , [she]82-elizabeth found little other cause for satisfaction in the loss of [the regiment]650-the regiment . [Their]1814-their parties abroad were less varied than before ; and at [home]3219-home [she]82-elizabeth had [a mother]1816-a mother and [sister]3891-sister , whose constant repinings at the dulness of everything around [them]1814-their threw a real gloom over [their]1814-their domestic circle ; and , though [Kitty]86-lady catherine might in time regain [her]86-lady catherine natural degree of sense , since the disturbers of [her]86-lady catherine brain were removed , [[her]82-elizabeth other sister]1818-her other sister , from whose disposition greater evil might be apprehended , was likely to be hardened in all [her]1818-her other sister folly and assurance , by a situation of such double danger as [a watering - place]1819-a watering - place and [a camp]1820-a camp . Upon the whole , therefore , [she]82-elizabeth found , what has been sometimes found before , that an event to which [she]82-elizabeth had looked forward with impatient desire , did not , in taking place , bring all the satisfaction [she]82-elizabeth had promised [herself]82-elizabeth . It was consequently necessary to name some other period for the commencement of actual felicity ; to have some other point on which [her]82-elizabeth wishes and hopes might be fixed , and by again enjoying the pleasure of anticipation , console [herself]82-elizabeth for the present , and prepare for another disappointment . [Her]82-elizabeth tour to [the Lakes]4002-the lakes was now the object of [her]82-elizabeth happiest thoughts : it was [her]82-elizabeth best consolation for all the uncomfortable hours which the discontentedness of [[her]82-elizabeth mother]241-her mother and [Kitty]86-lady catherine made inevitable ; and could [she]82-elizabeth have included [Jane]83-jane in the scheme , every part of it would have been perfect .

" But it is fortunate , "[82-elizabeth] thought [she]82-elizabeth , " that [I]82-elizabeth have something to wish for . Were the whole arrangement complete , [my]82-elizabeth disappointment would be certain . But here , by carrying with [me]82-elizabeth one ceaseless source of regret in [[my]82-elizabeth sister]3280-my sister 's absence , [I]82-elizabeth may reasonably hope to have all [my]82-elizabeth expectations of pleasure realized . A scheme of which every part promises delight can never be successful ; and general disappointment is only warded off by the defence of some little peculiar vexation . "[82-elizabeth]

When [Lydia]84-lydia went away [she]84-lydia promised to write very often and very minutely to [[her]84-lydia mother]241-her mother and [Kitty]86-lady catherine ; but [her]84-lydia letters were always long expected , and always very short . Those to [[her]84-lydia mother]241-her mother contained little else than that [they]1825-they were just returned from [the library]1011-the library , where [such and such officers]1827-such and such officers had attended [them]1825-they , and where [she]84-lydia had seen such beautiful ornaments as made [her]84-lydia quite wild ; that [she]84-lydia had a new gown , or a new parasol , which [she]84-lydia would have described more fully , but was obliged to leave off in a violent hurry , as [Mrs. Forster]107-colonel forster called [her]84-lydia , and [they]1828-they were going to [the camp]1772-the camp ; and from [her]84-lydia correspondence with [[her]84-lydia sister]328-her sister there was still less to be learnt , for [her]84-lydia letters to [Kitty]86-lady catherine , though rather longer , were much too full of lines under the words to be made public .

After the first fortnight or three weeks of [her]84-lydia absence , health , good - humour , and cheerfulness began to reappear at [Longbourn]7-longbourn . Everything wore a happier aspect . [The families who had been in [town]264-town for the winter]1831-the families who had been in town for the winter came back again , and summer finery and summer engagements arose . [Mrs. Bennet]85-mrs. bennet was restored to [her]85-mrs. bennet usual querulous serenity ; and by the middle of June [Kitty]86-lady catherine was so much recovered as to be able to enter [Meryton]9-meryton without tears,--an event of such happy promise as to make [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth hope , that by the following Christmas [she]82-elizabeth might be so tolerably reasonable as not to mention [an officer]902-an officer above once a day , unless , by some cruel and malicious arrangement at [the War Office]1834-the war office , [another regiment]1835-another regiment should be quartered in [Meryton]9-meryton .

The time fixed for the beginning of [their]1836-they northern tour was now fast approaching ; and a fortnight only was wanting of it , when a letter arrived from [Mrs. Gardiner]125-mrs. gardiner , which at once delayed its commencement and curtailed its extent . [Mr. Gardiner]153-mr. gardiner would be prevented by business from setting out till a fortnight later in July , and must be in [London]5-london again within a month ; and as that left too short a period for [them]1836-they to go so far , and see so much as [they]1836-they had proposed , or at least to see it with the leisure and comfort [they]1836-they had built on , [they]1836-they were obliged to give up [the Lakes]4002-the lakes , and substitute a more contracted tour ; and , according to the present plan , were to go no farther northward than [Derbyshire]6-derbyshire . In [that county]1838-that county there was enough to be seen to occupy the chief of [their]1836-they three weeks ; and to [Mrs. Gardiner]125-mrs. gardiner it had a peculiarly strong attraction . [The town where [she]125-mrs. gardiner had formerly passed some years of [her]125-mrs. gardiner life , and where [they]1836-they were now to spend a few days]1839-the town where she had formerly passed some years of her life , and where they were now to spend a few days , was probably as great an object of [her]125-mrs. gardiner curiosity as all the celebrated beauties of [Matlock]35-matlock , [Chatsworth]36-chatsworth , [Dovedale]37-dovedale , or [the Peak]38-the peak .

[Elizabeth]82-elizabeth was excessively disappointed : [she]82-elizabeth had set [her]82-elizabeth heart on seeing [the Lakes]4002-the lakes ; and still thought there might have been time enough . But it was [her]82-elizabeth business to be satisfied -- and certainly [her]82-elizabeth temper to be happy ; and all was soon right again .

With the mention of [Derbyshire]6-derbyshire , there were many ideas connected . It was impossible for [her]82-elizabeth to see the word without thinking of [Pemberley]12-pemberley and [its owner]1841-its owner . " But surely , "[82-elizabeth] said [she]82-elizabeth , " [I]82-elizabeth may enter [[his]1841-its owner county]342-his county with impunity , and rob it of a few petrified spars , without [his]1841-its owner perceiving [me]82-elizabeth . "[82-elizabeth]

The period of expectation was now doubled . Four weeks were to pass away before [[her]82-elizabeth uncle]573-her uncle and [aunt]3971-aunt 's arrival . But [they]1844-they did pass away , and [Mr.]1845-mr. and [Mrs. Gardiner]125-mrs. gardiner , with [[their]1846-their four children]1847-their four children , did at length appear at [Longbourn]7-longbourn . [The children]1848-the children , [two girls of six and eight years old]1849-two girls of six and eight years old , and [two younger boys]1850-two younger boys , were to be left under the particular care of [[their]1846-their cousin]671-their cousin [Jane]83-jane , who was [the general favourite]1852-the general favourite , and whose steady sense and sweetness of temper exactly adapted [her]83-jane for attending to [them]1848-the children in every way -- teaching [them]1848-the children , playing with [them]1848-the children , and loving [them]1848-the children .

[The Gardiners]154-the gardiners stayed only one night at [Longbourn]7-longbourn , and set off the next morning with [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth in pursuit of novelty and amusement . One enjoyment was certain -- that of suitableness as [companions]1853-companions ; a suitableness which comprehended health and temper to bear inconveniences -- cheerfulness to enhance every pleasure -- and affection and intelligence , which might supply it among [themselves]154-the gardiners if there were disappointments abroad .

It is not the object of this work to give a description of [Derbyshire]6-derbyshire , nor of any of [the remarkable places through which [their]1846-their route thither]1854-the remarkable places through which their route thither lay -- [Oxford]39-oxford , [Blenheim]40-blenheim , [Warwick]41-warwick , [Kenilworth]42-kenilworth , [Birmingham]43-birmingham , etc . , are sufficiently known . [A small part of [Derbyshire]6-derbyshire]1855-a small part of derbyshire is all the present concern . To [the little town of]1856-the little town of [Lambton]44-lambton , [the scene of [Mrs. Gardiner]125-mrs. gardiner 's former residence]1857-the scene of mrs. gardiner 's former residence , and where [she]125-mrs. gardiner had lately learned that [some acquaintance]1858-some acquaintance still remained , [they]1846-their bent [their]1846-their steps , after having seen all the principal wonders of [the country]448-the country ; and within five miles of [Lambton]44-lambton , [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth found , from [[her]82-elizabeth aunt]1198-her aunt , that [Pemberley]12-pemberley was situated . [It]12-pemberley was not in [[their]1846-their direct road]1861-their direct road ; nor more than a mile or two out of [it]12-pemberley . In talking over [their]1846-their route the evening before , [Mrs. Gardiner]125-mrs. gardiner expressed an inclination to see [the place]2998-the place again . [Mr. Gardiner]153-mr. gardiner declared [his]153-mr. gardiner willingness , and [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth was applied to for [her]82-elizabeth approbation .

" [[My]1198-her aunt love]3055-my love , should not [you]3055-my love like to see [a place of which [you]3055-my love have heard so much]4466-a place of which you have heard so much ? "[1198-her aunt] said [[her]82-elizabeth aunt]1198-her aunt . " [A place , too , with which so many of [your]3055-my love acquaintance]4467-a place , too , with which so many of your acquaintance are connected . [Wickham]136-wickham passed all [his]136-wickham youth [there]305-there , [you]3055-my love know . "[1198-her aunt]

[Elizabeth]82-elizabeth was distressed . [She]82-elizabeth felt that [she]82-elizabeth had no business at [Pemberley]12-pemberley , and was obliged to assume a disinclination for seeing [it]12-pemberley . [She]82-elizabeth must own that [she]82-elizabeth was tired of [great houses]1864-great houses : after going over so many , [she]82-elizabeth really had no pleasure in fine carpets or satin curtains .

[Mrs. Gardiner]125-mrs. gardiner abused [her]125-mrs. gardiner stupidity . " If [it]12-pemberley were merely [a fine house]4469-a fine house richly furnished , "[125-mrs. gardiner] said [she]125-mrs. gardiner , " [I]125-mrs. gardiner should not care about it [myself]125-mrs. gardiner ; but [the grounds]4470-the grounds are delightful . [They]4470-the grounds have some of [the finest woods in [the country]448-the country]4471-the finest woods in the country . "[125-mrs. gardiner]

[Elizabeth]82-elizabeth said no more ; but [her]82-elizabeth mind could not acquiesce . The possibility of meeting [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy , while viewing [the place]2998-the place , instantly occurred . It would be dreadful ! [She]82-elizabeth blushed at the very idea ; and thought it would be better to speak openly to [[her]82-elizabeth aunt]1198-her aunt , than to run such a risk . But against this there were objections ; and [she]82-elizabeth finally resolved that it could be the last resource , if [her]82-elizabeth private inquiries as to the absence of [the family]416-the family were unfavourably answered .

Accordingly , when [she]82-elizabeth retired at night , [she]82-elizabeth asked [the chambermaid]1868-the chambermaid whether [Pemberley]12-pemberley were not [a very fine place]1869-a very fine place , what was the name of [[its]12-pemberley proprietor]814-its proprietor , and , with no little alarm , whether [the family]416-the family were down for the summer ? A most welcome negative followed the last question ; and [her]82-elizabeth alarms being now removed , [she]82-elizabeth was at leisure to feel a great deal of curiosity to see [the house]3001-the house [herself]82-elizabeth ; and when the subject was revived the next morning , and [she]82-elizabeth was again applied to , could readily answer , and with a proper air of indifference , that [she]82-elizabeth had not really any dislike to the scheme .

To [Pemberley]12-pemberley , therefore , [they]1873-they were to go .

III .

[Elizabeth]82-elizabeth , as [they]1873-they drove along , watched for the first appearance of [Pemberley Woods]45-pemberley woods with some perturbation ; and when at length [they]1873-they turned in at [the lodge]1874-the lodge , [her]82-elizabeth spirits were in a high flutter .

[The park]1315-the park was very large , and contained great variety of ground . [They]1873-they entered [it]1315-the park in [one of [its]1315-the park lowest points]1876-one of its lowest points , and drove for some time through [a beautiful wood stretching over a wide extent]1877-a beautiful wood stretching over a wide extent .

[Elizabeth]82-elizabeth 's mind was too full for conversation , but [she]82-elizabeth saw and admired every remarkable spot and point of view . [They]1873-they gradually ascended for half a mile , and then found [themselves]1873-they at the top of a considerable eminence , where [the wood]1878-the wood ceased , and the eye was instantly caught by [Pemberley House]46-pemberley house , situated on [the opposite side of [the valley]1880-the valley]1879-the opposite side of the valley , into which [the road]1290-the road with some abruptness wound . [It]46-pemberley house was [a large , handsome stone building , standing well on rising ground , and backed by [a ridge of high woody hills]1883-a ridge of high woody hills]1882-a large , handsome stone building , standing well on rising ground , and backed by a ridge of high woody hills ; and in front a stream of some natural importance was swelled into greater , but without any artificial appearance . [Its]46-pemberley house banks were neither formal nor falsely adorned . [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth was delighted . [She]82-elizabeth had never seen a place for which nature had done more , or where natural beauty had been so little counteracted by an awkward taste . [They]1873-they were all of [them]1873-they warm in [their]1873-they admiration ; and at that moment [she]82-elizabeth felt that to be [mistress of [Pemberley]12-pemberley]1884-mistress of pemberley might be something !

[They]1873-they descended [the hill]1885-the hill , crossed [the bridge]1886-the bridge , and drove to the door ; and , while examining the nearer aspect of [the house]3001-the house , all [her]82-elizabeth apprehension of meeting [its owner]1841-its owner returned . [She]82-elizabeth dreaded lest [the chambermaid]1868-the chambermaid had been mistaken . On applying to see [the place]2998-the place , [they]1873-they were admitted into [the hall]685-the hall ; and [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth , as [they]1873-they waited for [the housekeeper]816-the housekeeper , had leisure to wonder at [her]816-the housekeeper being where [she]816-the housekeeper was .

[The housekeeper]816-the housekeeper came ; [a respectable looking elderly woman]1894-a respectable looking elderly woman , much less fine , and more civil , than [she]82-elizabeth had any notion of finding [her]816-the housekeeper . [They]1873-they followed [her]82-elizabeth into [the dining - parlour]518-the dining - parlour . It was [a large , well - proportioned room]1896-a large , well - proportioned room , handsomely fitted up . [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth , after slightly surveying [it]1896-a large , well - proportioned room , went to a window to enjoy [its]1896-a large , well - proportioned room prospect . [The hill]1885-the hill , crowned with wood , from which [they]1873-they had descended , receiving increased abruptness from the distance , was a beautiful object . Every disposition of [the ground]1898-the ground was good ; and [she]82-elizabeth looked on the whole scene , [the river]1899-the river , the trees scattered on [its]1899-the river banks , and [the winding of [the valley]1880-the valley]1900-the winding of the valley , as far as [she]82-elizabeth could trace it , with delight . As [they]1873-they passed into [other rooms]1902-other rooms , these objects were taking different positions ; but from every window there were beauties to be seen . [The rooms]1903-the rooms were lofty and handsome , and [their]1903-the rooms furniture suitable to the fortune of [[their]1903-the rooms proprietor]1904-their proprietor ; but [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth saw , with admiration of [his]1904-their proprietor taste , that it was neither gaudy nor uselessly fine,--with less of splendour , and more real elegance , than the furniture of Rosings .

" And of [this place]4473-this place , "[82-elizabeth] thought [she]82-elizabeth , " [I]82-elizabeth might have been [mistress]4474-mistress ! With [these rooms]4475-these rooms [I]82-elizabeth might have now been familiarly acquainted ! Instead of viewing [them]4475-these rooms as [a stranger]3408-a stranger , [I]82-elizabeth might have rejoiced in [them]4475-these rooms as [my]82-elizabeth own , and welcomed to [them]4475-these rooms as [visitors]4477-visitors [[my]82-elizabeth uncle]3488-my uncle and [aunt]3971-aunt . But , no , "[82-elizabeth] recollecting [herself]82-elizabeth , " that could never be ; [[my]82-elizabeth uncle]3488-my uncle and [aunt]3971-aunt would have been lost to [me]82-elizabeth ; [I]82-elizabeth should not have been allowed to invite [them]4477-visitors . "[82-elizabeth]

This was a lucky recollection -- it saved [her]82-elizabeth from something like regret .

[She]82-elizabeth longed to inquire of [the housekeeper]816-the housekeeper whether [[her]82-elizabeth master]1906-her master were really absent , but had not courage for it . At length , however , the question was asked by [[her]82-elizabeth uncle]573-her uncle ; and [she]82-elizabeth turned away with alarm , while [Mrs. Reynolds]183-mrs. reynolds replied , that [he]573-her uncle was ; adding , " But [we]1908-we expect [him]573-her uncle to - morrow , with [a large party of [friends]3787-friends]4482-a large party of friends . "[183-mrs. reynolds] How rejoiced was [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth that [their]1908-we own journey had not by any circumstance been delayed a day !

[[Her]82-elizabeth aunt]1198-her aunt now called [her]82-elizabeth to look at a picture . [She]82-elizabeth approached , and saw the likeness of [Mr. Wickham]136-wickham , suspended , amongst several other miniatures , over the mantel - piece . [[Her]82-elizabeth aunt]1198-her aunt asked [her]82-elizabeth , smilingly , how [she]82-elizabeth liked it . [The housekeeper]816-the housekeeper came forward , and told [them]1908-we it was the picture of [a young gentleman]1912-a young gentleman , [the son of [[her]82-elizabeth late master 's steward , who had been brought up by [him]1912-a young gentleman at [his]1912-a young gentleman own expense]1914-her late master 's steward , who had been brought up by him at his own expense]1913-the son of her late master 's steward , who had been brought up by him at his own expense . " [He]1912-a young gentleman is now gone into [the army]4484-the army , "[816-the housekeeper] [she]816-the housekeeper added ; " but [I]816-the housekeeper am afraid [he]1912-a young gentleman has turned out very wild . "[816-the housekeeper]

[Mrs. Gardiner]125-mrs. gardiner looked at [[her]125-mrs. gardiner niece]1276-her niece with a smile , but [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth could not return it .

" And that , "[183-mrs. reynolds] said [Mrs. Reynolds]183-mrs. reynolds , pointing to another of the miniatures , " is [[my]183-mrs. reynolds master]4485-my master -- and very like [him]1912-a young gentleman . It was drawn at the same time as the other -- about eight years ago . "[183-mrs. reynolds]

" [I]125-mrs. gardiner have heard much of [[your]82-elizabeth master]4486-your master 's fine person , "[125-mrs. gardiner] said [Mrs. Gardiner]125-mrs. gardiner , looking at the picture ; " it is a handsome face . But , [Lizzy]82-elizabeth , [you]82-elizabeth can tell [us]4487-us whether it is like or not . "[125-mrs. gardiner]

[Mrs. Reynolds]183-mrs. reynolds ' respect for [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth seemed to increase on this intimation of [her]82-elizabeth knowing [[her]82-elizabeth master]1906-her master .

" Does [that young lady]3630-that young lady know [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy ? "[183-mrs. reynolds]

[Elizabeth]82-elizabeth coloured , and said , " A little . "[82-elizabeth]

" And do not [you]183-mrs. reynolds think [him]89-mr. darcy [a very handsome gentleman]4489-a very handsome gentleman , [ma'am]3119-ma'am ? "[183-mrs. reynolds]

" Yes , very handsome . "[82-elizabeth]

" [I]183-mrs. reynolds am sure _ [I]183-mrs. reynolds _ know none so handsome ; but in [the gallery]4491-the gallery [upstairs]703-upstairs [you]4493-you will see a finer , larger picture of [him]89-mr. darcy than this . [This room]4494-this room was [[[my]183-mrs. reynolds late master]4495-my late master 's favourite room]4496-my late master 's favourite room , and these miniatures are just as they used to be then . [He]89-mr. darcy was very fond of them . "[183-mrs. reynolds]

This accounted to [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth for [Mr. Wickham]136-wickham 's being among [them]1917-them .

[Mrs. Reynolds]183-mrs. reynolds then directed [their]1918-their attention to one of [Miss Darcy]124-miss darcy , drawn when [she]124-miss darcy was only eight years old .

" And is [Miss Darcy]124-miss darcy as handsome as [[her]124-miss darcy brother]3108-her brother ? "[153-mr. gardiner] said [Mr. Gardiner]153-mr. gardiner .

" Oh , yes -- [the handsomest young lady that ever was seen]4498-the handsomest young lady that ever was seen ; and so accomplished ! [She]124-miss darcy plays and sings all day long . In [the next room]4499-the next room is a new instrument just come down for [her]124-miss darcy -- a present from [[my]153-mr. gardiner master]4485-my master : [she]124-miss darcy comes here to - morrow with [him]4485-my master . "[153-mr. gardiner]

[Mr. Gardiner]153-mr. gardiner , whose manners were easy and pleasant , encouraged [her]183-mrs. reynolds communicativeness by [his]153-mr. gardiner questions and remarks : [Mrs. Reynolds]183-mrs. reynolds , either from pride or attachment , had evidently great pleasure in talking of [[her]183-mrs. reynolds master]1906-her master and [[his]153-mr. gardiner sister]559-his sister .

" Is [[your]153-mr. gardiner master]4486-your master much at [Pemberley]12-pemberley in the course of the year ? "[153-mr. gardiner]

" Not so much as [I]153-mr. gardiner could wish , [sir]3161-sir : but [I]153-mr. gardiner dare say [he]4485-my master may spend half [his]4485-my master time [here]2994-here ; and [Miss Darcy]124-miss darcy is always down for the summer months . "[153-mr. gardiner]

" Except , "[82-elizabeth] thought [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth , " when [she]124-miss darcy goes to [Ramsgate]31-ramsgate . "[82-elizabeth]

" If [[your]153-mr. gardiner master]4486-your master would marry , [you]153-mr. gardiner might see more of [him]4485-my master . "[153-mr. gardiner]

" Yes , [sir]3161-sir ; but [I]82-elizabeth do not know when _ that _ will be . [I]82-elizabeth do not know who is good enough for [him]4485-my master . "[82-elizabeth]

[Mr.]1921-mr. and [Mrs. Gardiner]125-mrs. gardiner smiled . [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth could not help saying , " It is very much to [his]4485-my master credit , [I]82-elizabeth am sure , that [you]3161-sir should think so . "[82-elizabeth]

" [I]590-the other say no more than the truth , and what [everybody]304-everybody will say that knows [him]4485-my master , "[590-the other] replied [the other]590-the other . [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth thought this was going pretty far ; and [she]82-elizabeth listened with increasing astonishment as [the housekeeper]816-the housekeeper added , " [I]816-the housekeeper have never had a cross word from [him]4485-my master in [my]816-the housekeeper life , and [I]816-the housekeeper have known [him]4485-my master ever since [he]4485-my master was four years old . "[816-the housekeeper]

This was praise of all others most extraordinary , most opposite to [her]82-elizabeth ideas . That [he]1921-mr. was not [a good - tempered man]1924-a good - tempered man had been [her]82-elizabeth firmest opinion . [Her]82-elizabeth keenest attention was awakened : [she]82-elizabeth longed to hear more ; and was grateful to [[her]82-elizabeth uncle]573-her uncle for saying,--

" There are [very few people of whom so much can be said]4507-very few people of whom so much can be said . [You]82-elizabeth are lucky in having such [a master]4508-a master . "[573-her uncle]

" Yes , [sir]3161-sir , [I]82-elizabeth know [I]82-elizabeth am . If [I]82-elizabeth were to go through [the world]303-the world , [I]82-elizabeth could not meet with a better . But [I]82-elizabeth have always observed , that [they]4511-they who are good - natured when [children]4512-children , are good - natured when [they]4512-children grow up ; and [he]4508-a master was always [the sweetest tempered , most generous - hearted boy in [the world]303-the world]4513-the sweetest tempered , most generous - hearted boy in the world . "[82-elizabeth]

[Elizabeth]82-elizabeth almost stared at [her]573-her uncle . " Can this be [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy ? "[82-elizabeth] thought [she]82-elizabeth .

" [[His]4508-a master father]340-his father was [an excellent man]4516-an excellent man , "[125-mrs. gardiner] said [Mrs. Gardiner]125-mrs. gardiner .

" Yes , [ma'am]3119-ma'am , that [he]4508-a master was indeed ; and [[his]4508-a master son]3533-his son will be just like [him]4508-a master -- just as affable to [the poor]4519-the poor . "[82-elizabeth]

[Elizabeth]82-elizabeth listened , wondered , doubted , and was impatient for more . [Mrs. Reynolds]183-mrs. reynolds could interest [her]82-elizabeth on no other point . [She]82-elizabeth related the subjects of the pictures , the dimensions of [the rooms]1903-the rooms , and the price of the furniture in vain . [Mr. Gardiner]153-mr. gardiner , highly amused by the kind of family prejudice , to which [he]153-mr. gardiner attributed [her]82-elizabeth excessive commendation of [[her]82-elizabeth master]1906-her master , soon led again to the subject ; and [she]82-elizabeth dwelt with energy on [his]1906-her master many merits , as [they]1928-they proceeded together up the great staircase .

" [He]1906-her master is [the best landlord]4520-the best landlord , and [the best master]4521-the best master , "[82-elizabeth] said [she]82-elizabeth , " that ever lived . Not like [the wild young men now - a - days , who think of nothing but [themselves]4522-the wild young men now - a - days , who think of nothing but themselves]4522-the wild young men now - a - days , who think of nothing but themselves . There is not one of [[his]1906-her master tenants]3556-his tenants or [servants]3324-servants but what will give [him]1906-her master a good name . [Some people]4118-some people call [him]1906-her master proud ; but [I]82-elizabeth am sure [I]82-elizabeth never saw anything of it . To [my]82-elizabeth fancy , it is only because [he]1906-her master does not rattle away like [other young men]4526-other young men . "[82-elizabeth]

" In what an amiable light does this place [him]1906-her master ! "[82-elizabeth] thought [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth .

" This fine account of [him]1906-her master , "[1198-her aunt] whispered [[her]82-elizabeth aunt]1198-her aunt as [they]1930-they walked , " is not quite consistent with [his]1906-her master behaviour to [[our]1930-they poor friend]4527-our poor friend . "[1198-her aunt]

" Perhaps [we]1930-they might be deceived . "[1198-her aunt]

" That is not very likely ; [our]1930-they authority was too good . "[1198-her aunt]

On reaching [the spacious lobby above]1931-the spacious lobby above , [they]1930-they were shown into [a very pretty sitting - room]1932-a very pretty sitting - room , lately fitted up with greater elegance and lightness than [the apartments below]1933-the apartments below ; and were informed that it was but just done to give pleasure to [Miss Darcy]124-miss darcy , who had taken a liking to [the room]250-the room , when last at [Pemberley]12-pemberley .

" [He]1906-her master is certainly [a good brother]4528-a good brother , "[82-elizabeth] said [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth , as [she]82-elizabeth walked towards one of the windows .

[Mrs. Reynolds]183-mrs. reynolds anticipated [Miss Darcy]124-miss darcy 's delight , when [she]183-mrs. reynolds should enter [the room]250-the room . " And this is always the way with [him]1906-her master , "[183-mrs. reynolds] [she]183-mrs. reynolds added . " Whatever can give [[his]1906-her master sister]559-his sister any pleasure , is sure to be done in a moment . There is nothing [he]1906-her master would not do for [her]559-his sister . "[183-mrs. reynolds]

[The picture gallery]1936-the picture gallery , and two or three of [the principal bed - rooms]1937-the principal bed - rooms , were all that remained to be shown . In the former were many good paintings : but [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth knew nothing of the art ; and from such as had been already visible below , [she]82-elizabeth had willingly turned to look at some drawings of [Miss Darcy]124-miss darcy 's , in crayons , whose subjects were usually more interesting , and also more intelligible .

In [the gallery]4491-the gallery there were many family portraits , but they could have little to fix the attention of [a stranger]3408-a stranger . [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth walked on in quest of the only face whose features would be known to [her]82-elizabeth . At last it arrested [her]82-elizabeth -- and [she]82-elizabeth beheld a striking resemblance of [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy , with such a smile over the face , as [she]82-elizabeth remembered to have sometimes seen , when [he]89-mr. darcy looked at [her]82-elizabeth . [She]82-elizabeth stood several minutes before the picture , in earnest contemplation , and returned to it again before [they]1940-they quitted [the gallery]4491-the gallery . [Mrs. Reynolds]183-mrs. reynolds informed [them]1940-they , that it had been taken in [[his]89-mr. darcy father]340-his father 's lifetime .

There was certainly at this moment , in [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth 's mind , a more gentle sensation towards the original than [she]82-elizabeth had ever felt in the height of [their]1940-they acquaintance . The commendation bestowed on [him]89-mr. darcy by [Mrs. Reynolds]183-mrs. reynolds was of no trifling nature . What praise is more valuable than the praise of [an intelligent servant]1943-an intelligent servant ? As [a brother]440-a brother , [a landlord]1945-a landlord , [a master]4508-a master , [she]82-elizabeth considered how many [people]3234-people 's happiness were in [his]89-mr. darcy guardianship ! How much of pleasure or pain it was in [his]89-mr. darcy power to bestow ! How much of good or evil must be done by [him]89-mr. darcy ! Every idea that had been brought forward by [the housekeeper]816-the housekeeper was favourable to [his]89-mr. darcy character ; and as [she]82-elizabeth stood before the canvas , on which [he]89-mr. darcy was represented , and fixed [his]89-mr. darcy eyes upon [herself]82-elizabeth , [she]82-elizabeth thought of [his]89-mr. darcy regard with a deeper sentiment of gratitude than it had ever raised before : [she]82-elizabeth remembered its warmth , and softened its impropriety of expression .

When all of [the house]3001-the house that was open to general inspection had been seen , [they]1950-they returned down stairs ; and , taking leave of [the housekeeper]816-the housekeeper , were consigned over to [the gardener]1952-the gardener , who met [them]1950-they at [the hall]685-the hall door .

As [they]1950-they walked across [the lawn]1954-the lawn towards [the river]1899-the river , [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth turned back to look again ; [[her]82-elizabeth uncle]573-her uncle and [aunt]3971-aunt stopped also ; and while [the former]327-the former was conjecturing as to the date of [the building]1959-the building , [the owner of [it]1959-the building [himself]1960-the owner of it himself]1960-the owner of it himself suddenly came forward from [the road]1290-the road which led behind [it]1959-the building to [the stables]1962-the stables .

[They]1950-they were within twenty yards of [each other]3144-each other ; and so abrupt was [his]1960-the owner of it himself appearance , that it was impossible to avoid [his]1960-the owner of it himself sight . [Their]1950-they eyes instantly met , and the cheeks of each were overspread with the deepest blush . [He]1960-the owner of it himself absolutely started , and for a moment seemed immovable from surprise ; but shortly recovering [himself]1960-the owner of it himself , advanced towards the party , and spoke to [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth , if not in terms of perfect composure , at least of perfect civility .

[She]82-elizabeth had instinctively turned away ; but stopping on [his]1960-the owner of it himself approach , received [his]1960-the owner of it himself compliments with an embarrassment impossible to be overcome . Had [his]1960-the owner of it himself first appearance , or [his]1960-the owner of it himself resemblance to the picture [they]1950-they had just been examining , been insufficient to assure [the other two]1964-the other two that [they]1950-they now saw [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy , [the gardener]1952-the gardener 's expression of surprise , on beholding [[his]1960-the owner of it himself master]1966-his master , must immediately have told it . [They]1950-they stood a little aloof while [he]1960-the owner of it himself was talking to [[their]1950-they niece]1967-their niece , who , astonished and confused , scarcely dared lift [her]1967-their niece eyes to [his]1960-the owner of it himself face , and knew not what answer [she]1967-their niece returned to [his]1960-the owner of it himself civil inquiries after [[her]1967-their niece family]885-her family . Amazed at the alteration of [his]1960-the owner of it himself manner since [they]1950-they last parted , every sentence that [he]1960-the owner of it himself uttered was increasing [her]1967-their niece embarrassment ; and every idea of the impropriety of [her]1967-their niece being found there recurring to [her]1967-their niece mind , the few minutes in which [they]1950-they continued together were some of the most uncomfortable of [her]1967-their niece life . Nor did [he]1960-the owner of it himself seem much more at ease ; when [he]1960-the owner of it himself spoke , [his]1960-the owner of it himself accent had none of its usual sedateness ; and [he]1960-the owner of it himself repeated [his]1960-the owner of it himself inquiries as to the time of [her]1967-their niece having left [Longbourn]7-longbourn , and of [her]1967-their niece stay in [Derbyshire]6-derbyshire , so often , and in so hurried a way , as plainly spoke the distraction of [his]1960-the owner of it himself thoughts .

At length , every idea seemed to fail [him]1960-the owner of it himself ; and after standing a few moments without saying a word , [he]1960-the owner of it himself suddenly recollected [himself]1960-the owner of it himself , and took leave .

[The others]507-the others then joined [her]1967-their niece , and expressed [their]507-the others admiration of [his]1960-the owner of it himself figure ; but [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth heard not a word , and , wholly engrossed by [her]82-elizabeth own feelings , followed [them]507-the others in silence . [She]82-elizabeth was overpowered by shame and vexation . [Her]82-elizabeth coming there was the most unfortunate , the most ill - judged thing in [the world]303-the world ! How strange must it appear to [him]1960-the owner of it himself ! In what a disgraceful light might it not strike so vain [a man]3042-a man ! It might seem as if [she]1967-their niece had purposely thrown [herself]1967-their niece in [his]1960-the owner of it himself way again ! Oh ! why did [she]1967-their niece come ? or , why did [he]1960-the owner of it himself thus come a day before [he]1960-the owner of it himself was expected ? Had [they]1972-they been only ten minutes sooner , [they]1972-they should have been beyond the reach of [his]1960-the owner of it himself discrimination ; for it was plain that [he]1960-the owner of it himself was that moment arrived , that moment alighted from [his]1960-the owner of it himself horse or [[his]1960-the owner of it himself carriage]1973-his carriage . [She]82-elizabeth blushed again and again over the perverseness of the meeting . And [his]1960-the owner of it himself behaviour , so strikingly altered,--what could it mean ? That [he]1960-the owner of it himself should even speak to [her]82-elizabeth was amazing!--but to speak with such civility , to inquire after [[her]82-elizabeth family]885-her family ! Never in [her]82-elizabeth life had [she]82-elizabeth seen [his]1960-the owner of it himself manners so little dignified , never had [he]1960-the owner of it himself spoken with such gentleness as on this unexpected meeting . What a contrast did it offer to [his]1960-the owner of it himself last address in [Rosings Park]19-rosings park , when [he]1960-the owner of it himself put [his]1960-the owner of it himself letter into [her]82-elizabeth hand ! [She]82-elizabeth knew not what to think , or how to account for it .

[They]1975-they had now entered a beautiful walk by [the side of the water]1976-the side of the water , and every step was bringing forward a nobler fall of ground , or a finer reach of [the woods to which [they]1975-they were approaching]1977-the woods to which they were approaching : but it was some time before [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth was sensible of any of it ; and , though [she]82-elizabeth answered mechanically to the repeated appeals of [[her]82-elizabeth uncle]573-her uncle and [aunt]3971-aunt , and seemed to direct [her]82-elizabeth eyes to such objects as [they]1975-they pointed out , [she]82-elizabeth distinguished no part of the scene . [Her]82-elizabeth thoughts were all fixed on [that one spot of [Pemberley House]46-pemberley house]1980-that one spot of pemberley house , whichever it might be , where [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy then was . [She]82-elizabeth longed to know what at that moment was passing in [his]89-mr. darcy mind ; in what manner [he]89-mr. darcy thought of [her]82-elizabeth , and whether , in defiance of everything , [she]82-elizabeth was still dear to [him]89-mr. darcy . Perhaps [he]89-mr. darcy had been civil only because [he]89-mr. darcy felt [himself]89-mr. darcy at ease ; yet there had been _ that _ in [his]89-mr. darcy voice , which was not like ease . Whether [he]89-mr. darcy had felt more of pain or of pleasure in seeing [her]82-elizabeth , [she]82-elizabeth could not tell , but [he]89-mr. darcy certainly had not seen [her]82-elizabeth with composure .

At length , however , the remarks of [[her]82-elizabeth companions]3898-her companions on [her]82-elizabeth absence of mind roused [her]82-elizabeth , and [she]82-elizabeth felt the necessity of appearing more like [herself]82-elizabeth .

[They]1982-they entered [the woods]1983-the woods , and , bidding adieu to [the river]1899-the river for a while , ascended some of [the higher grounds]1985-the higher grounds ; whence , in spots where the opening of the trees gave the eye power to wander , were many charming views of [the valley]1880-the valley , [the opposite hills]1987-the opposite hills , with [the long range of woods]1988-the long range of woods overspreading many , and occasionally part of [the stream]1989-the stream . [Mr. Gardiner]153-mr. gardiner expressed a wish of going round [the whole park]1990-the whole park , but feared it might be beyond a walk . With a triumphant smile , [they]1982-they were told , that it was ten miles round . It settled the matter ; and [they]1982-they pursued the accustomed circuit ; which brought [them]1982-they again , after some time , in a descent among [hanging woods]1991-hanging woods , to the edge of [the water]1992-the water , and one of [its]1992-the water narrowest parts . [They]1982-they crossed [it]1992-the water by [a simple bridge]1993-a simple bridge , in character with the general air of the scene : it was [a spot less adorned than any [they]1982-they had yet visited]1994-a spot less adorned than any they had yet visited ; and [the valley]1880-the valley , here contracted into [a glen]1996-a glen , allowed room only for [the stream]1989-the stream , and a narrow walk amidst the rough coppice - wood which bordered [it]1992-the water . [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth longed to explore [its]1992-the water windings ; but when [they]1982-they had crossed [the bridge]1886-the bridge , and perceived [their]1982-they distance from [the house]3001-the house , [Mrs. Gardiner]125-mrs. gardiner , who was not [a great walker]2000-a great walker , could go no farther , and thought only of returning to [the carriage]3217-the carriage as quickly as possible . [[Her]125-mrs. gardiner niece]1276-her niece was , therefore , obliged to submit , and [they]1982-they took [their]1982-they way towards [the house]3001-the house on [the opposite side of [the river]1899-the river]2004-the opposite side of the river , in the nearest direction ; but [their]1982-they progress was slow , for [Mr. Gardiner]153-mr. gardiner , though seldom able to indulge the taste , was very fond of fishing , and was so much engaged in watching the occasional appearance of some trout in the water , and talking to [the man]3091-the man about [them]2007-them , that [he]153-mr. gardiner advanced but little . Whilst wandering on in this slow manner , [they]1982-they were again surprised , and [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth 's astonishment was quite equal to what it had been at first , by the sight of [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy approaching [them]1982-they , and at no great distance . The walk being here less sheltered than on the other side , allowed [them]1982-they to see [him]3091-the man before [they]1982-they met . [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth , however astonished , was at least more prepared for an interview than before , and resolved to appear and to speak with calmness , if [he]3091-the man really intended to meet [them]1982-they . For a few moments , indeed , [she]82-elizabeth felt that [he]3091-the man would probably strike into some other path . The idea lasted while a turning in the walk concealed [him]3091-the man from [their]1982-they view ; the turning past , [he]3091-the man was immediately before [them]1982-they . With a glance [she]82-elizabeth saw that [he]3091-the man had lost none of [his]3091-the man recent civility ; and , to imitate [his]3091-the man politeness , [she]82-elizabeth began as [they]1982-they met to admire the beauty of [the place]2998-the place ; but [she]82-elizabeth had not got beyond the words " delightful , "[82-elizabeth] and " charming , "[82-elizabeth] when some unlucky recollections obtruded , and [she]82-elizabeth fancied that praise of [Pemberley]12-pemberley from [her]82-elizabeth might be mischievously construed . [Her]82-elizabeth colour changed , and [she]82-elizabeth said no more .

[Mrs. Gardiner]125-mrs. gardiner was standing a little behind ; and on [her]82-elizabeth pausing , [he]3091-the man asked [her]82-elizabeth if [she]82-elizabeth would do [him]3091-the man the honour of introducing [him]3091-the man to [[her]82-elizabeth friends]310-her friends . This was a stroke of civility for which [she]82-elizabeth was quite unprepared ; and [she]82-elizabeth could hardly suppress a smile at [his]3091-the man being now seeking the acquaintance of [some of those very people , against whom [his]3091-the man pride had revolted]2010-some of those very people , against whom his pride had revolted , in [his]3091-the man offer to [herself]82-elizabeth . " What will be [his]3091-the man surprise , "[82-elizabeth] thought [she]82-elizabeth , " when [he]3091-the man knows who [they]310-her friends are ! [He]3091-the man takes them now for [people of fashion]4530-people of fashion . "[82-elizabeth]

The introduction , however , was immediately made ; and as [she]82-elizabeth named [their]2011-them relationship to [herself]82-elizabeth , [she]82-elizabeth stole a sly look at [him]3091-the man , to see how [he]3091-the man bore it ; and was not without the expectation of [his]3091-the man decamping as fast as [he]3091-the man could from [such disgraceful companions]2012-such disgraceful companions . That [he]3091-the man was _ surprised _ by the connection was evident : [he]3091-the man sustained it , however , with fortitude : and , so far from going away , turned back with [them]2011-them , and entered into conversation with [Mr. Gardiner]153-mr. gardiner . [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth could not but be pleased , could not but triumph . It was consoling that [he]3091-the man should know [she]82-elizabeth had [some relations for whom there was no need to blush]2013-some relations for whom there was no need to blush . [She]82-elizabeth listened most attentively to all that passed between [them]2011-them , and gloried in every expression , every sentence of [[her]82-elizabeth uncle]573-her uncle , which marked [his]3091-the man intelligence , [his]3091-the man taste , or [his]3091-the man good manners .

The conversation soon turned upon fishing ; and [she]82-elizabeth heard [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy invite [him]3091-the man , with the greatest civility , to fish there as often as [he]3091-the man chose , while [he]3091-the man continued in [the neighbourhood]3015-the neighbourhood , offering at the same time to supply [him]3091-the man with fishing tackle , and pointing out [those parts of [the stream where there was usually most sport]2017-the stream where there was usually most sport]2016-those parts of the stream where there was usually most sport . [Mrs. Gardiner]125-mrs. gardiner , who was walking arm in arm with [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth , gave [her]82-elizabeth a look expressive of [her]82-elizabeth wonder . [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth said nothing , but it gratified [her]82-elizabeth exceedingly ; the compliment must be all for [herself]82-elizabeth . [Her]82-elizabeth astonishment , however , was extreme ; and continually was [she]82-elizabeth repeating , " Why is [he]3091-the man so altered ? From what can it proceed ? It can not be for _ [me]82-elizabeth _ , it can not be for _ [my]82-elizabeth _ sake that [his]3091-the man manners are thus softened . [My]82-elizabeth reproofs at [Hunsford]15-hunsford could not work such a change as this . It is impossible that [he]3091-the man should still love [me]82-elizabeth . "[82-elizabeth]

After walking some time in this way , [the two ladies in front]2018-the two ladies in front , [the two gentlemen]760-the two gentlemen behind , on resuming [their]760-the two gentlemen places , after descending to [the brink of [the river]1899-the river]2020-the brink of the river for the better inspection of [some curious water - plant]2022-some curious water - plant , there chanced to be a little alteration . It originated in [Mrs. Gardiner]125-mrs. gardiner , who , fatigued by the exercise of the morning , found [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth 's arm inadequate to [her]125-mrs. gardiner support , and consequently preferred [[her]125-mrs. gardiner husband]255-her husband 's . [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy took [her]125-mrs. gardiner place by [[her]125-mrs. gardiner niece]1276-her niece , and [they]2025-we walked on together . After a short silence [the lady]584-the lady first spoke . [She]584-the lady wished [him]255-her husband to know that [she]584-the lady had been assured of [his]255-her husband absence before [she]584-the lady came to [the place]2998-the place , and accordingly began by observing , that [his]255-her husband arrival had been very unexpected--"for [[your]255-her husband housekeeper]4531-your housekeeper , "[584-the lady] [she]584-the lady added , " informed [us]2025-we that [you]255-her husband would certainly not be here till to - morrow ; and , indeed , before [we]2025-we left [Bakewell]47-bakewell , [we]2025-we understood that [you]255-her husband were not immediately expected in [the country]448-the country . "[584-the lady] [He]255-her husband acknowledged the truth of it all ; and said that business with [[his]255-her husband steward]2028-his steward had occasioned [his]255-her husband coming forward a few hours before the rest of [the party with whom [he]255-her husband had been travelling]2029-the party with whom he had been travelling . " [They]4533-they will join [me]255-her husband early to - morrow , "[255-her husband] [he]255-her husband continued , " and among [them]4533-they are [some who will claim an acquaintance with [you,--Mr . Bingley]79-mr. bingley and [[his]255-her husband sisters]282-his sisters]4534-some who will claim an acquaintance with you,--mr . bingley and his sisters . "[255-her husband]

[Elizabeth]82-elizabeth answered only by a slight bow . [Her]82-elizabeth thoughts were instantly driven back to the time when [Mr. Bingley]79-mr. bingley 's name had been last mentioned between [them]2030-them ; and if [she]82-elizabeth might judge from [his]255-her husband complexion , _ [his]255-her husband _ mind was not very differently engaged .

" There is also [one other person in the party]4536-one other person in the party , "[255-her husband] [he]255-her husband continued after a pause , " who more particularly wishes to be known to [you]82-elizabeth . Will [you]82-elizabeth allow [me]255-her husband , or do [I]255-her husband ask too much , to introduce [[my]255-her husband sister]3280-my sister to [your]82-elizabeth acquaintance during [your]82-elizabeth stay at [Lambton]44-lambton ? "[255-her husband]

The surprise of such an application was great indeed ; it was too great for [her]82-elizabeth to know in what manner [she]82-elizabeth acceded to it . [She]82-elizabeth immediately felt that whatever desire [Miss Darcy]124-miss darcy might have of being acquainted with [her]82-elizabeth , must be the work of [[her]82-elizabeth brother]3108-her brother , and without looking farther , it was satisfactory ; it was gratifying to know that [his]255-her husband resentment had not made [him]255-her husband think really ill of [her]82-elizabeth .

[They]2032-they now walked on in silence ; each of [them]2032-they deep in thought . [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth was not comfortable ; that was impossible ; but [she]82-elizabeth was flattered and pleased . [His]255-her husband wish of introducing [[his]255-her husband sister]559-his sister to [her]82-elizabeth was a compliment of the highest kind . [They]2032-they soon outstripped [the others]507-the others ; and when [they]2032-they had reached [the carriage]3217-the carriage , [Mr.]2036-mr. and [Mrs. Gardiner]125-mrs. gardiner were half a quarter of a mile behind .

[He]255-her husband then asked [her]82-elizabeth to walk into [the house]3001-the house -- but [she]82-elizabeth declared [herself]82-elizabeth not tired , and [they]2032-they stood together on [the lawn]1954-the lawn . At such a time much might have been said , and silence was very awkward . [She]82-elizabeth wanted to talk , but there seemed an embargo on every subject . At last [she]82-elizabeth recollected that [she]82-elizabeth had been travelling , and [they]2032-they talked of [Matlock]35-matlock and [Dovedale]37-dovedale with great perseverance . Yet time and [[her]82-elizabeth aunt]1198-her aunt moved slowly -- and [her]82-elizabeth patience and [her]82-elizabeth ideas were nearly worn out before the _ tete - a - tete _ was over .

On [Mr.]2040-mr. and [Mrs. Gardiner]125-mrs. gardiner 's coming up [they]2032-they were all pressed to go into [the house]3001-the house and take some refreshment ; but this was declined , and [they]2032-they parted on each side with the utmost politeness . [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy handed [the ladies]249-the ladies into [the carriage]3217-the carriage ; and when [it]3217-the carriage drove off , [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth saw [him]89-mr. darcy walking slowly towards [the house]3001-the house .

The observations of [[her]82-elizabeth uncle]573-her uncle and [aunt]3971-aunt now began ; and each of [them]2032-they pronounced [him]89-mr. darcy to be infinitely superior to anything [they]2032-they had expected .

" [He]89-mr. darcy is perfectly well - behaved , polite , and unassuming , "[573-her uncle] said [[her]82-elizabeth uncle]573-her uncle .

" There _ is _ something a little stately in [him]89-mr. darcy , to be sure , "[1198-her aunt] replied [[her]82-elizabeth aunt]1198-her aunt ; " but it is confined to [his]89-mr. darcy air , and is not unbecoming . [I]1198-her aunt can now say with [the housekeeper]816-the housekeeper , that though [some people]4118-some people may call [him]89-mr. darcy proud , _ [I]1198-her aunt _ have seen nothing of it . "[1198-her aunt]
