" [I]1198-her aunt was never more surprised than by [his]89-mr. darcy behaviour to [us]2032-they . It was more than civil ; it was really attentive ; and there was no necessity for such attention . [His]89-mr. darcy acquaintance with [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth was very trifling . "[1198-her aunt]

" To be sure , [Lizzy]82-elizabeth , "[1198-her aunt] said [[her]82-elizabeth aunt]1198-her aunt , " [he]89-mr. darcy is not so handsome as [Wickham]136-wickham ; or rather [he]89-mr. darcy has not [Wickham]136-wickham 's countenance , for [his]89-mr. darcy features are perfectly good . But how came [you]82-elizabeth to tell [us]2051-us that [he]89-mr. darcy was so disagreeable ? "[1198-her aunt]

[Elizabeth]82-elizabeth excused [herself]82-elizabeth as well as [she]82-elizabeth could : said that [she]82-elizabeth had liked [him]2050-him better when [they]2051-us met in [Kent]17-kent than before , and that [she]82-elizabeth had never seen [him]2050-him so pleasant as this morning .

" But perhaps [he]89-mr. darcy may be a little whimsical in [his]89-mr. darcy civilities , "[573-her uncle] replied [[her]82-elizabeth uncle]573-her uncle . " [[Your]82-elizabeth great men]4540-your great men often are ; and therefore [I]573-her uncle shall not take [him]89-mr. darcy at [his]89-mr. darcy word about fishing , as [he]89-mr. darcy might change [his]89-mr. darcy mind another day , and warn [me]573-her uncle off [[his]89-mr. darcy grounds]4541-his grounds . "[573-her uncle]

[Elizabeth]82-elizabeth felt that [they]2051-us had entirely mistaken [his]2050-him character , but said nothing .

" From what [we]2051-us have seen of [him]89-mr. darcy , "[125-mrs. gardiner] continued [Mrs. Gardiner]125-mrs. gardiner , " [I]125-mrs. gardiner really should not have thought that [he]89-mr. darcy could have behaved in so cruel a way by [anybody]3099-anybody as [he]89-mr. darcy has done by [poor Wickham]136-wickham . [He]89-mr. darcy has not an ill - natured look . On the contrary , there is something pleasing about [his]89-mr. darcy mouth when [he]89-mr. darcy speaks . And there is something of dignity in [his]89-mr. darcy countenance , that would not give one an unfavourable idea of [his]89-mr. darcy heart . But , to be sure , [the good lady who showed [us]2051-us [the house]3001-the house]4543-the good lady who showed us the house did give [him]89-mr. darcy a most flaming character ! [I]125-mrs. gardiner could hardly help laughing aloud sometimes . But [he]89-mr. darcy is [a liberal master]4545-a liberal master , [I]125-mrs. gardiner suppose , and _ that _ , in the eye of [a servant]499-a servant , comprehends every virtue . "[125-mrs. gardiner]

[Elizabeth]82-elizabeth here felt [herself]82-elizabeth called on to say something in vindication of [his]2053-his behaviour to [Wickham]136-wickham ; and , therefore , gave [them]2054-they to understand , in as guarded a manner as [she]82-elizabeth could , that by what [she]82-elizabeth had heard from [[his]2053-his relations in [Kent]17-kent]2055-his relations in kent , [his]2053-his actions were capable of a very different construction ; and that [his]2053-his character was by no means so faulty , nor [Wickham]136-wickham 's so amiable , as they had been considered in [Hertfordshire]4-hertfordshire . In confirmation of this , [she]82-elizabeth related the particulars of all the pecuniary transactions in which [they]2054-they had been connected , without actually naming [her]82-elizabeth authority , but stating it to be such as might be relied on .

[Mrs. Gardiner]125-mrs. gardiner was surprised and concerned : but as [they]2054-they were now approaching the scene of [her]125-mrs. gardiner former pleasures , every idea gave way to the charm of recollection ; and [she]125-mrs. gardiner was too much engaged in pointing out to [[her]125-mrs. gardiner husband]255-her husband all the interesting spots in [[its]2057-its environs]2058-its environs , to think of anything else . Fatigued as [she]125-mrs. gardiner had been by the morning 's walk , [they]2054-they had no sooner dined than [she]125-mrs. gardiner set off again in quest of [[her]125-mrs. gardiner former acquaintance]2059-her former acquaintance , and the evening was spent in the satisfactions of an intercourse renewed after many years ' discontinuance .

The occurrences of the day were too full of interest to leave [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth much attention for [any of [these new friends]2061-these new friends]2060-any of these new friends ; and [she]82-elizabeth could do nothing but think , and think with wonder , of [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy 's civility , and , above all , of [his]89-mr. darcy wishing [her]82-elizabeth to be acquainted with [[his]89-mr. darcy sister]559-his sister .

IV .

[Elizabeth]82-elizabeth had settled it that [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy would bring [[his]89-mr. darcy sister]559-his sister to visit [her]82-elizabeth the very day after [her]82-elizabeth reaching [Pemberley]12-pemberley ; and was , consequently , resolved not to be out of sight of [the inn]1717-the inn the whole of that morning . But [her]82-elizabeth conclusion was false ; for on the very morning after [their]2061-these new friends own arrival at [Lambton]44-lambton [these visitors]2065-these visitors came . [They]2061-these new friends had been walking about [the place]2998-the place with [some of [[their]2061-these new friends new friends]2068-their new friends]2067-some of their new friends , and were just returned to [the inn]1717-the inn to dress [themselves]2061-these new friends for dining with [the same family]2070-the same family , when the sound of [a carriage]3123-a carriage drew [them]2061-these new friends to a window , and [they]2061-these new friends saw [a gentleman]3407-a gentleman and lady in a curricle driving up [the street]748-the street . [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth , immediately recognizing the livery , guessed what it meant , and imparted no small degree of surprise to [[her]82-elizabeth relations]577-her relations , by acquainting [them]577-her relations with the honour which [she]82-elizabeth expected . [[Her]82-elizabeth uncle]573-her uncle and [aunt]3971-aunt were all amazement ; and the embarrassment of [her]82-elizabeth manner as [she]82-elizabeth spoke , joined to the circumstance itself , and many of the circumstances of the preceding day , opened to [them]2061-these new friends a new idea on the business . Nothing had ever suggested it before , but [they]2061-these new friends now felt that there was no other way of accounting for such attentions from such a quarter than by supposing a partiality for [[their]2061-these new friends niece]1967-their niece . While these newly - born notions were passing in [their]2061-these new friends heads , the perturbation of [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth 's feelings was every moment increasing . [She]82-elizabeth was quite amazed at [her]82-elizabeth own discomposure ; but , amongst other causes of disquiet , [she]82-elizabeth dreaded lest the partiality of [the brother]1245-the brother should have said too much in [her]82-elizabeth favour ; and , more than commonly anxious to please , [she]82-elizabeth naturally suspected that every power of pleasing would fail [her]82-elizabeth .

[She]82-elizabeth retreated from the window , fearful of being seen ; and as [she]82-elizabeth walked up and down [the room]250-the room , endeavouring to compose [herself]82-elizabeth , saw such looks of inquiring surprise in [[her]82-elizabeth uncle]573-her uncle and [aunt]3971-aunt as made everything worse .

[Miss Darcy]124-miss darcy and [[her]124-miss darcy brother]3108-her brother appeared , and this formidable introduction took place . With astonishment did [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth see that [[her]82-elizabeth new acquaintance]2083-her new acquaintance was at least as much embarrassed as [herself]82-elizabeth . Since [her]82-elizabeth being at [Lambton]44-lambton , [she]82-elizabeth had heard that [Miss Darcy]124-miss darcy was exceedingly proud ; but the observation of a very few minutes convinced [her]82-elizabeth that [she]82-elizabeth was only exceedingly shy . [She]82-elizabeth found it difficult to obtain even a word from [her]82-elizabeth beyond a monosyllable .

[Miss Darcy]124-miss darcy was tall , and on a larger scale than [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth ; and , though little more than sixteen , [her]124-miss darcy figure was formed , and [her]124-miss darcy appearance womanly and graceful . [She]124-miss darcy was less handsome than [[her]124-miss darcy brother]3108-her brother , but there was sense and good - humour in [her]124-miss darcy face , and [her]124-miss darcy manners were perfectly unassuming and gentle . [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth , who had expected to find in [her]82-elizabeth as acute and unembarrassed an observer as ever [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy had been , was much relieved by discerning such different feelings .

[They]2085-they had not been long together before [Darcy]89-mr. darcy told [her]82-elizabeth that [Bingley]79-mr. bingley was also coming to wait on [her]82-elizabeth ; and [she]82-elizabeth had barely time to express [her]82-elizabeth satisfaction , and prepare for such a visitor , when [Bingley]79-mr. bingley 's quick step was heard on the stairs , and in a moment [he]79-mr. bingley entered [the room]250-the room . All [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth 's anger against [him]89-mr. darcy had been long done away ; but had [she]82-elizabeth still felt any , it could hardly have stood its ground against the unaffected cordiality with which [he]89-mr. darcy expressed [himself]89-mr. darcy on seeing [her]82-elizabeth again . [He]89-mr. darcy inquired in a friendly , though general , way , after [[her]82-elizabeth family]885-her family , and looked and spoke with the same good - humoured ease that [he]89-mr. darcy had ever done .

To [Mr.]2088-mr. and [Mrs. Gardiner]125-mrs. gardiner [he]89-mr. darcy was scarcely [a less interesting personage]2089-a less interesting personage than to [herself]82-elizabeth . [They]2090-they had long wished to see [him]89-mr. darcy . [The whole party before [them]2090-they]2091-the whole party before them , indeed , excited a lively attention . The suspicions which had just arisen of [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy and [[their]2090-they niece]1967-their niece , directed [their]2090-they observation towards [each]867-each with an earnest , though guarded , inquiry ; and [they]2090-they soon drew from those inquiries the full conviction that one of [them]2090-they at least knew what it was to love . Of [the lady]584-the lady 's sensations [they]2090-they remained a little in doubt ; but that [the gentleman]285-the gentleman was overflowing with admiration was evident enough .

[Elizabeth]82-elizabeth , on [her]82-elizabeth side , had much to do . [She]82-elizabeth wanted to ascertain the feelings of [each of [[her]82-elizabeth visitors]1370-her visitors]2096-each of her visitors , [she]82-elizabeth wanted to compose [her]82-elizabeth own , and to make [herself]82-elizabeth agreeable to all ; and in the latter object , where [she]82-elizabeth feared most to fail , [she]82-elizabeth was most sure of success , for those to whom [she]82-elizabeth endeavoured to give pleasure were pre - possessed in [her]82-elizabeth favour . [Bingley]79-mr. bingley was ready , [Georgiana]147-georgiana was eager , and [Darcy]147-georgiana determined , to be pleased .

In seeing [Bingley]79-mr. bingley , [her]82-elizabeth thoughts naturally flew to [[her]82-elizabeth sister]328-her sister ; and oh ! how ardently did [she]82-elizabeth long to know whether any of [his]79-mr. bingley were directed in a like manner . Sometimes [she]82-elizabeth could fancy that [he]79-mr. bingley talked less than on former occasions , and once or twice pleased [herself]82-elizabeth with the notion that , as [he]79-mr. bingley looked at [her]82-elizabeth , [he]79-mr. bingley was trying to trace a resemblance . But , though this might be imaginary , [she]82-elizabeth could not be deceived as to [his]79-mr. bingley behaviour to [Miss Darcy]124-miss darcy , who had been set up as a rival to [Jane]83-jane . No look appeared on either side that spoke particular regard . Nothing occurred between [them]2099-we that could justify the hopes of [[his]79-mr. bingley sister]559-his sister . On this point [she]82-elizabeth was soon satisfied ; and two or three little circumstances occurred ere [they]2099-we parted , which , in [her]82-elizabeth anxious interpretation , denoted a recollection of [Jane]83-jane , not untinctured by tenderness , and a wish of saying more that might lead to the mention of [her]83-jane , had [he]79-mr. bingley dared . [He]79-mr. bingley observed to [her]82-elizabeth , at a moment when [the others]507-the others were talking together , and in a tone which had something of real regret , that it " was a very long time since [he]79-mr. bingley had had the pleasure of seeing [her]83-jane ; "[79-mr. bingley] and , before [she]82-elizabeth could reply , [he]79-mr. bingley added , " It is above eight months . [We]2099-we have not met since the 26th of November , when [we]2099-we were all dancing together at [Netherfield]2-netherfield . "[79-mr. bingley]

[Elizabeth]82-elizabeth was pleased to find [his]79-mr. bingley memory so exact ; and [he]79-mr. bingley afterwards took occasion to ask [her]82-elizabeth , when unattended to by any of [the rest]2102-the rest , whether _ all _ [[her]82-elizabeth sisters]3023-her sisters were at [Longbourn]7-longbourn . There was not much in the question , nor in the preceding remark ; but there was a look and a manner which gave them meaning .

It was not often that [she]82-elizabeth could turn [her]82-elizabeth eyes on [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy [himself]79-mr. bingley ; but whenever [she]82-elizabeth did catch a glimpse [she]82-elizabeth saw an expression of general complaisance , and in all that [he]79-mr. bingley said , [she]82-elizabeth heard an accent so far removed from _ hauteur _ or disdain of [[his]79-mr. bingley companions]2104-his companions , as convinced [her]82-elizabeth that the improvement of manners which [she]82-elizabeth had yesterday witnessed , however temporary its existence might prove , had at least outlived one day . When [she]82-elizabeth saw [him]79-mr. bingley thus seeking the acquaintance , and courting the good opinion of [people with whom any intercourse a few months ago would have been a disgrace]2105-people with whom any intercourse a few months ago would have been a disgrace ; when [she]82-elizabeth saw [him]79-mr. bingley thus civil , not only to [herself]82-elizabeth , but to the very relations whom [he]79-mr. bingley had openly disdained , and recollected [their]2106-their last lively scene in [Hunsford Parsonage]48-hunsford parsonage , the difference , the change was so great , and struck so forcibly on [her]82-elizabeth mind , that [she]82-elizabeth could hardly restrain [her]82-elizabeth astonishment from being visible . Never , even in the company of [[his]79-mr. bingley dear friends]2107-his dear friends at [Netherfield]2-netherfield , or [his]79-mr. bingley dignified relations at [Rosings]20-rosings , had [she]82-elizabeth seen [him]79-mr. bingley so desirous to please , so free from self - consequence or unbending reserve , as now , when no importance could result from the success of [his]79-mr. bingley endeavours , and when even the acquaintance of those to whom [his]79-mr. bingley attentions were addressed , would draw down the ridicule and censure of [the ladies both of [Netherfield]2-netherfield and [Rosings]20-rosings]2108-the ladies both of netherfield and rosings .

[[Their]2106-their visitors]2109-their visitors stayed with [them]2106-their above half an hour ; and when [they]2106-their arose to depart , [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy called on [[his]89-mr. darcy sister]559-his sister to join [him]89-mr. darcy in expressing [their]2106-their wish of seeing [Mr.]2111-mr. and [Mrs. Gardiner]125-mrs. gardiner , and [Miss Bennet]82-elizabeth , to dinner at [Pemberley]12-pemberley , before [they]2106-their left [the country]448-the country . [Miss Darcy]124-miss darcy , though with a diffidence which marked [her]124-miss darcy little in the habit of giving invitations , readily obeyed . [Mrs. Gardiner]125-mrs. gardiner looked at [[her]125-mrs. gardiner niece]1276-her niece , desirous of knowing how _ [she]1276-her niece _ , whom the invitation most concerned , felt disposed as to its acceptance , but [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth had turned away [her]82-elizabeth head . Presuming , however , that this studied avoidance spoke rather a momentary embarrassment than any dislike of the proposal , and seeing in [[her]82-elizabeth husband]255-her husband , who was fond of society , a perfect willingness to accept it , [she]82-elizabeth ventured to engage for [her]82-elizabeth attendance , and the day after the next was fixed on .

[Bingley]79-mr. bingley expressed great pleasure in the certainty of seeing [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth again , having still a great deal to say to [her]82-elizabeth , and many inquiries to make after all [[their]2106-their Hertfordshire friends]2115-their hertfordshire friends . [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth , construing all this into a wish of hearing [her]82-elizabeth speak of [[her]82-elizabeth sister]328-her sister , was pleased ; and on this account , as well as [some others]2117-some others , found [herself]82-elizabeth , when [[their]2106-their visitors]2109-their visitors left [them]2106-their , capable of considering the last half hour with some satisfaction , though while it was passing the enjoyment of it had been little . Eager to be alone , and fearful of inquiries or hints from [[her]82-elizabeth uncle]573-her uncle and aunt , [she]82-elizabeth stayed with [them]2106-their only long enough to hear [their]2106-their favourable opinion of [Bingley]79-mr. bingley , and then hurried away to dress .

But [she]82-elizabeth had no reason to fear [Mr.]2120-mr. and [Mrs. Gardiner]125-mrs. gardiner 's curiosity ; it was not [their]2106-their wish to force [her]82-elizabeth communication . It was evident that [she]82-elizabeth was much better acquainted with [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy than [they]2106-their had before any idea of ; it was evident that [he]89-mr. darcy was very much in love with [her]82-elizabeth . [They]2106-their saw much to interest , but nothing to justify inquiry .

Of [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy it was now a matter of anxiety to think well ; and , as far as [their]2106-their acquaintance reached , there was no fault to find . [They]2106-their could not be untouched by [his]89-mr. darcy politeness ; and had [they]2106-their drawn [his]89-mr. darcy character from [their]2106-their own feelings and [[his]89-mr. darcy servant]2121-his servant 's report , without any reference to any other account , [the circle in [Hertfordshire]4-hertfordshire to which [he]89-mr. darcy was known]2122-the circle in hertfordshire to which he was known would not have recognized it for [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy . There was now an interest , however , in believing [the housekeeper]816-the housekeeper ; and [they]2106-their soon became sensible that the authority of [a servant , who had known [him]89-mr. darcy since [he]89-mr. darcy was four years old , and whose own manners indicated respectability , was not to be hastily rejected . Neither had anything occurred in the intelligence of [[their]2106-their Lambton friends]2125-their lambton friends that could materially lessen its weight]2124-a servant , who had known him since he was four years old , and whose own manners indicated respectability , was not to be hastily rejected . neither had anything occurred in the intelligence of their lambton friends that could materially lessen its weight . [They]2106-their had nothing to accuse [him]89-mr. darcy of but pride ; pride [he]89-mr. darcy probably had , and if not , it would certainly be imputed by [the inhabitants of [a small market town where [the family]416-the family did not visit]2127-a small market town where the family did not visit]2126-the inhabitants of a small market town where the family did not visit . It was acknowledged , however , that [he]89-mr. darcy was [a liberal man]2129-a liberal man , and did much good among [the poor]4519-the poor .

With respect to [Wickham]136-wickham , [the travellers]2131-the travellers soon found that [he]89-mr. darcy was not held [there]305-there in much estimation ; for though the chief of [his]89-mr. darcy concerns with [the son of [[his]89-mr. darcy patron]3682-his patron]2133-the son of his patron were imperfectly understood , it was yet a well - known fact that , on [his]89-mr. darcy quitting [Derbyshire]6-derbyshire , [he]89-mr. darcy had left many debts behind [him]89-mr. darcy , which [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy afterwards discharged .

As for [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth , [her]82-elizabeth thoughts were at [Pemberley]12-pemberley this evening more than the last ; and the evening , though as it passed it seemed long , was not long enough to determine [her]82-elizabeth feelings towards _ one _ in [that mansion]2135-that mansion ; and [she]82-elizabeth lay awake two whole hours , endeavouring to make them out . [She]82-elizabeth certainly did not hate [him]89-mr. darcy . No ; hatred had vanished long ago , and [she]82-elizabeth had almost as long been ashamed of ever feeling a dislike against [him]89-mr. darcy , that could be so called . The respect created by the conviction of [his]89-mr. darcy valuable qualities , though at first unwillingly admitted , had for some time ceased to be repugnant to [her]82-elizabeth feelings ; and it was now heightened into somewhat of a friendlier nature by the testimony so highly in [his]89-mr. darcy favour , and bringing forward [his]89-mr. darcy disposition in so amiable a light , which yesterday had produced . But above all , above respect and esteem , there was a motive within [her]82-elizabeth of good - will which could not be overlooked . It was gratitude;--gratitude , not merely for having once loved [her]82-elizabeth , but for loving [her]82-elizabeth still well enough to forgive all the petulance and acrimony of [her]82-elizabeth manner in rejecting [him]89-mr. darcy , and all the unjust accusations accompanying [her]82-elizabeth rejection . [He]89-mr. darcy who , [she]82-elizabeth had been persuaded , would avoid [her]82-elizabeth as [[his]89-mr. darcy greatest enemy]2136-his greatest enemy , seemed , on this accidental meeting , most eager to preserve the acquaintance ; and without any indelicate display of regard , or any peculiarity of manner , where [their]2137-their two selves only were concerned , was soliciting the good opinion of [[her]82-elizabeth friends]310-her friends , and bent on making [her]82-elizabeth known to [[his]89-mr. darcy sister]559-his sister . Such a change in [a man of so much pride]2140-a man of so much pride excited not only astonishment but gratitude -- for to love , ardent love , it must be attributed ; and , as such , its impression on [her]82-elizabeth was of a sort to be encouraged , as by no means unpleasing , though it could not be exactly defined . [She]82-elizabeth respected , [she]82-elizabeth esteemed , [she]82-elizabeth was grateful to [him]89-mr. darcy , [she]82-elizabeth felt a real interest in [his]89-mr. darcy welfare ; and [she]82-elizabeth only wanted to know how far [she]82-elizabeth wished that welfare to depend upon [herself]82-elizabeth , and how far it would be for the happiness of both that [she]82-elizabeth should employ the power , which [her]82-elizabeth fancy told [her]82-elizabeth [she]82-elizabeth still possessed , of bringing on the renewal of [his]89-mr. darcy addresses .

It had been settled in the evening , between [the aunt]2141-the aunt and [niece]2142-niece , that such a striking civility as [Miss Darcy]124-miss darcy 's , in coming to [them]2143-they on the very day of [her]124-miss darcy arrival at [Pemberley]12-pemberley -- for [she]124-miss darcy had reached it only to a late breakfast -- ought to be imitated , though it could not be equalled , by some exertion of politeness on [their]2143-they side ; and , consequently , that it would be highly expedient to wait on [her]124-miss darcy at [Pemberley]12-pemberley the following morning . [They]2143-they were , therefore , to go . [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth was pleased ; though when [she]82-elizabeth asked [herself]82-elizabeth the reason , [she]82-elizabeth had very little to say in reply .

[Mr. Gardiner]153-mr. gardiner left [them]2143-they soon after breakfast . The fishing scheme had been renewed the day before , and a positive engagement made of [his]153-mr. gardiner meeting [some of [the gentlemen]290-the gentlemen at [Pemberley]12-pemberley]2144-some of the gentlemen at pemberley by noon .

[V.

Convinced]186-v. convinced as [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth now was that [Miss Bingley]91-miss bingley 's dislike of [her]82-elizabeth had originated in jealousy , [she]82-elizabeth could not help feeling how very unwelcome [her]82-elizabeth appearance at [Pemberley]12-pemberley must be to [her]82-elizabeth , and was curious to know with how much civility on [that lady]2146-that lady 's side the acquaintance would now be renewed .

On reaching [the house]3001-the house , [they]2143-they were shown through [the hall]685-the hall into [the saloon]2149-the saloon , whose northern aspect rendered [it]2149-the saloon delightful for summer . [Its]2149-the saloon windows , opening to the ground , admitted a most refreshing view of [the high woody hills behind [the house]3001-the house]2150-the high woody hills behind the house , and of the beautiful oaks and Spanish chestnuts which were scattered over [the intermediate lawn]2152-the intermediate lawn .

In [this room]4494-this room [they]2143-they were received by [Miss Darcy]124-miss darcy , who was sitting there with [Mrs. Hurst]90-mrs. hurst and [Miss Bingley]91-miss bingley , and [the lady with whom [she]124-miss darcy lived in [London]5-london]2154-the lady with whom she lived in london . [Georgiana]147-georgiana 's reception of [them]2143-they was very civil , but attended with all that embarrassment which , though proceeding from shyness and the fear of doing wrong , would easily give to those who felt [themselves]2155-themselves inferior the belief of [her]147-georgiana being proud and reserved . [Mrs. Gardiner]125-mrs. gardiner and [[her]125-mrs. gardiner niece]1276-her niece , however , did [her]147-georgiana justice , and pitied [her]147-georgiana .

By [Mrs. Hurst]90-mrs. hurst and [Miss Bingley]91-miss bingley [they]2143-they were noticed only by a courtesy ; and on [their]2143-they being seated , a pause , awkward as such pauses must always be , succeeded for a few moments . It was first broken by [Mrs. Annesley]187-mrs. annesley , [a genteel , agreeable - looking woman]2157-a genteel , agreeable - looking woman , whose endeavour to introduce some kind of discourse proved [her]187-mrs. annesley to be more truly well - bred than either of the others ; and between [her]187-mrs. annesley and [Mrs. Gardiner]125-mrs. gardiner , with occasional help from [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth , the conversation was carried on . [Miss Darcy]124-miss darcy looked as if [she]124-miss darcy wished for courage enough to join in it ; and sometimes did venture a short sentence , when there was least danger of its being heard .

[Elizabeth]82-elizabeth soon saw that [she]82-elizabeth was [herself]82-elizabeth closely watched by [Miss Bingley]91-miss bingley , and that [she]82-elizabeth could not speak a word , especially to [Miss Darcy]124-miss darcy , without calling [her]82-elizabeth attention . This observation would not have prevented [her]82-elizabeth from trying to talk to [the latter]487-the latter , had [they]2143-they not been seated at an inconvenient distance ; but [she]82-elizabeth was not sorry to be spared the necessity of saying much : [her]82-elizabeth own thoughts were employing [her]82-elizabeth . [She]82-elizabeth expected every moment that [some of [the gentlemen]290-the gentlemen]2159-some of the gentlemen would enter [the room]250-the room : [she]82-elizabeth wished , [she]82-elizabeth feared , that [the master of [the house]3001-the house]639-the master of the house might be amongst [them]2159-some of the gentlemen ; and whether [she]82-elizabeth wished or feared it most , [she]82-elizabeth could scarcely determine . After sitting in this manner a quarter of an hour , without hearing [Miss Bingley]91-miss bingley 's voice , [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth was roused by receiving from [her]82-elizabeth a cold inquiry after the health of [[her]82-elizabeth family]885-her family . [She]82-elizabeth answered with equal indifference and brevity , and [the other]590-the other said no more .

The next variation which [their]2166-they visit afforded was produced by the entrance of [servants]3324-servants with cold meat , cake , and a variety of all the finest fruits in season ; but this did not take place till after many a significant look and smile from [Mrs. Annesley]187-mrs. annesley to [Miss Darcy]124-miss darcy had been given , to remind [her]82-elizabeth of [her]82-elizabeth post . There was now employment for [the whole party]521-the whole party ; for though [they]2166-they could not all talk , [they]2166-they could all eat ; and the beautiful pyramids of grapes , nectarines , and peaches , soon collected them round the table .

While thus engaged , [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth had a fair opportunity of deciding whether [she]82-elizabeth most feared or wished for the appearance of [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy , by the feelings which prevailed on [his]89-mr. darcy entering [the room]250-the room ; and then , though but a moment before [she]82-elizabeth had believed [her]82-elizabeth wishes to predominate , [she]82-elizabeth began to regret that [he]89-mr. darcy came .

[He]89-mr. darcy had been some time with [Mr. Gardiner]153-mr. gardiner , who , with two or [three other gentlemen from [the house]3001-the house]2170-three other gentlemen from the house , was engaged by [the river]1899-the river ; and had left [him]89-mr. darcy only on learning that [the ladies of [the family]416-the family]2173-the ladies of the family intended a visit to [Georgiana]147-georgiana that morning . No sooner did [he]89-mr. darcy appear , than [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth wisely resolved to be perfectly easy and unembarrassed;--a resolution the more necessary to be made , but perhaps not the more easily kept , because [she]82-elizabeth saw that the suspicions of [the whole party]521-the whole party were awakened against [them]521-the whole party , and that there was scarcely an eye which did not watch [his]89-mr. darcy behaviour when [he]89-mr. darcy first came into [the room]250-the room . In no countenance was attentive curiosity so strongly marked as in [Miss Bingley]91-miss bingley 's , in spite of the smiles which overspread [her]82-elizabeth face whenever [she]82-elizabeth spoke to [one of its objects]2177-one of its objects ; for jealousy had not yet made [her]82-elizabeth desperate , and [her]82-elizabeth attentions to [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy were by no means over . [Miss Darcy]124-miss darcy , on [[her]124-miss darcy brother]3108-her brother 's entrance , exerted [herself]124-miss darcy much more to talk ; and [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth saw that [he]89-mr. darcy was anxious for [[his]89-mr. darcy sister]559-his sister and [herself]124-miss darcy to get acquainted , and forwarded , as much as possible , every attempt at conversation on either side . [Miss Bingley]91-miss bingley saw all this likewise ; and , in the imprudence of anger , took the first opportunity of saying , with sneering civility,--

" Pray , [Miss Eliza]82-elizabeth , are not [the ----shire militia removed from [Meryton]9-meryton]4547-the ----shire militia removed from meryton ? [They]4547-the ----shire militia removed from meryton must be a great loss to _ [[your]82-elizabeth _ family]4548-your _ family . "[91-miss bingley]

In [Darcy]124-miss darcy 's presence [she]82-elizabeth dared not mention [Wickham]136-wickham 's name : but [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth instantly comprehended that [he]89-mr. darcy was uppermost in [her]82-elizabeth thoughts ; and the various recollections connected with [him]89-mr. darcy gave [her]82-elizabeth a moment 's distress ; but , exerting [herself]82-elizabeth vigorously to repel the ill - natured attack , [she]82-elizabeth presently answered the question in a tolerably disengaged tone . While [she]82-elizabeth spoke , an involuntary glance showed [her]82-elizabeth [Darcy]124-miss darcy with a heightened complexion , earnestly looking at [her]82-elizabeth , and [[his]89-mr. darcy sister]559-his sister overcome with confusion , and unable to lift up [her]82-elizabeth eyes . Had [Miss Bingley]91-miss bingley known what pain [she]82-elizabeth was then giving [[her]82-elizabeth beloved friend]2181-her beloved friend , [she]82-elizabeth undoubtedly would have refrained from the hint ; but [she]82-elizabeth had merely intended to discompose [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth , by bringing forward the idea of [a man to whom [she]82-elizabeth believed [her]82-elizabeth partial]2182-a man to whom she believed her partial , to make [her]82-elizabeth betray a sensibility which might injure [her]82-elizabeth in [Darcy]124-miss darcy 's opinion , and , perhaps , to remind [the latter]487-the latter of all the follies and absurdities by which [some part of [[her]82-elizabeth family]885-her family]2184-some part of her family were connected with that corps . Not a syllable had ever reached [her]82-elizabeth of [Miss Darcy]124-miss darcy 's meditated elopement . To [no creature]2186-no creature had it been revealed , where secrecy was possible , except to [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth ; and from all [Bingley]91-miss bingley 's connections [[her]82-elizabeth brother]3108-her brother was particularly anxious to conceal it , from that very wish which [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth had long ago attributed to [him]3108-her brother , of [their]2188-their becoming hereafter [her]82-elizabeth own . [He]3108-her brother had certainly formed such a plan ; and without meaning that it should affect [his]3108-her brother endeavour to separate [him]3108-her brother from [Miss Bennet]82-elizabeth , it is probable that it might add something to [his]3108-her brother lively concern for the welfare of [[his]3108-her brother friend]286-his friend .

[Elizabeth]82-elizabeth 's collected behaviour , however , soon quieted [his]3108-her brother emotion ; and as [Miss Bingley]91-miss bingley , vexed and disappointed , dared not approach nearer to [Wickham]136-wickham , [Georgiana]147-georgiana also recovered in time , though not enough to be able to speak any more . [[Her]82-elizabeth brother]3108-her brother , whose eye [she]82-elizabeth feared to meet , scarcely recollected [her]82-elizabeth interest in the affair ; and the very circumstance which had been designed to turn [his]3108-her brother thoughts from [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth , seemed to have fixed them on [her]82-elizabeth more and more cheerfully .

[Their]2191-their visit did not continue long after the question and answer above mentioned ; and while [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy was attending [them]2191-their to [[their]2191-their carriage]977-their carriage , [Miss Bingley]91-miss bingley was venting [her]91-miss bingley feelings in criticisms on [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth 's person , behaviour , and dress . But [Georgiana]147-georgiana would not join [her]91-miss bingley . [[Her]82-elizabeth brother]3108-her brother 's recommendation was enough to insure [her]82-elizabeth favour : [his]3108-her brother judgment could not err ; and [he]3108-her brother had spoken in such terms of [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth , as to leave [Georgiana]147-georgiana without the power of finding [her]82-elizabeth otherwise than lovely and amiable . When [Darcy]147-georgiana returned to [the saloon]2149-the saloon , [Miss Bingley]91-miss bingley could not help repeating to [him]3108-her brother some part of what [she]91-miss bingley had been saying to [[his]3108-her brother sister]559-his sister .

" How very ill [Eliza Bennet]82-elizabeth looks this morning , [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy , "[91-miss bingley] [she]91-miss bingley cried : " [I]91-miss bingley never in [my]91-miss bingley life saw anyone so much altered as [she]82-elizabeth is since the winter . [She]82-elizabeth is grown so brown and coarse ! [Louisa]117-louisa and [I]91-miss bingley were agreeing that [we]4549-we should not have known [her]82-elizabeth again . "[91-miss bingley]

However little [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy might have liked such an address , [he]89-mr. darcy contented [himself]89-mr. darcy with coolly replying , that [he]89-mr. darcy perceived no other alteration than [her]91-miss bingley being rather tanned,--no miraculous consequence of travelling in the summer .

" For [my]91-miss bingley own part , "[91-miss bingley] [she]91-miss bingley rejoined , " [I]91-miss bingley must confess that [I]91-miss bingley never could see any beauty in [her]82-elizabeth . [Her]82-elizabeth face is too thin ; [her]82-elizabeth complexion has no brilliancy ; and [her]82-elizabeth features are not at all handsome . [Her]82-elizabeth nose wants character ; there is nothing marked in its lines . [Her]82-elizabeth teeth are tolerable , but not out of the common way ; and as for [her]82-elizabeth eyes , which have sometimes been called so fine , [I]91-miss bingley never could perceive anything extraordinary in them . [They]4550-they have a sharp , shrewish look , which [I]91-miss bingley do not like at all ; and in [her]82-elizabeth air altogether , there is a self - sufficiency without fashion , which is intolerable . "[91-miss bingley]

Persuaded as [Miss Bingley]91-miss bingley was that [Darcy]89-mr. darcy admired [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth , this was not the best method of recommending [herself]91-miss bingley ; but [angry people]2196-angry people are not always wise ; and in seeing [him]89-mr. darcy at last look somewhat nettled , [she]91-miss bingley had all the success [she]91-miss bingley expected . [He]89-mr. darcy was resolutely silent , however ; and , from a determination of making [him]89-mr. darcy speak , [she]91-miss bingley continued,--

" [I]91-miss bingley remember , when [we]4551-we first knew [her]82-elizabeth in [Hertfordshire]4-hertfordshire , how amazed [we]4551-we all were to find that [she]82-elizabeth was [a reputed beauty]4552-a reputed beauty ; and [I]91-miss bingley particularly recollect [your]89-mr. darcy saying one night , after [they]4551-we had been dining at [Netherfield]2-netherfield , ' _ [She]82-elizabeth _ [a beauty]4553-a beauty ! [I]91-miss bingley should as soon call [[her]82-elizabeth mother]241-her mother a wit . ' But afterwards [she]82-elizabeth seemed to improve on [you]89-mr. darcy , and [I]91-miss bingley believe [you]89-mr. darcy thought [her]82-elizabeth rather pretty at one time . "[91-miss bingley]

" Yes , "[89-mr. darcy] replied [Darcy]89-mr. darcy , who could contain [himself]89-mr. darcy no longer , " but _ that _ was only when [I]89-mr. darcy first knew [her]82-elizabeth ; for it is many months since [I]89-mr. darcy have considered [her]82-elizabeth as [one of [the handsomest women of [my]89-mr. darcy acquaintance]4556-the handsomest women of my acquaintance]4555-one of the handsomest women of my acquaintance . "[89-mr. darcy]

[He]89-mr. darcy then went away , and [Miss Bingley]91-miss bingley was left to all the satisfaction of having forced [him]89-mr. darcy to say what gave [no one]3271-no one any pain but [herself]91-miss bingley .

[Mrs. Gardiner]125-mrs. gardiner and [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth talked of all that had occurred during [their]2198-their visit , as [they]2198-their returned , except what had particularly interested [them]2198-their both . The looks and behaviour of [everybody]304-everybody [they]2198-their had seen were discussed , except of [the person who had mostly engaged [their]2198-their attention]2200-the person who had mostly engaged their attention . [They]2198-their talked of [[his]2200-the person who had mostly engaged their attention sister]559-his sister , [[his]2200-the person who had mostly engaged their attention friends]407-his friends , [[his]2200-the person who had mostly engaged their attention house]3109-his house , [his]2200-the person who had mostly engaged their attention fruit , of everything but [himself]2200-the person who had mostly engaged their attention ; yet [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth was longing to know what [Mrs. Gardiner]125-mrs. gardiner thought of [him]2200-the person who had mostly engaged their attention , and [Mrs. Gardiner]125-mrs. gardiner would have been highly gratified by [[her]125-mrs. gardiner niece]1276-her niece 's beginning the subject .

[VI .

Elizabeth]188-elizabeth had been a good deal disappointed in not finding a letter from [Jane]83-jane on [their]2198-their first arrival at [Lambton]44-lambton ; and this disappointment had been renewed on each of the mornings that had now been spent [there]305-there ; but on the third [her]82-elizabeth repining was over , and [[her]82-elizabeth sister]328-her sister justified , by the receipt of two letters from [her]82-elizabeth at once , on one of which was marked that it had been mis - sent elsewhere . [Elizabeth]188-elizabeth was not surprised at it , as [Jane]83-jane had written the direction remarkably ill .

[They]2198-their had just been preparing to walk as the letters came in ; and [[her]82-elizabeth uncle]573-her uncle and aunt , leaving [her]82-elizabeth to enjoy [them]2208-them in quiet , set off by [themselves]2198-their . The one mis - sent must be first attended to ; it had been written five days ago . The beginning contained an account of all [their]2198-their little parties and engagements , with such news as [the country]448-the country afforded ; but the latter half , which was dated a day later , and written in evident agitation , gave more important intelligence . It was to this effect:--

" Since writing the above , [dearest Lizzy]188-elizabeth , something has occurred of a most unexpected and serious nature ; but [I]2210-i am afraid of alarming [you]188-elizabeth -- be assured that [we]2198-their are all well . What [I]2210-i have to say relates to poor [Lydia]84-lydia . An express came at twelve last night , just as [we]2198-their were all gone to bed , from [Colonel Forster]107-colonel forster , to inform [us]2198-their that [she]84-lydia was gone off to [Scotland]49-scotland with [one of [[his]107-colonel forster officers]4558-his officers]4557-one of his officers ; to own the truth , with [Wickham]136-wickham ! Imagine [our]2198-their surprise . To [Kitty]86-lady catherine , however , it does not seem so wholly unexpected . [I]2210-i am very , very sorry . So imprudent a match on both sides ! But [I]2210-i am willing to hope the best , and that [his]107-colonel forster character has been misunderstood . Thoughtless and indiscreet [I]2210-i can easily believe [him]107-colonel forster , but this step ( and let [us]2198-their rejoice over it ) marks nothing bad at heart . [His]107-colonel forster choice is disinterested at least , for [he]107-colonel forster must know [[my]2210-i father]3256-my father can give [her]84-lydia nothing . [[Our]2198-their poor mother]4560-our poor mother is sadly grieved . [[My]2210-i father]3256-my father bears it better . How thankful am [I]2210-i , that [we]2198-their never let [them]4562-they know what has been said against [him]107-colonel forster ; [we]2198-their must forget it [ourselves]2198-their . [They]4562-they were off Saturday night about twelve , as is conjectured , but were not missed till yesterday morning at eight . The express was sent off directly . [[My]2210-i dear]2993-my dear [Lizzy]188-elizabeth , [they]4562-they must have passed within ten miles of [us]2198-their . [Colonel Forster]107-colonel forster gives [us]2198-their reason to expect [him]107-colonel forster [here]2994-here soon . [Lydia]84-lydia left a few lines for [[his]107-colonel forster wife]231-his wife , informing [her]231-his wife of [their]4562-they intention . [I]2210-i must conclude , for [I]2210-i can not be long from [[my]2210-i poor mother]4566-my poor mother . [I]2210-i am afraid [you]188-elizabeth will not be able to make it out , but [I]2210-i hardly know what [I]2210-i have written . "[2210-i]

Without allowing [herself]2210-i time for consideration , and scarcely knowing what [she]2210-i felt , [Elizabeth]188-elizabeth , on finishing this letter , instantly seized the other , and opening it with the utmost impatience , read as follows : it had been written a day later than the conclusion of the first .

" By this time , [[my]2210-i dearest sister]4567-my dearest sister , [you]188-elizabeth have received [my]2210-i hurried letter ; [I]2210-i wish this may be more intelligible , but though not confined for time , [my]2210-i head is so bewildered that [I]2210-i can not answer for being coherent . [Dearest Lizzy]82-elizabeth , [I]2210-i hardly know what [I]2210-i would write , but [I]2210-i have bad news for [you]188-elizabeth , and it can not be delayed . Imprudent as a marriage between [Mr. Wickham]136-wickham and [[our]4568-our poor [Lydia]84-lydia]4569-our poor lydia would be , [we]4568-our are now anxious to be assured it has taken place , for there is but too much reason to fear [they]4570-they are not gone to [Scotland]49-scotland . [Colonel Forster]107-colonel forster came yesterday , having left [Brighton]32-brighton the day before , not many hours after the express . Though [Lydia]84-lydia 's short letter to [Mrs. F.]190-mrs. f. gave [them]4570-they to understand that [they]4570-they were going to [Gretna Green]50-gretna green , something was dropped by [Denny]135-denny expressing [his]135-denny belief that [W.]191-w. never intended to go [there]305-there , or to marry [Lydia]84-lydia at all , which was repeated to [Colonel F.]192-colonel f. , who , instantly taking the alarm , set off from [B.]51-b. , intending to trace [their]4570-they route . [He]192-colonel f. did trace [them]4570-they easily to [Clapham]52-clapham , but no farther ; for on entering [that place]4572-that place , [they]4570-they removed into [a hackney - coach]4573-a hackney - coach , and dismissed the chaise that brought [them]4570-they from [Epsom]53-epsom . All that is known after this is , that [they]4570-they were seen to continue [the [London]5-london road]4574-the london road . [I]2210-i know not what to think . After making every possible inquiry on [that side [London]5-london]4575-that side london , [Colonel F.]192-colonel f. came on into [Hertfordshire]4-hertfordshire , anxiously renewing them at [all the turnpikes]4576-all the turnpikes , and at [the inns in [Barnet]54-barnet and [Hatfield]55-hatfield]4577-the inns in barnet and hatfield , but without any success,--no [such people]3396-such people had been seen to pass through . With the kindest concern [he]192-colonel f. came on to [Longbourn]7-longbourn , and broke [his]192-colonel f. apprehensions to [us]4579-us in a manner most creditable to [his]192-colonel f. heart . [I]2210-i am sincerely grieved for [him]192-colonel f. and [Mrs. F.]190-mrs. f. ; but [no one]3271-no one can throw any blame on [them]4581-their . [Our]4579-us distress , [[my]2210-i dear]2993-my dear [Lizzy]82-elizabeth , is very great . [[My]2210-i father]3256-my father and [mother]3198-mother believe the worst , but [I]2210-i can not think so ill of [him]192-colonel f. . Many circumstances might make it more eligible for [them]4581-their to be married privately in [town]264-town than to pursue [their]4581-their first plan ; and even if _ [he]192-colonel f. _ could form such a design against [a young woman of [Lydia]84-lydia 's connections]4586-a young woman of lydia 's connections , which is not likely , can [I]2210-i suppose [her]84-lydia so lost to everything ? Impossible ! [I]2210-i grieve to find , however , that [Colonel F.]192-colonel f. is not disposed to depend upon [their]4581-their marriage : [he]192-colonel f. shook [his]192-colonel f. head when [I]2210-i expressed [my]2210-i hopes , and said [he]192-colonel f. feared [W.]191-w. was not [a man to be trusted]4587-a man to be trusted . [[My]2210-i poor mother]4566-my poor mother is really ill , and keeps [her]4566-my poor mother room . Could [she]4566-my poor mother exert [herself]4566-my poor mother , it would be better , but this is not to be expected ; and as to [[my]2210-i father]3256-my father , [I]2210-i never in [my]2210-i life saw [him]3256-my father so affected . [Poor Kitty]86-lady catherine has anger for having concealed [their]4581-their attachment ; but as it was a matter of confidence , one can not wonder . [I]2210-i am truly glad , dearest [Lizzy]82-elizabeth , that [you]82-elizabeth have been spared something of these distressing scenes ; but now , as the first shock is over , shall [I]2210-i own that [I]2210-i long for [your]82-elizabeth return ? [I]2210-i am not so selfish , however , as to press for it , if inconvenient . Adieu ! [I]2210-i take up [my]2210-i pen again to do , what [I]2210-i have just told [you]82-elizabeth [I]2210-i would not ; but circumstances are such , that [I]2210-i can not help earnestly begging [you]82-elizabeth all to come here as soon as possible . [I]2210-i know [[my]2210-i dear uncle]3970-my dear uncle and [aunt]3971-aunt so well , that [I]2210-i am not afraid of requesting it , though [I]2210-i have still something more to ask of [the former]327-the former . [[My]2210-i father]3256-my father is going to [London]5-london with [Colonel Forster]107-colonel forster instantly , to try to discover [her]3971-aunt . What [he]3256-my father means to do , [I]2210-i am sure [I]2210-i know not ; but [his]3256-my father excessive distress will not allow [him]3256-my father to pursue any measure in the best and safest way , and [Colonel Forster]107-colonel forster is obliged to be at [Brighton]32-brighton again to - morrow evening . In such an exigence [[my]2210-i uncle]3488-my uncle 's advice and assistance would be everything in [the world]303-the world ; [he]3256-my father will immediately comprehend what [I]2210-i must feel , and [I]2210-i rely upon [his]3256-my father goodness . "[2210-i]

" Oh ! where , where is [[my]82-elizabeth uncle]3488-my uncle ? "[82-elizabeth] cried [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth , darting from [her]82-elizabeth seat as [she]82-elizabeth finished the letter , in eagerness to follow [him]2211-him , without losing a moment of the time so precious ; but as [she]82-elizabeth reached the door , it was opened by [a servant]499-a servant , and [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy appeared . [Her]82-elizabeth pale face and impetuous manner made [him]2211-him start , and before [he]2211-him could recover [himself]2211-him enough to speak , [she]82-elizabeth , in whose mind every idea was superseded by [Lydia]84-lydia 's situation , hastily exclaimed , " [I]82-elizabeth beg [your]2211-him pardon , but [I]82-elizabeth must leave [you]2211-him . [I]82-elizabeth must find [Mr. Gardiner]153-mr. gardiner this moment on business that can not be delayed ; [I]82-elizabeth have not an instant to lose . "[82-elizabeth]

" [Good God]95-god ! what is the matter ? "[2211-him] cried [he]2211-him , with more feeling than politeness ; then recollecting [himself]2211-him , " [I]2211-him will not detain [you]82-elizabeth a minute ; but let [me]2211-him , or let [the servant]462-the servant , go after [Mr.]4598-mr. and [Mrs. Gardiner]125-mrs. gardiner . [You]82-elizabeth are not well enough ; [you]82-elizabeth can not go [yourself]82-elizabeth . "[2211-him]

[Elizabeth]82-elizabeth hesitated ; but [her]82-elizabeth knees trembled under [her]82-elizabeth , and [she]82-elizabeth felt how little would be gained by [her]82-elizabeth attempting to pursue [them]2213-them . Calling back [the servant]462-the servant , therefore , [she]82-elizabeth commissioned [him]2211-him , though in so breathless an accent as made [her]82-elizabeth almost unintelligible , to fetch [[his]2211-him master]1966-his master and [mistress]4474-mistress [home]3219-home instantly .

On [his]2211-him quitting [the room]250-the room , [she]82-elizabeth sat down , unable to support [herself]82-elizabeth , and looking so miserably ill , that it was impossible for [Darcy]89-mr. darcy to leave [her]82-elizabeth , or to refrain from saying , in a tone of gentleness and commiseration , " Let [me]89-mr. darcy call [[your]82-elizabeth maid]4599-your maid . Is there nothing [you]82-elizabeth could take to give [you]82-elizabeth present relief ? A glass of wine ; shall [I]89-mr. darcy get [you]82-elizabeth one ? [You]82-elizabeth are very ill . "[89-mr. darcy]

" No , [I]82-elizabeth thank [you]89-mr. darcy , "[82-elizabeth] [she]82-elizabeth replied , endeavouring to recover [herself]82-elizabeth . " There is nothing the matter with [me]82-elizabeth . [I]82-elizabeth am quite well , [I]82-elizabeth am only distressed by some dreadful news which [I]82-elizabeth have just received from [Longbourn]7-longbourn . "[82-elizabeth]

[She]82-elizabeth burst into tears as [she]82-elizabeth alluded to it , and for a few minutes could not speak another word . [Darcy]89-mr. darcy , in wretched suspense , could only say something indistinctly of [his]89-mr. darcy

concern , and observe [her]82-elizabeth in compassionate silence . At length [she]82-elizabeth spoke again . " [I]82-elizabeth have just had a letter from [Jane]83-jane , with such dreadful news . It can not be concealed from [anyone]3102-anyone . [[My]82-elizabeth youngest sister]4601-my youngest sister has left all [[her]4601-my youngest sister friends]310-her friends -- has eloped ; has thrown [herself]4601-my youngest sister into the power of -- of [Mr. Wickham]136-wickham . [They]310-her friends are gone off together from [Brighton]32-brighton . _ [You]4603-you _ know [him]136-wickham too well to doubt the rest . [She]83-jane has no money , no connections , nothing that can tempt [him]136-wickham to -- [she]83-jane is lost for ever . "[82-elizabeth]

[Darcy]89-mr. darcy was fixed in astonishment .

" When [I]82-elizabeth consider , "[82-elizabeth] [she]82-elizabeth added , in a yet more agitated voice , " that _ [I]82-elizabeth _ might have prevented it ! _ [I]82-elizabeth _ who knew what [he]136-wickham was . Had [I]82-elizabeth but explained some part of it only -- some part of what [I]82-elizabeth learnt , to [[my]82-elizabeth own family]3913-my own family ! Had [his]136-wickham character been known , this could not have happened . But it is all , all too late now . "[82-elizabeth]

" [I]89-mr. darcy am grieved , indeed , "[89-mr. darcy] cried [Darcy]89-mr. darcy : " grieved -- shocked . But is it certain , absolutely certain ? "[89-mr. darcy]

" Oh , yes ! [They]310-her friends left [Brighton]32-brighton together on Sunday night , and were traced almost to [London]5-london , but not beyond : [they]310-her friends are certainly not gone to [Scotland]49-scotland . "[82-elizabeth]

" And what has been done , what has been attempted , to recover [her]83-jane ? "[89-mr. darcy]

" [[My]82-elizabeth father]3256-my father has gone to [London]5-london , and [Jane]83-jane has written to beg [[my]82-elizabeth uncle]3488-my uncle 's immediate assistance , and [we]4607-we shall be off , [I]82-elizabeth hope , in half an hour . But nothing can be done ; [I]82-elizabeth know very well that nothing can be done . How is such [a man to be worked on]4608-a man to be worked on ? How are they even to be discovered ? [I]82-elizabeth have not the smallest hope . It is every way horrible ! "[82-elizabeth]

[Darcy]89-mr. darcy shook [his]89-mr. darcy head in silent acquiescence .

" When _ [my]82-elizabeth _ eyes were opened to [his]89-mr. darcy real character , oh ! had [I]82-elizabeth known what [I]82-elizabeth ought , what [I]82-elizabeth dared to do ! But [I]82-elizabeth knew not -- [I]82-elizabeth was afraid of doing too much . Wretched , wretched mistake ! "[82-elizabeth]

[Darcy]89-mr. darcy made no answer . [He]89-mr. darcy seemed scarcely to hear [her]2219-her , and was walking up and down [the room]250-the room in earnest meditation ; [his]89-mr. darcy brow contracted , [his]89-mr. darcy air gloomy . [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth soon observed , and instantly understood it . [Her]82-elizabeth power was sinking ; everything _ must _ sink under such a proof of family weakness , such an assurance of the deepest disgrace . [She]82-elizabeth could neither wonder nor condemn ; but the belief of [his]89-mr. darcy self - conquest brought nothing consolatory to [her]82-elizabeth bosom , afforded no palliation of [her]82-elizabeth distress . It was , on the contrary , exactly calculated to make [her]82-elizabeth understand [her]82-elizabeth own wishes ; and never had [she]82-elizabeth so honestly felt that [she]82-elizabeth could have loved [him]89-mr. darcy , as now , when all love must be vain .

But self , though it would intrude , could not engross [her]82-elizabeth . [Lydia]84-lydia -- the humiliation , the misery [she]84-lydia was bringing on [them]2221-them all -- soon swallowed up every private care ; and covering [her]82-elizabeth face with [her]82-elizabeth handkerchief , [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth was soon lost to everything else ; and , after a pause of several minutes , was only recalled to a sense of [her]82-elizabeth situation by the voice of [[her]82-elizabeth companion]1675-her companion , who , in a manner which , though it spoke compassion , spoke likewise restraint , said,--

" [I]1675-her companion am afraid [you]82-elizabeth have been long desiring [my]1675-her companion absence , nor have [I]1675-her companion anything to plead in excuse of [my]1675-her companion stay , but real , though unavailing concern . Would to [Heaven]181-heaven that anything could be either said or done on [my]1675-her companion part , that might offer consolation to such distress ! But [I]1675-her companion will not torment [you]82-elizabeth with vain wishes , which may seem purposely to ask for [your]82-elizabeth thanks . This unfortunate affair will , [I]1675-her companion fear , prevent [[my]1675-her companion sister]3280-my sister 's having the pleasure of seeing [you]82-elizabeth at [Pemberley]12-pemberley to - day . "[1675-her companion]

" Oh , yes ! Be so kind as to apologize for [us]4610-us to [Miss Darcy]124-miss darcy . Say that urgent business calls [us]4610-us [home]3219-home immediately . Conceal the unhappy truth as long as it is possible . [I]2223-his know it can not be long . "[2223-his]

[He]2223-his readily assured [her]2224-her of [his]2223-his secrecy , again expressed [his]2223-his sorrow for [her]2224-her distress , wished it a happier conclusion than there was at present reason to hope , and , leaving [his]2223-his compliments for [her]2224-her relations , with only one serious parting look , went away .

As [he]2223-his quitted [the room]250-the room , [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth felt how improbable it was that [they]2226-their should ever see [each other]3144-each other again on such terms of cordiality as had marked [their]2226-their several meetings in [Derbyshire]6-derbyshire ; and as [she]82-elizabeth threw a retrospective glance over the whole of [their]2226-their acquaintance , so full of contradictions and varieties , sighed at the perverseness of those feelings which would now have promoted its continuance , and would formerly have rejoiced in its termination .

If gratitude and esteem are good foundations of affection , [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth 's change of sentiment will be neither improbable nor faulty . But if otherwise , if the regard springing from such sources is unreasonable or unnatural , in comparison of what is so often described as arising on a first interview with its object , and even before two words have been exchanged , nothing can be said in [her]2224-her defence , except that [she]2224-her had given somewhat of a trial to the latter method , in [her]2224-her partiality for [Wickham]136-wickham , and that its ill success might , perhaps , authorize [her]2224-her to seek the other less interesting mode of attachment . Be that as it may , [she]2224-her saw [him]136-wickham go with regret ; and in this early example of what [Lydia]84-lydia 's infamy must produce , found additional anguish as [she]2224-her reflected on that wretched business . Never since reading [Jane]83-jane 's second letter had [she]2224-her entertained a hope of [Wickham]136-wickham 's meaning to marry [her]2224-her . No one but [Jane]83-jane , [she]2224-her thought , could flatter [herself]2224-her with such an expectation . [Surprise]193-surprise was the least of all [her]2224-her feelings on this development . While the contents of the first letter remained on [her]2224-her mind , [she]2224-her was all surprise , all astonishment , that [Wickham]136-wickham should marry [a girl whom it was impossible [he]136-wickham could marry for money]2228-a girl whom it was impossible he could marry for money ; and how [Lydia]84-lydia could ever have attached [him]136-wickham had appeared incomprehensible . But now it was all too natural . For such an attachment as this , [she]2224-her might have sufficient charms ; and though [she]2224-her did not suppose [Lydia]84-lydia to be deliberately engaging in an elopement , without the intention of marriage , [she]2224-her had no difficulty in believing that neither [her]2224-her virtue nor [her]2224-her understanding would preserve [her]2224-her from falling an easy prey .

[She]2224-her had never perceived , while [the regiment]650-the regiment was in [Hertfordshire]4-hertfordshire , that [Lydia]84-lydia had any partiality for [him]136-wickham ; but [she]2224-her was convinced that [Lydia]84-lydia had wanted only encouragement to attach [herself]84-lydia to [anybody]3099-anybody . Sometimes [one officer]2231-one officer , sometimes another , had been [her]2224-her favourite , as [their]2232-their attentions raised [them]2232-their in [her]2224-her opinion . [Her]2224-her affections had been continually fluctuating , but never without an object . The mischief of neglect and mistaken indulgence towards [such a girl]2233-such a girl -- oh ! how acutely did [she]2224-her now feel it !

[She]2224-her was wild to be at [home]3219-home -- to hear , to see , to be upon the spot to share with [Jane]83-jane in the cares that must now fall wholly upon [her]2224-her , in [a family so deranged]2235-a family so deranged ; [a father]3245-a father absent , [a mother incapable of exertion , and requiring constant attendance]2237-a mother incapable of exertion , and requiring constant attendance ; and though almost persuaded that nothing could be done for [Lydia]84-lydia , [[her]2224-her uncle]573-her uncle 's interference seemed of the utmost importance , and till [he]573-her uncle entered [the room]250-the room the misery of [her]2224-her impatience was severe . [Mr.]2240-mr. and [Mrs. Gardiner]125-mrs. gardiner had hurried back in alarm , supposing , by [the servant]462-the servant 's account , that [[their]2242-their niece]1967-their niece was taken suddenly ill ; but satisfying [them]2242-their instantly on that head , [she]2224-her eagerly communicated the cause of [their]2242-their summons , reading the two letters aloud , and dwelling on the postscript of the last with trembling energy . Though [Lydia]84-lydia had never been a favourite with [them]2242-their , [Mr.]2244-mr. and [Mrs. Gardiner]125-mrs. gardiner could not but be deeply affected . Not [Lydia]84-lydia only , but all were concerned in it ; and after the first exclamations of surprise and horror , [Mr. Gardiner]153-mr. gardiner readily promised every assistance in [his]153-mr. gardiner power . [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth , though expecting no less , thanked [him]153-mr. gardiner with tears of gratitude ; and [all three]2245-all three being actuated by one spirit , everything relating to [their]2245-all three journey was speedily settled . [They]2245-all three were to be off as soon as possible . " But what is to be done about [Pemberley]12-pemberley ? "[125-mrs. gardiner] cried [Mrs. Gardiner]125-mrs. gardiner . " [John]170-john told [us]2245-all three [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy was here when [you]125-mrs. gardiner sent for [us;--was]4612-us;--was it so ? "[125-mrs. gardiner]

" Yes ; and [I]125-mrs. gardiner told [him]89-mr. darcy [we]2245-all three should not be able to keep [our]2245-all three engagement . _ That _ is all settled . "[125-mrs. gardiner]

" What is all settled ? "[590-the other] repeated [the other]590-the other , as [she]590-the other ran into [[her]590-the other room]489-her room to prepare . " And are [they]4613-they upon such terms as for [her]590-the other to disclose the real truth ? Oh , that [I]590-the other knew how it was ! "[590-the other]

But wishes were vain ; or , at best , could serve only to amuse [her]590-the other in the hurry and confusion of the following hour . Had [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth been at leisure to be idle , [she]82-elizabeth would have remained certain that all employment was impossible to one so wretched as [herself]82-elizabeth ; but [she]82-elizabeth had [her]82-elizabeth share of business as well as [[her]82-elizabeth aunt]1198-her aunt , and amongst the rest there were notes to be written to all [[their]2249-their friends]2250-their friends at [Lambton]44-lambton , with false excuses for [their]2249-their sudden departure . An hour , however , saw the whole completed ; and [Mr. Gardiner]153-mr. gardiner , meanwhile , having settled [his]153-mr. gardiner account at [the inn]1717-the inn , nothing remained to be done but to go ; and [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth , after all the misery of the morning , found [herself]82-elizabeth , in a shorter space of time than [she]82-elizabeth could have supposed , seated in [the carriage]3217-the carriage , and on [the road]1290-the road to [Longbourn]7-longbourn .

[VII]194-vii .

" [I]573-her uncle have been thinking it over again , [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth , "[573-her uncle] said [[her]82-elizabeth uncle]573-her uncle , as [they]2255-they drove from [the town]1033-the town ; " and really , upon serious consideration , [I]573-her uncle am much more inclined than [I]573-her uncle was to judge as [[your]82-elizabeth eldest sister]4238-your eldest sister does of the matter . It appears to [me]573-her uncle so very unlikely that [any young man]4615-any young man should form such a design against [a girl who is by no means unprotected or friendless , and who was actually staying in [[his]4615-any young man Colonel 's family]4617-his colonel 's family]4616-a girl who is by no means unprotected or friendless , and who was actually staying in his colonel 's family , that [I]573-her uncle am strongly inclined to hope the best . Could [he]573-her uncle expect that [[her]4238-your eldest sister friends]310-her friends would not step forward ? Could [he]573-her uncle expect to be noticed again by [the regiment]650-the regiment , after such an affront to [Colonel Forster]107-colonel forster ? [His]573-her uncle temptation is not adequate to the risk . "[573-her uncle]

" Do [you]573-her uncle really think so ? "[82-elizabeth] cried [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth , brightening up for a moment .

" Upon [my]125-mrs. gardiner word , "[125-mrs. gardiner] said [Mrs. Gardiner]125-mrs. gardiner , " [I]125-mrs. gardiner begin to be of [[your]82-elizabeth uncle]3374-your uncle 's opinion . It is really too great a violation of decency , honour , and interest , for [him]3374-your uncle to be guilty of it . [I]125-mrs. gardiner can not think so very ill of [Wickham]136-wickham . Can [you]82-elizabeth , [yourself]82-elizabeth , [Lizzie]82-elizabeth , so wholly give [him]3374-your uncle up , as to believe [him]3374-your uncle capable of it ? "[125-mrs. gardiner]

" Not perhaps of neglecting [his]3374-your uncle own interest . But of every other neglect [I]573-her uncle can believe [him]3374-your uncle capable . If , indeed , it should be so ! But [I]573-her uncle dare not hope it . Why should [they]4621-they not go on to [Scotland]49-scotland , if that had been the case ? "[573-her uncle]

" In the first place , "[153-mr. gardiner] replied [Mr. Gardiner]153-mr. gardiner , " there is no absolute proof that [they]4621-they are not gone to [Scotland]49-scotland . "[153-mr. gardiner]

" Oh , but [their]4621-they removing from the chaise into [a hackney coach]4622-a hackney coach is such a presumption ! And , besides , no traces of them were to be found on [the Barnet road]4623-the barnet road . "[573-her uncle]

" Well , then,--supposing [them]4621-they to be in [London]5-london -- [they]4621-they may be [there]305-there , though for the purpose of concealment , for no more exceptionable purpose . It is not likely that money should be very abundant on either side ; and it might strike [them]4621-they that [they]4621-they could be more economically , though less expeditiously , married in [London]5-london , than in [Scotland]49-scotland . "[153-mr. gardiner]

" But why all this secrecy ? Why any fear of detection ? Why must [their]4621-they marriage be private ? Oh , no , no -- this is not likely . [[His]3374-your uncle most particular friend]4625-his most particular friend , [you]4626-you see by [Jane]83-jane 's account , was persuaded of [his]3374-your uncle never intending to marry [her]83-jane . [Wickham]136-wickham will never marry [a woman]3011-a woman without some money . [He]136-wickham can not afford it . And what claims has [Lydia]84-lydia , what attractions has [she]84-lydia beyond youth , health , and good humour , that could make [him]3374-your uncle for [her]84-lydia sake forego every chance of benefiting [himself]3374-your uncle by marrying well ? As to what restraint the apprehensions of disgrace in [the corps]4628-the corps might throw on a dishonourable elopement with [her]84-lydia , [I]573-her uncle am not able to judge ; for [I]573-her uncle know nothing of the effects that such a step might produce . But as to [your]4626-you other objection , [I]573-her uncle am afraid it will hardly hold good . [Lydia]84-lydia has [no brothers]4629-no brothers to step forward ; and [he]3374-your uncle might imagine , from [[my]573-her uncle father]3256-my father 's behaviour , from [his]3256-my father indolence and the little attention [he]3256-my father has ever seemed to give to what was going forward in [[his]3256-my father family]375-his family , that _ [he]3256-my father _ would do as little and think as little about it , as [any father]4632-any father could do , in such a matter . "[573-her uncle]

" But can [you]82-elizabeth think that [Lydia]84-lydia is so lost to everything but love of [him]3374-your uncle , as to consent to live with [him]3374-your uncle on any other terms than marriage ? "[153-mr. gardiner]

" It does seem , and it is most shocking , indeed , "[82-elizabeth] replied [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth , with tears in [her]82-elizabeth eyes , " that [a sister]437-a sister 's sense of decency and virtue in such a point should admit of doubt . But , really , [I]82-elizabeth know not what to say . Perhaps [I]82-elizabeth am not doing [her]84-lydia justice . But [she]84-lydia is very young : [she]84-lydia has never been taught to think on serious subjects ; and for the last half year , nay , for a twelvemonth , [she]84-lydia has been given up to nothing but amusement and vanity . [She]84-lydia has been allowed to dispose of [her]84-lydia time in the most idle and frivolous manner , and to adopt any opinions that came in [her]84-lydia way . Since the ----shire were first quartered in [Meryton]9-meryton , nothing but love , flirtation , and [officers]458-officers , have been in [her]84-lydia head . [She]84-lydia has been doing everything in [her]84-lydia power , by thinking and talking on the subject , to give greater -- what shall [I]82-elizabeth call it?--susceptibility to [her]84-lydia feelings ; which are naturally lively enough . And [we]4635-we all know that [Wickham]136-wickham has every charm of [person]4636-person and address that can captivate [a woman]3011-a woman . "[82-elizabeth]

" But [you]2257-you see that [Jane]83-jane , "[1198-her aunt] said [[her]2257-you aunt]1198-her aunt , " does not think so ill of [Wickham]136-wickham , as to believe [him]136-wickham capable of the attempt . "[1198-her aunt]

" Of whom does [Jane]83-jane ever think ill ? And who is there , whatever might be [their]4638-their former conduct , that [she]83-jane would believe capable of such an attempt , till it were proved against [them]4638-their ? But [Jane]83-jane knows , as well as [I]82-elizabeth do , what [Wickham]136-wickham really is . [We]4635-we both know that [he]136-wickham has been profligate in every sense of the word ; that [he]136-wickham has neither integrity nor honour ; that [he]136-wickham is as false and deceitful as [he]136-wickham is insinuating . "[82-elizabeth]

" And do [you]82-elizabeth really know all this ? "[125-mrs. gardiner] cried [Mrs. Gardiner]125-mrs. gardiner , whose curiosity as to the mode of [her]125-mrs. gardiner intelligence was all alive .

" [I]82-elizabeth do , indeed , "[82-elizabeth] replied [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth , colouring . " [I]82-elizabeth told [you]82-elizabeth the other day of [his]136-wickham infamous behaviour to [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy ; and [you]82-elizabeth , [yourself]82-elizabeth , when last at [Longbourn]7-longbourn , heard in what manner [he]136-wickham spoke of [the man who had behaved with such forbearance and liberality]4639-the man who had behaved with such forbearance and liberality towards [him]136-wickham . And there are other circumstances which [I]82-elizabeth am not at liberty -- which it is not worth while to relate ; but [his]136-wickham lies about [the whole Pemberley family]4640-the whole pemberley family are endless . From what [he]136-wickham said of [Miss Darcy]124-miss darcy , [I]82-elizabeth was thoroughly prepared to see [a proud , reserved , disagreeable girl]4641-a proud , reserved , disagreeable girl . Yet [he]136-wickham knew to the contrary [himself]136-wickham . [He]136-wickham must know that [she]4641-a proud , reserved , disagreeable girl was as amiable and unpretending as [we]4642-we have found [her]4641-a proud , reserved , disagreeable girl . "[82-elizabeth]

" But does [Lydia]84-lydia know nothing of this ? can [she]84-lydia be ignorant of what [you]82-elizabeth and [Jane]83-jane seem so well to understand ? "[82-elizabeth]

" Oh , yes!--that , that is the worst of all . Till [I]82-elizabeth was in [Kent]17-kent , and saw so much both of [Mr. Darcy]89-mr. darcy and [his]136-wickham relation [Colonel Fitzwilliam]164-colonel fitzwilliam , [I]82-elizabeth was ignorant of the truth [myself]82-elizabeth . And when [I]82-elizabeth returned [home]3219-home [the ----shire]4644-the ----shire was to leave [Meryton]9-meryton in a week or fortnight 's time . As that was the case , neither [Jane]83-jane , to whom [I]82-elizabeth related the whole , nor [I]82-elizabeth , thought it necessary to make [our]4642-we knowledge public ; for of what use could it apparently be to [anyone]3102-anyone , that the good opinion , which all [the neighbourhood]3015-the neighbourhood had of [him]136-wickham , should then be overthrown ? And even when it was settled that [Lydia]84-lydia should go with [Mrs. Forster]107-colonel forster , the necessity of opening [her]84-lydia eyes to [his]136-wickham character never occurred to [me]82-elizabeth . That _ [she]84-lydia _ could be in any danger from the deception never entered [my]82-elizabeth head . That such a consequence as _ this _ should ensue , [you]4647-you may easily believe was far enough from [my]82-elizabeth thoughts . "[82-elizabeth]

" When [they]4648-they all removed to [Brighton]32-brighton , therefore , [you]4647-you had no reason , [I]82-elizabeth suppose , to believe [them]4648-they fond of [each other]3144-each other ? "[82-elizabeth]

" Not the slightest . [I]82-elizabeth can remember no symptom of affection on either side ; and had anything of the kind been perceptible , [you]4647-you must be aware that [ours]4650-ours is not [a family on which it could be thrown away]4651-a family on which it could be thrown away . When first [he]136-wickham entered [the corps]4628-the corps , [she]84-lydia was ready enough to admire [him]136-wickham ; but so [we]4650-ours all were . [Every girl in or near [Meryton]9-meryton]4653-every girl in or near meryton was out of [her]84-lydia senses about [him]136-wickham for the first two months : but [he]136-wickham never distinguished _ [her]84-lydia _ by any particular attention ; and , consequently , after a moderate period of extravagant and wild admiration , [her]84-lydia fancy for [him]136-wickham gave way , and [others of [the regiment]650-the regiment]4654-others of the regiment , who treated [her]84-lydia with more distinction , again became [her]84-lydia favourites . "[82-elizabeth]

It may be easily believed , that however little of novelty could be added to [their]2259-their fears , hopes , and conjectures , on this interesting subject by its repeated discussion , [no other]2260-no other could detain [them]2259-their from it long , during the whole of the journey . From [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth 's thoughts it was never absent . Fixed there by the keenest of all anguish , self - reproach , [she]82-elizabeth could find no interval of ease or forgetfulness .

[They]2259-their travelled as expeditiously as possible ; and sleeping one night on [the road]1290-the road , reached [Longbourn]7-longbourn by dinnertime the next day . It was a comfort to [Elizabeth]82-elizabeth to consider that [Jane]83-jane could not have been wearied by long expectations .

[The little Gardiners , attracted by the sight of a chaise]2262-the little gardiners , attracted by the sight of a chaise , were standing on the steps of [the house]3001-the house , as [they]2259-their entered [the paddock]2264-the paddock ; and when [the carriage]3217-the carriage drove up to the door , the joyful surprise that lighted up [their]2259-their faces and displayed itself over [their]2259-their whole bodies , in a variety of capers and frisks , was the first pleasing earnest of [their]2259-their welcome .

[Elizabeth]82-elizabeth jumped out ; and after giving each of [them]2259-their a hasty kiss , hurried into [the vestibule]1004-the vestibule , where [Jane]83-jane , who came running [downstairs]2267-downstairs from [[[her]83-jane mother]241-her mother 's apartment]2269-her mother 's apartment , immediately met [her]83-jane .

[Elizabeth]82-elizabeth , as [she]82-elizabeth affectionately embraced [her]83-jane , whilst tears filled the eyes of [both]774-both , lost not a moment in asking whether anything had been heard of [the fugitives]2271-the fugitives .

" Not yet , "[83-jane] replied [Jane]83-jane . " But now that [[my]83-jane dear uncle]3970-my dear uncle is come , [I]83-jane hope everything will be well . "[83-jane]

" Is [[my]82-elizabeth father]3256-my father in [town]264-town ? "[82-elizabeth]

" Yes , [he]3256-my father went on Tuesday , as [I]83-jane wrote [you]83-jane word . "[83-jane]

" And have [you]82-elizabeth heard from [him]3256-my father often ? "[82-elizabeth]

" [We]774-both have heard only once . [He]3256-my father wrote [me]83-jane a few lines on Wednesday , to say that [he]3256-my father had arrived in safety , and to give [me]83-jane [his]3256-my father directions , which [I]83-jane particularly begged [him]3256-my father to do . [He]3256-my father merely added , that [he]3256-my father should not write again , till [he]3256-my father had something of importance to mention . "[83-jane]
